DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used b0110-b0111, PM-The Persuaders II, an undated advance sent June 12 for use June 26, are asked to use the following story. The story also moved spot June 25 as a0406-a0407.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported June 26 that New Mexico lobbyist Edwin T. Mahr's firm spent $1 million in 1987-89 on lobbying the New Mexico Legislature and misattributed to him an estimate that 80 percent of the spending was for entertainment. The $1 million was the total spending reported by all New Mexico lobbyists, of which about 80 percent was for entertainment expenses, according to calculations by the AP.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Helps Keep Elvis Alive At U.S. Postal Service
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf of b0158 sent June 22, ``The first ...,'' to CORRECT year picture was taken from 1968 to 1969; PICKS UP 17th graf, ``Pictures are ...''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MR1 sent June 25.
DOC.TEXT: Pat Geiger, known around town as ``the Elvis Lady,'' has spent the past seven years keeping Elvis Presley alive. Elvis the postage stamp, that is. From the kitchen table of her tidy, comfortable home on Route 10, Geiger runs the ``Elvis Postage Stamp Campaign.'' Her goal is to convince the U.S. Postal Service to give ``The King'' its stamp of approval. ``Without question, Elvis Presley is the perfect subject for a U.S. commemorative postage stamp,'' Geiger said. ``He was and, even though he left us 13 years ago, continues to be one of this country's greatest goodwill ambassadors.'' Her devotion may pay off. A Postal Service official says Elvis is, indeed, still alive _ in a postal sense. ``There's a very good chance that sometime in the future there will be an Elvis stamp,'' said Frank Thomas, a Postal Service marketing specialist in Washington, D.C. ``Personally, I think there will be.'' The major obstacle for a Presley postage stamp is ``concern over the lifestyle issue,'' Thomas said. The Postal Service has received mail complaining that honoring a known drug abuser ``sends a bad message'' to America's youth, he said. But Geiger scoffs at that notion, pointing to other stamp subjects with controversial private lives. Presley stamps already have been issued in at least seven countries, including West Germany, she said. Since beginning her campaign in 1983, Geiger said she has gone through five postmasters general and is now on her sixth, Anthony Frank. Frank reportedly said soon after taking office that he supports an Elvis stamp. But after the ensuing outcry over Presley's well-documented drug abuse _ the King died of an overdose in 1977 _ Frank retreated and said the issue requires further review. His wavering prompted Geiger to publicly call him a ``wimp.'' It also renewed her determination to honor the man she credits with changing her life. ``I will not give up until either Elvis gets his stamp or I die, whichever comes first,'' the 70-year-old great-grandmother said over a lunchtime beer. To understand the extent of Geiger's passion for Presley, one must visit her house. It is wall-to-wall _ and floor-to-ceiling _ Elvis. Posters line every wall, most highlighting Presley's 1970s jumpsuit phase. Bookcases are stuffed with Presley tomes, both reverential and scandalous. Shelves burst with videocassettes of Presley movies, and photo albums hold thousands of pictures. That's not including her records and tapes. The first Presley picture Geiger bought, a black-and-white shot taken at a 1969 press conference, will be buried with her, she vows. ``Pictures are my addiction,'' Geiger said, then adds, ``Pardon me, Evis, for using that word.'' Presleymania came late in Geiger's life. Although her older son dressed in pink and black in the 1950s to emulate Presley, Geiger did not convert until a 1968 TV show known as the ``Comeback Special.'' ``I looked at that man in that black leather suit and said `Phew!,''' Geiger said. ``I sat in that chair and said, `Nobody is that good looking.' It was kind of sudden. I was never the same after that night.'' The postage stamp entered her life in 1983, when a fellow Presley fan mentioned the idea. After some investigating, Geiger learned ordinary citizens are not eligible for stamp consideration until 10 years after their deaths. So Geiger spent the next several years laying the groundwork for her big 1987 push. ``I thought it would be a simple thing,'' she said. ``Boy, was I naive.'' Postal Service officials have come to know Geiger well, Thomas said. She is, in fact, one of their best customers, firing off letters to anybody connected with the agency. ``You name `em, I've written to 'em,'' she said, waving a wrist adorned with an Elvis Presley watch. Commemorative postage stamps are nominated by the 15-member Citizens' Stamp Advisory Committee, which meets every two months, and then must be approved by the postmaster general, Thomas said. Although Presley has been eligible for three years, he still has not been chosen for the honor. Does this mean Elvis _ the stamp _ is dead? ``No, not at all,'' Thomas said. The committee might include Presley in a stamp series on American musicians, but that doesn't sit well with Geiger. ``Elvis was one of a kind! There will never be another!'' she said. ``He does not fit into a group!'' The committee will announce next year's commemorative stamps within a month, Thomas said. ``If they don't announce it, that doesn't mean it won't show up in 1991,'' he said. ``The fact that they're spending so much time on the subject is a positive sign.'' Meanwhile, Geiger waits impatiently and spends her days mostly on Presley-related matters. There are the constant letters from supporters around the world, the radio appearances, the newspaper interviews. ``How did I get here? I absolutely do not know,'' she said. ``Next to my children, he's the most important person in my life. I don't know what I'd do if there wasn't an Elvis.''

DOC.HEAD: Housing Shortage Reveals Dark Side of City of Light
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Not far from Satan's Alley and a dead-end street called God, 48 families live in a public square. They are victims of a war on squatters waged by a city of plenty with little room for its poor. Since March 15, when a winter moratorium on evictions ended, riot police arriving before dawn have cleared dozens of buildings. The evictions inspire denunciations, demonstrations and charges that the city of Paris, where housing prices are soaring, is trying to push the poor out of town. ``We're miserable here because we have nothing,'' said Assa Kan, a 30-year-old woman from Mali with six children. They are among 150 people who have lived under tents since May 2 in the Place de la Reunion. ``At night, it's really cold,'' she said, caressing the chapped cheeks of her 4-month-old daughter. ``All the children are sick.'' Hers is the largest of three camps set up by squatters or renters turned out of condemned buildings. Nine families camp at the foot of Sacre Coeur, the Montmartre basilica, and six live outside a city government office. In announcing the spring offensive, Paris officials said squatting had reached ``inadmissible'' proportions. ``The city is duty-bound to solve this problem'' and evictions are ``the only way to stop the multiplication of squatters,'' said Jean Tiberi, deputy to Mayor Jacques Chirac. Within days, 300 people were homeless, nearly half of them children. ``These people had a right to squat,'' said Abbe Pierre, a bearded Roman Catholic cleric who is France's premier champion of the needy. ``When a man is hungry, he has the right to take bread from the baker.'' Abbe Pierre's humanitarian organization, the Emmaus Community, provided tents for those evicted. A siege mentality prevails in the Place de la Reunion, which is ringed with rosebushes and dotted with orange and blue tents. Amenities consist of one water spigot, three portable toilets like those used at construction sites, and intermittent lighting at night via an extension cord from a nearby cafe. One tent serves as a kitchen. Mrs. Kan and others said they would remain until the city provided a suitable alternative. ``We are confronted with the unacceptable,'' Bertrand Main, deputy chief of the League of Human Rights, told reporters. ``Demands for rehousing are met with a wall of silence, incomprehension and, sometimes, contempt.'' Paris proposed temporary housing for the evicted in buildings scheduled for demolition in St. Denis, a poor northern suburb. Officials there objected. ``We don't have a money problem in Paris; we have a problem of land,'' Tiberi, the deputy mayor, said in explaining the housing shortage on French radio. ``For moral reasons ... we cannot accept the principle of rehousing squatters,'' who rob legal occupants of apartment space, he said. At a news conference, Abbe Pierre said: ``It is a crime to refuse lodging in a city like Paris, where several thousand apartments are vacant.'' The Committee Against Poor Housing, a protest group that finds vacant buildings for squatters, claims there are 3,000 to 4,000 vacant, government-subsidized Moderate Rent Housing units around Paris. The city denies it. Officials say the number of buildings occupied by squatters, most of them Africans, has grown from 36 to 187 in three years and 41 of the buildings are subsidized units, which have a waiting list of 50,000. Mayor Chirac said in a letter to Abbe Pierre, made public June 20, that rehousing evicted squatters would be a ``profound injustice'' to people on the waiting list. ``Paris is a city with heart,'' he said, ``but ... neither the capital nor the Paris region can take in all the misery of the world.'' Critics claim the city is being transformed into a ghetto for the elite. President Francois Mitterrand denounced those ``who enrich themselves while sleeping'' because they own ``a good piece of land or a nice apartment.'' Prices have risen so quickly, he said, ``that they are starting to exclude the possibility of suitable lodging for senior executives with salaries that can reach 50,000 francs per month,'' about $8,700. Frederica Koch and Amina Amara are among those keeping a vigil with the homeless at the Place de la Reunion. Ms. Koch was evicted last year from the rent-controlled apartment she occupied for 25 years and, at 58, is a squatter. She lost her job as a clothes cutter during a 10-year battle to keep her home. Ms. Amara, a single woman with five children, has been on a waiting list for a low-rent apartment for 15 years. After eviction from one building, she and her two youngest children spent a year in a shabby hotel and two months in a restaurant basement before squatting anew in December. ``This problem is too big for us,'' said Berhima Tembely, an immigrant from Senegal who paid a sympathy visit to the square. ``The rich people are treating us like dogs. You have to fight to live in this world.''

DOC.HEAD: ROCKIN' IN RHYTHM: Atlanta _ New Center of R&B
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Get ready for a plateful of soul _ more hot sounds from ``Hot-lanta.'' Atlanta in the 1990s is emerging as the new center for rhythm and blues, just as Detroit did in the '60s with Motown. Recording artists are flocking to the South's capital from New York and Los Angeles, drawn by a cheaper real estate market and more privacy. ``Atlanta was one of the country's best-kept secrets,'' said Tom Wright, owner of Cheshire Sound Studios, where singers such as Peabo Bryson and Bobby Brown come to record. ``Not anymore.'' Bryson was new in the music business and Atlanta seemed like a good place to start. So when the relatively unknown Bang records offered him a contract, he snapped it up. Nineteen years later, he's still here, after raising a family and building a prosperous career. ``Atlanta was not a throbbing metropolis full of opportunity in the recording industry, but it was also not a New York City _ all crowded,'' Bryson said in an interview. ``I wanted to develop my writing style here, learn to make recordings. Now the producers are here, the equipment is here. I'm glad I stayed.'' Bryson was joined last year by Brown, the former New Edition member whose multiplatinum album, ``Don't Be Cruel,'' sst bakes under the summer sun, winter is arriving in earnest in southern Australia, with heavy snowfalls, high winds and hail causing traffic havoc in some areas. In Sydney, strong winds uprooted trees and snapped power lines on Wednesday night, cutting power to hundreds of families in the city's north and southeast. Marine police were kept busy on Sydney Harbor after boats broke their moorings. Some highways were closed by snow and sleet in highland areas of New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania states. A Weather Bureau spokesman said the high temperature was just 49 degrees in Melbourne on Wednesday, the city's lowest June maximum in four years. A gale warning was in effect for all Victorian and Tasmanian coastal waters. Some areas reported winds of up to 60 mph on Wednesday night. Heavy snowfalls and blizzards were reported at ski resorts in northeastern Victoria state, and more rough weather was in the forecast. A spokesman for the Bureau of Meteorology in Tasmania, an island state off Australia's southern coast, said temperatures in the capital, Hobart, had dipped almost 9 degrees below average to a minimum of 36 degrees.

DOC.HEAD: Ways to Beat The Heat
With PM-Heat-Fires, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The scorching heat wave in the Southwest is taking its toll. Here are some tips to beat the heat: People most at risk in hot weather are those suffering from such conditions as diabetes, heart disease, blood vessel disease, stroke, burns, alcoholism or obesity. Persons who have reduced capacity to sweat also may have problems in the heat, as will those with diarrhea, who can easily become dehydrated. In hot weather, plan to reduce physical activity, and when outside stay in the shade or wear a wide-brimmed hat or use an umbrella to keep out of the sun. Park the car in a shady area and roll down the windows to let the hot air out before getting into it. And dress coolly, in light-colored loose-fitting clothes. Use air conditioners or electric fans when possible. If these are not available, go to an air-conditioned library, movie or shopping mall during the heat of the day. Bathing or showering in cool water helps, as will drinking plenty of liquids. But avoid alcohol, coffee, tea or other drinks that cause fluid loss. Do not take salt tablets unless recommended by a doctor. Too much heat can lead to heat cramps, heat exhaustion and finally heat stroke. Here is a rundown on these three problems: _Heat stroke is the most dangerous heat-related illness and it requires emergency treatment. Often the victim can no longer sweat and immediate help is needed to reduce the temperature and prevent serious damage. Symptoms include a body temperature of 104 degrees and higher; dizziness, faintness or unconsciousness; sometimes hot, dry or reddened skin; staggering; possible diarrhea; rapid pulse; confusion; headache and agitation. First aid begins with calling for emergency medical help. Cool the victim by removing as much clothing as possible and sponging the skin with cool, not cold, water. If the victim is conscious, give sips of liquid, but if unconscious do not force liquid. Get the victim to a hospital immediately. _Heat exhaustion is the most common heat-related illness. Symptoms include clammy or sweaty skin, normal or slightly elevated temperature, dizziness or feeling faint, profuse perspiration, rapid pulse, nausea and thirst. First aid includes rest in a cool location where you can sit or lie down. Restore fluids by slowly drinking liquids, and gently apply wet towels to the body. Check with a physician to see if salt or medication is needed. _Heat cramps are the least serious of the heat-related illnesses, but if not treated they can lead to more serious problems. Heat cramps usually occur after exercise or physical labor in the heat. Symptoms are sweaty skin, possible weakness or nausea, occasional tingling in the arms and legs, and muscle cramps, often beginning in the abdomen and legs. First aid includes getting out of the sun and into a cool place; lying down and drinking cool liquids. Check with a physician to see if salt or medication is needed.

DOC.HEAD: World War II Bomb Found in West German Government District
DOC.TEXT: Construction workers excavating a building site near Parliament dug out a mound of rubble containing a 2,200-pound U.S. bomb but didn't discover the ``live'' World War II relic until later, officials say. The bomb went undetected Tuesday until it was being unloaded at a dump site along the highway connecting Bonn to Cologne, city officials in Cologne said. It had been driven in a dump truck from the construction site through Bonn. Bomb experts were immediately called, sealed off the area and safely defused the bomb. According to an aerial photograph of the construction site, officials said the bomb had been buried about 12 feet deep in what is now the government center of Bonn. Since the end of World War II, thousands of tons of unexploded bombs and other munitions left over from the war have been uncovered in Germany, and bomb experts are regularly called out to defuse them to prevent injuries to the public.

DOC.HEAD: Geologists Find Evidence That Islands Once Linked
DOC.TEXT: Marine geologists say they have found evidence of a huge land bridge that linked New Zealand's North and South islands during the peak of the last ice age 20,000 years ago. Since the 1950s, scientists have believed that a very narrow land bridge once existed that would explain the discovery on the North Island of rocks and remains from animals thought to be unique to the South Island. But recent survey work by Department of Scientific and Industrial Research marine geologists suggests that the bridge was a broad, windswept plain, fanned by numerous rivers which fed the bridge with sediment. It probably had a open, seaward-facing western shoreline, battered by a harsh climate of storms and strong southwesterly winds. Scientist Scott Nodder said recently that based on the preliminary work, he believes the bridge probably was exposed during a time when sea levels were low, during the peak of the last ice age. As the ice age waned, the bridge was breached at its most shallow point about 15,000 years ago, creating the Cook Strait. Nodder said he has used a combination of core sampling and echo sounders to survey below the sea floor. That has revealed a combination of sediments and a sequence of sea beds that lend weight to he huge land bridge theory.

DOC.HEAD: News Reading _ and Watching _ Hit New Lows Among the Young, Study Finds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf: ``In the,'' to CORRECT margin of error from 3 points to 2 points
DOC.TEXT: Americans under age 30 know less about what's going on in the country and the world than any other generation in the past 50 years, according to a study of how people keep up with the news. It found that younger Americans are less likely than earlier generations to have read a newspaper or watched a television news show. When people under age 35 were asked 25 years ago whether they had read a newspaper ``yesterday,'' 67 percent said yes. When the same question was put this year to a slightly younger group, people under age 30, only 24 percent said yes. Television news-watching has dropped, too. In 1965, 52 per cent of people under 35 said they watched the TV news ``yesterday''; this year, 41 percent of those under 30 said they caught the TV news ``yesterday.'' The study said that from 1941 to 1975, young Americans were on a par with their elders in public knowledge and in following most major news events closely. But since 1975, younger people have been less attentive and the trend is accelerating, it said. ``The Information Age has spawned ... an uninformed and uninvolved population,'' concludes the study. It was conducted by the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press, sponsored by the company which publishes the Los Angeles Times. The center's own polls and those of four other polling organizations taken over the years were analyzed. Even though the average 30-year-old is more likely to use a computer, to have attended college and even more likely to be reading a book than someone 20 years senior, the younger generation knows less about the world, the study said. In the latest measurement, 12,000 random sample interviews conducted between May 1989 and last March were analyzed. The number of young people who could correctly answer questions about current news was at its lowest level since pollsters started asking questions about familiarity with the news in the early 1940s. The polls had a margin or error of plus or minus 2 percentage points. ``Social scientists and pollsters have long recognized that younger people have usually been somewhat less attuned to politics and serious issues,'' the study said. ``But the difference now is more striking than ever before.'' ``The Army-McCarthy hearings, Watergate and Vietnam were stories followed closely by young and old alike. However, since the mid-70s young people have shown much less interest in most news, including the biggest stories with the most far-reaching implications.'' The exceptions: sports news and the abortion issue. There, the young match their elders in news interest. In 1989, 25 percent of each group kept up with the World Series; 41 percent of the young and 33 percent of people over 50 knew about the Supreme Court's most recent major abortion ruling. But, the survey reported, younger Americans are 20 percent less likely than those over 30 to know who won the recent election in Nicaragua, what happened to Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu or what the Soviet Union's role has been in the political upheavals of Eastern Europe. The study said that in the 1940s a majority of people _ both those under and those over 30 _ could identify Norman Thomas, the American socialist. And in the 1960s two-thirds of young people and 59 percent over those over 50 could identify Earl Warren, the chief justice of the United States from 1953 to 1969. By contrast, in a March, 1990 survey, less than a quarter of people under 30 and less than half of those over 50 could identify Jim Wright, who resigned a year ago as speaker of the House of Representatives, or Helmut Kohl, chancellor of West Germany. A newspaper editor, William B. Ketter of the Quincy (Mass.) Patriot Ledger, called the findings distressing. ``I think it is symptomatic of our fast-food, fast-paced society where they want everything instantly and don't want to concentrate on newspapers, and apparently that even extends now to television,'' said Ketter. He is chairman of the Readership Committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, which is seeking ways to make newspapers more attractive to readers. ``I call it a dangerous camel under the tent because I think if our society becomes less informed about the events that go on in the world and at home it becomes less vigilant for the protections of the Constitution, and that could spell problems,'' Ketter said.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Buries Its Past And Its Money
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: East Germany will bid goodbye to an old currency by burying it in salt mines and feeding it to foundries, clearing the way for new cash and a radically different way of life. At the stroke of midnight Saturday, the 42-year-old East German mark of the ousted Communist regime will be replaced by one of the free market's most powerful forces, the West German mark. An East German who buys a beer with his old money in the minutes before midnight could have his change brought back in West German marks, so quick is this change to take place. That modest event would signal the economic unification of the two German states, the end of four decades of East German socialism and the de facto creation of a single Germany. The West German state bank, the Bundesbank, has trucked in 25 billion uncirculated West German marks, said spokesman Sigfried Guterman in Frankfurt. ``Transporting money is our business,'' he said Wednesday. ``This was a little more complicated.'' Guterman said heavily guarded trucks from Bundesbank offices throughout West Germany brought 600 tons of paper money _ 400 million individual bills _ and 500 tons of coins during the past two months. The money was distributed to 15 different cities. The East German State Bank has been taking that money to 10,000 different locations, where it will be available to East Germans beginning Sunday. Long lines at banks nationwide continued as East Germans filled out forms to convert their savings accounts to West German marks. Guterman said there have been no major problems replacing one currency with another virtually overnight. The 25 billion in West German marks is new, uncirculated cash that should be enough to accomodate the nation, Guterman said. East Germany now only has 12.3 billion East German marks in circulation, said Bernd Schroeter, spokesman for the East German State Bank. All citizens will be asked to deposit their remaining East German cash in banks by July 6. There, it is to be counted, sorted and wrapped. After final inventory, the bills will be stored in salt mines pending their later destruction, Schroeter said. East Germany is not equipped to burn large amounts of bills in environmentally safe ways, he said. Guterman said East Germany might have to use the Bundesbank facilities to burn the money. Most of the coins are pure aluminum _ which drew chuckles from Westerners _ and two denominations are in copper. Schroeter said these will be melted down and recycled. The East German currency is small and flimsy compared with the large West German bills. The 50-mark bill carries the picture of Friedrich Engels, who with Karl Marx drafted the blueprint for modern socialism. The back depicts a giant factory spewing smoke. The East German currency was non-convertible and virtually worthless outside the East bloc. After the East German revolt last autumn, it was traded on the black market at a 20-1 rate for West German money. Now, small savings accounts will be traded at a 1-1 rate, with larger amounts converted at a 2-1 rate. The Bundesbank has been planning a new West German currency for years, and will begin circulating some notes on Oct. 1. By the end of the next year, Guterman said, all the current money will be replaced. Concidentally, one of the first bills that goes into circulation on Oct. 1 _ the 100 mark note _ will depict the East German city of Leipzig. ``It is more or less by accident,'' Guterman said. ``Nobody knew there would be a currency union when these bills were designed.'' Leipzig is on the back of the bill because it is the birthplace of the person on the front, 19th century German pianist Clara Schumann. Leipzig is also the home of the an East German currency mint, and Guterman said it will be used to print part of the new 5 mark note.

DOC.HEAD: Government Extends State of Emergency in Peru
DOC.TEXT: The government has extended a state of emergency for 60 more days in a third of the Peru's territory, giving the military broad powers to fight leftist guerrillas. The move comes a month before Alberto Fujimori's inauguration as president and affects eight states and one province. Peru is divided into 24 states, which are sub-divided into provinces. The state of emergency applies to the states of Apurimac, Ayacucho, Huancavelica, Junin, Pasco, Huanuco, San Martin and Ucayali. It also covers Ucayali province in Loreto state. The decree puts the areas _ in Peru's central and southern highlands and northern jungle _ under military control and allows authorities to restrict freedom of movement, detain people without charge and conduct searches without warrants. Lima, the capital and home to a third of Peru's 22 million people, also is under a state of emergency. But it is administered by the national police. Political violence related to the decade-old Shining Path insurgency has killed more than 18,500 people. The government first imposed the state of emergency in December 1982 in Ayacucho, birthplace of the rebel movement. The measure has since been steadily extended to other areas as the rebel violence has expanded.

DOC.HEAD: Task Force Ends Three-Year Mission
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: California's lampooned and lauded self-esteem task force goes out of business Sunday, but its backers feel really good about its accomplishments. Its creator, state Assemblyman John Vasconcellos, says the task force ``brought self-esteem from an object of ridicule to a subject of respect _ throughout our state, across our nation and even now around our entire world. ``Self-esteem, formerly only cautiously addressed in the privacy of therapeutic encounters and personal growth weekends, has now become legitimate and mainstream, in conversation and in practice,'' said Vasconcellos, a Democrat from San Jose. Virginia and Maryland created their own task forces last year and several other states are considering it. Forty-nine of California's 58 counties now have their own self-esteem task forces. Vasconcellos will present the task force work to the annual convention of the National Conference of State Legislators in Nashville, Tenn., in August. The same month, the First International Conference on Self Esteem is scheduled in Oslo, Norway. The California task force's 144-page report, ``Toward a State of Esteem,'' has sold more than 20,000 copies at $4 each since coming out in January. The report defines self-esteem as ``appreciating my own worth and importance and having the character to be accountable for myself and to act responsibly toward others.'' While the law creating California's task force expires on July 1, Vasconcellos has plenty of plans for the future. ``It's a conclusion of a phase, like a commencement,'' he said. A bill moving through the Legislature would create a state ombudsperson for self-esteem to monitor state agencies and see if they're following the task force recommendations. Another bill would provide $100,000 to the non-profit National Council for Self Esteem so it can replace the task force as a clearinghouse for self-esteem information. Vasconcellos became interested in the subject nearly a decade ago, partly because of his ``own painful personal struggle _ despite repeated successes and achievements in my life _ to develop my own self-esteem.'' Also, as chairman of the Assembly's budget-writing Ways and Means Committee, he saw the state pour billions into ``too-little, too-late efforts to confine and-or repair our fellow Californians.'' He proposed a self-esteem commission in 1984. It took until 1986, and one veto, to get lawmakers and Gov. George Deukmejian to agree. The California Task Force to Promote Self-Esteem and Personal and Social Responsibility was given a three-year life, at $245,000 a year. Shortly before its first meeting in April 1987, cartoonist Garry Trudeau spent three weeks lampooning the task force. In his ``Doonesbury'' comic strip, the airhead character ``Boopsie,'' an actress and out-of-body traveler, was named to the task force. Trudeau pulled out all the California jokes about new-age music, hot tubs and reincarnation. The nation laughed, but the task force members were not angry. ``The `Doonesbury' thing was a curious thing that made us famous, that gave us a national audience immediately that we could not have bought,'' Vasconcellos said. The task force went to work, with few further sniggers and a growing respect. It produced a report listing effective self-esteem programs in California, such as teaching arts in state prisons and giving self-esteem training to welfare recipients in Napa County. Its 46 recommendations range from making child-rearing courses more available to requiring teachers to have self-esteem training, to reducing class sizes. But Vasconcellos in his budget-writing role is faced with a 1990-91 state budget with a potential $3.6 billion shortfall and no money for new programs. ``It's ironic and frustrating. The saving grace is a lot of this doesn't cost any money. It's a change of attitude in people operating current programs,'' he said. ``Some money is needed to support self-esteem education. It would be helpful and a great investment.'' All the task force members but one signed the report, although seven wrote slightly critical comments. The non-signer, David Shannahoff-Khalsa, a Del Mar neuroscience researcher and yoga teacher, said self-esteem cannot be injected or given to anyone. Other critics say the report only lists common sense conclusions. ``It could have been figured out, but it hadn't been,'' responds Vasconcellos. ``But the truth is we have created a national awareness and I never thought we would come so far so fast.'' He said the task force is stimulating further research and new programs seeking to determine if self-esteem is mostly innate or can be learned. ``There's a chicken-egg quality to it. We're learning about it. We have lots more to learn. The hope is we're asking the right questions, finally.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry Slapped Ex-Model After Smoking Cocaine, Moore Testifies
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Moore resumes testimony at 10 a.m. EDT; will be led
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry slapped ex-model Rasheeda Moore to the floor after they smoked cocaine, and he appeared indifferent when she nearly passed out after a ``big hit'' of crack, she testified at the mayor's drug and perjury trial. Moore said Wednesday that she and Barry used cocaine powder, crack and opium more than 100 times in 15 private homes, a restaurant and four hotels from 1986 to 1989. She said they were lovers during most of that time. Moore depicted Barry as a man whose life was so consumed by drugs that he had her deliver cocaine to him at the mayor's office. They broke off their romance but continued to get together frequently to smoke crack, she said. Prosecutors were expected to use Moore's testimony to introduce as evidence an FBI videotape made last Jan. 18 when Barry allegedly smoked crack cocaine while visiting Moore at a Washington hotel. She was cooperating in an undercover sting operation that led to his arrest that night. Moore testified Wednesday that at a home after one crack-smoking session, Barry ``said he was addicted ... to cocaine.'' ``He was tired, he wanted to quit'' and had ``started going to church,'' she said. The mayor was ``talking about getting his spiritual life together.'' Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine-possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. One possession charge stems from the night of his arrest. The three-term mayor stared intently Wednesday as the 39-year-old Moore described their relationship. Barry's wife, Effi, sat in the front row of the spectator section, her face growing grim as the day wore on. Moore said that at Barry's request one day in 1988, she bought $40 worth of crack and carried it in a bag to his office. ``The mayor was expecting me,'' she testified. ``I gave him the cocaine, he gave me the money for it and I left.'' At the mayor's suggestion, the two smoked crack at Barry's home, she said, and also smoked crack at her mother's home on Mother's Day. On another occasion, she said, Barry nearly passed out in the basement of her mother's home after taking what he later described to her as ``a really great hit.'' During city budget briefings in 1988, Moore said, Barry passed her money to buy cocaine. She testified that she left, bought the drugs, returned to the municipal building and ``waited for the mayor to finish his budget hearings'' so that the two could ``go out and use the crack.'' She said Barry became violent after one session in a hotel room where they smoked crack through a homemade pipe. The mayor accused her of having a relationship with another man and ``slapped me,'' Moore said. She returned the slap, she said, but ``ended up on the floor'' when Barry slapped her again. While she was on the floor, Barry stood over her and said ``I haven't hit a woman in 20 years. You bring the worst out in a man,'' she testified. Another time, Moore said she started to pass out after ``I took a big hit'' during a crack-smoking spree with the mayor in the bathroom of a church leader's home. She said she cried out ``Marion, Marion, (but) ... all of a sudden he turned the light off'' and wandered out of the bathroom while she stood there in front of the mirror. She recovered her senses and followed Barry, who ``was moving very slowly.'' Moore said she asked him why he turned off the light, and he replied, ``I couldn't do anything, there was nothing I could do.'' ``I could have died,'' she told the court. ``It was just insanity.'' She said the mayor's security guards were aware of her drug purchases, occasionally passing her money in envelopes from Barry to buy cocaine. ``I hope you're not going to be bad tonight,'' she quoted one of Barry's guards, James Stays, as quipping to her as she went out to make a drug buy. Moore began cooperating with the government after her arrest in California for drunken driving. She has been in the federal witness protection program since Jan. 29 because of threats on her life, Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin told the judge.

DOC.HEAD: Marsalis, Bailey Perform at JVC Jazz Festival
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY15
DOC.TEXT: Wynton Marsalis and Pearl Bailey were an unusual pairing for a jazz concert and, sure enough, the two halves of the evening were opposites. Singer Bailey was show business Wednesday night, talking folksy and amusingly and strutting around between songs. Marsalis and his band went the other direction, playing two long suites of composed, structured jazz in an hour. As a finale, when Bailey sang ``The Battle Hymn of the Republic,'' Marsalis came out and played trumpet along with her and her quartet. It gave the evening a pleasingly unified feeling it certainly hadn't had before. Moments before, Bailey sang ``Hello, Dolly!'' and announced this was her last concert before having a knee-replacement operation. Before that came the musical high point of the evening, a long drum solo by Louie Bellson in ``After You've Gone'' that was a marvel of sound, fire, subtlety and musicality. Marsalis and his band began the JVC Jazz Festival concert at Avery Fisher Hall with ``Uptown Ruler Suite'' and a suite about a man and woman, Sugar Cane and Sweetie Pie. The first piece was cerebral and the second more lively and swinging. Marsalis may aspire to be the Duke Ellington of today, presenting new jazz suites and tone poems. One could remain interested in these two pieces if one tried _ both had lots of instrumental solos _ but they didn't reach out and grab you like Ellington's bursts of melody and changing moods. Even for a jazz festival audience, Marsalis might do better to program only one of these per evening. His band is fantastic. Marsalis' articulate solos were understated but gained strength because of it. The other musicians are Todd Williams and Wessell Anderson, saxophonists; trombonist Wycliff Gordon, pianist Eric Reid, drummer Herlin Riley and bassist Reginald Veal. Bellson played drums for Bailey and Paul Smith was at piano, Keeter Betts on d reaching down from the stage to shake hands. She flung the microphone cord around and gestured with graceful hands. She began with ``On the Road Again,'' sang ``Unforgettable'' in a quietly serious way as a tribute to Nat ``King'' Cole, was fervent on ``For Once in My Life.'' Her distinctive voice was strong and true in ``Can You Read My Mind?''. Just when one was getting impatient with the show biz patter, Bailey said, ``Oh, Pearl, you are forever young.'' For that infectiously upbeat statement, one is quite won over.

DOC.HEAD: New Commissioner Watching Out for Animals and Scientists Alike
LaserPhoto BX3
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Stuart Wiles is committed above all to the 60,000 mice, pigs, rats, rabbits, monkeys and dogs that are part of this city's $100 million-a-year animal research business. But the nation's first commissioner of laboratory animals also must protect the interests of science in a city that is home to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard University. Wiles doesn't have an office yet and hasn't started making spot checks, but he has made contact with the 23 laboratories he became responsible for May 7 under a new city ordinance. For animal-rights activists, Wiles' appointment represents a victory in their battle to ensure humane lives and, when the time comes, painless deaths for lab animals. ``I feel for the animals,'' said Wiles, 56, a veterinarian trained at Boston's Angell Memorial Animal Hospital. ``But I also understand the scientific perspective.'' This balance is key to Wiles' popularity both with researchers and with moderate animal-rights activists, who allow that laboratory experiments are necessary but say they must be conducted under controlled conditions. ``If you're going to have a commissioner, it seems we've got a guy who's going to be fair-minded and who understands all the issues,'' Ron Suduiko, assistant to MIT's president, said Wednesday. Wiles has seen the issue from both sides. He's a longtime animal lover who founded a veterinary hospital in rural Massachusetts and started his career as a supervisor at a Harvard research center. He served on a commission that developed the new ordinance, which a year ago won 8-0 approval from the City Council. The law has also served as a model for proposed ordinances in Lowell, Mass., and Evanston, Ill. Members of the medical and biotechnology community have generally accepted the ordinance, which was developed after animal-rights activists alleged possible laboratory abuse and the city launched an investigation. The city found lab conditions humane but suggested a commissioner's post be established to ensure that standards are maintained. Wiles will inspect academic and private laboratories, which could face fines of $300 a day for violations such as unkempt cages or improperly executed euthanasia. Each laboratory must have an animal-care committee that includes a non-affiliated member, who will be screened and monitored by Wiles. It will be his job to make sure these independent members _ who include a nun, lawyer and dance teacher _ understand and meet their responsibilities. ``I'll provide them with guidelines to follow when considering a proposed research project,'' he said. ``Questions like: `Is it worth it? What are the project's goals? Do you have to use 150 mice or can you get by with 50?''' Federal law protects dogs, cats and monkeys but excludes reptiles, amphibians, mice, rats and rabbits. The Cambridge ordinance will cover all research animals. Suduiko said Cambridge researchers have been concerned that the ordinance might impede their work on diseases such as AIDS and cancer. But Wiles has no plans to ``create a bureaucratic situation or be picky about the little things,'' like an errant piece of garbage or a slightly lethargic mouse. ``I'm looking at the bigger picture,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Boat People Face Forced Return Or Pushoffs But Still Flee
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Countries hit by unrelenting waves of Vietnamese refugees are getting tougher _ the boat people increasingly face being pushed back to sea or returned to this Communist land they risked their lives to flee. Aid officials say Malaysia took in more than 16,000 Vietnamese in 1989 but rebuffed about 8,700 others in the past year, indirectly causing some deaths. Other Southeast Asian nations implicity have threatened the same unless the United States by July 1 stops opposing the forced repatriation of those Vietnamese judged to be economic migrants. More than 117,000 Vietnamese refugees fill camps in the region. ``It is now the 11th hour for the Vietnamese boat people,'' Rep. Hamilton Fish, R-N.Y., told a Congressional hearing on June 21. ``If first asylum is to be retained, it must be at the uncomfortable price of re-examining the question of involuntary repatriation.'' Despite the increasing hostility, there appears little let-up in the exodus of more than 1.5 million people since the Communists toppled the U.S.-backed government of South Vietnam in April 1975. The desire to flee is so that strong Western officials commonly talk of Vietnam's ``exodus mentality.'' ``If you go to some of the provinces in the south, leaving by boat is part of life there,'' said Kai Nielsen, representative of the United Nations High Commissioner For Refugees in Ho Chi Minh City _ formerly the South Vietnamese capital of Saigon. ``People get arrested every day for trying to leave. There are some people who have tried 10 to 15 times,'' Nielsen said. ``In my age group, all my friends are leaving by boat,'' said a government employee, 30, who may follow them. ``A close friend who left in 1979 and came back to visit last year said it's very sad to live outside your native land, but it's better to be in a country where you can study and have a job.'' At risk is the collapse of the Comprehensive Plan of Action on refugees adopted a year ago at an international conference in Geneva. The plan committed countries to give refuge to all boat people, who are then screened to separate political refugees from economic migrants. Western countries are to resettle the refugees. But the large majority are economic migrants who will strain the region's camps indefinitely because the United States and Vietnam oppose their forced return. That and the arrival of 16,718 Vietnamese in 1989 _ an eight-year high _turned Malaysia from one of the most generous asylum nations into the most heartless. ``The perception is that there is little to lose in breaking the rules and a big price to pay for following them,'' said a Western diplomat. A total of 11,722 Vietnamese arrived in the region the first four months of this year, down from 18,351 the same period last year, according to U.N. figures. That brought the camp population to more than 117,000. Hong Kong, after a crisis-level influx in 1989, experienced an 83 percent decrease in arrivals the first five months compared to the same period last year. But arrivals in Indonesia shot up 450 percent as boats evicted by Malaysia landed there, and arrivals in Thailand increased 385 percent. Indonesia has been accused of giving supplies to a new wave of boat people, Cambodians fleeing their Vietnamese-installed regime, so they can sail onto Australia. The Philippines, another generous asylum country that has hardened, recently let 343 Vietnamese disembark from U.S. and Canadian warships that had rescued them only after getting assurances they would be resettled abroad by 1992. A Singaporean ship was bounced between Taiwan, Hong Kong and Thailand because authorities wouldn't accept the 17 Vietnamese aboard. Southeast Asia and Britain, Hong Kong's colonial ruler, have castigated the United States for opposing forced return yet refusing to house the boat people on its own territory. Washington says it opposes force until there are ``dramatic'' economic, social and political improvements in Vietnam. Some diplomats said that guilt over U.S. involvement in the Vietnam War prompted Washington to welcome those who flee. They said vengeance prompted it to treat Vietnam as an outcast to which it was not moral to return migrants. But one diplomat said Washington could compromise on what the Vietnamese call the ``gray area'' between forced and voluntary repatriation _ people who are ``not actively opposed to returning.'' He said such people won't state they want to return but would not protest if put on flights back home. Diplomats said Vietnam opposes forced repatriation to project an acceptable world image and to maintain efforts to establish diplomatic ties with the United States. Those forced back also pose security problems. Hanoi accepted a group of 51 forced back from Hong Kong in December, but has refused any more despite strong pressure from Britain and Malaysia. More are volunteering, and until recently this eased the pressure for forced repatriation. Since March 1989, more than 3,000 have freely returned from Hong Kong, mostly to northern Haiphong and Quang Ninh provinces. They bear news of harsh camp conditions and the West's ``compassion fatigue.'' ``They go back to their home villages, tell their relatives and neighbors and very quickly the message spreads,'' said Jacques Mouchet, representative of the U.N. High Commissioner For Refugees in Hanoi. Increasingly, Western nations say the exodus will never end unless they alleviate Vietnam's economic problems. France and Italy resumed aid the past year, breaking the U.S.-led aid embargo imposed after Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978. Through private groups, Britain recently funded development of areas from which people have fled.

DOC.HEAD: Latin American Debt Plan Hailed as Long Overdue
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's proposal to forgive billions of dollars in debt owed by Latin American countries is being hailed as a long-overdue initiative that will help struggling democracies and boost U.S. standing in the world. The president laid out a package of proposals Wednesday to forgive part of the $12 billion owed to the U.S. government by Latin American and Caribbean countries. Bush said some of the debt could be swapped to buy environmentally endangered land. In addition, he called for work to begin on a ``hemisphere-wide free trade zone'' and said the United States would work with other developed countries to channel up to $300 million annually to Latin America to spur foreign investment. The proposals represented an about-face for the administration. It had been resisting congressional calls for debt forgiveness on the ground it could open the floodgates for domestic demands from groups ranging from farmers to people with old student loans. The administration predicted that the Latin American debt concessions would have little trouble winning congressional approval. The initial reaction both at home and abroad was favorable. Brazilian President Fernando Collor de Mello told Bush in a phone call that his proposal was ``comprehensive, bold and innovative,'' a Brazilian spokesman said. Honduran President Rafael Callejas termed Bush's proposals ``encouraging news,'' while a spokesman said Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari viewed Bush's speech as a ``very important redefinition of the U.S. position regarding economic development in Latin America.'' John Reed, head of Citicorp, a large U.S. bank with about $8 billion in loans in Latin America, said he welcomed the initiative as a way to bring economic growth and prosperity back to Latin America. ``The president acknowledged that in this changed world the United States cannot forget Latin America,'' said Reed. He said the proposal would meet some objections by commercial banks to the administration's Third World debt plan outlined last year by Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. Brady's plan did not address debt owed to the United States and other governments, but rather offered incentives for commercial banks to write off a portion of their $1.3 trillion in Third World debt. Commercial banks had argued that they were being forced to shoulder the entire burden. C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington-based research organization, said the administration was recognizing that bolder foreign economic initiatives were needed for America to retain its leadership role in a post-Cold War world. ``The United States really had been a laggard in debt forgiveness to other countries,'' Bergsten said. ``A realization may be setting in that the United States may be shut out in world leadership unless it takes a more forthright stance.'' Brady told reporters that the new initiative for Latin America could set a precedent for countries in other parts of the world, particularly Poland. That nation has been pressing Western countries to forgive part of its $39 billion foreign debt, most of it owed to governments, to bolster Poland's struggling economic reforms. An administration official, briefing reporters on condition of anonymity, said the issue of Polish debt was certain to be discussed at the July 9-11 economic summit in Houston. Officials explained that the debt forgiveness proposal would focus primarily on $7 billion of loans made at favorable rates, primarily to finance purchases of U.S. farm products. The amount of debt forgiveness will be contingent on a country's willingness to institute economic reform programs under the supervision of the International Monetary Fund. The administration said part of the remaining $5 billion in loans owed to agencies such as the U.S. Export-Import Bank could be used for debt-for-nature swaps to encourage Third World nations to protect natural resources. Officials said smaller and medium-sized countries such as Honduras, El Salvador and Jamaica stood to benefit the most from the debt forgiveness plan because a higher percentage of their foreign debt was owed to the U.S. government. Bush proposed a U.S. contribution of $100 million annually to be matched by similar $100 million in donations from European nations and Japan into an investment fund to provide incentives for Latin nations to attract foreign investment. The president said upcoming negotiations with Mexico over removing all trade barriers between the two nations could set a precedent for establishing a free-trade zone stretching from ``the port of Anchorage to the Tierra del Fuego'' at the southern tip of South America. The United States already has a free trade agreement with Canada.

DOC.HEAD: NRC Says Some Low-Level Waste Can be Handled as Ordinary Trash
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission says about one-third of the nation's low-level nuclear waste is ``below regulatory concern,'' thereby paving the way for industry to dispose of it as normal trash. The new policy, announced Wednesday, could end the special handling requirements for any radioactive products or wastes that expose people to no more than about 3 percent of the radiation they absorb naturally. Consumer groups condemned the policy change. Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen, demanded the removal of all five members of the NRC, charging they had elected ``to trade off people's lives in favor of the financial interests of the nuclear industry.'' ``Nothing could be further from the truth,'' NRC Chairman Kenneth M. Carr declared at a news briefing at the commission's headquarters in nearby Rockville, Md. ``None of this is going to affect public health and safety.'' Instead, Carr insisted, the new federal policy placing the wastes ``below regulatory concern'' will allow federal and state regulators ``to spend our resources on threats that are more important. We think that in the long run, we're going to save more lives.'' Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., chairman of the House Interior subcommittee on energy, wasn't so sure. ``I'm disturbed at the prospect of permitting the disposal of certain low-level radioactive wastes from nuclear power plants in thousands of landfills across the country,'' he said. ``It is imperative that Congress closely scrutinize this new policy.'' Miller scheduled a hearing on the issue for July 26. Carr stressed that the policy decision does not free industry from current disposal requirements. The NRC plans to air the issue at a nationwide series of public hearings. Barring a reversal, industries then would have to prove on a case-by-case basis that particular radioactive wastes fall within the guidelines for regulatory exemption. The policy would apply to radioactive wastes involving the final stages of cleanup of decommissioned nuclear plants, consumer products involving small amounts of radioactive materials and a variety of radioactive wastes generated by hospitals and research institutions. Aside from making disposal of such materials easier and cheaper, it would open the way for some items to be recycled as consumer products. Jonathan Becker, who has traced the issue for Public Citizen, said the policy change could mean that as much as one-third of the low-level radioactive materials now sent to special burial sites could be dumped into community landfills, incinerators or sewer systems. That could save the nuclear power industry, hospitals and laboratories $82 million a year, he said. Pennsylvania, Illinois, New York, North Carolina, Alabama, South Carolina and California now generate the largest amounts of low-level radioactive waste each year. Becker said the NRC's own risk assumptions indicated the new policy could lead to an additional 2,500 cancer deaths annually. Moreover, he contended, the decision flies in the face of recent reports by the National Research Council and the Environmental Protection Agency that the cancer risk from radiation may be much higher than previously known. In the Northeast, several nuclear utilities have pledged to continue to dispose of all radioactive wastes as currently prescribed, no matter what the NRC does, to avoid exacerbating public alarm about their operations. Under recent federal law, the states must trim their reliance on dumps in Nevada, South Carolina and Washington state and build their own disposal sites, either on a statewide or regional basis. Their plans are due by 1993, but several already face strong local protests from citizens who don't want nuclear dumps in their backyards. The NRC says localized nuclear materials _ such as those in a dump site _ that subject individuals to radiation doses of less than 10 millirem per year would qualify for the regulatory exemption. A stiffer standard, 1 millirem per year, would apply to recycled products or consumer goods that are broadly distributed, such as smoke detectors or wristwatches with luminescent dials. By comparison, the NRC says, Americans receive 300 millirem or more per year in the normal course of their lives. This includes an average 200 millirem from the air they breathe, 30 millirem from cosmic radiation, 40 millirem from their food and drink and 30 millirem from soils and building materials. A normal chest X-ray yields about 20 millirem.

DOC.HEAD: Redskins Owner's Wife Cooperates in Drug Investigations
DOC.TEXT: A bad check charge against the fourth wife of Washington Redskins owner Jack Kent Cooke has been dropped after she allegedly cooperated in several cases involving major drug dealers. Commonwealth's Attorney Robert F. Horan Jr. said Assistant U.S. Attorney Liam O'Grady asked him to be lenient with Marlene L. Ramallo Chalmers. Horan dropped the grand larceny charges pending against her. ``They (federal officials) were interested in us giving her a break because she testified and provided information in a number of major drug cases,'' Horan said. ``Restitution had been made and we agreed to drop the charges. Anytime someone will give you a major drug distributor, that's important.'' In 1986, Chalmers, 37, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to import less than a kilogram of cocaine, according to court records. Chalmers married Cooke, 77, on May 5 at his Middleburg estate. She could not be reached for comment. Chalmers was arrested April 7, 1988, on a felony charge of writing four bad checks to the Cosmetic Center. The checks totalled $285.78. In Virginia, any bad check over $200 is a felony. According to court records, Chalmers, a native of Bolivia, became involved in a drug smuggling scheme that involved couriers transporting cocaine from La Paz, Bolivia to Rio de Janeiro to the United States. Chalmers allegedly provided a cover by buying tickets and providing expense money for couriers. In the 1986 case, she was charged with conspiracy to import cocaine, importing cocaine and distribution and possession with intent to distribute cocaine and travel in foreign commerce from National Airport in aid of racketeering, according to court records. Those charges were dismissed.

DOC.HEAD: Focusing Flaw Cripples $1.5 Billion Telescope; Human Error Possible
LaserGraphic, LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: The Hubble Space Telescope is crippled by a focusing flaw that may have been caused by an undetected ``prescription'' error during the manufacture of polished mirrors aboard the $1.5 billion craft. NASA's announcement of the problem Wednesday sent a shudder of disappointment through an astronomy community that has waited years for what were expected to be unprecedented views of the universe from the orbiting telescope. The space agency said the focusing problem in the Hubble mirrors cannot be fixed from the ground and at least two of the five instruments aboard the spacecraft will be virtually useless until a repair mission is flown by the space shuttle. Plans call for such a mission in 1993, but the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said it hopes to make the flight sooner. An official of the Danbury, Conn., company that made the mirrors said the flaw may have been caused by a human error in testing of the primary and secondary Hubble telescope mirrors as they were being ground and polished. ``It appears that one of the elements may have been manufactured to a prescription that wouldn't give you the desired result,'' said Jack Rehnberg, chief of the space science office at the Hughes Danbury Optical Co. ``It could have been a human error.'' Rehnberg said the problem could be either in the primary or secondary mirror or the manner that the two work together. A NASA investigation, led by Lew Allen of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., is expected to start this week. Hubble was placed in a 381-mile orbit on April 25 amid dazzling promises by NASA that the telescope could revolutionize the human concept of the universe. The telescope, circling the Earth far above the obscuring effects of the atmosphere, was expected to be able to see objects such stars and galaxies that are 25 times fainter than those seen by telescopes on the ground. For the first time, Hubble would permit humans to look up to 14 billion light years into space _ some 84 billion trillion miles. This could give a glimpse of objects as they were just a few billion years after the ``big bang'' that is thought to have started the universe. Instead, said NASA scientist Ed Weiler, images captured by the flawed Hubble now will be little better than what can be done by telescopes on Earth. ``It is very disappointing, extremely disappointing,'' said Kim Leschly of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``Many people were hoping to see new views of the universe. Now we'll have to wait. That's very, very disappointing,'' said David Koo, an astronomer at the University of California, Santa Cruz. Hubble deputy project manager Jean Olivier said the misfocusing mirrors were discovered this week when engineers attempted to fine-tune the path of light between the primary and secondary mirrors. He said they discovered ``there was no single one point ... with a crisp, clean image.'' Additional testing showed that the problem was in the manufacture of the mirrors and that there was nothing that could be done from the ground to correct the flaw. Blaming the mirrors came as a surprise because NASA had touted Hubble's 94-inch primary mirror as the smoothest large mirror ever made. But somehow, a mistake was made, said Rehnberg of Hughes Danbury Optical. ``We could have erred in the assembly of some of the test equipment and it didn't get picked up even though we've had lots of reviews, and checks and rechecks,'' he said. Weiler said the focusing problems means that a faint object camera, designed to detect objects not otherwise visible, will see no better than instruments on the ground. And a wide field camera will be virtually useless, he said. ``There is no real science we can do with it at this time,'' he said. Three instruments that study stars in ultraviolet and infrared radiation will not be as seriously affected, although a high-speed photometer will be able to do ``about half the science'' scheduled, Weiler said. Hubble has had problems from early in the program. It was originally scheduled for launch in 1986, but was delayed for four years when the shuttle fleet was grounded following the Challenger accident. After the telescope was deployed in orbit on April 25, engineers learned that a cable was blocking rotation of an antenna. The problem was corrected by limiting the antenna movement. Then engineers learned that a computer program was pointing the telescope at the wrong points in the sky. Computer software was changed. The flawed mirrors on Hubble cannot be taken out and replaced by the shuttle, but Weiler said replacement instruments could compensate for the misfocused mirrors with special optics. ``We are pretty optimistic that we can take out all of the aberration,'' said Weiler. Olivier said the Hubble mirrors were tested individually on the ground but never as a combination because that would have cost ``hundreds of millions of dollars.'' Hughes Danbury Optical, then a division of Perkin-Elmer, built the Hubble telescope assembly under a $450 million contract that included performance incentives.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Hubble Trouble Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are key facts about the Hubble Space Telescope: Size: 42.5 feet long, 14 feet diameter telescope ``barrel.'' Weight: 25,500 pounds. Launched: April 24, 1990 aboard space shuttle Discovery. Placed in 381-mile orbit the next day by astronauts. Purpose: To study the universe with the most powerful telescope ever placed in orbit. Designed to give views of celestial objects 25 times fainter than the faintest seen from Earth, unobstructed by the earth's atmosphere. Instruments: Faint Object Camera; Faint Object Spectrograph; Goddard High Resolution Spectrograph; High Speed Photometer; Wide Field Planetary Camera. Planned Lifetime: 15 years. Powered: Solar-powered batteries. Communications: Radio control from the Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland. Signals relayed through Tracking and Data Relay Satellites. Light Collection: 94.5 inch primary mirror reflects to 12.2-inch secondary mirror. Mirrors are set precisely 16 feet apart. Light is distributed through other mirrors and optics to five instruments and to fine guidance sensors that aim telescope. Data is transmitted to Earth as electronic signal. Visible light data is reformed into images by computer. History: Approved by Congress in 1977; prepared for launch in 1986, delayed by Challenger explosion. Manufacturer: Mirrors and telescope assembly by Perkin-Elmer Co., now Hughes Danbury Optical Systems, Inc., of Danbury, Conn., a subsidiary of General Motors Corp.'s Hughes Aircraft unit. Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, Inc. designed and built the spacecraft module and assembled and tested the entire craft. Cost: $1.5 billion for the spacecraft, $300 million for ground operations, $300 million for manufacture and testing of servicing equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Political Opponents Arrested, Tortured, and Executed In Sudan
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of opponents of Sudan's military government have been arrested, more than 60 tortured and many others executed since a coup one year ago, Amnesty International said today. The Khartoum government claims all political prisoners have been freed. But London-based human rights organization said it has details of more than 200 prisoners of conscience still in detention without charge or trial. Those arrested include political leaders, trade unionists, academics, lawyers and prominent human rights activists, Amnesty said in a statement. It called on the Sudanese government of Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir to release all political prisoners and take steps to prevent the torture of all inmates. El-Bashir seized power last June 30 after ousting a civilian government in the North African nation. He crushed a coup attempt in April by what he called leftists trying to replace his Moslem government with secular civilian rule and make peace with southern rebels, who are mainly Christian and animist. Since a state of emergency was declared after the coup, Amnesty said, hundreds of political opponents have been detained and many others executed or killed by government troops or militia. The government itself has said it executed 28 active or retired army officers in connection with the April coup attempt. Amnesty said that in the past six months more than 60 prisoners have been tortured in ``safe houses'' and secret interrogation centers in Khartoum by a new security force known as The Security of the Revolution which was formed after the coup. One prisoner is reported to have died recently from torture at one of these centers where prisoners are secretly held for up to several weeks before being taken to prison, Amnesty said. At the beginning of the year, it said, the government released 90 political prisoners and claimed that all prisoners had been freed. But Amnesty said more than 200 were still detained, including 70 being held ``in grossly inadequate conditions'' at the isolated Shalla prison in Sudan's western Darfur province, 500 miles from their families in Khartoum. Some sick prisoners are not receiving medical treatment and inmates have reported poor meals, filthy water and a complete lack of sanitary facilities, the statement said. Under the military government, Amnesty said, the scope of the death penalty has been broadened to include possessing foreign currency and organizing strikes. Prisoners sentenced to death since the coup have not been allowed to appeal their conviction and were denied full legal representation at their trials, it said. In southern Sudan, illegal killings by government forces and armed civilian militias have continued since the coup, Amnesty said. The human rights group said more than 100 civilian non-combatants were deliberately killed by pro-government militia in areas of armed conflict in October and November. And it said 42 southerners disappeared in custody after their arrest in Khartoum in late October. More than 200 suspected government opponents were arrested in the town of Juba in February, with many still in detention without charge or trial, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.NOTE: Eds: k.d. lang cq
DOC.TEXT: Bidding for the slip actress Kathleen Turner wears in Broadway's ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' escalated quickly after an auctioneer informed potential buyers she was wearing it just a few blocks away. ``She's sweating in it right now,'' Diddi Lynn Worsole Worsole said at the auction for Easter Seals on Tuesday. ``Maybe there will be a little perfume on it.'' Bidding had started at $500 and went up in increments of $100. Real estate broker Henry Setaro came in with the top bid of $1,200. ``It's the closest I will ever get to Kathleen Turner,'' said Setaro. ``I hope they don't wash it before I get it.'' Setaro's wife sat next to him during the bidding. Sandy Setaro said she approved of the purchase because the money was for a good cause. Turner plays Maggie in a low-cut, lavender, thigh-length, silk slip with lace trim. The slip actually is one of two that were custom-made for Turner to wear in the Tennessee Williams play, in accordance with a union regulation that requires two sets of each costume.

A radio station will no longer play the music of Grammy winner k.d. lang because the Canadian country star appears in a new ad campaign called ``Meat Stinks.'' KRVN in Lexington will boycott lang until she renounces the group People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals and her ``fanatic anti-meat philosophy,'' program director Charlie Brogan said. KRVN, which broadcasts country music, farm and market reports to Nebraska, Kansas and Iowa, was formed by farm groups in the late 1940s, Brogan said Wednesday. ``This is more than supporting the local economy. It's part of our mission of ag service,'' Brogan said. ``Her music has given her a platform. ... We decided by not playing her music, we're not enhancing that platform.'' The singer appears in the ad with a cow and says, ``If you knew how meat was made, you'd probably lose your lunch. I know _ I'm from cattle country. That's why I became a vegetarian. Meat stinks, and not just for animals but for human health and environment.'' Dan Mathews, PETA director of special projects, said the TV ads and a print ad campaign will begin this summer. ``We were thrilled to have k.d. lang with her cattle country background,'' Mathews said. ``Animals have no voice and k.d. has such a beautiful voice.''

A broker has stepped up efforts to sell Monkey Business, the yacht that scuttled Gary Hart's 1988 presidential bid. The 83-foot charter boat's owner first cast about for buyers last fall, and its captain, Butch Vogelsgang, said the asking price was $1.5 million. In ads in newspapers around the nation this week, the price was down to $1.225 million. For that the buyer will get a three-deck pleasure craft with a Jacuzzi, three rosewood-paneled staterooms _ and a bit of history. Hart, the former senator from Colorado, fell from Democratic presidential front-runner to infamy in less than a week after his charter trip from Florida to Bimini with model Donna Rice came to light in 1987. Hart and Rice denied any hanky-panky; Rice's friend Lynn Armandt told the news media otherwise _ and collected a hefty fee. Yacht broker Bob Offer of Fort Lauderdale is selling the boat for developer Donald Soffer. ``The boat has a character of its own,'' said Offer. ``When you walk on board, you really want to have a good time.'' Offer said Soffer, who had the Monkey Business custom-built in 1979, decided to market the boat in earnest because construction on a new 140-foot yacht is almost complete.

Mikhail Baryshnikov will dance in the United States for the first time this year during a fall tour of 18 cities from Miami to Minneapolis. The tour, announced Wednesday, will be called the White Oak Dance Project. Dances, including two new ones, will be by choreographer Mark Morris. The troupe will perform in Boston; Minneapolis; Madison, Wis.; Toledo, Columbus, Youngstown and Dayton, Ohio; Charleston, S.C.; Savannah, Ga.; Miami; Jacksonville, Daytona Beach, and Tampa, Fla.; Detroit; East Lansing, Mich.; Louisville, Ky., and two cities to be announced.

DOC.HEAD: Pacific Rim Playing Bigger Role in Farm Exports
DOC.TEXT: Exports come to mind quickly at the Agriculture Department when the livelihood of American farmers is discussed. And Pacific Rim countries are not far behind. What happens in the rim, notably Japan and other East Asian countries, bears heavily on U.S. agricultural exports and, consequently, the financial well-being of producers. Collectively, commodity exports to the major Pacific Rim countries are increasing again this year, but the growth is smaller than in 1989, a report by the department's Economic Research Service said Wednesday. Exports to Japan, South Korea and Taiwan are expected to increase but will not match the 10 percent gain of 1989 or the 28 percent jump in 1988, the report said. Agricultural sales to Canada are expected to rise sharply in the fiscal year that began last Oct. 1 because of a change in the reporting system, the agency said. Sales to Australia and New Zealand probably will increase, it said. ``Economic growth in the developed Pacific Rim slowed for the second straight year in 1989,'' the report said. ``Rising interest and inflation rates, and labor shortages in East Asia are straining the region's economies.'' One factor was a strengthening of the U.S. dollar against the Japanese yen, which possibly dampened demand for American farm products, the report said. Meanwhile, the dollar fell against the currencies of South Korea, Taiwan and Canada, which helped boost export prospects. Domestic policies, production and competitive exports are factors that draw attention from U.S. analysts. ``All developed Pacific Rim countries except New Zealand increased their agricultural output in 1989-90,'' the report said. ``Gross farm income was higher in all countries. Government support to agriculture was generally lower in 1988-89 and is estimated to fall further for most countries in 1989-90.'' Consumer eating habits remain diverse in the developed rim countries, the report said. But diets in the Asian countries ``are approaching those in Western countries as consumption of animal protein grows and starch consumption falls.'' Australia, a traditional supplier of grass-fed beef, is moving to supply grain-fattened beef to Japan. That means more competition for American producers. ``Current Australian feedlot capacity of about 600,000 head is expected to double by 1992,'' the report said. ``Much of the recent feedlot expansion has been with Japanese investment.'' Further, the report said, ``Australia has the cattle, feed grains and technology to be a significant U.S. competitor in high-quality, grain-fed beef to Japan and other Asian markets, although problems remain with infrastructure and stable feed supplies.'' New Zealand and Australia also have undertaken policy reforms that are aimed in part at making their farm products more competitive in world markets. ``Since 1984, New Zealand's farm sector has undergone a painful adjustment resulting from removal of direct farm support, rising interest rates and an appreciating exchange rate between 1985 and 1988,'' the report said. ``The policy reforms in the two countries have lowered government assistance to agriculture.''

Genetically altered potatoes that could be naturally deadly to beetles are being field-tested in the Pacific Northwest by a team led by Agriculture Department scientists. The outdoor tests were scheduled to begin this week in Prosser, Wash., geneticist Charles R. Brown of the department's Agricultural Research Service said Wednesday. ``Ultimately, we want to know whether potato plants could use this genetic weapon to combat Colorado potato beetles with little or no chemical insecticide,'' he said in a report issued here. Brown is based at the agency's vegetable and crop research unit in Prosser and is collaborating with other scientists from the University of Washington, Seattle, and another USDA researcher in Yakima, Wash. The quarter-acre potato plots are at Washington State University's research and extension center in Prosser. Brown said the added gene is from a strain of bacterium, Bacillus thuringiensis, or Bt, that lives in soil naturally and makes a beetle-killing protein. The Prosser tests were said to be the first in the United States involving Bt genes placed in potatoes. Other researchers at private companies and universities, however, have raised tomato, cotton and tobacco plants that use a Bt gene and show pest resistance. Brown said the Colorado potato beetle is ``probably the worst potato insect pest worldwide'' and that it has become resistant to many pesticides.

The Agriculture Department says China has bought an additional 139,400 metric tons of U.S. wheat under a price subsidy program. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said Wednesday that six private exporting companies made the deals under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Delivery of the wheat is scheduled for October, he said. The sales were part of 2 million tons authorized for China under EEP on May 2. Previous allocations had been exhausted except for 5,050 tons. Dickerson said China has slightly more than 1 million tons remaining in its current allocation. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat.
