Under EEP arrangements, private exporters can sell U.S. commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest subsidies averaged $19.82 per ton, or about 54 cents per bushel. The subsidized sales were handled by Continental Grain Co., 74,400 bushels; Central States Enterprises Inc., 35,000; and Mitsubishi International Corp., 30,000.

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Woes Trouble Astronomers
With PM-Hubble Trouble, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Astronomers had hoped the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope would give their field its biggest boost since Galileo first used a telescope in 1609. Now the trouble-plagued observatory may make them wait a few more years. ``We've been waiting for a decade, so to wait some more is pretty disappointing. I guess we'll have to suffer,'' said astronomer David Koo of the University of California at Santa Cruz. NASA announced Wednesday that an apparent manufacturing error prevents proper focusing of the mirrors on the telescope, which is the most expensive unmanned spacecraft ever built. Agency officials said that until shuttle astronauts can make repairs during a mission scheduled for 1993, the problem will make the telescope's most important instrument _ the wide-field and planetary camera _ virtually useless. NASA said it hopes to send a shuttle earlier. The flaw also will make the telescope's second camera, the faint object camera, unable to take pictures any better than those made by a telescope on the ground. The Hubble was designed to study extremely distant stars and galaxies. Three other instruments, which detect various types of light but are not cameras, will be less seriously impaired. ``It's a major blow to our hopes,'' said Kim Leschly, wide-field camera systems engineer at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``It is very disappointing, extremely disappointing.'' If the telescope's mirrors worked properly, the wide-field camera would be able to make out an object the size of a baseball from a distance of 200 miles. The camera was designed to help determine the age of the universe, test theories of how the universe evolved, search for possible planets orbiting nearby stars and map the surfaces of moons, asteroids and comets. ``There still will be images from the current camera that will be reasonably exciting, but they won't push the frontier,'' Leschly said. Approved by Congress in 1977, the launch of the Hubble was delayed not only by the 1986 Challenger explosion that grounded the shuttle fleet but by numerous technical problems. It finally was launched from shuttle Discovery in April. Scientists had ranked it with Galileo's first use of a telescope in importance. Leschly said Jet Propulsion Laboratory employees reacted to the latest problem by asking, ``How come people making the mirror didn't do their job right?'' ``As part of the Hubble team, you feel disappointed somebody didn't do it right,'' Leschly said, ``and that hurts.'' The mirrors and their supports were manufactured by Perkin-Elmer Corp., now Hughes Danbury Optical Corp., of Danbury, Conn. Company official Jack Rehnberg acknowledged human error may have been to blame. ``People aren't crying. It's just that there have been so many delays in this project that when you say wait another three years, it's slightly depressing,'' said John Holtzman, an astronomer with Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Farmers Oppose Drug-War Plan to Promote Crop Substitution
DOC.TEXT: Soybean farmers say they support the war on drugs, but they don't want the United States to encourage Bolivian coca farmers to grow soybeans instead of the leaf used to make cocaine. But a House Agriculture subcommittee chairman says the war against cocaine must not take a back seat to the interests of U.S. soybean farmers. ``As long as drugs remain the scourge they are to this country, they must be of highest priority, especially when the threat of competition to U.S. farm interests is minimal, as appears to be the case in this instance,'' Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kans., said at a hearing Wednesday of his subcommittee on wheat, soybeans and feed grains. ``Soybean farmers want to help in the drug problem. But it's not a good use of taxpayer dollars to subsidize competition if it doesn't reduce drug production,'' James Lee Adams, chairman of the American Soybean Association, said. He said his group did not lobby the Agriculture Department to block use of federal funds for a U.S. Agency for International Development program in Bolivia that was promoting soybean farming as an alternative to coca. But Allan Mendelowitz, of the General Accounting Office, told the subcommittee that an investigation of the situation revealed ``there is frequent, ongoing contact between the American Soybean Association and the Agriculture Department.'' Bolivia is second to Peru in coca leaf production. After processing in Colombia, most of the Bolivian leaf is sold as cocaine to drug users in the United States. President Bush signed an agreement Feb. 15 at the drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia, with the presidents of Bolivia, Colombia and Peru to encourage crop substitution and ``non-traditional exports'' as an alternative to the coca trade. ``I don't think there is a greater priority today than the war on drugs,'' added Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla. ``I'm dumbfounded by the response we got from the American Soybean Association. The Department of Agriculture should be severely chastised for any role they had.'' Christopher Goldthwait, of the Agriculture Department, said the federal program _ known as PL 480 or Food for Peace _ paying for the Bolivian soybean project restricts aid to commodities that do not compete with products grown in the United States. ``We remain concerned that project funds would contribute to expanding Bolivian soybean production for export which, in turn could adversely affect U.S. producers at a time when they were already losing markets,'' he said. Mendelowitz said soybeans offer one of the best alternatives to coca for Bolivia on the export market, though not enough soybeans are produced to be a real threat to American growers. In 1989, Bolivia exported about 44,000 tons of soybeans, while U.S. producers exported 17 million tons, Mendelowitz said. Frederick Schieck, of the Agency for International Development, said U.S. officials didn't start out to encourage Bolivians to grow soybeans. He said the original goal was increased wheat production, but because the growing season is long enough for two crops, farmers rotated into soybeans after the wheat harvest. He said Bolivia has a long way to go before any crop will replace the $300 million a year in foreign exchange earnings experienced from coca exports. Bolivia produces an estimated one-third of the world supply of coca leaf and is the most coca-dependent of the Andean countries, he said. About 250,000 Bolivians work in coca production.

DOC.HEAD: Court Sets Guidelines to Shield Children in Abuse Testimony
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court's decision to let states shield children from trauma when they testify in abuse cases is a ``victory for children,'' according to a youth welfare group. Many states already have adopted measures to protect young witnesses in this growing area of criminal law and now may determine whether their procedures meet the new guidelines set by the court. Most states permit the use of videotaped testimony of sexually abused children or allow one-way, closed-circuit televised testimony. Some have a two-way system in which the child witness can see the courtroom and the defendant on a monitor while the judge and jury view the child. The high court said Wednesday such measures may be constitutional _ depending on what safeguards are built in for defendants. The court, in a pair of 5-4 rulings, said people charged with child abuse have no guaranteed right to confront their young accusers face to face. The ruling highlighted a hectic conclusion to the court's 1989-90 term, leaving what are expected to be only some routine housecleaning chores. The justices did not plan to be on the bench today when announcements are made in those matters. In other action Wednesday, the court: _Upheld federal policies that favor minorities in awarding broadcast licenses, a major victory for affirmative action. By a 5-4 vote in cases from Florida and Connecticut, the justices said preferential Federal Communications Commission policies aimed at providing diversity over the nation's airwaves do not discriminate unlawfully against whites. _Limited the power of environmentalists to sue in federal court to prevent opening of federal lands to commercial development. _Upheld Arizona's death penalty law in a decision that also removes a constitutional cloud from similar laws in Idaho and Montana. _Ruled in a Maryland case that most of the nation's post offices may ban all soliciting on their property. The court examined the child abuse issue in cases from Maryland and Idaho and generally heartened advocates of children's rights. ``A state's interest in the physical and psychological well-being of child abuse victims may be sufficiently important to outweigh, at least in some cases, a defendant's right to face his or her accusers in court,'' Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote for the court. The number of cases is growing. More than 2.2 million child abuse reports were filed in 1988, according to the National Committee for the Prevention of Child Abuse. ``This is a victory for children,'' said Joyce Strom of the Child Welfare League of America. ``This is a step in the right direction of strengthening a judicial system to protect children and acknowledge their special need.'' The decisions were not a total victory for the states. Writing for the court in the Maryland case, O'Connor said states may not simply disregard the right of defendants to confront their accusers. States must show the elimination of the face-to-face confrontation is necessary to protect children and that steps have been taken to assure the testimony of the young witnesses is reliable, she said. O'Connor said trial judges may shield children from such confrontations only when there would be substantial emotional trauma _ not if the youngsters merely are nervous or reluctant to testify. The court upheld the child-molesting conviction of the owner of a Clarksville, Md., day care center. Four young children were allowed to testify via closed-circuit TV out of the defendant's presence. By a separate 5-4 vote, the court refused to reinstate a Boise, Idaho, woman's child abuse conviction thrown out by the state's highest court because the child did not testify. A pediatrician testified at the trial about his interview with the 2-year-old alleged victim.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Assembly Leader Attacked By Unknown Gunman
DOC.TEXT: Attackers apparently targeting the president of El Salvador's assembly hit one of his police escorts with gunfire on Wednesday but no one was injured, the politician said. Assembly president Ricardo Alvarenga, who was on his way home from the assembly, told a news conference that his car took off at high speed when he heard the shooting. He blamed the attack on leftist rebelsm, who have been fighting a series of U.S. backed governments for a decade. Alvarenga lamented the shooting incident because it occurred just two days after rightist government of President Alfredo Cristiani and guerrilla leaders completed a round of peace talks in Mexico. His words at the news conference were broadcast on independent Radio YSKL. Alvarenga, a member of Cristiani's governing Republican National Alliance, said he heard two or three shots lodge in one of his police escort's cars. He said one police cruiser had been in front of him and one in back. The incident happened during a rainstorm that caused a power outtage, leaving the streets dark. Alvarenga said the shots rang out when he was about 1.5 miles from the assembly.

DOC.HEAD: Sakharov's Widow: Gorbachev an Obstacle to Democratic Change
DOC.TEXT: Soviet human rights activist Yelena Bonner says President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has become an ``obstacle to democratic change,'' and that the Communist Party should step aside and take the government with it. The 73-year-old wife of the late Soviet physicist and Nobel Peace Prize winner Andrei D. Sakharov also accused Gorbachev and the Communists of provoking ethnic conflicts and blocking economic progress in the Soviet Union. ``At the beginning, when Gorbachev declared all these changes, he made a very serious, non-trivial step. But during the last two years he has not moved forward,'' Ms. Bonner said in an interview Tuesday. She said Gorbachev's reforms since he came to power five years ago have done little to improve the lot of the Soviet people. ``It turns out all the changes were made to guarantee him personal power. He becomes an obstacle to democratic change,'' Ms. Bonner told The Associated Press. Sakharov's widow was in Israel to dedicate a Jerusalem park in the honor of her late husband and accept an honorary degree in his name. Ms. Bonner married Sakharov in 1971 and lived with him in internal exile in the Volga city of Gorky from January 1980 until December 1986, when Gorbachev allowed Sakharov to return to Moscow. Ms. Bonner said she felt a strong democratic trend in the Soviet Union among people who seek ``a smooth transition to democracy.'' ``But the (Communist) party is blocking it and this provokes conflict,'' she said. Ms. Bonner noted that Sakharov, who died Dec. 14, had pushed for a multiparty system and demanded that state land be given to the peasants by the spring of 1989. But instead of embracing the changes suggested by Sakharov that ``could feed us in just two years,'' the government introduced a limited system of leasing some land from collective farms under which ``people are not free.'' Attempts to revive industry have also failed, Ms. Bonner said. She said the Communist Party has been slow to relinquish its political monopoly despite promising to do so, and that the leadership has maintained its old authoritarian ways in dealing with restive Soviet republics. Ms. Bonner cited the bloody dispute over the majority Armenian enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh in Soviet Azerbaijan. That dispute has grown into almost a guerrilla war between the two republics. Instead of following a democratic decision by Karabakh leaders who voted in favor of Armenian rule, she charged, Gorbachev ``adopted Stalinist constitution regarding the wholeness of borders'' and thus ignited the conflict. ``Gorbachev would change the constitution in two hours to assure an increase in power for himself. But when it came to people he decided the constitution could not be changed and statehood prevailed,'' she said. Earlier this year, Gorbachev pushed legislation through the Congress of People's Deputies that expanded the power of the presidency, to which he was then re-elected by deputies. Now, Soviet security forces are stationed in the capitals of the rival republics. Ms. Bonner said she feared ``this stupidity of military and political leadership'' could lead to worsened inter-ethnic bloodletting. Ms. Bonner also blamed the Soviet authorities for equally violent ethnic outbursts in Soviet Central Asia that she said resulted from worsening economic and ecological conditions. ``We _ not me and not the Russians but the central administration _ led Central Asia to complete devastation. We have destroyed a piece of the planet with our own hands,'' Ms. Bonner said. Her long list of criticisms of Gorbachev included his economic blockade of Lithuania after the Baltic republic declared independence on March 11. Since then, there have been moves by several other Soviet republics to secede. ``Now other republics gradually declare themselves sovereign and they all adopt laws saying their local laws prevail over the Soviet ones,'' Ms. Bonner said. ``Gorbachev and the leadership have lost their power, they must work out a new agreement with the republics and they will have exactly the amount of power the republics are ready to grant them.'' In the future, Ms. Bonner said she saw the Soviet Union as a coalition of free nations, perhaps with a mutual defense pact, that are bound by economic agreements. ``I don't know what he (Gorbachev) wants,'' she said. ``All his economic and political changes in the country are very ambivalent.''

DOC.HEAD: Shoppers Mourn Coming Demise of `A Very Classy Store'
DOC.TEXT: Huge ``Going Out of Business Sale'' banners plastered across the display windows of Garfinckel's department store obscured the mannequins in stylish black cocktail dresses and upscale beachwear. Carole Melham was shocked. She's been shopping at Garfinckel's since she was a little girl growing up in suburban Chevy Chase, Md. ``I just can't imagine they could let this happen,'' she said, standing on the sidewalk in 80-degree heat waiting for the doors to open Wednesday. ``It's symbolic of a lost era, like the Paris of the 1920s,'' she said. ``I was raised on Garfinckel's. Shopping was a major event. My mother bought me tons and tons of things here. I remember when there was a doorman to greet you. ``It was another world. I loved the atmosphere, the high ceilings, the elevators, the sales clerks who'd look for good buys and set things aside for you. Garfinckel's stayed old-fashioned, and it never went down the tubes. It was a very classy store. ``All that's left are congested malls in the suburbs where everyone chews gum. The merchandise has gotten so bad. The big stores, it's like shopping in a zoo or a barn. It's so raunchy. The world has changed. It's all very depressing.'' Garfinckel's, an elegant Washington landmark for 85 years, announced last week it was seeking protection from creditors in federal bankruptcy court and closing seven of its nine stores, including its flagship downtown emporium at the busy intersection of 14th and F streets. Retail industry analysts said Garfinckel's had fallen victim to aggressive competition from Bloomingdale's, Neiman-Marcus, Nordstrom and other large national department stores that have muscled into Washington's affluent suburbs in recent years. Garfinckel's troubles were compounded by a succession of five owners whose conflicting marketing strategies confused and disappointed their traditional customers, who included the rich and powerful of Washington. Many of them took their business elsewhere. The liquidation sale is intended to clear Garfinckel's store shelves and display cases of all merchandise, valued at $22 million, within 60 days. Under a court-approved deal, an estimated $9 million to $10 million of the sale proceeds is expected to go directly to one of Garfinckel's principal secured creditors. Mrs. Melham and her small son, Timothy, were among hundreds of white-gloved matrons, their yuppie offspring and eager bargain hunters who swarmed through Garfinckel's polished bronze doors at noon Wednesday. They snapped up Garfinckel's trademark luxury items _ Waterford crystal, Hermes scarves, Countess Mara silk ties, Godiva chocolates, Givenchy pantyhose and Christofle silverware _ at a 20 percent discount. Within 15 minutes, the front doors were ordered closed temporarily to contain the throng. A short time later, two of Garfinckel's wood-paneled elevators jammed under the crush of shoppers trying to get upstairs. ``I feel so very sad,'' said Gertrude Hallila, 72, who has been a loyal customer since she arrived in Washington during World War II. She remembers riding the trolley with her children for a day at Garfinckel's, with lunch in the Greenbrier Room. Maria Kostecka, who lives in the posh suburb of Potomac, Md., said she was ``extremely upset'' over Garfinckel's demise. She liked the ``excellent clothes,'' the dignified atmosphere _ no shoving or pushing in the spacious aisles _ and the ``very classy'' saleswomen. ``They would call my home and tell me about a forthcoming sale,'' she recalled. ``They knew my size, and they'd say they were holding a dress they thought I'd like. If I returned something two months later, they would take it back with a smile. Little things like that mean a lot.'' Mildred Pickett remembers moving to racially segregated Washington to work for the government in 1942. She was a young black stenographer from Canton, Ill., and a stranger to discrimination. ``Years ago, it was said Negroes couldn't come to Garfinckel's,'' she recalled. ``But if you dressed well and carried yourself well, they would accept some people, depending on the clerk. I never felt uncomfortable coming to a store like Garfinckel's. The quality was very good and all the clerks were courteous and businesslike. Why, the blouse I'm wearing today I bought on sale here 18 years ago.''

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release at 10 a.m. EDT; set by source
Report: Invest Social Security Surplus In College Scholarships
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Update likely after 10 a.m. news conference
DOC.TEXT: About 9 million Americans could get money to pay expenses for college or vocational training each year if a portion of the Social Security surplus is invested in a revolving loan fund, a group of economists said today. The Economic Policy Institute released a proposal by University of Massachusetts economist Barry Bluestone and colleagues to make available to every American a lifetime ``line of credit'' of $40,000 to finance the costs of college or university education or vocational training or apprenticeship. Social Security surpluses, estimated by the Congressional Budget Office to reach $73 billion by 1991, would be used to underwrite the program. Costs would total about $40 billion per year but are expected to rapidly decrease, as the surplus continues to grow. Borrowers could take up to 25 years to repay their loans by means of a levy on future earnings. The Internal Revenue Service would be charged with the collection duties, through payroll deductions. ``The key domestic issues facing America in the 1990s will center on questions of `equity' _ in both sense of the term,'' the report said. ``Equity means `fairness,' but it also refers to investment such as corporate stock that pays dividends based on the profitability of an asset.'' The proposal, called the Equity Investment in America program, applies the dual meaning of equity ``to mitigate the financial barriers to college and university schooling and vocational training for all students,'' regardless of income, age or social background. The report pointed to statistics that show the ratio of annual earnings of college graduates to high school graduates has increased from 1.5 to one in 1963 to more than 1.8 to one in 1987 _ an increase of 20 percent. A recent survey found that one-third of the students who delayed or indefinitely put off college pointed to the expense involved. The federal government has moved to disenfranchise middle-class students from federal assistance by restricting eligibility for grants, the report said. In 1979, the government set a $32,500 ceiling on family income for a student to be eligible for grant support. Today, despite inflation, a family must have an income no higher than $28,000 to be eligible for aid. The largest federal loan programs, the Stafford Student Loan, provides a maximum of $2,625 per academic year for the first two years of undergraduate study and $4,000 for each subsequent year, up to a five-year maximum of $17,250. Students over four years must add an average of $9,750 out of pocket to attend a public university and at least $26,750 to go to a private institution. The new program would assist about 9 million students each year _ 7 million to 7.5 million in colleges and universities and 1.7 million in vocational training, the study said. Bluestone and co-authors Alan Clayton-Matthews and John Havens of Boston College, and Howard Young of the University of Michigan said their plan would create a new Education Department agency to raise capital for the program, make the awards to students and oversee repayment. Under the plan, loan repayment amounts deducted by the IRS would remain low if a student's income after college is low, and increase an income levels increase. ``Across all participants in the system, the combination of increasing incomes, IRS collection of loan repayments and long repayment schedules will result in full repayment to the Social Security system,'' the authors said.

DOC.HEAD: Bowling Alley Transcends Lifestyle, Ethnic Divisions
DOC.TEXT: Bowling long ago shed its Fred Flintstone image and its wide appeal is no more apparent than at Marigold Bowl. There's a Japanese league, a Puerto Rican league, a janitors league and a gay league. About every variety of race, religion, occupation and ethnic background is represented at the 32-lane alley near the Chicago Cubs' Wrigley Field. ``We're a league of nations. Our customers are diversified,'' said owner Bob Fagenholz, 54. There's even a league called the Marigold Straits. ``We had a gay league bowling in front of us and another after us. We just wanted to define ourselves, but we spell it differently,'' said Fred Schmidt, an architect. Everybody seems to get along. ``When the gays first started bowling here, it was hard for some people to get used to _ like anything new. Now, they are used to it,'' said Fagenholz's son, Fred, who is Marigold's manager. Mark Miller of the American Bowling Congress in Milwaukee said, ``We'd like to believe that bowling centers are melting pots, and that those in the inner cities would have such mixed leagues.'' The number of U.S. bowlers rose from 68 million in 1987 to 74 million last year, according to the ABC.

DOC.HEAD: Administration's Backing of Rise in Child Labor Fines Praised
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's support for a tenfold increase in child labor law fines is a welcome change from the Reagan era's hands-off attitude, Democrats and union officials say. ``Any imposition on businesses _ that just wasn't done. This notion of increasing fines is a big improvement,'' AFL-CIO spokesman Rudy Oswald said Wednesday of the endorsement by Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole. Mrs. Dole, in testimony prepared for the House labor standards subcommittee today, backed legislation to increase from $1,000 to $10,000 the maximum penalty for businesses that employ youngsters in dangerous jobs or for too many hours. Mrs. Dole also supported stiffer criminal penalties so that prosecutors could seek jail terms for first-time willful violators. Currently, jail terms are only available upon the second conviction. The higher fines are in a bill by Reps. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., and Don Pease, D-Ohio. Mrs. Dole ``has talked about cracking down on this before, and it was met with skepticism. One has got to take her seriously now,'' Pease said Wednesday. Schumer's office called Dole's support a ``welcome change.'' The current penalties have not been changed since they were established in 1974. ``We seek a balance. Our goal is to impose penalties which are strong enough to deter violations, but do not dissuade law-abiding employers from offering productive work experiences for youth,'' Mrs. Dole's testimony said. Besides higher fines, Oswald called on the Labor Department to increase the size of its enforcement staff to ensure that businesses aren't exploiting children. Since March, federal labor agents have conducted two nationwide sweeps of fast-food chains and other businesses, finding nearly 20,000 violations of child labor laws. Mrs. Dole said one reason child labor violations have increased dramatically in recent years _ 128 percent since 1986 _ is the nation's tight labor market. The workforce has been expending at an annual rate of only 1 percent, its slowest rate in nearly 40 years. ``Faced with a shrinking pool of workers, some employers have reacted by putting young people to work in unsafe conditions, or for hours beyond the limits of the law,'' Mrs. Sole said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Pays Tribute to King, But Not Non-violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `Martin Luther ...,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with details of Mandela's arrival in Miami. SUBS 26th graf, `Miami Mayor ...,' to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AX3, AX5, AX6
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela paid silent tribute Wednesday at the tomb of Martin Luther King Jr., and the slain civil rights leader's widow fervently upheld Mandela's right to depart from non-violence in the struggle for black rights in South Africa. Mandela did not speak during the brief wreath-laying ceremony, which included the singing of the anthem of the U.S. civil rights movement, ``We Shall Overcome.'' Later, the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference that King founded, told Mandela: ``We reject the constant nagging you have experienced about violence. ... We respect the right of oppressed people everywhere to seek their own liberation.'' The audience of more than 1,500 people at Big Bethel AME Church cheered wildly. Coretta Scott King said, ``Reverend Lowery has spoken for all of us and he spoke well. We support you; we love you; we revere you.'' Mandela told the audience, ``As a result of your support and the hospitality you have shown us now, it is futile for the white minority in South Africa to resist the people's demand for one-person, one-vote.'' Mandela later addressed a sold-out rally at 46,000-seat Grant Field, praising King as a ``giant among giants.'' He quoted King's famous ``I Have a Dream'' speech, which ended with the declaration, ``Let freedom ring.'' ``Let us all exclaim, `Let freedom ring in South Africa,''' he said. The stadium crowd stood and cheered, chanted and waved their fists for 1{ minutes when Mandela took the podium, where he brought the Georgia audience greetings ``from the fighting people of South Africa.'' The rally capped the fourth stop on Mandela's U.S. tour, after New York, Boston and Washington. He arrived in Miami on Wednesday just before midnight. Mandela was greeted at the Alexander Hotel on Miami Beach by up to 200 supporters. But the visibly tired Mandela was hustled to his hotel room. The crowd chanted ``Free South Africa'' and then ``Free South Florida'' and finally ``Where is Suarez?'' The last chant referred to Miami Mayor Xavier Suarez, who denounced Mandela for his support of Cuba's Fidel Castro. In Atlanta, Martin Luther King III told a reporter that Mandela's visit to the center named for his father showed that, ``Clearly, he does not support violence. I think Mr. Mandela wants non-violent solutions, but the government has pushed him to that.'' Some local civil rights officials had suggested Mandela should follow King's philosophy and renounce violence. But upon his arrival here Wednesday morning, the founder of the African National Congress wasted no time reminding the group of his view that black South Africans face a different battle than the one King led. ``Unlike you, we are still under the grip of white supremacy,'' Mandela said at the airport. To reporters he added: ``Non-violence is a good policy when conditions permit.'' King was assassinated in 1968, five years after Mandela began his 27-year prison stay for plotting sabotage to overthrow the minority white government of South Africa. The government released him in February and negotiations are underway aimed at dismantling apartheid. A scheduled midday break for the 71-year-old Mandela was extended, delaying the wreath-laying ceremony by about three hours. Mandela has at times canceled events to rest during his grueling 14-nation tour of Europe and North America. A downpour soaked the 1,300 people waiting near King's crypt. A carnival atmosphere set in when the rain stopped, complete with popcorn vendors and music from a military band. Mandela was cheered by about 5,000 people along Auburn Avenue, a historic stretch of black businesses and civil rights landmarks, as he arrived at the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change. After a brief meeting with Mrs. King and other dignitaries, Mandela and his wife, Winnie, placed the wreath at the crypt, which sits above a reflecting pool at the King Center. Mandela also received honorary doctorate degrees from 40 predominantly black colleges at a convocation at Morehouse College. Later he was to appear at a sold-out rally at the 46,000-seat Grant Field. Mrs. Mandela received a standing ovation from a gathering of 1,500 people, mostly women, at a $100-a-plate luncheon benefiting the ANC. ``I cannot tell you how touched I am by this warmth, your kindness and your identity with our struggle,'' she said. ``We come from racist South Africa. ... You are reminding us what it is to belong to a family of mankind.'' At Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport, Gov. Joe Frank Harris, a white conservative Democrat, called Mandela an inspiration, and welcomed him to ``the birthplace of equality and justice for all of America.'' Mayor Maynard Jackson joined Mandela and his wife, Winnie, in raising a clenched fist salute during the playing of the ANC's anthem. Security considerations kept the crowd at the airport to 200 invited guests, including a group of children from a city-run interracial camp and a marching band. Along a nearby road, about 100 people strained to see the South African leader. There was no sign of protest over Mandela's refusal to repudiate Libyan President Moammar Gadhafi, Cuban leader Fidel Castro and Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat. But in the Miami area, where Mandela was scheduled to address a labor meeting Thursday, no official welcome was planned and Cuban-American groups planned rallies to protest Mandela's support of Castro. Suarez and four area Cuban-American mayors have accused Mandela for insensitivity to human rights in Cuba, and Mayor Alex Daoud of largely Jewish Miami Beach condemned him for ties to Gadhafi and Arafat. Black leaders vowed to take it upon themselves to welcome Mandela. ``He is our brother,'' said Johnnie McMillian, president of Miami's NAACP chapter. ``If they say he's not welcome, they're saying we're not welcome, too.'' Mandela's address Thursday to the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees in Miami Beach isn't open to the public, so black leaders planned shows of support outside the hall and in a Liberty City park, where the speech will be broadcast over loudspeakers. Meantime, leaders of various Cuban-American and anti-Castro groups met Tuesday night to plan a protest at the convention center. The Atlanta crowd carried only pro-Mandela signs. The John Birch Society bought a newspaper ad Monday condemning Mandela as a criminal, but Wednesday's crowd regarded him as a persecuted hero. ``He's been in jail for 27 years for trying to help Africa become a better place. That's not right,'' said 10-year-old Audrey Durden. ``I'm completely overwhelmed. This is very historical not only for Africa but for the world,'' said Ayesha Naji, 40, of Atlanta, a former resident of Liberia. ``He represents a worldwide hero for me.''

DOC.HEAD: Timber Workers Skeptical of Government Assurances
DOC.TEXT: Timber workers figure a mock sign at a local tavern best tells their future. ``Notice to Owl-Displaced Workers,'' the sign reads. Temporary jobs will open soon, including: ``Hiking Trail Builder, Grades I & 2; Hiking Boot Polisher; and Spotted Owl Nest Cleaner.'' The government Tuesday announced preliminary plans to restrict logging in the Northwest to protect the rare northern spotted owl. At the same time, the government said it will try to balance the industry's needs against the owl's. But Loggers at the Waterhole Tavern No. 1 were skeptical. They and others walking the main street of this one-mill town of 1,200 said that in the end, they're going to suffer. ``This industry has been in an uproar since the 1920s,'' growled Jim Miller, a logger, miller and part-time bartender. ``This spotted owl thing is just the latest setback for us.'' Miller and others said the industry already is feeling the effects of a weakened lumber products market as the nation's housing starts decline. Substantial logging cutbacks in virgin, or old-growth, forest to protect owls ``would affect us drastically,'' said Simpson Timber mill manager Del Orren. The mill down the street from the tavern employs 350 people making doors for homes. It relies exclusively on old-growth timber, he said. ``We're feeling the pinch some,'' he said. ``Any logging cutbacks are going to hurt.'' The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service said Friday the spotted owl, of which 3,000 to 5,000 pairs remain, would be designated a threatened species July 23. The move cheered environmentalists, who are seeking to protect not only the owl but the remaining centuries-old forests in Washington, Oregon and northern California. But the environmentalists want far more extensive restrictions on logging to protect the shy, 2-foot-tall owl than were announced Tuesday. A task force headed by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter is to devise a detailed plan by Sept. 1. The preliminary plan will reduce logging on U.S. Bureau of Land Management land in Oregon and Northern California at a cost of 1,000 jobs over the next two years, said Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan. He said 450 owls would be saved. An earlier, more extensive proposal by government scientists would have resulted in the loss of nearly 28,000 jobs on federal land over 10 years. Yeutter and Lujan also called on Congress to relax the Endangered Species Act so that policy makers will have more latitude to consider the economic and social impact of protecting wildlife. Jim Pissot, spokesman for the Audubon Society of Washington, said environmentalists will sue to stop any timber sales that threaten owl habitat. Timber workers were skeptical the government is looking out after their interests. ``You want to know what I think?'' Alfred Dierich, a guard at a logging site, said as he stood outside the town's main grocery store. ``I think it's all just a bunch of politics. ``Ain't nobody going to help us, and it's going to be rough any way you look at her,'' Dierich said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Criticizes Bush for Indecision
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee chairman says he is angered by President Bush's refusal to ``get off the fence'' and find a way to save the northern spotted owl while still protecting logging jobs in the Northwest. Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., contended Wednesday that a lack of scientific credibility in the administration's preliminary plans to protect the threatened owl will force a court battle that will paralyze the region's logging industry unless Congress steps in. ``The president is leading us right down the road and into a legal disaster,'' said Vento, chairman of the House Interior subcommittee on national parks and public lands. ``The administration is putting us right back in court _ right back into paralysis in that area,'' he said. The Fish and Wildlife Service last Friday declared the owl a threatened species. It cited scientific evidence that current forest management practices are inadequate to reverse the shrinking habitat and declining population that jeopardize the owl's survival. An estimated 3,000 to 5,000 pairs of the owls are believed to exist. Vento said he was most upset by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter's decision Tuesday to postpone an announcement on a solution to the problem and instead form a new timber task force that will report to Bush by Sept. 1 on how many trees the Forest Service should cut next year. ``The president ought to get off the fence instead of passing the buck to another blue-ribbon committee. We've got enough blue ribbons around here to go to the state fair,'' Vento said. ``We have got to have a reserved forest system. We have got to take some land and preserve it.'' Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said Tuesday that harvest reductions on Bureau of Land Management lands will be much less than was feared as a result of owl protection. Yeutter said he will chair the new task force that will strive to maintain near-current harvest levels in the Pacific Northwest forests inhabited by the 2-foot-tall owl. The announcements drew heated criticism from environmentalists, who subscribe to the scientific report that suggests Northwestern timber harvests must be cut nearly in half to ensure that the owl will not become extinct. Lujan said the BLM will enact a plan on Oct. 1 that will reduce BLM timber harvest levels in Oregon and northern California from 950 million board feet annually to 750 million board feet. BLM Director Cy Jamison said the plan will save more owls but cause less economic disruption than would a plan offered in April by a panel of government scientists chaired by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas. Jamison's plan would cost 1,000 jobs over two years, compared with the government's prediction that the Thomas report would result in the loss of nearly 8,000 logging jobs on BLM lands by the end of the decade. The Thomas plan also is projected to cost more than 20,000 jobs on Forest Service lands by the year 2000.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor's Murder Trial is the Talk of the Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Closing arguments scheduled for early afternoon EDT.
DOC.TEXT: The case of a doctor charged with murdering his wife and burying her in the basement of a house he bought with his pregnant girlfriend has transfixed this Midwestern community. The courthouse is filled each day, and a TV station has been taping each day's proceedings and airing them later in their entirety. ``Not many people get buried in the basement of a home your family's going to live in. This is more like a movie, a murder mystery,'' said Barbara Petit, a lifelong resident of this city of 50,000 midway between Columbus and Cleveland. Dr. John F. Boyle, a 47-year-old osteopath, is charged with aggravated murder and abuse of a corpse in the slaying of his wife, Noreen, 44. Police said Boyle suffocated her on New Year's Eve, buried her in the basement floor of a house he and his girlfriend had bought near Erie, Pa., and sealed the grave with concrete. Common Pleas Judge James Henson told jurors Wednesday that he expected deliberations to begin today. Boyle could receive up to life in prison if convicted. In testimony this week, Boyle said that he planned to have his 11-year-old son and 3-year-old adopted daughter live with him in the house, and that he promised his son he would search for his missing mother. ``I told him I would try to find his mommy, and if there was any talking to the police to be done, I would do it,'' Boyle said. Her body was dug up Jan. 25 during a police search of the house. During 9{ hours of testimony, Boyle denied allegations he killed his wife so he could end costly divorce proceedings and move to Pennsylvania with his lover, Sherri Campbell of Mansfield. He said his relationship with his wife had been poor since their marriage in 1968. Mrs. Boyle knew of his affair with Ms. Campbell, who on Jan. 12 gave birth to a child he fathered, Boyle said. Ms. Campbell has since filed a paternity suit against Boyle, who has been in jail since Jan. 25. He testified that his wife left him on the morning of Dec. 31. He never reported her missing. She had left several times during their marriage but returned each time, he said. In testimony last week, Boyle's son said that early on Dec. 31, he heard his parents arguing, heard a scream and heard a thump ``like a body hitting a wall.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,106.19, down 206.56 points, or 0.64 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Court Ruling Should Boost Minority Broadcast Ownership
DOC.TEXT: A surprise Supreme Court decision upholding broadcast affirmative action rules should reinvigorate efforts to increase minority ownership of U.S. radio and TV stations, broadcasters say. Recent legal challenges to the Federal Communications Commission rules had put a damper on attempts to expand minority broadcast ownership, the broadcasters said following Wednesday's 5-4 ruling. James L. Winston, executive director of the National Association of Black-Owned Broadcasters, said the court's decision ``means the FCC's ability to help promote minority ownership can now go forward without fear of constitutional challenge.'' Winston said blacks own 182 radio stations and 17 television stations, compared with 30 radio stations and one TV station in 1978 when the rules first were adopted. The FCC said blacks now own 3.5 percent of broadcast stations. ``While this still ... is not at the level we would like to see, we are pleased that the ability of the FCC to utilize policies to increase ownership will be allowed to continue and expand,'' Winston said. FCC Chairman Alfred Sikes said he was ``pleased that the cloud of doubt that has surrounded the commission's implementation of these policies has been dispelled.'' Lois Wright, vice president of Inner City Broadcasting Corp. in New York City, said the rules had been working effectively and ``I think they'll work more effectively now. ``These (Supreme Court) decisions have a direct impact,'' she added. ``Once you they're sustained, you're likely to get more deals'' for would-be minority broadcasters. Wright said the FCC under Sikes appears to be a better friend to the affirmative action rules than the FCC during the Reagan administration. Andrew J. Schwartzman of the Media Access Project, a coalition of groups that had urged the court to uphold the FCC policies, said he was surprised by the decision. ``Scrape me off the floor. The Supreme Court has opened the door of opportunity for America's minorities,'' he said. The court's ruling covered two cases. In a case from Florida, the justices allowed the commission to give special, favorable consideration to Hispanic minorities in deciding who would win a license for an Orlando TV station. In the other case involving a Connecticut TV station, the court upheld the commission's distress-sale policy, which lets a broadcaster faced with the loss of his license sell to a minority-owned business at 75 percent of the station's market value. The ruling was a victory for a Hispanic-led company in Hartford. Schwartzman said the ruling also lets the FCC continue its policy of giving preferential treatment to women seeking broadcast licenses. Although the court did not address the issue of women's rights, FCC affirmative action policies treat women and minorities almost identically. The ruling removes a threat to other federal affirmative action programs, including those adopted by the transportation and defense departments and by the Small Business Administration. In its most important previous ruling on preferential minority treatment by the federal government, a more liberal high court in 1980 upheld a public works program that set aside a percentage of federal funds for minority contracts. But more recently the court has cut back on affirmative action. Last year the justices struck down a Richmond, Va., program that set aside a percentage of local public works contracts for minority-owned businesses. That ruling cast doubt on the validity of numerous similar plans of states and cities but had no bearing on federal programs. In Wednesday's ruling, Justice William J. Brennan wrote for the court that congressional approval of racial preferences shields such programs from the kind of challenge that could invalidate similar state and city plans. ``It is of overriding significance in these cases that the FCC's minority ownership programs have been specifically approved _ indeed mandated _ by Congress,'' he said. But Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said the decision undermines the nation's fundamental commitment to equal treatment for all Americans. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy said the ruling conjures up images of racial segregation. Also dissenting were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Antonin J. Scalia. Justices William Brennan, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun, Byron R. White and John Paul Stevens were the majority.

DOC.HEAD: Town's Cemetery Expands Fourfold To Accommodate Bodies
With PM-Iran-Quake
DOC.TEXT: The earthquake that devastated this town of 40,000 people has quadrupled the size of its main cemetery. Dozens of gravediggers in orange coveralls have buried between 5,000 and 6,000 victims in trench graves, an official at the cemetery said Wednesday. ``We are still pulling out bodies from the debris,'' said the official, who asked not to be identified. About two acres have been added to the half acre of cemetery in the past week. ``At first we had to bury some people in unmarked mass graves three deep because there were so many and it was so hot,'' said the cemetery supervisor. In the new graves, 5-inch-thick white stones are set on end to form a low wall down the middle of the trench. The victims are buried down each side of the trench about a foot apart. A refrigerator truck carrying 67 shrouded bodies in ice waited next to two 100-foot-long trenches for relatives to arrive for funerals. The official said it was difficult contacting the relatives and he was unsure how long it would be before the funerals took place. The latest victims were so badly injured in the quake that they died after being hospitalized in Qazvin, about an hour's drive to the southeast. Manjil is about 180 miles northwest of the capital Tehran. A worker sprayed disinfectant Wednesday from tanks on the back of a pickup truck over the most recent trenches, containing the graves of 70 people buried in the morning. Most of Manjil, one of the towns hardest hit when the quake struck one week ago, is piles of rubble. No building escaped damage. Ali Taromian, 18, stood grieving at the grave of 30 members of his family, with a row of whie bricks placed carefully in the dark red-brown earth along the outlines of the rectangular ditch underneath. Included in the family plot were Taromian's mother, father, sister and brother. Only one other brother, who was watching soccer on television with Taromian, survived. The other family members were asleep in their beds and were unable to react in time to escape the falling rubble. A few yards away in the cemetery, 63-year-old Satar Mochtari knelt and pounded his gray head on the graves of his three children and three grandchildren. He scrabbled at the earth to show how he had clawed at the rubble in his home to save his children the instant the quake stopped. But one-by-one he pulled his 3-, 6- and 9-year-olds out dead. His three other children and wife survived. The cemetery official was part of a group of authorities sent by the city of Tehran to supervise the cleanup because Manjil's own leadership was lost. City hall, which contained the mayor's residence, was destroyed, killing the mayor and his wife. Their children, ages 6 and 8, were rescued from the wreckage 26 hours after the quake, said the official. He said 95 people had been rescued by search teams, some of the survivors found by trained dogs brought in by teams from France and Italy. The wind roared from the town aross the cemetery Wednesday with such force it was difficult for visitors to walk into the blast. Manjil, in a mountain pass, is a natural wind tunnel for currents passing at an average of 60 mph between the Saudi desert and the Siberian steppes. Temporary stones have been set over the quake victims' graves, with the name written in Farsi on a white cloth tied around the stone. About 10 of the stones in the most recent ditches were marked simply ``unknown.'' A bunch of flowers lay on a neighboring grave, and nearby two brown porcelain birds were stuck into the ground above a child's grave, identified only as Ali.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel OKs New Controls on Cable Services
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee approved a bill to place new cost and competition standards on the cable television industry amid warnings that irritated viewers are watching to see what Congress will do about poor service and soaring prices. Rep. Jim Cooper, D-Tenn., noted Wednesday that cable TV is a consumer issue affecting 52 million viewers who are also voters. The message was not lost on the House Energy and Commerce telecommunications subcommittee as it approved, by voice vote, a bill designed to control prices for basic cable TV services and ensure competition. A Senate committee earlier this month gave near-unanimous approval to a similar measure. Rep. Matthew Rinaldo, R-N.J., who helped subcommittee Chairman Edward Markey, D-Mass., draft the compromise bill, predicted the measure would pass the House this year. He said he would urge President Bush to sign the bill, although Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher and Justice Department officials told the House they opposed the measure. Several subcommittee members promised to try to amend the bill later to allow telephone companies to compete with cable. Major floor fights are expected over that proposal in the House and Senate. Congress in 1984 deregulated the cable TV industry. But consumer complaints about poor service and high charges prompted introduction of bills to rein in an industry that Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, calls an unregulated monopoly. ``This is a very significant consumer victory,'' Gene Kimmelman, legislative director of the Consumer Federation of America, said of the House bill. If enacted, ``It will finally bring cable rates down to reasonable levels and promote competition ... most usefully in rural America.'' Kimmelman has maintained that cable subscribers are paying twice what they should in the absence of effective competition. The House bill, he said, ``could actually lead to rate rollbacks for the communities that have experienced extreme (rate) increases.'' The cable TV industry condemned the bill. ``We are very troubled by this bill,'' said James Mooney, president of the National Cable Television Association. ``We do not support it.'' Mooney said ``many important issues remain to be resolved'' when the bill goes to the full Energy and Commerce Committee. Provisions of the bill include requirements that: _Cable systems provide a ``basic tier'' of local broadcast and public TV channels, with the Federal Communications Commission to decide on maximum rates for this tier. Pay channels such as Home Box Office would not be regulated. _The FCC develop criteria to identify ``unreasonable or abusive rates'' for cable-owned programs such as MTV and CNN. The Senate bill would allow FCC scrutiny only if a rate increase for these programs were challenged, and if the rates were found to be ``significantly excessive.'' _Programmers provide their signals for the backyard satellite dish industry and home satellite users. _The FCC study whether to limit the number of cable systems one company may own or limit cable operator ownership of programming.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Thinning of Arctic Ice
DOC.TEXT: About 55 cubic miles of ice disappeared from a Nevada-size section of the Arctic over 11 years, suggesting scientists should study the Arctic more closely for signs of global warming, a researcher reported today. The 15 percent decline is large for an area where scientists had thought ice was consistently thick, said researcher Peter Wadhams. But it is impossible to know whether global warming played any role, he said. Wadhams, of the University of Cambridge in England, presented his Arctic ice study in today's issue of the British journal Nature. Scientists predict a gradual warming of the Earth from a buildup of gases such as carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. The gases trap solar energy like a greenhouse around the Earth. Such a warming could lead to hotter summers, altered rainfall patterns that could disrupt agriculture and flooding in coastal areas, scientists say. Using data from submarine-based studies in 1976 and 1987, Wadhams calculated changes within a 112,000-square-mile triangle north of Greenland. That is slightly larger than Nevada. Wadhams studied the thickness of the submerged portions of huge floating chunks of sea ice. That is a good indicator of total ice thickness. He found that average thickness dropped from 17.5 feet in 1976 to 14.9 feet in 1987, about a 15 percent decrease. Over the study area, that corresponds to a loss of nearly 55 cubic miles of ice, he said. The missing ice did not necessarily melt away. The main reason for the decrease, Wadhams suggested, may be that thick ice broke apart in the months before the 1987 reading. That would leave open water that would freeze into relatively thin ice. This would reduce the overall average thickness for the region he studied. Such a mechanism would have nothing to do with global warming, John Walsh, a University of Illinois meteorology professor, said in an interview. But other factors may have been at work too, he said. ``The jury's still out on this,'' Walsh said. Thinning of Arctic ice can be an early sign of global warming, Wadhams wrote. But it is impossible to tell whether global warming played any role in his findings, because he lacks data from between the two years he sampled or from years since 1987, he said. The findings show that scientists must do more extensive monitoring to determine if Arctic ice is getting thinner or whether changes like the one he found are simply natural variations, he said. A Nature editorial called the new results ``provocative'' and agreed that more studies will be needed to discern true trends in the ice thickness. ``No data published so far can provide a reliable indication of whether the sea ice of the Arctic Basin is thinning, thickening or remaining essentially constant,'' wrote Alfred McLaren and Roger Barry of the University of Colorado at Boulder and R.H. Bourke of the Naval Postgraduate School in Monterey, Calif. McLaren, in an interview, said he believes Wadhams' results were due to natural variations in weather. ``I think that's all we can say right now until we know more,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 10 a.m. EDT; time set by source
Consumer Group Compiles List of Disciplined Doctors
DOC.TEXT: A consumer advocacy group today released a nationwide compendium that identifies nearly 7,000 medical professionals who have been disciplined by state and federal agencies. The roster, two inches thick and titled ``6892 Questionable Doctors,'' lists actions taken against physicians, dentists, chiropractors and podiatrists in 40 states and the District of Columbia. ``If your doctor is among the 6,892 on this list, you ought at least to question the quality of his or her care. At the very minimum, you should find out why,'' Dr. Sidney Wolfe, director of the Public Citizen Health Research Group, said in a statement released with the compilation. Although the nation's system for protecting the public from incompetent physicians has ``vastly improved'' in the past 15 years, it is still inadequate, said the group, founded by consumer activist Ralph Nader. ``Gaps the size of the Grand Canyon may have shrunk to Texas arroyos (desert streambeds), but they still snake everywhere across the landscape,'' the group's report said. ``And those dangerous doctors who fall through the cracks continue to kill, maim, defraud and otherwise injure their unknowing patients.'' The state-by-state consumer guide contains the names of doctors who have been disciplined by state medical boards, Medicare or the federal Drug Enforcement Administration. Also, each state's section lists names of doctors who have addresses in that state and were disciplined by medical boards in other states. It also contains the reason for the action, where available. Public Citizen said its compendium is the first such nationwide roster available to the public. The federal government is preparing to open a National Practitioner Data Bank listing information on state disciplinary actions, malpractice payments and revocation of hospital privileges. However, Public Citizen has complained that this information will not be available to the public. It will be accessible primarily to hospitals, health maintenance organizations and government agencies. Public Citizen asked state medical boards and federal agencies for actions taken against doctors since 1985. Some states provided actions that went back even further, while others provided data for only the last year or two. Still others didn't provide any information at all. State medical boards in Alabama, Alaska, Colorado, Oklahoma and South Dakota ``adamantly refused'' to provide the requested data, Public Citizen said. Five other states _ Arizona, Arkansas, Maine, Mississippi and New Mexico _ were willing to provide at least some information, but for various reasons did not, Public Citizen said.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
