DOC.HEAD: California Still Debating its Place on Presidential Calendar
DOC.TEXT: Candidates plotting strategy for the 1992 presidential race shouldn't make plans quite yet to trade the snows of Iowa and New Hampshire for California sunshine. The nation's most populous state may not shift its presidential primary after all. Four months ago, California was on the brink of shaking up the presidential nomination system by making its primary one of the earliest in the country. A bill to move the presidential primary from early June to the first Tuesday in March had passed both houses of the Legislature in different forms. Some supporters were predicting that delegate-rich California would overshadow Iowa and New Hampshire and become the first major stop on the campaign trail for presidential hopefuls. ``If you're a candidate running for president do you want to be trudging around in the snow or do you want to be in California?'' asked Assemblyman Mike Roos, a Los Angeles Democrat. But the early primary bill has been languishing in a two-house conference committee since late February. The delay is blamed on a dispute over when the state should hold its primary for state and congressional candidates and by the press of other business. Senate President Pro Tem David Roberti, a Los Angeles Democrat, said the bill has bogged down partly because ``everybody is suspicious that the other side is trying to get a partisan advantage.'' He gives the legislation a 50-50 chance of becoming law. Most legislators agree that the state should hold an earlier presidential primary. The June primary is one of the latest in the nation, meaning that presidential nominations usually are wrapped up by the time Californians vote. California voters have not played a key role in a nomination battle since 1972, when George McGovern defeated Hubert Humphrey in California and went on to win the Democratic nomination. If the early primary had been in effect in 1988, Californians would have voted three weeks _ instead of four months _ after the New Hampshire primary, giving themselves a big voice in determining the Republican and Democratic nominees. Debate on the legislation has focused on whether the state and congressional primary should still be held on the same day as the presidential primary. Under the proposed legislation, the state would continue to hold one primary _ in March in presidential election years and in June in non-presidential years. Democratic leaders support that approach, saying that otherwise voter turnout would drop off for state and congressional races. But Senate Republican leader Ken Maddy said members of his caucus won't support a consolidated March primary. They fear that new legislative districts drawn to reflect the 1990 census might not be in place in time for March 1992, and the current legislative districts favor Democrats. Republican leaders want a March presidential primary and a state and congressional primary in September, saying that would reduce spending for legislative and congressional races. Aides to the bill's chief author, Democratic Assemblyman Jim Costa, say the conference committee may not meet on the dispute until August. Democrats control both houses of the Legislature and could pass the legislation by themselves. But without substantial GOP support they could face a veto by Republican Gov. George Deukmejian that they couldn't override. ``The governor has his signature and I don't think the governor would do something that's opposed by a significant number of Republicans,'' Roberti said.

DOC.HEAD: FHA Borrowers Would Need More Money Up Front
DOC.TEXT: First-time home buyers seeking federally backed mortgages would pay more money and need larger down payments, under legislation approved by the Senate. The bill also authorizes a $3 billion increase in government spending on housing programs next year. It was approved by a 96-1 vote Wednesday night with only Sen. William Roth, R-Del., objecting. The measure also would extend for two years the $124,875 ceiling on FHA-insured mortgages that Congress last year raised from $101,250 in most high-cost areas. Housing Secretary Jack Kemp joined Senate sponsors earlier Wednesday in announcing a bipartisan agreement on key elements of the bill, which represents the biggest revamping of federal housing policies since 1968. Senate Banking Committee Chairman Don Riegle, D-Mich., said the bill ``charts a way out of a decade-long slide that has left 2 million Americans homeless.'' ``In the 1980s ... two-thirds of the families poor enough to get federal help with housing got none at all,'' Riegle said. ``And, after 35 years of rising steadily, home ownership plummeted in each of the last 10 years.'' But private lenders vowed immediately to oppose the Senate changes in the Federal Housing Administration mortgage insurance program when the issue reaches the House floor after Congress' July 4 recess. ``The compromise effectively closes the door to home ownership for thousands of American families,'' said Warren Lasko, head of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. Home buyers with FHA-backed loans would have to have at least a 5 percent down payment and would be required to pay at least two-thirds of closing costs up front, without financing. Loans with low down payments, deemed most at risk to default, would be subject to an added annual fee. Under the compromise, according to lawmakers, the up front costs to a young family ``in a typical case'' buying their first home with an FHA-insured mortgage would rise from $3,500 to $4,400. Borrowers currently can finance all closing costs, sometimes resulting in loans greater than the value of the home, on FHA-backed mortgages. Lasko estimated that 75,000 to 150,000 first-time home buyers would be closed out of FHA-backed loans. He called the change ``the result of an overreaction to the savings and loan scandal.'' The FHA insurance program lost $4.2 billion to bad loans in 1988, and its net worth has declined from $8 billion to $2.6 billion over the past decade. Auditors have warned that without at least an annual 4 percent increase in housing values, the mortgage insurance fund could require a massive infusion of taxpayer funds to remain solvent, just like the savings and loan bailout. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., a principal sponsor of the housing bill, had opposed changing the FHA rules last week but agreed to them in exchange to the administration dropping its opposition to a $3 billion increase in federal spending on housing. As passed, the legislation would authorize $18.1 billion in spending in fiscal 1991, $19.5 billion in 1992 and $21 billion in 1993, compared with the $14.5 billion being spent this year. In exchange for the new funds, Kemp's so-called Homeownership Opportunity for People Everywhere program, to encourage tenant purchase of public housing units, would get $1.9 billion over the next three years. Kemp said the administration supported the greater spending, despite budget constraints that prompted Bush a day earlier to swallow his no-tax-increase pledge. But he noted the final amount will depend on budget talks. Under the agreement, Senate Democrats also get their Housing Opportunity Program, which consolidates 10 existing housing programs funneling federal dollars to local governments for renovating or building housing. Democrats agreed to allow part of that money to be spent on vouchers for the poor to use for rental housing, despite the Senate's rejection of a similar amendment last week.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Debate Splits Senate on Regional Lines
DOC.TEXT: The issue of who pays for the savings and loan bailout is dividing Congress along regional lines. As the high price tag hits home, Northeastern lawmakers who have already agreed to the bailout are voicing resentment that so much of their constituents' money is flowing to the Sun Belt. That resentment is threatening to spill over into other spending issues from housing to water projects to farm programs. The first winds of this regional storm swept over the Senate on Wednesday as legislators from the Northeast and Midwest angrily challenged a move by Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, to shift federal housing grants to the populous Sun Belt states. Gramm's bid fizzled, but not before senators exchanged heated words for more than two hours on the Senate floor. ``This amendment has the possibilities of creating enormous regional animosities, of tearing us apart at a time when we need to be coming together,'' said Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass. By turning the S&L issue into a regional fight, the debate was significant in that it cut across party lines. Pundits and politicians have been predicting that the thrift crisis would become a major campaign issue, but the floor debate had members of both parties line up on opposite sides. Kerry said Gramm's proposal reflected an insatiable appetite for federal tax dollars. The bailout was a disaster with many villains, Kerry said, and it was a necessary solution. ``We're willing to do that. It's been done. We accept it,'' he said of the bailout. ``But apparently it isn't enough.'' Kerry spoke ominously of a farm bill about to come to the Senate floor. The bill ``with goodies galore'' for Western and Southern farm states, may have trouble getting through the Senate, he warned. If Gramm and others move to tilt other federal programs in favor of the Sunbelt, Kerry said, ``the repercussions are going to play out as we debate the farm bill.'' Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., got into the fray by threatening to block a water resources development bill which contains a substantial amount of money for Texas. Moynihan chairs a Senate subcommittee that is handling the bill. And Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., challenged Gramm by offering his own amendment to the housing legislation. D'Amato's proposal would have required Texas and other states with high S&L failure rates to give up housing money in proportion to the bailout dollars they were receiving. D'Amato argued that lax state regulations in Texas led to the S&L slide. New York taxpayers, meanwhile, were being asked to pay for a sizable portion of the bailout. ``The state of New York is on the hook for $17.3 billion to clean up a problem that its citizens did not cause and who will receive no benefit from its solution,'' D'Amato said. Gramm shot back that the S&L bailout money wasn't being poured into the coffers of the state of Texas or the bank accounts of its citizens. Rather, he said, it was paying back insured depositors, many of them high-roller investors from the Northeast. He called the idea of using ``trumped-up amendments based on the S&L bailout'' a ``cute and clever'' tactic. ``To in any way equate the S&L bailout with a formula for allocating community development block grant funds, a formula that in its current incarnation is absolutely unfair, is just outrageous,'' Gramm said. ``I'm not trying to beat a regional horse here.'' D'Amato admitted that his amendment was more of a symbolic gesture than a serious effort at legislation. But he said it reflected genuine anger.

DOC.HEAD: News Reading _ and Watching _ Hit New Lows Among the Young, Study Finds
DOC.TEXT: Americans under age 30 know less about what's going on in the country and the world than any other generation in the past 50 years, according to a study of how people keep up with the news. It found that Americans aged 18-30 are less likely than earlier generations to have read a newspaper or watched a television news show. Twenty-five years ago, 67 percent of people under age 35 said ``yes'' when asked if they had ``read a newspaper yesterday.'' Now only 24 percent say ``yes.'' Television news-watching has dropped, too. Young people who said they watched the TV news ``yesterday'' fell from 52 percent in 1965 to 41 percent this year. The study said that from 1941 to 1975, young Americans were on a par with their elders in public knowledge and in following most major news events closely. But since 1975, young people have been less attentive and the trend is accelerating, it said. ``The Information Age has spawned ... an uninformed and uninvolved population,'' concludes the study. It was conducted by the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press, sponsored by the company which publishes the Los Angeles Times. The center's own polls and those of four other polling organizations taken over the years were analyzed.
DOC.HEAD: Administration Official Says WIC Not an Emergency
DOC.TEXT: A money shortage that could force 240,000 low-income women and children out of a government nutrition program is not an emergency, an administration official says. Meanwhile, a bill that will help states get more money for the supplemental food program for women, infants and children, or WIC, was moving quickly through the House. The House education and labor committee approved a measure by Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, to let states borrow a greater amount of next year's WIC appropriation to cover current shortages. Hall introduced the bill Monday and a vote on the House floor could occur Thursday, officials said. House members criticized the Department of Agriculture, which administers WIC, for not seeking more money for the program, which has been battered in at least 20 states by food price increases and rebate reductions. ``It's an absolute outrage,'' said Rep. John Bryant, D-Texas. ``Why isn't the administration up here urging an emergency supplemental appropriations bill?'' ``This program faces a dire crisis,'' said Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., who chaired a hearing on WIC by the House budget committee's task force on human resources. Betty Jo Nelsen, administrator of the USDA's Food and Nutrition Service, said $11 million was being reallocated this week to make up for spending or budget shortfalls in some states. ``It will clearly not be enough,'' Ms. Nelsen said. But, when pressed by task force members, she refused to call the funding shortage an emergency. ``I would characterize it as a very difficult situation,'' Ms. Nelsen said. ``I would save severe crisis or emergency for when we can't serve women and children with medically related nutritional risks.''
DOC.HEAD: Company Recalls Blood Pressure Drug
DOC.TEXT: A New York drug company is recalling a generic drug used to treat high blood pressure after the Food and Drug Administration alleged the company submitted false information to the agency. Interpharm Inc. of Plainview, N.Y., agreed Wednesday to recall all three strengths of clonidine hydrochloride tablets from distributors and pharmacies and to conduct an audit of its 24 other products, the FDA said. The drug comes in small, round, blue tablets marked ``IP 47.'' Routine testing by the FDA found that ``samples of clonidine hydrochloride 0.3 milligram tablets submitted for bioequivalence testing by Interpharm were not the same as the product on the market,'' the agency said. The tablets Interpharm was marketing were blue, and in its application for approval the company told the FDA its tablets were blue. But the pills that were tested for bioequivalence before the drug was approved were peach-colored, the FDA said. The agency said it found no manufacturing or production data that indicated the company had ever made any peach-colored pills. The FDA said it had no evidence of a safety problem with the drug Interpharm was marketing, but questions whether the product is therapeutically equivalent to the brand name drug, Catapres, made by Boehringer Ingelheim. FDA officials advised patients who use the product to consult with their physician about switching to another product.
DOC.HEAD: Abortions Getting Harder to Find in Rural Areas, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Abortion services are getting harder to find in rural parts of the country and in some areas women have to travel hundreds of miles to a provider, a report by the Alan Guttmacher Institute said Wednesday. Nearly all of the nearly 1.6 million abortions performed in 1988 were performed in metropolitan areas. About 1.7 percent _ a total of 27,000 _ took place in rural areas, according to the survey by the independent, non-profit research group. In 1979, when 1.5 million abortions were performed in this country, about 4.5 percent of them, around 67,000, were in rural facilities. As the concentration of abortion services has continued to shift from hospitals to specialized clinics, women in rural areas have been hit hardest. Those women usually have had to rely on hospitals for abortion services, since small clinics often are not economical in rural areas, the report said. ``Our findings clearly show that access to abortion, which was already a tremendous problem for women living outside of the metropolitan areas of our country, is getting worse, even without additional state restrictions that may result from any new legislative activity,'' Stanley Henshaw, author of the report, said in a statement released with it.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Southern California Fires Destroy Hundreds of Homes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES bulletin series; minor editing.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LA12, STB1
DOC.TEXT: Wind-whipped wildfires, some caused by arson, destroyed more than 300 homes Wednesday in Southern California, officials said. One blaze destroyed 280 homes in Santa Barbara and Goleta alone, said Jan Bullard, spokesman for the Santa Barbara County Sheriff's Department. ``The fire is incredible. It came down from the mountains. It spread everywhere. It burned everything in its path,'' said another sheriff's spokesman, Tim Grasey. Fires burned dozens more homes in the hilly Los Angeles suburb of Glendale and in El Cerrito in Riverside County, authorities said. The Santa Barbara County fire was labeled arson. An unidentified incendiary device was found at the point where the fire started, officials said. The fire closed southbound lanes of Highway 101, a principal north-south California route, and burned a train trestle, forcing a Santa Barbara-to-San Diego Amtrak train to be held in Oxnard. It also burned a Sheriff's Department honor farm, set a fire station ablaze and forced evacuation of the jail. The blaze burned in the region where former President Reagan maintains his ranch, but it was not immediately known if the flames threatened the property. ``I've never seen anything like it,'' said Brenda Rein, who watched from a shopping mall as fire marched down a mountain. ``The whole sky was just orange. I looked up and saw the moon through the smoke, kind of a werewolf moon.'' The fire hit an area ravaged by a four-year drought, with water reserves at their lowest in memory. The fire near El Cerrito, about 60 miles east of Los Angeles, destroyed 15 homes, said California Department of Forestry spokeswoman Jeaneen Gardner. She said no more homes were believed threatened. The blaze there began when a U.S. Forest Service ``control burn'' to clear brush raged out of control, she said. Fire destroyed or damaged 32 homes in Glendale, Fire Battalion Chief Chris Gray said. More than a dozen of the $300,000-$700,000 houses burned to their foundations. Arson was suspected in the Glendale fire, Gray said. ``At this time, we have found a point of origin and a butane lighter,'' Gray said. He said a pin had been inserted in the lighter to keep it burning. ``That alone signals arson.'' About 1,000 students and teachers were evacuated from Glendale Community College in the middle of classes Wednesday as flames moved within yards of the campus. An arson blaze in Orange County, south of Los Angeles, spread over 1,500 acres to the San Bernardino County community of Sleepy Hollow. Three homes were engulfed and 2,000 residents were evacuated, forestry officials said. Peter Reyes, 29, was arrested for investigation of arson, said Maria Sabol, a fire department spokeswoman. A 125-acre fire near Hemet, in Riverside County, east of Los Angeles, injured 17 firefighters. In the Moreno Valley area, fire destroyed three homes. Smaller brush fires burned in San Diego and Ventura counties and in Cleveland National Forest in Riverside County. Fires were not the only problem, as the region coped with blistering heat. Utilities from the coast inland to Las Vegas asked the public to reduce electricity consumption. The mercury soared to 109 in downtown Los Angeles, seven degrees over the old 1976 mark for June 27. Tuesday's 112-degree mark was an all-time high, topping the old 110-degree record set Sept. 4, 1988. Temperatures topped 100 in valleys north and east of Los Angeles. Palm Springs hit 116 by early afternoon. San Diego was a record 91. Santa Barbara tied its record of 109. Heat began building in the region at the end of last week and soon erupted into a full-blown heat wave. Heat apparently killed a 4-year-old Los Angeles boy who got into an abandoned car in the San Fernando Valley on Tuesday. The heat wave was spawned by an enormous, upper-level, high pressure over New Mexico that beat back the normal cooling influence of the Pacific. ``I liken it to a huge umbrella sitting over the Southwest and it's just baking under there, but it's not quite reaching San Francisco,'' said National Weather Service meteorologist Art Lessard.

DOC.HEAD: Top Contras Hand Over Guns; End of Nicaragua's Civil War is Proclaimed
DOC.TEXT: After nine years of civil war that claimed about 30,000 lives, Nicaragua is finally at peace. ``I feel proud and happy as a Nicaraguan woman and mother because the boys have turned over their arms so Nicaragua can live in peace,'' President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro said Wednesday after a ceremony in which top Contra rebel leaders gave up their weapons. ``We're going to disarm everyone peacefully, without hate and without resentment,'' she said. During the ceremony formally ending the war, about 100 rebel commanders turned over surface-to-air missiles and automatic rifles to international observers from the United Nations and Organization of American States. The international force destroyed the Contra weapons with blowtorches on the spot in San Pedro de Lovago, about 100 miles east of Managua, the capital. The town is in the heart of the security zones established for the disarmament and voluntary resettlement of the Contras. ``Today the war ends,'' presidential spokesman Danilo Lacayo said. Shortly after the ceremony, 14 people, most of them journalists, were seriously injured when two helicopters carrying them back to Managua collided during takeoff. The Contra commanders were led by Israel Galeano, who had turned over a first batch of weapons, including 62 U.S.-made Red Eye missiles, to the head of the U.N.-OAS force, Gen. Agustin Quesada. ``We hope this signifies that peace will endure in Nicaragua,'' Galeano told the Spanish general. ``It is an honor to say to the Nicaraguan people: `Mission accomplished.' The struggle has been to establish a government of laws in this country,'' Galeano said, handing over his own rifle. The Contras, who were trained and supported by the United States, claim credit for forcing the former Sandinista government to call the Feb. 25 election that Mrs. Chamorro won. After losing the election, the Sandinistas allegedly distributed tens of thousands of automatic weapons to civilian supporters, urging them to ``defend the conquests'' of the Sandinista revolution. Mrs. Chamorro pledged during Wednesday's ceremony to ask local officials nationwide to ``tell me in writing'' where Sandinista arms caches are hidden. The Contras had cited the arming of the civilian population of this nation of 3.6 million people when they missed several previous deadlines to disarm. They finally began turning in their weapons on May 8, two weeks after the Sandinistas handed over power to Mrs. Chamorro. U.N. officials now say that only about 1,000 members of the once 18,000-strong rebel force still have their guns. He gave up the first batch of missiles on Tuesday in the town of El Amendro, 190 miles southeast of Managua in Rio San Juan Province, where the Contras have been promised land on which to settle. He said the United States had given the Contras more than 100 of the Red Eye missiles in the last four years of the war. He claimed the rebels had downed 35 government aircraft with them. The war, which was accompanied by harsh U.S. economic sanctions that helped bring the Nicaraguan economy to a virtual standstill, is seen as the key factor behind Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega's stunning electoral loss. Although a cease-fire has been in place since early 1988, sporadic combat _ and the hated military draft _ continued along with U.S. economic pressure. Washington lifted the sanctions after Mrs. Chamorro's victory and sent Nicaragua $300 million in badly needed foreign aid. Mrs. Chamorro abolished the draft on April 25, the day she took office. She later announced plans to reduce to army to half its current strength of more than 90,000. Nicaragua had amassed Central America's largest armed force with huge infusions of aid from the Soviet Union and its allies.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The fire is incredible. It came down from the mountains. It spread everywhere. It burned everything in its path.'' _ Santa Barbara County sheriff's spokesman Tim Grasey, on wildfires that destroyed hundreds of homes.

``The Information Age has spawned ... an uninformed and uninvolved population.'' _ A study that concluded Americans under age 30 know less about what's going on in the country and the world than any other generation in the past 50 years.

``If you go to some of the provinces in the south, leaving by boat is part of life there. ... People get arrested every day for trying to leave. There are some people who have tried 10 to 15 times.'' _ Kai Nielsen, representative of the U.N. High Commissioner For Refugees in Ho Chi Minh City, on the plight of the Vietamese boat people.

DOC.BYLINE: Legislative Chief's Convoy Attacked ^By DOUGLAS GRANT MINE
DOC.TEXT: The National Assembly's president says one of his police escorts was hit by gunfire in an attack he blamed on leftist rebels, who have recently promised not to attack civilian officials. The rightist politician, Ricardo Alvarenga, said no one was injured. There was no immediate rebel comment on the reported attack Wednesday night. Alvarenga told a news conference he was driving his pickup truck home from the legislature when the police car traveling in front of him was struck by several bullets. He said he accelerated to escape. The lawmaker, a member of the governing Republican National Alliance (ARENA), said another vehicle following his and carrying bodyguards was also struck by gunfire. Alvarenga blamed the attack on the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, which has for 10 years fought a succession of U.S.-backed governments. The rebels, who are discussing peace with government representatives in monthly meetings, said in a communique earlier this year they would refrain from attacking civilian government officials. On Wednesday, a judge issued an arrest warrant for an army officer accused of destroying evidence in the November massacre of six Jesuit priests, their cook and her teen-age daughter. The government is under pressure from the rebels to resolve the Jesuit case. The rebels demanded army officers be made accountable for rights abuses at the latest round of peace talks that ended this week in Mexico. The warrant was issued after widespread criticism of the investigation into the massacre by a U.S. congressional committee and leaders of El Salvador's Roman Catholic Church. The charges accuse Lt. Col. Carlos Camilo Hernandez of destroying the mission logs of troops accused in the shootings at Central American University. Hernandez, an executive officer of the elite Belloso Battalion in San Salvador, is the former assistant director of the military college where the troops were stationed. The warrant was issued by Judge Ricardo Zamora, who is handling the politically charged investigation. It asks military officials to arrest Hernandez and hand him over to the civilian court for prosecution. Neither the armed forces press office nor the U.S. Embassy would comment on the latest development in the Jesuit case. Defense attorney Joaquin Barahona said the judge based his warrant on the testimony of several witnesses as well as statements by Hernandez himself. Hernandez is the 10th person charged in the case. The director of the military college, Col. Guillermo Benavides; three lieutenants; and five enlisted men have been charged with the slayings. No Salvadoran officer has ever been prosecuted for a human rights crime, despite the deaths of tens of thousands of people at the hands of death squads linked to the armed forces or President Alfredo Cristiani's ARENA party. To date, the only evidence presented against Benavides has been that of other defendants, which is not admissible in Salvadoran courts. However, a key military witness appeared before the judge Wednesday in a closed hearing. Col. Carlos Armando Aviles, who reportedly blew the case open by telling a U.S. military adviser who was responsible for the slayings, arrived Wednesday in El Salvador from Taiwan, where he had been sent for ``military training'' after the Jesuit massacre. ``Aviles is a key witness,'' a defense lawyer, requesting anonymity, told The Associated Press. ``If he testifies to what he has said unofficially, it will be overwhelming evidence against the defendants.'' Asked about the latest developments in the Jesuit case at a news conference Wednesday, Cristiani would only comment: ``If the judge thinks he has proof he should proceed according to the law.'' The massacre took place during a huge offensive by leftist rebels. Army positions at the college had come under fire several times. The six priests and educators, their housekeeper and her 15-year-old daughter were roused from their sleep before dawn Nov. 16 and killed by troops of the elite Atlacatl infantry battalion. Two of three lieutenants leading the death squad said Benavides issued an order to kill the priests. The investigation has moved slowly and there have been reports that crucial evidence has been destroyed, that military witnesses have been given assignments abroad to keep them from testifying, and that the true masterminds of the slayings were being protected. The far-right considered the left-leaning Jesuit academics subversive because they blamed social injustice, rather than international communist expansion, for El Salvador's revolution. The murders provoked an international outcry and calls from some quarters in the U.S. Congress for sharp cuts in aid to El Salvador, the largest recipient of U.S. aid in the hemisphere.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Dip In Tokyo, Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index retreated moderately today after a sharp climb the previous day, and the dollar edged up against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average fell 206.56 points, or 0.64 percent, closing at 32,106.19. The index fell quickly in the morning as market players turned cautious after Wednesday's 740.98-point gain, traders said. At the end of morning trading, it was down 258.52 points. It rebounded somewhat in the afternoon as investors bought electric issues that have been performing well this year, said Masahiro Umemori, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. Trading was thin, with first section volume estimated at 450 million shares, down from Wednesday's 600 million. The dollar closed at 154.42 yen, up 0.07 yen from Wednesday's 154.35-yen finish. It opened at 154.57 yen and ranged between 154.27 yen and 154.63 yen. Dealers said dollars were being sold above 154.60 yen and bought at around 154.20 yen in technical position adjustments. ``Trading lacked direction in the absence of market-affecting news,'' said Koichiro Amaya, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. The dollar opened higher following dollar-buying in the Sydney market, which opened earlier than Tokyo's. But the currency weakened toward the end of morning trading. Dealers said participants adjusted positions before a series of important political and economic events scheduled next week. Among them are German monetary unification, the U.S. Federal Reserve Board's open market committee meeting and the Soviet Communist Party congress. About $7.07 billion changed hands in spot trading, down from Wednesday's $12.16 billion. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was down to 86.75 points at 5 p.m. from Wednesday's close of 87.05. The yield stood at 7.240 percent, up from the previous day's 7.175 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Fundamentalists Suspected In Acid Attack on Journalist
DOC.TEXT: A journalist who covers the war in Afghanistan for a Western news agency was in critical condition today after being attacked with acid, officials said. Moslem fundamentalists were blamed by a newspaper which employs the journalist, Mansoor Khan, 25. Khan, Peshawar correspondent for the English-language newspaper The Democrat, suffered burns over more than half his body and could lose sight in one eye, doctors and newspaper executives said. Khan, who also works for the British-based Reuters news agency, was attacked by two masked men who broke into his house early Wednesday in western Peshawar, police said. They beat him up, then threw acid on him, police said. No one claimed responsibility for the attack. Khan has been reporting on the mujahedeen guerrillas' 12-year-old struggle to overthrow the Soviet-backed government of Afghanistan. His accounts at times have been critical of the insurgents. In a stinging front-page editorial today, the Democrat accused fundamentalists of trying to kill Khan. ``When politics come to be infested by fanatics and fundamentalists of the sort we encounter in our life today, journalists who stand by their principles invite the ire of the extremists,'' the editorial said. Moslem fundamentalists have been blamed for a number of attacks and threats against foreigners living in Peshawar, as well as Afghans working for Western relief organizations. A radical organization called the International Jihad Organization has been blamed for threats against several aid groups. It also has been blamed for the June 16 attempted murder of the director of the Australian-based Shelter Now International and a death threat against the director of the U.S.-based International Rescue Committee. Both are Americans and have left the country. Little is known about the group. It is believed to be linked to Hezb-i-Islami, or Party of God, the most anti-West of the seven Afghan resistance parties based in Peshawar. As Washington and Moscow move closer to a political settlement of the war, diplomatic sources say, many Afghans have launched an anti-West campaign to counter what they see as a U.S. attempt to push the fundamentalists to the sidelines.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps Pullout Shows Vulnerability Of Americans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with farewell ceremony. Picks up 4th pvs, `American officials...'
DOC.TEXT: The withdrawal of Peace Corps volunteers highlights the vulnerability of the estimated 140,000 Americans in this country as they become steadily drawn into its 21-year-old Communist insurgency. U.S. officials announced Wednesday that they were suspending Peace Corps operations in the Philippines and sending the 261 volunteers home because of intelligence reports that Communist rebels planned to kill or kidnap them. Volunteers were to begin leaving by commercial flights after President Corazon Aquino invited them to an emotional farewell ceremony at the Malacanang presidential palace. Many in the group wept as volunteer Kim Rylander of Denison, Texas, told the president she regretted leaving the Philippines ``because I left my heart here.'' Mrs. Aquino promised the volunteers to investigate the threats against the Peace Corps, which has assigned volunteers to the Philippines for nearly 29 years. She said she hoped Washington ``will reassess the situation'' and allow volunteers to return. American officials refuse to elaborate on the reported rebel threat. But the decision to evacuate volunteers shows that U.S. diplomats take it seriously. That represents a dramatic shift in U.S. perceptions of American vulnerability in the Marxist insurgency. For years, it had been widely assumed that Americans were somehow invulnerable to systematic rebel attack. But since April 1989, eight Americans, including six affiliated with the U.S. military, are believed to have been slain by the New People's Army, the armed wing of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines. Last month, the rebels claimed responsibility for killing two American airmen outside the U.S.-run Clark Air Base and vowed more assassinations until all U.S. troops leave the country. In reaction, the U.S. military scaled down an exercise, restricted movement of its personnel and even offered to ship soldiers' families back home free of charge. The actions were all in reaction to the rebel threat. A senior American official, speaking on condition of anonymity, insisted that the decision to suspend Peace Corps operations did not mean the rebels were gaining strength or that Washington was losing confidence in Mrs. Aquino. Instead, the official said the rebels were resorting to terrorism because the Armed Forces of the Philippines was slowly winning the war. The American official said recent security precautions had prevented the rebels from killing senior U.S. diplomats or military officers and that the guerrillas are now aiming to hit ``soft targets,'' such as Peace Corps volunteers. The official said it was better to remove the volunteers based on a single intelligence report rather than risk having a single volunteer killed or kidnapped. But if that be the case, how will the United States respond if the New People's Army further expands its target list to include American businessmen and other civilians? According to the U.S. Embassy, there are up to 140,000 Americans in the Philippines, including about 40,000 affiliated with the military. Protecting all of them is impossible. U.S. officials acknowledge that the rebels are targeting U.S. government employees and troops but insist there is no sign that civilians are at risk. Last week, however, Philippine military sources said captured rebel documents indicate the guerrillas plan to step up attacks on foreigners in the next six months. The first Americans slain in the insurgency were three naval officers killed in a 1974 ambush near the Subic Bay naval base. After that, rebels avoided targeting Americans for more than 12 years, though many of the villages around the sprawling U.S.-run Clark Air Base are longtime New People's Army strongholds. That changed in October 1987, when rebels killed three Americans in coordinated attacks outside Clark, 50 miles north of Manila. U.S. officials believe the attacks were ordered after American ambulances evacuated Philippine soldiers wounded in a rebel ambush. In April 1989, rebels killed U.S. Army Col. James ``Nick'' Rowe in an ambush in suburban Quezon City. Since then, seven other Americans are believed to have been slain by the rebels. By all signs, the rebels have steadily become less selective in their targets. In public statements, the rebels claim American civilians are not at risk if they avoid involvement in the government's counterinsurgency. Rebel sources say they are after ``quality targets,'' such as senior diplomats and military officers. But except for Rowe, all Americans slain by the rebels since 1987 were either military enlisted men or civilians without important posts. The two airmen killed last month were on temporary duty in the Philippines and apparently picked for assassination at random. Last month, the State Department cautioned Americans to be careful traveling in the Philippines. But they have not been told to stay away or leave. The U.S. official insisted that Americans were safe in Manila and major tourist destinations if they exercise routine precautions. But within the past month, the guerrillas have killed several Filipino soldiers, including a colonel, in broad daylight on major streets in the capital.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Policemen, Judge Murdered; Car Bomb Deactivated
DOC.TEXT: Assassins hired by drug bosses are being blamed in the killings of another seven policemen, and authorities say a judge who handled drug trafficking cases has also been shot to death. Three of the policemen shot to death Wednesday were killed on the streets of the northwestern city of Medellin, headquarters of the world's largest cocaine gang, a spokesman with the city police department said by telephone. The other four policemen were killed in the town of Dorada, about 75 miles north of the capital of Bogota. They were in a patrol car when gunmen in a passing car opened fire with submachine guns and pistols, police said in a news release carried by the radio network Caracol. The Medellin cartel has unleashed a bloodbath against Colombian policemen, especially in Medellin. Including Wednesday's deaths, 132 policemen have been killed in the city this year. The cartel has said it will pay about $4,300 for each policeman killed in Colombia. Drug traffickers and government security forces have been locked in a deadly war since the slaying last August of a presidential candidate who advocated extradition of drug suspects to the United States. Also Wednesday, police in Medellin deactivated a car bomb comprised of 1,000 pounds of dynamite, the police spokesman said. The dynamite was in a taxi and was armed with a fuse and detonators, the policeman said. The taxi was in a parking lot only about a half-block from the city government's administrative office building. It was the second car bomb deactivated in Medellin in a week. The judge who was killed, 29-year-old Samuel Alfonso Rodriguez, was driving a car accompanied by his wife when he was shot to death in the northeastern city of Bucaramanga, police said in a communique broadcast by the RCN radio network. He was the fifth judge killed since the government crackdown on drug traffickers began on Aug. 18. In the last 10 months, the traffickers have responded to the crackdown with 283 terrorist acts, including one that brought down a domestic airliner, that have killed 274 people.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Pill Finds Ally in Doctors' Group
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, `In a ...' to CORRECT to Wednesday sted Tuesday.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Abortion Impact, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The controversial French abortion pill has won backing from the American Medical Association, the nation's largest doctors' association. In a voice vote Wednesday, the AMA's 436-member policy-making House of Delegates endorsed testing and possible use of the RU-486 abortion pill. ``The abortion issue, pro and con, should not interfere with our ability to conduct all kinds of investigations for all kinds of problems,'' said Dr. Charles Sherman, chairman of the AMA committee that recommended support for the pill. The pill is not available in the United States, and no U.S. companies have applied for Food and Drug Administration approval to market it in this country because, doctors say, they fear running afoul of the anti-abortion movement. Some doctors in the AMA, whose 290,000 members account for about 45 percent of the nation's physicians, said the pill appears safer and cheaper than surgical abortion and may be useful in treating brain tumors, breast cancer and other illnesses. A leading abortion opponent attacked the AMA action. ``I think it is outrageous for doctors to be thinking up better ways for killing their little patients,'' John Willke, president of National Right to Life, said in a telephone interview from his Washington office. Some doctors taking part in AMA's annual policy-making session this week also said they feared the pill being distributed on the black market. The director of the Reproductive Health Technologies Project, a coalition of abortion rights, family planning and women's health groups, welcomed the AMA move. ``It's extremely important that the AMA, representing the mainstream medical community in the country, has spoken out,'' Marie Bass said from Washington. The drug causes the uterus to shed its lining, as occurs in menstruation, and expel a fertilized egg. RU-486, or mifepristone, was developed in 1980 by the French pharmaceutical company Roussel Uclaf and approved for use there in September 1988. The following month, Roussel Uclaf pulled RU-486 off the market because anti-abortion advocates boycotted the company's products. Two days later, the French government, a minority owner of the company, ordered it to resume marketing. Since then, the anti-abortion movement has inhibited the company from distributing the drug for testing outside of France, doctors said. They said their action was an attempt to counter that. AMA doctors said RU-486 might be effective in treating meningiomas, which are types of brain tumors, breast cancer, gynecological malignancies, and Cushings Syndrome, which can induce high blood pressure, obesity and diabetes. In other business at the AMA convention, the House of Delegates on approved a model plan for mandatory employer-covered health insurance. The package would cost an average of $1,700 a year per employee, against the current national average of $2,300 to $2,600. The AMA also rejected a proposal to censor editorials in the Journal of the American Medical Association. The Illinois State Medical Society, angered by several editorials critical of doctors, had suggested a panel review such material. The association also inaugurated C. John Tupper, elected last year, as its new president. Tupper, an internist from Davis, Calif., succeeds Alan R. Nelson of Salt Lake City.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Hungarian Communists Said To Harbor Infamous Terrorist `Carlos'
DOC.TEXT: A decade ago, Communist leaders harbored the elusive international terrorist ``Carlos'', who masterminded deadly attacks in Western Europe and is still at large, the new government says. Interior Minister Balasz Horvath said Wednesday that after incriminating documents were found he ordered an investigation into the former Communist regime's having provided terrorists with safe haven. Three former Communist officials named by Horvath _ former Interior Minister Andras Benkei, former President Karoly Nemeth and high-ranking party official Antal Gyenes _ have denied any knowledge of or role in sheltering terrorists. Horvath said that chief among the terrorists was Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, alias Carlos, who masterminded a 1975 attack on an OPEC meeting in Vienna that killed three people and 1984 bombings in Marseille, France, that killed five. The development follows arrests this month in East Germany of leftist terrorist suspects who officials say were given new identities and allowed to live there while the Communists were in power. Unlike other Eastern European countries where Communists were removed from power, in Hungary no Communist leader has been arrested or charged in connection with activities during 45 years of Communist rule, which ended with free elections in April. Horvath said it was ``obviously a political decision to let these people (terrorists) come and stay in Hungary. ``It remains to be proved that they were undergoing training here, but the inventory seems to point in a certain direction,'' he told reporters. He did not elaborate. Horvath said the deputy national police chief, Andras Turos, came to him with the information over the weekend. He said the government documents included a 1979 Interior Ministry report on the arrival of Carlos and his group and a 1980 ministry report saying the terrorists had left behind explosives, guns, rockets and rocket launchers. Horvath said it is not known where the group obtained these items. He said a 1980 letter from Carlos to former longtime Communist Party leader Janos Kadar thanked Kadar for allowing the group to use Hungary as a base. Kadar stepped down in May 1988 and was replaced by Communist reformer Karoly Grosz. Benkei, the ex-interior minister, was quoted by the Nepszabadsag newspaper on Wednesday as saying, ``This must be a misunderstanding. I did not deal with such matters. I retired in 1980. Hiding people? Nonsense. Lies.'' Nepszabadsag, a former Communist Party paper, reported that Carlos and his associates were indeed in Hungary in those years. Citing a ``well-informed'' but unnamed source, the paper stated that ``a very small circle of leaders knew about the authorization, and their stay was ... (safeguarded by) state security organs. ``According to the information we have, their stay was not linked to any terrorist action, but was to provide the terrorists rest and recreation,'' Nepszabadsag reported. Another Budapest daily, Magyar Hirlap, said Wednesday that there had been a terrorist training camp at Csopak, on the northern shore of Lake Balaton, but provided no further information. Horvath told reporters that there has been no evidence uncovered so far that Carlos and his group were in Csopak. Carlos, a Venezuelan sometimes called ``The Jackal,'' headed Interpol's most-wanted list in 1975. The son of a wealthy Communist lawyer, Carlos has been linked with a bombing Dec. 31, 1984, in Marseille that killed five people and wounded 41. He is also accused of plotting the 1975 hijacking of an Air France jetliner to Uganda that ended with the Israeli commando raid at Entebbe airport, and the kidnapping of 11 OPEC oil ministers in Vienna in which three people were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Heat Wave Continues in Southwest
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures were in the 90s early today in the sweltering desert Southwest, where a heat wave lingered for a fourth day. Most of the nation enjoyed fair weather early today, but rain fell in southern Florida and the coastal Pacific Northwest. Thunderstorms developed over the northern Plains. The Great Lakes region was expected to receive rainfall today. Thunderstorms were forecast in the Ohio Valley and the northern Midwest. Forecasters said a high pressure system would keep temperatures at record highs in the southern Rockies and Southwest, with temperatures likely to climb into the 110s. Unusually hot temperatures were likely later in the day in San Diego County. An agricultural heat advisory was posted into the weekend, and a heat advisory was posted through Friday over other inland portions of the county. Phoenix cooled early today to 96 degrees at 1 a.m., and Las Vegas dipped to 90. In the Plains, North Platte, Neb., was 91 degrees at 2 a.m., but dropped 10 degrees within the next two hours. Temperatures in Phoenix, where the mercury hit a record 122 degrees on Tuesday, dropped slightly to a high of 118 on Wednesday. The nation's high Wednesday was 121 degrees at Luke Air Force Base, northwest of Phoenix. Marie 46 fair; San Antonio 78 fair. _West: Albuquerque 76 partly cloudy; Anchorage 54 fair; Boise 59 fair; Casper 66 fair; Fairbanks 64 fair; Great Falls 55 partly cloudy; Honolulu 76 fair; Las Vegas 89 windy; Los Angeles 65 fair; Medford 59 fair; Pendleton 63 cloudy; Phoenix 94 fair; Portland, Ore., 61 showers; Reno 57 fair; Salt Lake City 63 fair; San Diego 69 fair; San Francisco 56 partly cloudy; Seattle 58 cloudy; Spokane 62 cloudy. _International: Calgary 50 partly cloudy; Montreal 55 partly cloudy; Ottawa 48 partly cloudy; Regina 57 partly cloudy; Toronto 50 partly cloudy; Winnipeg 64 showers; Mexico City 59 partly cloudy; Acapulco 82 cloudy; San Juan 80 fair.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar strengthened today as dealers continued to study the repercussions of President Bush's recent reversal on new taxes. Dealers felt that while higher U.S. taxes will help solve the country's budget deficit and encourage lower interest rates, there is little sign that the Federal Reserve is likely to lower rates soon. Some traders thought new taxes would lead to a weaker dollar. Others said a lower U.S. budget deficit, combined with a shrinking trade deficit, would boost confidence in the U.S. economy and ultimately produce a firmer dollar. The dollar weakened in Europe on Tuesday in the immediate aftermath of Bush's remarks on taxes, but recovered most of its losses during Wednesday morning trading. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.07 yen to a closing 154.42 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 153.60 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.6655 West German marks, up from 1.6625 _1.4130 Swiss francs, up from 1.4033 _5.5970 French francs, up from 5.5775 _1.8735 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8700 _1,224.00 Italian lire, up from 1,217.50 _1.1704 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1705 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.7352, compared with $1.7445 late Wednesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $350.40 a troy ounce, up from $350.05 bid late Wednesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $350.90. In Zurich, the bid price was $351.00, up from $349.90 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $351.34, up from Wednesday's close of $350.55. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $4.81 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $4.84.

DOC.HEAD: L.A. Board Redraws District Under Court Pressure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Supported of...' to CORRECT to Supporters.
DOC.TEXT: Beating a court deadline by three hours, Los Angeles County's Board of Supervisors redrew one of its voting districts to make it roughly half Hispanic. The plan, adopted 3-2 Wednesday, was prompted by a federal judge's ruling June 4 that the board had illegally kept Hispanics from getting elected by redrawing the boundaries in 1981 to spread their numbers across several districts. U.S. District Judge David Kenyon had imposed a deadline of 3 p.m. Wednesday to correct the violations of the federal Voting Rights Act. He will consider the plan on July 5. The supervisors drew the new boundaries by carving up Supervisor Ed Edelman's district. Edelman condemned the plan and predicted the judge would reject it. He said the proposed district is only 46 percent registered Hispanic voters, shy of the more than 50 percent demanded by the judge. Supporters of the plan said they hoped the judge would consider the so-called ``push'' factor _ the assumption that there are more voting-age people in an area than have actually registered. Kenyon's ruling followed a lawsuit by the U.S. Justice Department, the American Civil Liberties Union and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund. They contended the board had illegally diluted Hispanic voting strength. Hispanics make up about 35 percent of the county's 8.7 million people. But no Hispanic has been elected to the board since 1875. The judge has said that if the board fails to correct violations of the Voting Rights Act, he will redraw the district. The Mexican-American group refused immediate comment on the redistricting plan.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Fire On Suspected Rebels At Communist Guerrilla's Funeral, Two Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with military saying gunmen were soldiers, other details, background. ADDS byline.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Philippines-Americans, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers wearing masks and civilian clothes opened fire today on the funeral procession for a slain Communist rebel, killing two mourners. They also arrested 21 people, police said. The shooting came shortly before President Corazon Aquino told departing U.S. Peace Corps volunteers that her government would never allow ``the disciples and supporters of violence'' to achieve victory. She was referring to Communist rebels who allegedly planned to kill Peace Corps volunteers, forcing U.S. officials to suspend the group's operations in the Philippines and order staffers home. More than 50 mourners were approaching the capital's North Cemetery with the body of Benjamin Tabuena, 42, a former member of a rebel assassination squad, when at least five gunmen in civilian clothes ordered pallbearers to stop and lie face down. Witnesses said two of the mourners, including one pallbearer, tried to run but were shot and killed. As the shooting erupted, mourners scurried for cover. Some gunmen seized film and cameras from news photographers at gunpoint. Tabuena later was buried by cemetery workers on orders from the gunmen. ``It was like an ambush,'' said one witness, who asked that his name be withheld to prevent reprisals. After the shooting stopped, the masked gunmen rounded up male mourners, searched them at gunpoint and hustled them away. Capt. Arsenio Pinacate, spokesman for the military's Capital Command, said the gunmen were soldiers on an authorized mission to arrest rebels. He did not explain why they wore masks and civilian clothing. Pinacate quoted Lt. Col. George Alino, commander of the Capital Command northern sector, as saying the troops fired after suspected rebels resisted arrest but did not elaborate. Pinacate said mourners were arrested after they waived ``subversive placards'' during the funeral march. A policeman at a nearby precinct said two Capital Command officers brought 21 people alleged to be rebels to the station. The policeman would not give his name. Tabuena was a member of the Alex Boncayao Brigade, the Manila wing of the New People's Army. The brigade is believed to have killed scores of police and soldiers in the capital this year. Tabuena was slain June 18 after he and four others assassinated a policeman. Tabuena's daughter, Almeira, said none of those arrested was a member of her father's group. They were simply friends and neighbors who turned out for his funeral, she said. The New People's Army, the military branch of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines, has been fighting for 21 years to establish a Marxist state. International and local human rights groups have frequently accused police and soldiers of violating civil rights in connection with the counter-insurgency campaign, despite Mrs. Aquino's oft-stated pledge to respect individual liberties.

DOC.HEAD: American Song Program Marks Interlude in Jazz Festival
DOC.TEXT: On the sixth night of the nine-day JVC Jazz Festival, a program featuring American song proved to be a pleasant, off-beat event. Compared to some of the festival's over-amplified concerts in larger halls, the Town Hall theater off Times Square had the feeling of a small nightclub. The place, the players, the audience all combined for a thoroughly enjoyable Wednesday evening of jazz. First came Barbara Lea, a graceful singer whose enunciation and phrasing were impeccable. Despite a balky microphone, she gave the evening a romantic touch with some Vincent Youmans' standards _ among them, ``I Want to Be Happy'' and ``Time on My Hands'' _ from the 1920s and 1930s. Deftly accompanying her were the Keith Ingham Trio; Dick Sudhalter on trumpet and flugelhorn provided some apt punctuation. Next the evening's Odd Couple: the scholarly Dick Hyman on piano and the street-smart Ruby Braff on cornet. But what lovely music they made _ first some selections from Alan Jay Lerner's and Frederick Loewe's ``My Fair Lady,'' then a Fats Waller stride piece ``Hand Full of Keys.'' Hyman's solo performance of ``Blue Skies'' made that classic new. They finished up with ``If I Could Be With You One Hour Tonight.'' Gerry Mulligan and his quartet distinguished themselves after intermission and sent the crowd, murmuring with pleasure, into the warm night. Saxophonist Mulligan sang only one song _ ``I Never Was a Young Man'' _ and that largely without a microphone, but his instrumental songs were highly satisfying, among them a Brazilian-accented ``A Gift for Dizzy'' and a tender ``Song for Strayhorn.'' ``An Evening of American Song,'' as the program was named, deserves a rerun. It showcased some solid performers and charmed several generations of jazz-lovers in the audience.

DOC.HEAD: Three Van Gogh Paintings Stolen From Dutch Museum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs after 9th, `The paintings...' to ADD further information on ownership of paintings, art world speculation on likelihood of ransom demand, insurance status. Picks up 10th graf `The most...'
DOC.TEXT: Three early oil paintings by 19th century Dutch master Vincent van Gogh have been stolen from a small provincial museum in this southern town, the third theft in two years of Van Gogh works. The paintings taken Wednesday night from the Noordbrabants Museum were identified by the museum as ``The Sitting Farmer's Wife'', ``The Digging Farmer's Wife'' and ``Wheels of the Water Mill in Gennep''. Guy Jennings, an Impressionism expert at Christie's auction house in London, said by telephone that such minor works by Van Gogh are worth about $1 million each but would be virtually impossible to sell on the open market. Peter Veenland, a member of the museum's board of directors, confirmed the theft of the paintings, the museum's only three works by the painter. Dutch radio quoted police as saying the paintings were stolen from the museum 55 miles south of Amsterdam after entry was apparently gained through a broken window. The alarm system at the museum was not functioning and police were called by a neighbor who heard the sound of breaking glass, the radio said. It did not say whether the alarm was disabled during the theft or was out of order before the break-in. A police spokesman reached by phone would only confirm that the paintings were missing. The paintings date from about 1884, known as the artist's Brabant period, when he worked among the farmers and rural artisans of the Brabant, which encompasses a large part of the southern Netherlands. Paintings from Van Gogh's Brabant period are generally dark in tone and employ none of the bright colors of his later French period, which have brought record auction prices. ``They really are Flemish School pictures before he really discovered Impressionism,'' said Jennings, the Christie's expert. ``The Sitting Farmer's Wife'' and `The Wheels of the Water Mill in Gennep'' were on loan from the National Fine Arts Service, said Service spokeswoman Marry de Zwaan. ``The Digging Farmer's Wife'' was owned by the museum. The vast treasure trove of art owned by the Dutch nation is not insured. There was speculation in the Dutch art world that the paintings were stolen for ransom rather than resale, since underground sales of stolen art usually realize only 10-15 percent of a painting's open market value, Jennings said. The most significant of the Dutch impressionist's works are held by Amsterdam's Van Gogh Museum and the Kroeller-Mueller Museum near the eastern Dutch town of Otterlo. In December 1988, three Van Goghs, including one version of his famous depiction of rural poverty, ``The Potato Eaters,'' were stolen from the Kroeller-Mueller. In May of that year, three other works by modern masters, including Van Gogh's ``Carnations,'' were taken from Amsterdam's Municipal Museum. All the stolen works were subsequently recovered. Wednesday's theft came during the final weeks of a major exhibition of hundreds of Van Gogh's paintings and drawings at the Van Gogh Museum and the Kroeller-Mueller. No thefts or vandalism have been reported at the show, which marks the centenary of the artist's death.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Dies from Wounds, Becomes Ninth Victim of Office Gunman
DOC.TEXT: A woman wounded in the massacre at an auto loan office has died, raising the death toll to 10. Jewel Belote, 50, a stenographer at the General Motors Acceptance Corp., died Wednesday from her gunshot wounds, said Vince Scolaro, a spokesman at University Medical Center. Seven workers and one customer were killed and five people were wounded June 18 by James Edward Pough, who opened fire in the office before killing himself. In January, GMAC repossessed Pough's car, then notified him in March that he still owed $6,394. The weekend before the office shooting, Pough killed two people and wounded two others on Jacksonville streets, authorities said. Two of the people wounded in the office shooting _ a worker and a customer _were released from hospitals Tuesday. Two employees remain hospitalized.

DOC.HEAD: Obey Warns Israel of Aid Cut if Settlements Expanded in Occupied Areas
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Leads with 3 grafs to identify Obey as chairman of a House appropriations subcommittee; picks up 4th graf, In Jerusalem ...
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a House panel that oversees foreign aid is warning Israel that he will support cutting its aid next year if that government expands settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``If Israel expands their settlements in any way, or if they add a single new settlement, I will make a flat commitment to support any request made by the administration to reduce aid to Israel in next year's bill,'' said Rep. David Obey, D-Wis. The comments set Obey, chairman of the House Appropriations' foreign operations subcommittee, on a collision course with the newly installed right-wing Israeli government, which has promised to expand settlements in the territories seized in the 1967 six-day war. In Jerusalem, a top aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today he regretted such warnings. Yossi Ben-Aharon, director-general of Shamir's office, would not say whether Israel planned such expansions. ``I don't want to answer any questions on settlements because it would only inflate their importance. We hope that the issue will be removed from the agenda of U.S.-Israeli relations,'' he told The Associated Press. Obey issued the warning as the House approved a $15.7 billion aid bill for the year beginning Oct. 1, which includes Israel's customary $3 billion in military and economic aid, making it the largest single recipient of U.S. largess. The overall bill represented what Obey termed the start of a gradual turn away from America's emphasis on military aid to its friends and allies around the globe, and toward economic development and trade. It cut nearly $400 million President Bush had sought in military assistance and put the money into aid to Africa, refugees, children and Eastern Europe. As it worked through a pile of proposed amendments to the bill, the House also voted narrowly to preserve President Bush's policy of not sending U.S. aid to international family planning groups linked to abortion, and to keep non-lethal aid flowing to Cambodia's non-communist resistance. Obey said he meant his comments on Israeli settlement as ``a very friendly warning'' intended to head off developments that could further jeopardize peace in the unstable region. He said the amount of any aid cut would be based on how much is spent on expanding present settlements or creating new ones. ``Israel is a sovereign nation and has the right to do anything they want. But the U.S. government has no obligation to fund, either directly or indirectly, settlements which we believe to be an impediment to the peace process,'' he said. On the population issue, the House voted 224 to 198 to send $3 million through private groups for family planning and other health projects in Romania, whose people have for decades been subject to a government policy against contraception. But the amendment, offered by Rep. Christopher Smith, R-N.J., excluded two groups from participation _ the United Nations Population Fund and the International Planned Parenthood Federation _ which participate in abortion counseling, referral or services. Smith's opponents argued that those two groups are the only ones that now operate in Romania, so barring them would make any aid program for that country ineffective. But Smith and allies countered that Bush would veto any bill that included funding for the two abortion-linked agencies. The lawmakers also adopted, 260 to 162, an amendment by Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., to provide $7 million in non-lethal aid to the coalition opposing Cambodia's Vietnamese-installed government. That replaced language in the bill barring any aid to the resistance, a prohibition supported by members who feared the dominance of the Khmer Rouge in the coalition. The Khmer Rouge ruled Cambodia in the 1970s and were responsible for the deaths of more than 1 million people in what became known as ``the killing fields.'' They are the strongest military faction in a coalition which also receives millions of dollars in covert U.S. military aid. The bill _ the principal vehicle for U.S. military, economic and development aid to friends and allies _ still faces serious objections from the White House because of a provision cutting military aid to El Salvador. The measure would withhold half of next year's $85 million in aid and apply conditions intended to keep the warring government and leftist FMLN rebels at the peace table. Negotiations on a new bipartisan policy toward El Salvador are being conducted separately between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and a team of House Democrats and Republicans.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Radicals, Unimpressed by Party Changes, Plan Split
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party radicals said today they had virtually given up hope for major reforms of their party and predicted a schism at the upcoming congress, despite President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's appeals for unity. Leaders of the Democratic Platform, a group struggling to drastically change the Communist Party from within, told a news conference that they were unimpressed by party efforts at internal reform. ``In reality, despite the many statements of leaders, the Communist Party has shown it is simply incapable of reforming itself,'' said Vladimir Lysenko, one of the group's leaders. The proposed split in the Communist Party would be the first since 1922, and Gorbachev, the party's general secretary, has warned that it would divide and weaken the forces struggling for reform. Hard-liners appeared to be consolidating their strength before the 28th Congress of the Communist Party, due to open in the Kremlin on Monday. The reformist Democratic Platform has the backing of only about 100 of 4,700 delegates at the congress, but is believed to have much wider support in the party rank-and-file. Lysenko said the group would fight for its views at the congress, but ``if it proves impossible, there will be a statement that either the Communist Party has split or a new party is starting.'' Another Democratic Platform leader, Stepan Sulakshin, said he expected more than 2 million of the Communist Party's 19 million members to quit. Gorbachev, speaking last week to a congress of Communists from the Russian republic, said a split in the party would be ``a gift'' to opponents of his reforms. Lysenko predicted ``a very hard time for Gorbachev'' from hard-liners, but the platform leaders said they opposed a proposal to put off the congress until autumn to stem the conservative tide. A plenum of the party's Central Committee is expected to address the timing of the congress and other issues on Friday, but with both right and left coming out against it, a postponement appeared unlikely. Lysenko criticized a proposed new set of party rules published today in the Community Party daily Pravda, as well as a proposed program published Wednesday. The new documents make a pretense at reform, he said, but remained ``wholly in the old spirit,'' retaining tight discipline over the party, forbidding factions and refusing to remove party cells from workplaces. The Democratic Platform wants the party to allow factions, relinquish its massive assets, remove itself from direct management of the country and become a western-style parliamentary party. Party ideology chief Vadim Medvedev said the leadership tried to accommodate the Democratic Platform as it drafted its new rules and program, but also tried to build a consensus with the party mainstream and the traditionalist Marxist Platform. The rules make several key changes in the workings of the Communist Party political machine: _The party leader would be called the chairman instead of the general secretary and be elected directly by the 4,700-member congress instead of the 249-member Central Committee. _The collective leadership would be called the Presidium instead of the Politburo. It is expected to be enlarged from its current dozen members to include the heads of the 15 republic parties, although this is not specified in the published proposal. _The Central Committee could be replenished in between congresses. That would make its membership much more fluid. _Party leaders could not be elected to more than two terms in a row. _Republic parties would become more independent.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Kills 7-Year-Old Girl; Rival Militias Fight in Hills
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded near a Syrian army checkpoint in Moslem west Beirut early today and another wrecked the office of a pro-Iraqi group in south Lebanon, police reported. The explosions killed a 7-year-old girl and wounded 10 people. The girl was slain when a bomb exploded near the Baath Arab Socialist Party office in Sidon, the southern provincial capital, officials said. Four other people were wounded in the blast that devastated the office on the first floor of a six-story apartment building in the port city's main thoroughfare. Iraq and Syria, ruled by rival wings of the Baath Party, have been feuding for 11 years. In the Beirut bombing, police said six civilians were wounded, among them an unidentified Sri Lankan woman. The Datsun that exploded in the Talet el-Khayyat district 400 yards from the Syrian checkpoint contained about 65 pounds of TNT, according to an explosives expert. Five cars were set on fire by the blast. It damaged apartment buildings and several shops, leaving the street littered with broken glass and twisted metal. Residents said the car had been parked on the street for several days. As is usual with bombings in Lebanon, there were no claims of responsibility. A chain of bombings since the Syrian army moved into west Beirut in 1987 to quell militia anarchy has been seen as a campaign designed to undermine the Syrian peacekeeping effort. Also in south Lebanon, Sunni Moslem militiamen of the Nasserite Popular Organization battled with fighters of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army east of Sidon, the provincial capital. Police reported one South Lebanon Army militiaman was killed and two Nasserites were wounded in the clashes with mortars, rocket-propelled grenades and machine guns around Kfar Falous, a hilltop village east of Sidon on the front line between the two forces.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Regrets U.S. Warning Against Building More Settlements
With PM-Foreign Aid
DOC.TEXT: A top aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today he regretted warnings that U.S. aid would be cut if Israel expanded Jewish settlements in occupied lands. Yossi Ben-Aharon, director-general of Shamir's office, refused to say whether Israel planned such expansions. ``I don't want to answer any questions on settlements because it would only inflate their importance. We hope that the issue will be removed from the agenda of U.S.-Israeli relations,'' he told The Associated Press. But Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner said that ``it's obvious that nobody has sought to put limits on existing settlements.'' Pazner dismissed as ``pure speculation'' reports that Shamir and his ultra-rightist coalition partners had agreed to build 5,000 new housing units a year in the settlements. Five thousand new units would house 25,000 people. The recent report by the Haaretz daily also said that by September, 1,050 new housing units will be completed in the settlements, bringing 6,800 more settlers into the occupied lands. Israel captured the territories in the 1967 war with its Arab neighbors. According to a recent survey by the newspaper, 84,000 Jewish settlers live in the West Bank and 4,000 in the Gaza Strip. Previous figures put the number of West Bank settlers at about 75,000 and those in Gaza at 2,500. U.S. Rep. David Obey, chairman of the House Foreign Aid Subcommittee, said in Washington on Wednesday he would support cuts in U.S. aid to Israel if its government persisted in expanding settlements in the occupied territories. ``The U.S. government has no obligation to fund, either directly or indirectly, settlements which we believe to be an impediment to the peace process,'' said Obey, D-Wis. President Bush has spoken out sharply against Jewish settlements in the occupied lands, and the issue has been a main factor in the deteriorating relations between the two allies. Referring to Obey's warning, Ben-Aharon said: ``We regret this attitude.'' Ben-Aharon said Israel's top priority was the absorption of Soviet Jewish immigrants. ``We are not taken up now with the subject of settlements because the big agenda item is immigration,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Planners OK Preserving Stage Where Malcolm X Was Slain
DOC.TEXT: The stage where Malcolm X was slain will be preserved under a plan to build a $25 million biomedical research laboratory at the site of the Audubon Ballroom in Harlem. The City Planning Commission approved the laboratory construction Wednesday with the provision that a substantial portion of the building across from Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center be preserved. That includes 40 percent of the Audubon Ballroom and the stage on which the black nationalist leader was shot on Feb. 21, 1965. The commission had reserved decision last May on a plan to demolish the ballroom to make way for the partly state-funded research building being planned by Columbia University and the city.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Proposes Way to Choose Palestinian Delegation
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today proposed to President Bush that Israel have a say in approving Palestinian delegates for proposed Middle East peace talks, Israel and army radio reported. The reports said the proposal, in a letter to Bush, opposed the inclusion of deportees or Palestinians from Arab east Jerusalem, as suggested by Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Israel has objected to what it views as attempts to give the PLO an indirect role in the talks. Under the U.S. plan, the Palestinian delegation would hold preliminary peace talks with Israelis in Cairo, Egypt. Shamir's office confirmed the prime minister sent the letter to Bush today in response to a letter from Bush two weeks ago. The Bush letter urged Israel's new right-wing government to advance the peace process and requested answers to Baker's proposals, Shamir's office said. It would not comment on the reported proposal to choose Palestinian delegates from a pool of names that would require approval from Israel. ``We are ready to continue to cooperate with Secretary Baker to advance a dialogue with a Palestinian delegation that will be composed on a name-by-name basis,'' the Israel radio report quoted Shamir's letter as saying. ``But, as you know Mr. President, we disagree with the participation of deportees and Arabs from Jerusalem in the delegation.'' Shamir has opposed participation of exiles or east Jerusalem residents as demanded by Palestinians. He fears that would be seen as conceding issues of principle on Palestinian demands to make Jerusalem the capital of a Palestinian state and to give the right of return to millions of Arabs living abroad. Israel has also objected to giving the Palestine Liberation Organization an indirect role in the negotiations, claiming the PLO is a terrorist organization dedicated to the destruction of Israel. In his letter to Bush, Shamir shifted the emphasis from the stalled attempt to start a dialogue with the Palestinians to the broader question of reaching peace with Israel's Arab neighbors, the radio reports said.
