Shamir reportedly told Bush the refusal of Arab states to end the state of war with Israel was at the heart of the conflict in the region, the report said. He emphasized most efforts should be aimed at reaching peace between Israel and its Arab neighbors.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Building Blaze Forces Evacuation; Delays Edition
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and fire in the basement of the Dallas Times Herald newspaper forced an evacuation of the building and moved the printing of today's edition to another newspaper's presses. One worker was injured and a woman was treated for smoke inhalation. About 200 people were forced to leave the building because of dense smoke. The fire was out less than an hour after it was reported Wednesday night. ``It was an electrical short in the electrical room,'' said Deputy Fire Chief Larry Roberts. A delayed morning edition of the Times Herald was printed at the Fort Worth Star-Telegram, 35 miles to the west. Jerry Zinnick, director of production at the Star-Telegram, said the newspaper had sufficient press capacity to allow the Times Herald to use two of its presses. About 200,000 copies were printed by 6 a.m.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Candidate Bows Out of Election Race Against Barney Frank
DOC.TEXT: One of two Republican candidates for the seat of U.S. Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., has withdrawn from the race for personal reasons. Jim Nuzzo, a physician and former White House staff member, was considered the favorite candidate of the state GOP hierarchy. His withdrawal Wednesday leaves only one GOP candidate, John Soto, a lawyer and accountant. ``Regrettably ... I must announce today that due to personal reasons my family and I have decided that I will no longer be a candidate for office,'' Nuzzo said. ``This decision does not come lightly or easily.'' Frank has been the subject of a House ethics committee investigation into his relationship with a male prostitute. The committee has not yet issued its report. Frank has no opposition for the Democratic nomination in the Sept. 18 primary.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lets Stand Ruling that Overturns Most Death Sentences in Three States
DOC.TEXT: A day after it upheld Arizona's death penalty law, the Supreme Court today let stand a ruling that had the effect of overturning most existing death sentences in Arizona, Idaho and Montana. By a 4-3 vote, the justices refused to reinstate the death sentence of John Harvey Adamson, convicted of murdering newspaper reporter Don Bolles in 1976. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals previously had struck down Adamson's death sentence. But the justices Wednesday upheld Arizona's death penalty law in a decision directly conflicting with the 9th Circuit court's ruling in Adamson's case. In throwing out Adamson's sentence, the appeals court struck down a key provision of Arizona's death penalty law _ one which was declared valid by the Supreme Court on Wednesday. Idaho and Montana have the same provisions in their death penalty laws. The confusing turn of events apparently was sparked by the fact that Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, a former state judge in Arizona, and Anthony M. Kennedy, a former 9th Circuit court judge, took no part in acting on Arizona's appeal in Adamson's case. That left only Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White and Antonin Scalia voting to set aside the 9th Circuit court's ruling. Justices Willam J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens, who voted Wednesday to strike down Arizona's death penalty law, apparently voted to deny Arizona's appeal in the Adamson case. The net result: A Supreme Court decision upholding Arizona's death penalty law and a 9th Circuit court decision striking it down both remain on the books. The practical effect: It appears Adamson cannot be sentenced to death. Today's high court action was sparked by an appeal filed by Arizona Attorney General Bob Corbin. Bolles, who had been investigating organized crime for The Arizona Republic in Phoenix, died June 11, 1976, nine days after his car exploded. Prosecutors said Adamson was paid $10,000 to attach a bomb to the reporter's car. Before dying, Bolles identified Adamson as the man who had made an appointment to see him the day of the bombing. Adamson originally was allowed to plead guilty to second-degree murder in exchange for his testimony against two others allegedly involved in the murder plot. His testimony helped convict Max Dunlap, a building contractor, and James Robison, a plumber. But the Arizona Supreme Court threw out the Dunlap and Robison convictions in 1980 and ordered a new trial for them. The two have not been retried. Adamson, who by 1980 was serving a 20-year prison term, said he would not testify at a new trial unless the state met additional conditions _ including his release and the government's help in establishing a new identity. After Adamson's refusal to cooperate, state prosecutors filed first-degree murder charges against him. He was tried, convicted and sentenced to death. The 9th Circuit court threw out Adamson's death sentence in 1986, ruling that he had been subjected to ``double jeopardy.'' The Supreme Court reversed that ruling and reinstated the death sentence by a 5-4 vote in 1987. The 9th Circuit then considered other issues raised by Adamson's case, and once again threw out his death sentence. The case is Lewis vs. Adamson, 88-1553.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects County Attorney's Suit Against Minnesota TV Station
DOC.TEXT: A St. Paul, Minn., prosecutor who says he was defamed by a Minneapolis television station's reporting about a mysterious 1982 death lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The justices, without comment, refused to revive Ramsey County Attorney Tom Foley's libel lawsuit against WCCO-TV. A state trial judge threw out Foley's suit before it reached a jury, and the Minnesota Supreme Court upheld that dismissal last Dec. 26. Kathleen Greening's body was found under water in the bathtub of her Lauderdale home July 21, 1982. The county medical examiner initially listed the manner of death as ``undetermined,'' but in the fall of 1985 was considering changing that designation to ``homicide.'' WCCO-TV in early 1986 investigated the death and its handling by the criminal justice system. Its reports were critical of all public officials and agencies involved in the investigation, including Foley and his office. Foley contended that the WCCO reports libeled him in at least 197 statements, which a state trial judge divided into factual scenarios: _That Foley requested the attorney general's office to remove a state investigator from the case. _That Foley blocked the issuance of a search warrant for the financial records of Mrs. Greening's husband, one of his campaign contributors but also a suspect in the murder investigation. _That Foley was aware of an inherent conflict of interest involving himself and Mrs. Greening's husband. _That Foley asked Medical Examiner Michael McGee not to change the death certificate designation from ``undetermined'' to ``homicide.'' The Minnesota Supreme Court said Foley was not entitled to have his allegations reach a jury because he had failed to offer enough evidence of ``actual malice'' _ that the statements were false and made with knowledge or reckless disregard of their falsity. In the appeal acted on today, Foley said the state courts reviewed the issues and facts of his case with no ``deference to or mention of the rich record supporting triable issue of actual malice against'' the television station. The case is Foley vs. WCCO-TV, 89-1882.

DOC.HEAD: China Imposes Penalty for Desecrating the Flag
DOC.TEXT: Chinese who desecrate the national flag can be imprisoned for up to three years under a law passed by legislators today. The nation's first flag law, adopted by the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, also forbids the use of the standard in advertisements or as a trademark, the official Xinhua News Agency said. Xinhua said wilful damage to a flag is punishable by up to three years of imprisonment, detention, surveillance or deprivation of political rights. Before the law was passed, China often harshly punished those who defaced any of its national symbols. Last year a Chinese court gave a life sentence to a man who during the pro-democracy demonstrations threw paint on the large portrait of Mao hanging from Tiananmen Gate. In the United States this week, the House of Representatives rejected a proposed amendment to the Constitution permitting the enactment of laws making it illegal to desecrate the flag. The Chinese law says every citizen and organization must respect and take good care of the national flag, which shows four small and one large yellow star against a red field. The large star stands for the Communist Party, and the small stars represent various classes in Chinese society. The red color represents the Communist revolution. The law says China's flag since the Communist takeover in 1949 must be raised every day on Tiananmen Square, at the gate to the Communist headquarters of Zhongnanhai, in front of various government and party offices and at ports, airports and border railway stations. All full-time schools must fly the flag whenever school is in session. Work units and neighborhood committees must raise the flag on national holidays and other major occasions. Flags should be flown at half-mast when Chinese leaders or foreigners who have contributed to world peace die, or when disasters cause heavy casualties. The law, to go into effect on October 1, China's National Day, also states that flags may be produced only by officially designated enterprises.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Chief Questions Evidence on Global Warming
DOC.TEXT: The head of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency said today that a recent U.N. report by a prestigious group of scientists on global warming was insufficient to persuade the United States to take action. EPA Administrator William Reilly told reporters that the problem is not ``understood with the degree of certainty that would warrant'' taking action to curb emissions of carbon dioxide and other so-called greenhouse gases. Taking such action, which could affect everything from cars to power plants, would result in ``very substantial economic dislocation,'' Reilly said at the international conference on the ozone layer. The report, released earlier this month by the United Nations-backed Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, pooled the expertise of some of the world's leading scientists. It concluded that the earth's temperature has already begun to warm, and appealed for urgent action to curb emissions of greenhouse gases to prevent potential climatological disaster. But sweeping changes to the U.S. and world economy would be needed to reduce the burning of fossil fuels that produce carbon dioxide. The United States, the leading carbon dioxide producer, wants more study into whether global warming is taking place and, if so, what is causing it. The administration has increased the budget for research into climate change by 57 percent this year, Reilly said. Reilly's comments were the strongest statement so far by an administration official on the report. They seemed to indicate a rejection of its unequivocal conclusions. ``We do not believe at this time that the evidence is sufficiently compelling to move us toward the dislocation and highly expensive interventions that would be required'' to cut emissions, Reilly said. David D. Doniger of the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington, accused the United States of refusing to accept the work of a group it had previously supported. ``The U.S. had been saying it was waiting for the report,'' said Doniger, who is attending the ozone conference as an observer. ``One thing is clear. It is getting harder and harder for our country to hide behind the veil of insufficient knowledge.'' The report is bound to figure in discussions next month in Houston, at the summit of the seven leading industrialized democracies. Last year's summit declaration dwelt extensively on environmental issues and the upcoming meeting is being viewed as the next major step in international global warming policy. The final report of the U.N. panel is scheduled for release in August, before the World Climate Change conference in November in Geneva.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Makes Final Plea for Demjanjuk's Life
DOC.TEXT: The lawyer for convicted Nazi war criminal John Demjanjuk made a final plea to Israel's Supreme Court today to spare his life, arguing there is enough doubt ``to take the gallows out of this case.'' Yoram Sheftel, Demjanjuk's lawyer, ended his appeal by asking a panel of five justices to overturn the death sentence because of ``lingering doubt'' about Demjanjuk's guilt. ``There is no case that potentially could contain a mistake more than this case,'' he argued. Sheftel has argued that Demjanjuk is innocent, a victim of mistaken identity and not ``Ivan the Terrible,'' a gas-chamber operator at the Treblinka death camp in World War II. The appeal began May 14 and was the longest in Israel's history, with 13 days of defense arguments and 12 days for the prosecution. Sheftel also asked the Supreme Court not to hand down a decision before Jan. 1 in order to give the defense time to investigate possible new evidence. Chief Justice Meir Shamgar said the justices would consider the request but did not indicate when they would rule. Demjanjuk, a 70-year-old retired Cleveland autoworker, was convicted and sentenced to death in April 1988 for crimes against humanity and crimes against the Jewish people. His trial lasted 14 months. Three trial judges agreed with the prosecution that Demjanjuk was ``Ivan the Terrible,'' the Treblinka guard who raped, beat and slashed Jews as they were forced into the gas chambers. More than 850,000 Jews were murdered at Treblinka in Nazi-occupied Poland in 1942-43. A Ukrainian native, Demjanjuk claims he is a victim of mistaken identity and says he spent those years in several German POW camps as a captured Soviet soldier.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Find Homes Spared Alongside Leveled Homes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Grgich, 4th graf, is cq.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Fires, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jennifer and Rick Cook drove up the long, narrow driveway to see what was left of Jennifer's parents' home. ``Oh God! Oh God!'' she wailed as their car snaked back into the hills, passing through thick smoke, ash and embers. But there was the house she grew up in _ untouched by the firestorm that had swept through several hours earlier. ``It's OK. It's OK,'' she said, tears streaming down her cheeks. A few minutes later she was reunited with her parents, Susan and George Grgich, who credited their home's survival to a new asphalt roof. The Grgiches were among the fortunate _ those who escaped the 3,500-acre inferno Wednesday night in the suburban foothills of this quiet, wealthy coastal city. At least 280 families lost their homes in the blaze, which leveled entire neighborhoods. Firefighters often could do little more than soak the remains of what were once $750,000 homes. In some instances, they were able to save homes adjacent to the worst damage. Utility workers moved from house to house in the early morning darkness, shutting off gas valves. Otherwise, neighborhoods were deserted, with the only sound the eerie whistle of a flaming gas main or the tumble of pots and pans in what was once the cupboard of a designer kitchen. One vantage point revealed a residential landscape dotted by flames for miles in every direction. Under an orange sky filled with soot, one resident narrated his escape. ``I started reading the paper after I came home from work and then my 12-year-old said, `Daddy, the back yard is on fire,''' said Bryan Gaggs, whose home was untouched while those of two of his nearest neighbors were gutted. ``When I finally left the house, I thought my house was already going. But it turned out to be unscathed,'' Gaggs said. About a half-mile away, across a small canyon, seven homes were destroyed. Jerry Neeley, wearing a dentist's mask to breathe through the smoke, stayed behind to try to save his sprawling residence. ``It was like an inferno,'' he said. ``I saw smoke a couple miles away and had just put hamburgers on. I hurried dinner so we could all go upstairs and watch the fire. And then it was on us. It must have traveled several miles in less than 30 minutes.'' Neeley threw flammable items, including lawn furniture, into his pool. At a Red Cross rescue center in the gymnasium at the University of California, Santa Barbara, evacuees gathered around a radio as a roving reporter rattled off the street addresses of homes that had been burned to the ground. One woman, who identified herself only as Sue, heard her street address called. ``I didn't get one picture,'' she said, sobbing gently. ``I didn't get a photograph. Not one thing. Not one memory.'' Her husband, who has Parkinson's disease, was rescued. ``We've got each other,'' Sue said. ``We'll start (again) somehow.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises New US-Japan Trade Agreement
With PM-Japan-US
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that an agreement to slash America's huge trade deficit with Japan will reduce tensions with Tokyo and be ``beneficial for the entire world.'' ``I welcome and endorse this joint report,'' Bush said in a written statement after U.S. and Japanese negotiators announced an accord to trim the United States' $49 billion trade imbalance. The president said both countries had identified trade barriers, ``taken initial corrective actions and made commitments to take further steps to resolve a wide range of structural problems.'' The agreement emerged from a series of complex negotiations called the Structural Impediments Initiative, or SII, involving the removal of barriers to open trading. The president did not spell out the details of the accord. However, Bush said the steps that will be taken ``will have a positive effect on our economies, encouraging open and competitive markets, promoting sustained world economic growth, contributing to a reduction in global payments imbalances and enhancing the quality of life in both Japan and the United States.'' He said that although the agreement was only between Japan and the United States, ``the effects will be beneficial for the entire world.'' Bush said the personal efforts of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu ``were responsible in large measure for the substantial progress'' achieved. The president commended Kaifu for ``his strong and courageous political leadership.'' In Tokyo, Linn Williams, the U.S. deputy trade representative, said Bush's willingness to consider tax revenue increases had helped move the talks forward. Bush said the removal of trade barriers ``is a two way street. ``As Japan tackles its structural problems,'' he said, ``so must the United States.'' He pledged to work with Congress to reduce the mushrooming U.S. budget deficit and to strengthen public and private saving. ``Both our governments recognize that further effort will be necessary in order to address fully these structural problems and to maintain the momentum of our adjustment efforts,'' Bush said. He said that continuing progress in the SII talks ``can help us move away from trade disputes, thus allowing us to focus our efforts on more positive activities as we continue to develop a global partnership between our two countries.''

DOC.HEAD: The War in Nicaragua At A Glance
With PM-Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: The end of the civil war in Nicaragua brings to a close a period of bloodshed that has severely scarred this Central American nation. Here at a glance are some of the key events of that civil war:
DURATION: 1981-1990
CASUALTIES: Estimated at 30,000 dead and 25,000 wounded.

SANDINISTAS: Left-wing group, known as the Sandinista National Liberation Front, formed to overthrow the Somoza family. After Somoza's ouster on July 17, 1979, the Sandinistas abrogated the 1974 constitution and dissolved the bicameral National Congress.

CONTRAS: The Contras _ Spanish contraction for ``counterrevolutionary'' _ began as a group of about 2,000 former National Guardsmen considered to be supporters of Somoza who retreated north to Honduras. Their numbers were swelled with the arrival of Miskito Indians fleeing the Sandinistas' attempt to integrate them.

U.S. AID: Congress approved a covert Contras aid program by the CIA in 1981, but reduced it two years later and cut it off entirely in 1984 after allegations were raised about human rights abuses by the guerrillas. The Reagan administration supported military aid for the Contras, despite Congressional battles with opposition Democrats. An estimated $10 million to $30 million in illegal arms-for-hostages profits were diverted to the Contras in the Iran-Contra affair.

CHRONOLOGY: July 17, 1979 _ Anastasio Somoza, whose family had ruled Nicaragua with U.S. support since the 1930s, flees to Miami. November 1980 _ First attacks launched by anti-Sandinista rebels known as Contras. February 1981 _ Reagan administration announces suspension of aid to Nicaragua and accuses Sandinista government of supporting leftist guerrillas in El Salvador. April 6-7, 1984 _ Commando units operating from a U.S. ship plant mines in Nicaragua's ports. Jan. 10, 1985 _ Daniel Ortega is inaugurated as president following national elections. May 1, 1985 _ Reagan announces a trade embargo against Nicaragua. Aug. 7, 1987 _ Five Central American presidents sign a regional peace plan. Feb. 3, 1988 _ Congress cuts off military aid to the Contras. Non-lethal aid continues. Feb. 14, 1989 _ Five Central American presidents agree the Contras should be demobilized. Ortega agrees to hold free elections in 1990. April 28, 1989 _ President Bush signs a $49 million non-lethal aid package for the Contras that will run out three days after the 1990 Nicaraguan elections. Aug. 7, 1989 _ The Central American presidents formalize demobilization accord. Feb. 25, 1990 _ Ortega and the Sandinistas suffer stunning defeat in elections to U.S.-backed coalition led by Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. March 13 _ President Bush lifts the economic embargo and asks Congress for $300 million in aid, including $45 million to demobilize and relocate the Contras. April 19 _ Sandinistas, Contras and the coalition agree on a cease-fire and the immediate concentration of the Contras in security zones. The Contras agree to begin surrendering their weapons April 25, inauguration day, and to disband by June 10. April 25 _ Mrs. Chamorro takes office in peaceful transition of government. June 27 _ Contra commanders surrender weapons to Mrs. Chamorro.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0560 to correct writethru designator
Sri Lanka Admits Civilians Killed in Raids on Guerrillas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with death toll rising to 1,679. Pickup 6th pvs, `Helicopter gunships...'
DOC.TEXT: The government today acknowledged that it killed civilians during bombing and strafing raids on Tamil rebels, and it blamed pilot error for the deaths. The deputy defense minister, Ranjan Wijeratne, gave no figures for the number of civilians killed in savage fighting in Sri Lanka's north and east. At least 1,679 combatants have been killed in the 17-day-old upsurge in the country's civil war. The latest deaths included 35 rebels killed in fighting Wednesday and today, military officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Four government soldiers also were killed, they said. Most of the air raids have focused on Jaffna, a densely-populated city of 120,000 in the north. ``Some bombs have hit targets which we did not envisage and we regret that,'' Wijeratne told a weekly news briefing. Wijeratne denied a rebel claim that the government had used napalm, a powerful defoliant, in its air attacks. Helicopter gunships and bombers have bombed and strafed the town in an attempt to break a rebel siege on Jaffna Fort, one of two government military installations in the rebel-controlled north. At least 225 soldiers and policemen are trapped inside the fort. Last week, government helicopters dropped leaflets on the city warning nearby residents to evacuate their homes. To capture the 200-year-old fort, Tamil rebels have attempted to tunnel under the installation and to scale its walls with explosives tied to their bodies. Each attempt has failed, the military said. In the briefing, Gen. Cyril Ranatunge also defended military policy, saying that helicopter gunships did not attack unidentified targets. ``We are not going to kill our own people,'' he said. His answer was in response to a reporter who claimed he watched two helicopter gunships shoot up a village for 15 minutes in eastern Sri Lanka where there were no apparent rebel fortifications or targets. A helicopter gunship also strafed a vehicle carrying foreign correspondents, including a Los Angeles Times reporter, on Monday. The correspondents were not injured. Military officials said the government had launched a mass recruitment campaign to prepare for what many think will be a long war with the guerrillas. So far 12,000 men, mostly Sinhalese, have volunteered to fight, military officials said. Tamil rebels have waged a war for a separate homeland in the north and the east since 1983. The fighting has claimed more than 11,000 lives. The latest round of fighting ended a 13-month-old cease-fire negotiated between the government and the rebels in May 1989. The flareup began June 11 after a Tamil man claimed he was manhandled by Sinhalese police. Tamil Tiger guerrillas responded by attacking police stations in the east. Members of the mainly Hindu Tamil minority claim they are discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese, who dominate the government and military and are predominantly Buddhist. Sinhalese make up 75 percent of the island's 16 million people and control the army and the government. Tamils comprise 18 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Government Conditionally Welcomes Rebel Cease-Fire
DOC.TEXT: The government today conditionally welcomed a rebel-proposed cease-fire and transitional government. In a long statement issued by the Council of State, the government said it was possible to ``consider these and other issues'' if the rebels stop fighting and halt support for independence of the country's northernmost province. Tigrean rebels said Sunday they were ready to implement an immediate cease-fire if President Mengistu Haile Mariam's government stepped down and was replaced by a broad-based interim government that would hold internationally supervised elections. The Council of State said it would consider the proposals if the Tigreans halt their support of a separate insurgency seeking independence for the northernmost province, Eritrea, and ``refrain from destabilizing the territorial integrity of the country.'' A Western diplomat said the government seemed to be testing the water. ``It's sniffing around like a dog to see if the rebels are serious about becoming engaged in discussion,'' he said on condition of anonymity. ``Their backs are against the wall. They've got to take advantage of anything that comes along.'' The government has held two rounds of inclusive talks with the Tigreans, both of which have faltered over the rebels' demands for an interim government. Since August, the TPLF, or Tigrean People's Liberation Front, and its ally, the Ethiopian People's Democratic Movement, have captured a wide area of northern Ethiopia, including their home province, Tigre. Tigre is the southern neighbor of Eritrea where the Eritrean People's Liberation Front has been fighting for independence since 1961 in Africa's longest war. The Tigreans and Eritreans both long have demanded Mengistu's ouster and regularly coordinate offensives. The Tigreans, in their push south, have come to within 100 miles of the capital. The Eritreans, meanwhile, have seized all but Eritrea's provincial capital, Asmara, including the nation's only deep-water port, Massawa.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Gets Cold Shoulder From Politicians; Protests Feared
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with supporters and protesters outside convention center. Picks up 8th graf, `After Mandela...'. Speech delayed until at least 11:35 a.m. EDT, departure for Detroit now scheduled for 1:50 p.m.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AX2, XMHB1
DOC.TEXT: City officials shunned Nelson Mandela on his arrival overnight in Miami, where the South African activist's embrace of Cuba's Fidel Castro has driven a wedge between blacks and Cuban-Americans. About 300 demonstrators today joined an estimated 2,000 people outside a convention center where Mandela was to speak. The demonstrators, mostly Cuban-Americans, waved placards protesting Mandela's praise of Castro. ``Mandela is a traitor,'' said Ricardo Acabader, who wrapped himself in the Cuban flag. ``I'm here to fight for human rights.'' Police kept the two groups apart, although they shouted back and forth with megaphones and at least one fistfight was broken up. Mandela, who earlier Wednesday laid a wreath at the grave of Martin Luther King Jr. in Atlanta, arrived at Miami's airport just before midnight to none of the fanfare with which he was met in the four other U.S. cities he has visited. ``We do feel somewhat embarrassed,'' Gerald McEntee, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said after welcoming Mandela. ``Embarrassed for the state of Florida and embarrassed for Dade County.'' A crowd of about 200 people who greeted Mandela outside his hotel early today chanted ``Free South Africa'' and then ``Free South Florida'' and finally ``Where is Suarez?'' _ a reference to Miami Mayor Xavier Suarez, who denounced Mandela for his support of Castro. ``We're here to show him our love and appreciation,'' said Doris Dorcilini. ``We're unhappy that our local politicians are not doing the same. We're going to remember this when they need us.'' Mandela, 71, was scheduled to speak today to the AFSCME convention, but his speech was delayed by 2{ hours. The 1.25 million-member union has been a strong supporter of Mandela's African National Congress. He was to head to Detroit later in the day. Inside the convention hall, only a small group of Miami-area officials waited for Mandela, including Dade County Commissioner Charles Dusseau. ``In Miami, opinions tend to be very heartfelt,'' he said. ``That's why you get this kind of reaction. There's been a lot of suffering on both sides, and it's difficult for each side to understand the other.'' After Mandela last week reaffirmed his support for Castro, the Miami City Commission, with three Cuban-American members, dropped plans for a welcome proclamation. Five Cuban-American mayors issued a statement condemning his support for Castro. Mayor Alex Daoud of this largely Jewish city criticized Mandela for supprting not only Castro but the Palestine Liberation Organization and Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. Leaders of Miami's black community, wracked by racial violence four times in the past decade, pledged to avenge the slight to Mandela. ``He is our brother,'' said Johnnie McMillian, president of Miami's NAACP chapter. ``If they say he's not welcome, they're saying we're not welcome, too.'' In an often-moving visit to Atlanta on Wednesday, Mandela paid silent tribute to the slain leader of the U.S. civil rights movement, then borrowed from King's ``I Have a Dream'' speech at a sold-out rally at 46,000-seat Grant Field. ``His dreams are certainly going to see the light of day in our country,'' Mandela said. ``Let freedom ring in South Africa! We will continue to struggle until we have transformed South Africa into a united, non-racial, non-sexist, democratic country.'' Although King espoused non-violence, several prominent civil rights leaders defended Mandela's refusal to renounce force in the struggle for racial equality in South Africa. ``We who are thoroughly committed to the advocacy of non-violence nonetheless respect the right of oppressed people everywhere to seek their own liberation,'' the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference that King founded, said during a gathering at Big Bethel AME Church. ``Rev. Lowery has spoken for all of us and he spoke well,'' King's widow, Coretta Scott King, said to Mandela. ``We support you; we love you; we revere you.'' Mandela said black South Africans face a different battle than the one King led. ``Unlike you, we are still under the grip of white supremacy,'' Mandela said. To reporters he added: ``Non-violence is a good policy when conditions permit.''

DOC.HEAD: Jailed Reporter in Texas Refused Emergency Request
DOC.TEXT: A Supreme Court justice today refused to help a Texas television news reporter who Wednesday began a six-month jail term for refusing to surrender the name of a confidential source in a police killing. Justice Byron R. White, acting without any comment, denied an emergency request by Brian Karem, a reporter for KMOL-TV in San Antonio. The request had sought to postpone Karem's sentence while he appeals the contempt-of-court finding against him. Karem, speaking from the Bexar County Jail steps Wednesday, said, ``I sure don't want to do six months in jail but I'm going to keep my promise.'' Karem defied three court orders to turn over confidential notes of a telephone interview with one of two jailed murder suspects last year. Lawyers for the two suspects in the case say they have to know who arranged the interviews to assure a fair trial. Karem has said the source fears for his life if his identity is revealed. The jailing stems from an interview Karem conducted last year with capital murder defendant Henry Hernandez, accused with his brother, Julian, in the March 1989 shooting death of policeman Gary Williams. During the interview, Henry Hernandez said he shot the officer in self-defense. Prosecutors also want Karem's notes, to be sure that no law enforcement officer made promises that could affect the outcome of the case in exchange for letting Hernandez talk to Karem. The case is Karem vs. Priest, A-929.

DOC.HEAD: Head of Justice Department's Criminal Division Quitting
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with new grafs 1-8 to UPDATE with announcement of resignation; picks up 8th graf pvs bg'ng, Following the ...
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Justice Department's criminal division today announced his resignation to enter private law practice, creating another vacancy in the agency's top ranks. Assistant Attorney General Edward S.G. Dennis Jr., a career federal prosecutor who has headed the criminal division since 1988, said in a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh that he plans to leave the Justice Department on Aug. 31. Dennis said in a statement that he will become a senior partner at the prestigious Philadelphia law firm of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius. Dennis's departure adds another vacancy to the top echelons of the Justice Department, which has been plagued by a series of personnel difficulties under Thornburgh. But officials stressed that Dennis's resignation is unrelated to the recent staff turmoil, which came to a head in May when Deputy Attorney General Donald B. Ayer resigned. Nevertheless, two sources said Dennis had grown frustrated with Thornburgh's management style, which had centralized decision making in the attorney general's office. In a statement, Dennis said Thornburgh ``has provided outstanding leadership to the department, and I am delighted to have had the opportunity to work under him.'' In a letter to President Bush, Dennis said his decision to leave ``is based upon family considerations and my feeling that I will not be a complete lawyer until I succeed in the private practice of law.'' Following the resignation of Ayer, who sources say was frozen out of decision making, Thornburgh reassigned two longtime aides who had served him when he was Pennsylvania governor. The reassignment of chief spokesman David Runkel and chief of staff Robert S. Ross Jr. was an attempt to counter criticism that Thornburgh was surrounded by a ``palace guard'' of loyalists, officials conceded. William P. Barr, the acting deputy attorney general who has been nominated to take that job permanently, told the Senate Judiciary Committee Wednesday that he is restoring the traditional role of the agency's No. 2 position. Barr, appearing at his confirmation hearing, said Thornburgh's staff took on more responsibility than the attorney general intended because of the difficulty recruiting new people at the end of the Reagan administration. Thornburgh, who took office in August 1988, was asked to stay on as Bush's attorney general. The personnel difficulties continued, however. Thornburgh's first choice to be deputy, Robert Fiske, was scuttled by conservatives who objected to the New York lawyers's involvement in judicial screening by the American Bar Association. Dennis, who is the first black to head the Justice Department's criminal division, also served as acting deputy attorney general last year. A former U.S. attorney in Philadelphia, Dennis will join the national litigation group of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius. Officials noted that as a Reagan administration holdover, Dennis long had plans to leave the department, particularly because he commutes daily from his home near Philadelphia. Several other nominations for vacant positions are pending in the Senate. Lee Rawls was recently nominated to head the Office of Legislative Affairs to replace Carol Crawford, who resigned last winter following a series of bureaucratic turf wars.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Consider Reviving Lawsuit Against Indiana Prosecutor
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to consider reviving a lawsuit against an Indiana prosecutor who advised police to hypnotize a woman suspected of shooting her children. The court said it will review a ruling that the prosecutor is immune from being sued for such conduct. The case stems from a shooting at the home of Cathy Burns in Muncie, Ind., on Sept. 2, 1982. Ms. Burns, who worked as a police dispatcher in Muncie, said an intruder shot and wounded her two sons, Eddie Griffin and Denny Sells, while they slept and knocked her unconscious. A message scrawled on the bathroom mirror in lipstick said, ``I took what you loved most.'' Police suspected Ms. Burns shot her sons and planned to ask her to submit to hypnosis after she passed lie detector and voice stress tests. Chief Deputy Prosecutor Richard Reed of Delaware County, Ind., advised the police to go ahead with the hypnosis. The police officers said they doubted the technique was lawful because they had been told during their police academy training that hypnotizing suspects was unacceptable. Under hypnosis, Ms. Burns identified the assailant as ``Katie'' and also referred to herself at one point as ``Katie.'' The police officers concluded that she had a split personality and regarded her statement under hypnosis as a confession. The police then obtained a search warrant after misleading a judge by not disclosing that her statement was made while hypnotized. The judge later ruled the statement inadmissible and Reed dropped the prosecution. But Ms. Burns said Reed continued making statements to the news media saying he was convinced of her guilt. Ms. Burns then sued the deputy prosecutor, accusing him of violating her civil rights. A federal judge threw out the suit. The ruling was upheld in Feburary by the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. ``A prosecutor is absolutely immune from suit when acting as a legal advisor to police officers,'' the appeals court said. The case would be different if Reed had participated in administering the hypnosis, the appeals court said. But it said it did not regard what Reed did as participating in the investigation. The case is Burns vs. Reed, 89-1715.

DOC.HEAD: Marcos-Khashoggi Case Heading for Jury After Prosecution Rebuttal
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos and Adnan Khashoggi heard themselves described as willing participants in a complex scheme of fraud and deception as government prosecutors wrapped up their case against the pair. Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella delivered a final, stinging rebuttal to the defense on Thursday. He stacked packs of Philippine pesos on the rail of the jury box to dramatize his claim that Mrs. Marcos knew her husband, the late President Ferdinand Marcos, was enriching himself by stealing millions from his country's treasury. And he charged that Khashoggi knew a U.S. federal court injunction had frozen the Marcoses' U.S. assets before he agreed in 1986 to backdate documents to show that he, not they, owned four New York buildings and some paintings. ``When you look at all the evidence you will be convinced beyond a reasonable doubt that Imelda Marcos is guilty and that Adnan Khashoggi also is guilty,'' LaBella told the jurors. Today, U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan instructed the jurors on the law in the case. The jurors, who will be sequestered at the close of his charge, were to begin deliberations in the afternoon. Keenan said the jurors can convict only if they find the defendants' guilt was proven beyond a reasonable doubt after a part of a broader package including spending cuts to reduce the deficit. On Thursday, the Treasury received nearly $5.39 in bids for every $1 of four year notes that it wanted to sell as part of a $8.31 four-year note auction. That was the strongest demand on record for an issue of that maturity, market analysts said. ``The market has handled the supply this week pretty well,'' said James Winder, money market economist for Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. In addition to the four-year note auction, the government sold $17.2 billion in three-month and six-month bills on Monday and $11.25 billion in two-year notes on Tuesday. Winder said there may also be ``some lingering positive feeling from the president's change of heart on taxes.'' There were no new economic reports out today, but Winder said the ``general perception is our economy is weak.'' Economic weakness increases chances that the Federal Reserve will encourage lower interest rates, a developmnet that would boost bond prices. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments were up 1-16 point, intermediate maturities advanced by between 5-32 point and \ point and long-term issues were up as much as 9-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., the financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, edged up 1.54 to 1,159.11. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.99 percent as the discount slipped 3 basis points to 7.74 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 8.05 percent as the discount lost 2 basis points to 7.64 percent. Yields on one-year bills dropped to 8.07 percent as the discount fell 3 basis points to 7.54 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 5-16 percent, unchanged from late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Parliament Begins Debating Independence Moratorium
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's prime minister today urged parliament to freeze the republic's declaration of independence, saying Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would then lift an economic blockade and begin talks. Kazimera Prunskiene, opening a critical debate on the proposed moratorium, said Lithuania could leave in place all subsequent decisions. Those include replacement of the Soviet Constitution by a Lithuanian document and a resolution suggesting that Lithuanian youth can ignore the Soviet draft. The debate in the Lithuanian Supreme Council parliament began after Gorbachev held a series of discussions with Mrs. Prunskiene and Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis to try to solve their dispute over Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. The streets of the Lithuanian capital were calm, and there was little visible evidence of the economic blockade in which the Soviet Union has cut off most natural gas, all oil, and a variety of other raw materials and manufactured goods. The blockade, imposed in April, has put nearly 50,000 of the republic's 1.1 million workers out of work. ``The moratorium is only on the declaration of independence, not on all the other acts,'' Mrs. Prunskiene said. ``It's a political statement.'' ``The status of Lithuania doesn't change and the Supreme Council remains the same,'' she said, pressing the recalcitrant parliament to accept a compromise. Soviet officials have not commented on the talks Tuesday and Wednesday between Gorbachev and Lithuanian officials. The only official statement released late Tuesday said talks with the republic of 3.8 million people could begin only if it declares a moratorium. It said the talks can only be held in the framework of a nationwide discussion of a new treaty of union among republics. Lithuania's compromise proposal calls for a three-month moratorium on independence, but the moratorium would not take effect until the Soviet Union opened formal negotiations with leaders of the Baltic republic, government spokesman Ceslovas Jursenas said. Landsbergis, who has been less enthusiastic about a compromise than Mrs. Prunskiene, did not clearly endorse one in his statement to the parliament. But he did tell deputies that ``it's most important to get the negotiations started.'' He said the Lithuanian leadership wanted to choose the best conditions for entering critical talks over just how separation could be achieved. The Soviet Union forcibly annexed Lithuania, along with its Baltic neighbors Estonia and Latvia, in 1940. All three republics have been seeking to secede, but Lithuania has taken the lead. One member of parliament, Eduardas Vilkas, said after listening to Mrs. Prunskiene that he understood her to be requesting ``a political step, not a juridical one, to say that Gorbachev is not the loser.'' Vilkas said he favored a compromise but that many Lithuanian legislators opposed the deal. ``This is very difficult psychologically for many deputies,'' he said. Algis Cekuolis, an adviser to the parliament, predicted that the discussion would be sharp. Some deputies insisted on a two-thirds majority before agreeing to the compromise, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Heat Wave Bakes Southwest From California to Texas
With PM-Fires, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, `After back-to-back ...' to UPDATE with overnight low in Phoenix. Subs 5th graf, ``I liken ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with fires in Southern Califnornia, conditions in Nebraska, Wyoming. Picks up 6th graf pvs: `Today's forecast ...'
DOC.TEXT: Phoenix opened shelters for the homeless and Southern Californians headed for the beach for relief from a heat wave gripping the Southwest for a fourth day today. The death toll rose to at least six in Arizona and California. Temperatures soared into the 100s from California to Texas on Wednesday, causing blackouts in Los Angeles and two more heat-related deaths in Arizona. After back-to-back, all-time records of 120 and 122 degrees, the heat abated only slightly Wednesday in Phoenix, topping out at 118 _ a record for the date. This morning the temperature plummeted but it was still a hot 87. An enormous high-pressure system over New Mexico created the heat wave by beating back the Pacific Ocean's normal cooling influence. ``I liken it to a huge umbrella sitting over the Southwest and it's just baking under there,'' said National Weather Service meteorologist Art Lessard. In Southern California, fires worsened by four years of drought and the searing heat destroyed some 300 houses, forced thousands of people from their homes, injured scores of firefighters and closed highways. One person was arrested on suspicion of arson in Orange County. Nebraska and Wyoming also sweltered under record-breaking heat. In Wyoming, U.S. Forest Service officials expressed concern that the hot, dry breezy weather could quickly dry out brushy areas and increase the fire danger. Today's forecast offered no relief. The weather service said highs would be in the 100s in the inland cities and slightly lower elsewhere through Sunday. Phoenix officials opened shelters for the homeless and distributed fans to the poor and elderly. Bill Maguire, a doctor at Maricopa Medical Center, said 15 to 20 people had been treated for heat-related emergencies by mid-afternoon, up from 10 on Tuesday. ``It's the cumulative effect,'' Maguire said. ``If their apartment doesn't have air conditioning, maybe they made it through yesterday and pooped out today.'' In Yuma, Ariz., some 30 inmates at the county jail filed protests with the sheriff's office after the tempterature in the 208-bed jail hit 98 degrees, 13 degrees above the maximum set under a federal court order on jail conditions. In Los Angeles, the mercury climbed to 109, seven degrees over the 1976 mark for the date. Power outages from air conditioning and other uses were scattered throughout the city; 5,000 customers lost electricity for a few hours. Utilities from the coast inland to Las Vegas asked the public to conserve electricity. Temperatures topped 100 in valleys north and east of Los Angeles. Palm Springs hit 116 by early afternoon. Normally balmy San Diego was a record 91. Los Angeles County lifeguards bolstered their forces to handle the throngs seeking relief at the beach, where temperatures were about 20 degrees lower. In Lubbock, Texas, the Postal Service told customers to expect minor delays in delivery because carriers would be taking more breaks to drink water and cool off. Lubbock is sweltering through the hottest June on record, with 18 days of temperatures over 100. ``We are concerned for their health,'' said Don Jones, postal field operations director. ``This is bad weather for them.'' Not everyone was bothered by the heat. ``I live in Arizona. I'm used to it. That's the reason I live here. The hotter it gets the more it keeps people away. I've lived here all my life. I love it,'' said Anthony Hardin of Phoenix. A 57-year-old suburban Phoenix man died after working outdoors at his home. His body temperature had reached 108, police said. Later Wednesday, a 45-year-old woman was found dead in her downtown apartment, where the temperature had hit 105. The deaths of three other people Tuesday in Phoenix also were ruled heat-related. Authorities in Los Angeles said a 4-year-old boy died in a parked car with the windows rolled up Tuesday.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Armored Car Robbery, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0510,0601
DOC.HEAD: Investigators Suspect `Inside Job' in Armored-Car Holdup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `Meloni said...', with four grafs to UPDATE with details on van. Picks up 13 graf, `Michael Bucci...'.
DOC.TEXT: FBI and sheriff's officials said the $10.8 million holdup of an armored car may have been an inside job, and they began questioning past and present employees of the courier service. The robbery by at least two men with a shotgun Tuesday was the biggest armored car heist in U.S. history. ``The fact that they had so much money ... it's logical that they had some information,'' said Paul Bellito, an FBI spokesman in Buffalo. ``People have to be somewhat familiar with the routes of travel, what their work habits are, where they stop.'' The armored car was seized at gunpoint after the driver and guard stopped at a convenience store for coffee and sandwiches while making a cash delivery to the Federal Reserve Bank in Buffalo, officials said. No one was injured. The driver and guard told authorities they had been forced to drive to a wooded area, where they were bound, gagged and blindfolded. The robbers put money bags weighing at least 1,500 pounds into another vehicle and fled. The two employees of the Armored Motor Service of America were given a lie-detector test, said sheriff's spokesman Tom Ryan. He would not disclose the results. Capt. Neil Flood said dozens of past and present employees were being interviewed. ``You knock off an armored car, you've got to know something about the business,'' he said. Sheriff Andrew P. Meloni said the unidentified driver and guard had not been ruled out as suspects. FBI agent G. Robert Langford said one of the holdup men was in a brown outfit similar to the uniforms worn by the armored car company's guards. ``We don't know if that means he was an employee or if the uniform was used to gain access to the truck or to prevent him from attracting a lot of attention,'' Langford said. Investigators also were trying to determine how the holdup men penetrated the car's gunport with a shotgun, the Democrat and Chronicle of Rochester reported today. The sliding metal hatch should have been locked, the paper said. Meloni said the van used in the robbery was found Wednesday as a result of a telephone tip. It was abandoned in the driveway of a social club, about five miles from where the holdup took place. ``Finding the van quickly is a real break for us,'' Meloni said today. ``Now the public may be able to tell us where the van has been.'' The van, originally dark blue, had been recently painted dull gray. The van was filled with covered money trays from the armored car. Meloni said some cash was found in envelopes in the van, but he would not say how much. ``It was very little, comparatively speaking,'' he said. Michael Bucci, AMSA executive vice president, told the Syracuse Post-Standard that the convenience store stop violated company policy. However, AMSA controller George Clark said Wednesday there is no rule prohibiting stops. Langford said company insiders are often involved in armored car robberies, which are particularly difficult to pull off. ``In a crime like this, you often see the involvement of a current or former employee who might have access to information about routes, times, and the amount of money that is being transported,'' he said. ``But it's just one possibility.''

DOC.HEAD: Hussein Warns Iraq Is Ready For War
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein says his country is prepared for a war he views as ``inevitable'' unless Israel stops what he calls its aggressive policies, a report published today said. The Wall Street Journal quoted Hussein as saying other countries are mistaken if they believe Iraq is too tired from eight years of fighting with Iran to ``indulge in a new war.'' ``Their assessment is totally wrong,'' he said. ``We shall respond to an Israeli attack whenever it comes and wherever.'' Hussein called Israel an ``evil entity'' and said the United States was indifferent to Mideast concerns, but he repeatedly said Iraq would strike only if Israel strikes first. If war happens, he promised it would not end quickly and ``the outcome will not be one Israel desires.'' ``Iraq is in possession of binary chemical weapons. Our scientists and military men calculate this is sufficient enough to deter an Israeli nuclear attack,'' he said. `If the great powers use any opportunity they see available to suppress others and to reap benefits at others' expense, then the others will find themselves in a position that will force them to use any means available,'' he warned.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Oilman Incensed At Corporate Japan's Force-Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 8th graf, `Koito President to CORRECT name to Matsuura, sted Matsuuda; Subs 11th graf, `Boone Co. ... to INSERT number of seats Pickens wants and total number on board; INSERTS 1 graf after 20th graf, `Greenmail involves ...' with Pickens greenmail quote.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TOK8
DOC.TEXT: Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens Jr. angrily stalked out of a shareholders meeting today after an auto parts company refused to give him a seat on its board of directors. Earlier, Pickens and 52 American shareholders of his private investment firm, Boone Co., marched into a luxury hotel near the headquarters of Koito Manufacturing Co. for the c shareholders meeting. Three hours later Pickens left in a huff before the vote on his proposal for seats ompany's annualon the board of Koito's directors. ``It was a sham, an absolute farce. Here today, Koito completely showed the world what it's all about in corporate Japan,'' he said. He charged that corporate Japan is a ``closed system'' because Koito managers wouldn't answer his questions. ``If that kind of meeting was in the United States, I'm telling you, they'd put them all in jail. It's a lousy deal.'' At the meeting, Boone and others of his entourage asked a numbseases such as AIDS and cancer. But Wiles has no plans to ``create a bureaucratic situation or be picky about the little things,'' like an errant piece of garbage or a slightly lethargic mouse. ``I'm looking at the bigger picture,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter Refuses to Hand Over Notes, Surrenders to Jail Officials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to UPDATE with Supreme Court justice denying request; incorporating Washington-dated PM-Scotus-Reporter, a0569. Picks up 2nd graf, `I sure...'. SUBS grafs 8-10, ``Karem said...', with two grafs to conform. Picks up 11th graf, `It does...'.
DOC.TEXT: A Supreme Court justice today refused to help a Texas television news reporter who has begun serving a six-month jail term for refusing to surrender the name of a source. Justice Byron R. White, without comment, denied an emergency request by Brian Karem of San Antonio's KMOL-TV. The request sought to postpone Karem's sentence while he appeals the contempt-of-court finding against him. ``I sure don't want to do six months in jail,'' KMOL-TV reporter Brian Karem said on the Bexar County Jail steps as he surrendered to begin serving the jail term Wednesday. ``But I'm going to keep my promise.'' The reporter has defied three court orders to turn over confidential notes of a telephone interview last year with one of the two suspects jailed in the murder case. Prosecution and defense lawyers, who are preparing for the murder case, contend they need to know who arranged the interview. Karem has said the source fears for his life if his identity is revealed. ``We can't live up to our principles every day in life,'' Karem told reporters as he entered the jail. ``But I think this is an important enough issue and I feel strongly enough about it that I want to live up to how I believe.'' Karem had hoped to stay out of jail while he appealed the contempt citations. But those hopes ended Tuesday when the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals refused to issue a stay. Sheriff Harlon Copeland met Karem on the steps of the jail. The reporter was accompanied by KMOL news director Ron Harig, station manager Bob Donohue and Karem's father, James. Karem said his only hope for release would be for the source to come forward or for the U.S. Supreme Court to block his sentence pending appeal. ``It does not look very good for the First Amendment today,'' said his attorney, Laurence Macon. Harig said the station would hold Karem's job open and continue to pay him while he is jailed. The jailing stems from an interview Karem conducted last year with capital murder defendant Henry David Hernandez, accused with his brother Julian in the March 1989 shooting death of police officer Gary Williams. Henry Hernandez said during the interview that he shot the officer in self-defense. Prosecution and defense attorneys say they have to know who arranged the interview so that they can determine whether it can be used in the trial under rules of evidence. Henry Hernandez' attorney does not want the interview admitted in the trial. Julian Hernandez' attorney does.

DOC.HEAD: Snow, High Winds Sweep Across Southern Australia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs with police cadets suffering hypothermia.
DOC.TEXT: While the American West bakes under the summer sun, winter is arriving in earnest in southern Australia, with heavy snowfall, high wind and hail causing traffic havoc in some areas. In Sydney, strong wind uprooted trees and snaped power lines on Wednesday night, cutting power to hundreds of families in the city's north and southeast. Marine police were kept busy on Sydney Harbor after boats broke their moorings. Some highways were closed by snow and sleet in highland areas of New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania states. A Weather Bureau spokesman said the high temperature was just 49 degrees in Melbourne on Wednesday, the city's lowest June maximum in four years. A gale warning was in effect for all Victorian and Tasmanian coastal waters. Some areas reported wind of up to 60 mph on Wednesday night. Heavy snowfalls and blizzards were reported at ski resorts in northeastern Victoria state, and more rough weather was in the forecast. A spokesman for the Bureau of Meteorology in Tasmania, an island state off Australia's southern coast, said temperatures in the capital, Hobart, had dipped almost 9 degrees below average to a minimum of 36 degrees. Twenty first-year police recruits were airlifted out of Tasmania's central highlands today after suffering mild hypothermia, frostbite and fatigue. The superintendent of the Tasmanian Police Academy, Richard McCreadie, said the recruits, aged about 18 to 25, and their three instructors were into their third day of survival training in the Walls of Jerusalem National Park on Wednesday when gales, snow and sub-freezing temperatures hit. ``My understanding is that they are only going to be first-aid cases,'' McCreadie said. ``Obviously, conditions have been very, very difficult and these kids have not had much experience.''

DOC.HEAD: ANC Leader Touches Raw Nerve with Tactics But US Not without Sin Either
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT:
Nelson Mandela touched a raw nerve among some Americans with his effusive praise of the likes of Libya's Moammar Gadhafi and Cuba's Fidel Castro and his refusal to renounce violence. In Miami, where Mandela arrived late Wednesday, city officials bowed to the wishes of angry Cuban-Americans and shunned the celebrated former prisoner. The Miami City Commission dropped plans for a welcome proclamation last week after Mandela lauded Castro. In effect, Mandela's critics are telling him to be more discriminating in his choice of friends. But those same critics might ponder some of the allies the United States has had over the years. Panama's Manuel Noriega was considered a strategic ally until the United States turned its back on him three years ago. Before that, there were a host of military presidents in Latin America who enjoyed U.S. confidence and generosity. In Africa, few leaders have wielded a heavier hand than Zaire's Mobutu Sese Seko, a close U.S. ally for years. In 1972, President Nixon embraced China at the time of the Cultural Revolution, a period of extraordinary brutality in that country. In the 1930's, Joseph Stalin was responsible for the deaths of millions but that didn't stop President Franklin Roosevelt from joining forces with him against the Nazis during World War II. Basically, Mandela's defense is somewhat the same as that which the United States has used in defending its selection of allies: the enemy of my enemy is my friend. Columnist Charles Krauthammer sympathizes with Mandela's position. ``One can hardly expect of a beleaguered people the high-minded, clean-handed sifting of allies of a Sweden,'' Krauthammer wrote. The United States felt it could not afford to be choosy about its allies in the life-or-death struggle against Hitler. Mandela feels the same way about apartheid. ``Our attitude toward any country is determined by the attitude of that country toward apartheid,'' Mandela said last week. He feels a kinship for Yasser Arafat because the Palestine Liberation Organization, like Mandela's African National Congress, ``is fighting for the right of self-determination.'' Those remarks have not gone unnoticed. Sen. Connie Mack, R-Fla., has criticized Mandela for his support for the ``terrorist triad'' of Castro, Gadhafi and Arafat. Rep. Lawrence Smith, D-Fla., pointedly boycotted Mandela's address Tuesday to a joint meeting of Congress. Others, like Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, attended but withheld applause. The Washington Post editorialized that it was ``hardly noble'' of Mandela, given the articulate way he portrays human rights conditions in his own country, to decline comment on the ``ruthless, even murderous places'' where the ANC has allies. On the question of use of force, President Bush said Monday, with Mandela standing at his side, that a resort to violence to resolve South Africa's problems is improper. Mandela replied that he could not renounce violence if peaceful efforts fail. He drew criticism from some members of Congress but Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., thinks Bush is applying a double standard to South Africa in demanding an end to violence. ``Only in the case of South Africa has the doctrine of nonviolence emerged as a central element of our policy,'' said Wolpe, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Africa subcommittee. He said that in addition to invading Panama and bombing Libya, the United States has armed resistance fighters on three continents. In each case, the U.S. concluded that force was necessary as a last resort, something Mandela can identify with. ``If we are forced to resort to violence,'' he told Bush Monday, ``it is because we have no alternative whatsoever.''
EDITOR'S NOTE _ George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for the Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Canton Executes 39 in Crackdown on Crime
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-nine people were executed in the southern city of Canton for crimes ranging from prostitution to murder, a local newspaper reported. The Yangcheng Evening News said Wednesday the executions were carried out immediately after the sentences were announced by local courts. Nine people were executed for committing serious robberies, and seven people were sentenced to death for murder, the newspaper said. Those executed also included four people convicted of trading in arms and ammunition, and two convicted of engaging in prostitution, the paper said. Public Security Minister Wang Fang this month announced a new campaign on crime, focusing on murder and other serious offenses. Reports of arrests and executions have noticeably increased since late May, including the executions earlier this week of 14 drug traffickers. China launches anti-crime campaigns every few years, but without discernibly slowing the nation's growing crime rate. Executions are carried out by a single gunshot to the back of the head.

DOC.HEAD: Court Clerk Convicted of Stealing De Gaulle's Birth Certificate
DOC.TEXT: A court clerk received a four-month suspended prison sentence for stealing Charles De Gaulle's birth certificate from the office where she worked. Paulette Duriez, 51, was convicted Wednesday of taking the certificate home with her last October and replacing it with a photocopy. One of her duties at a high court office in Lille was to assure the safekeeping of legal documents. De Gaulle, born in 1890, was leader of the Free French forces during World War II and was president of France from 1959 to 1969. He died in 1970. He has been the focus of numerous commemorations this year marking the centennial of his birth and the 50th anniversary of his radio appeal for French resistance to Nazi occupation.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators Reach Agreement on Trade Deficit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Kaifu comment, details from the accord.
DOC.TEXT: Japanese and U.S. negotiators today reached an agreement to help trim the $49 billion U.S. trade deficit with Japan. They hailed the accord as an unprecedented step toward easing tensions between the two partners. President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu both issued statements saying the pact would enhance their countries' global partnership and also benefit other countries. ``I welcome and endorse this joint report,'' Bush said in Washington, as talks concluded at the Foreign Ministry in Tokyo. Kaifu said Japan may find it painful to implement the report. ``However, these measures are intended to achieve a major reform of the Japanese economy in the consumer's best interests,'' he said. Both leaders said that while Japan pledged in a 57-page report a raft of measures to improve foreign companies' access to its market, Washington had to reduce its budget deficit and improve the competitiveness of U.S. industry. Kaifu praised Bush's willingness to consider tax revenue increases as a deficit-reduction move. Bush commended Kaifu for ``his strong and courageous political leadership.'' The negotiations ran through four grueling days, an extension from the planned two days. There had been concern that this round in the so-called Structural Impediments Initiative might have to be continued next week to reach agreement. Linn Williams, the U.S. deputy trade representative, said: ``It is a remarkable thing that these two economies have done. I see this as a kind of joint leadership. Japan and the United States got together on difficult issues and worked together constructively. We should be pleased with the efforts and results.'' ``Particularly Prime Minister Kaifu and President Bush can be proud. They have done something no two other countries have done before,'' he added. Bush and Kaifu talked by telephone late Wednesday about Japan's final increased offer to boost public works spending, a key area of disagreement. Williams said the trade talks were ``an important influence'' on Bush's tax move, which is aimed at reducing the federal budget deficit. The deficit is regarded as a fundamental cause of the trade imbalance, because it fuels U.S. demand for consumption and imports from Japan. Raising U.S. tax revenues may thus reduce Japanese exports and cut the trade imbalance. Bush's announcement was followed by a Japanese compromise Wednesday to increase planned public works spending. That might help reduce the trade imbalance by increasing sales of U.S. products and construction services in Japan and soaking up some excess Japanese savings and investment funds. While Bush risked political flak over taxes, the Japanese worry about adding to inflation with a big increase in public works spending. The final draft shows Japan agreed to $2.77 trillion in public works spending over 10 years, up from $1.7 trillion in the 10 years to 1990. Other measures on the Japanese side aimed at improving foreign companies' access to the market include: _Submitting legislation by March to release more land for housing and buildings and to curb high land prices. _Attaining clearance within 24 hours of imports by 1991. _Having the Fair Trade Commission take more formal action in anti-monopoly cases instead of quiet persuasion. A bill is to go before the current session of Parliament to raise fines to deter cartels. _Having the commission increase its monitoring of transactions with the business groups called ``keiretsu'' to deter anti-competitive practices, publicize findings, enhance foreign companies' ability to sell goods to companies in such groups. _Amending the criminal code to increase fines against bid-rigging. _Using deregulation to speed the process for approving large retail stores, widen liquor sales and open the distribution system. _Increasing the number of patent examiners and other measures to shorten within five years the time to process patent applications from the current 37 months to 24 months. _Surveying and publicizing differences between high Japanese prices and foreign prices; having the government implement 52 measures that have been identified as likely to reduce such price differentials. _Abolishing a law giving the government power to restrict direct foreign investment if it could affect similar Japanese domestic businesses. On the U.S. side, the federal budget deficit was the lead item, and the report included the statement Bush made Tuesday accepting ``tax revenue increases'' _ a departure from his campaign promise of ``Read my lips'' _ as a way to cut the deficit. Other American promises: _Urging Congress to pass a bill to create family savings accounts and other measures to increase the low U.S. savings level. _Increasing federal funding for research and development. _Partially relaxing a ban on exports of California heavy crude oil. _Creating more programs to promote exports. _Enacting measures to reach goals of excellence in education and to improve the quality of the U.S. work force.

DOC.HEAD: Strike Against Government Cripples Bangladesh
DOC.TEXT: A strike to protest new taxes and to demand the resignation of President Hussain Muhammad Ershad shut down shops, businesses, transport and schools over most of the country Thursday, news reports said. Most major towns, including the capital, were without public transportation during the 12-hour work stoppage. Groups of demonstrators paraded on the streets, United News of Bangladesh said. Opposition leaders threatened more protests. ``We are planning a non-cooperation movement against Ershad,'' said Kamal Hossain, a leader of the Awami League party, one of the organizers of the strike Thursday. ``No taxes to Ershad government. That will be our next slogan.'' The opposition claimed that 60 people were injured in police attacks on protesters Thursday. Police officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said no one was injured. They said about 100 picketers were detained but were released when the strike was over. Soon after the strike began at 6 a.m., Ershad left for Beijing on a five-day state visit. United News said protesters threw stones at the car of a government minister who had gone to see the president off at the airport. Police chased away the demonstrators and the car escaped damage, the news agency said. Ershad, a 59-year-old former army general, took power in a bloodless coup in 1982. The opposition accuses him of rigging votes to win subsequent presidential and parliamentary elections. An opposition movement to force Ershad's resignation gathered strength in 1987 and early 1988 but dissipated amid differences between the two major opposition parties _ the Awami League and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party. But the government's announcement this month to raise taxes has united the opposition again. Both major opposition parties said the proposals were ``anti-people,'' and they jointly organized a nationwide strike June 17. Thursday's strike went on as scheduled despite an announcement by Ershad on Monday that he was slashing the tax proposals and would not place any levies on kerosene oil, edible oil, soap and salt. Opposition leaders said the cuts were not enough and demanded dropping of all new taxes and Ershad's resignation. The annual per capita income of Bangladesh, one of the poorest countries in the world, is about $168.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Hero Buried; Search for Survivors Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with boy pulled alive from rubble, in coma; pickup 3rd pvs, `Officials of...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY22
DOC.TEXT: A 9-year-old boy was pulled alive from the rubble of his earthquake-flattened home where he was trapped for nearly a week, the official news media said today. Also today, a legislator who died during relief efforts following the deadly June 21 quake in northernwestern Iran was given a hero's burial. The official Islamic Republic News Agency said the 9-year-old, Morteza Amirpour, was found by Soviet rescuers late Wednesday next to the bodies of family members in the ruins of the village of Rahmatabad near Rudbar, 125 miles northwest of Tehran. It said the boy, who was in a coma, was taken to a provincial hospital for treatment after being freed 162 hours after the quake. The agency provided no other detail in its three-sentence report. IRNA said 15 aftershocks Wednesday and today jolted the stricken northwestern provinces of Gilan and Zanjan, which bore the brunt of the June 21 earthquake. Officials of the Red Crescent, the Iranian equivalent of the Red Cross, said Wednesday that they have counted 40,000 dead and 60,000 injured. Government officials said earlier that 50,000 Iranians were killed, 200,000 injured and 500,000 left homeless. Nearly 200 transports from 26 countries, including the United States, have airlifted urgently needed supplies in since the weekend, despite criticism of Western humanitarian aid by Iran's isolationalist radicals. IRNA said Mohammad Hassan Eftekhari, a member of the 270-seat Parliament who died in a helicopter crash Wednesday in the northwest, was given a hero's burial in his hometown of Fouman in northern Iran. Senior military and government officials attended a funeral procession for him in Rasht, the agency reported. Four of the other 14 relief workers aboard the army's U.S.-built CH-47 Chinook transport were critically injured when it crashed in bad weather in the mountainous Kelishom region in the southern sector of the quake zone. Eftekhari had ``constantly supervised the relief operations'' since the earthquake struck, IRNA reported. The Geophysics Center at Tehran University said the strongest of the latest aftershocks measured 4.8 on the Richter Scale. The killer quake registered between 7.3 and 7.7 on the scale, which is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake. There have been more than 400 aftershocks in the devastated region in the last week, adding to the chaos and misery. IRNA quoted an unidentified senior official at the Tehran center as saying the tectonic fault that caused the deadly quake was ``gradually stabilizing.'' That was welcome news for the thousands of Iranian and foreign rescue workers who have been clawing through the rubble of 342 flattened towns and villages in the rugged region. The aftershocks have blocked roads, halting truck convoys carrying tents, blankets, medicine and food into the pulverized provinces. IRNA said one of the latest temblors caused landslides blocked a key road between the devastated city of Rasht on the Caspian Sea and Rudbar to the southwest for the second time in a week. ``Efforts are under way to clear the road,'' the agency reported. Relief officials in the stricken region northwest of Tehran said that with hope running out of still finding survivors trapped in the rubble, the relief operation is concentrating more on taking care of the living. IRNA and official Tehran Radio reported another 20 aircraft carrying hundreds of tons of aid in an international relief operation have landed at Tehran's Mehrabad airport in the last 24 hours.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Thursday by the Supreme Court.
DEATH PENALTY
A day after it upheld Arizona's death penalty law, the court let stand a ruling that had the effect of overturning most existing death sentences in Arizona, Idaho and Montana. By a 4-3 vote, the justices refused to reinstate the death sentence of John Harvey Adamson, convicted of murdering newspaper reporter Don Bolles in 1976. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals previously had struck down Adamson's death sentence. But the justices Wednesday upheld Arizona's death penalty law in a decision directly conflicting with the 9th Circuit court's ruling in Adamson's case. In throwing out Adamson's sentence, the appeals court struck down a key provision of Arizona's death penalty law _ one which was declared valid by the Supreme Court on Wednesday. Idaho and Montana have the same provisions in their death penalty laws. They allow judges, rather than juries, to impose the death sentence. The case is Lewis vs. Adamson, 88-1553.
FAT STUDENT
