The court agreed to study the appeal of a Rhode Island college ordered to pay nearly $44,000 to a former nursing student kicked out because she was too fat. The justices said they will review one aspect of the case in which Salve Regina College in Newport, R.I., was ordered to pay the award to Sharon L. Russell. The case is Salve Regina College vs. Russell, 89-1629.
TAWANA BRAWLEY
The court refused to block an investigation into alleged misconduct by a lawyer who represented Tawana Brawley, the black New York teen-ager who said she was the victim of a racially motivated assault. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by C. Vernon Mason, who says the investigation is a form of illegal harassment. The case is Mason vs. Department Disciplinary Committee, 89-1752.
HYPNOSIS
The court agreed to consider reviving a lawsuit against an Indiana prosecutor who advised police to hypnotize a woman suspected of shooting her children. The court said it will review a ruling that the prosecutor is immune from being sued for such conduct. The case is Burns vs. Reed, 89-1715.

DOC.HEAD: Dummies All Around at Convention
DOC.TEXT: Since he was 8 years old, Al Getler has wanted to spend his spare time with dummies. He is 29 now, and doing just that. Getler is a part-time ventriloquist who is chairing that 16th-annual International Ventriloquists Convention, a three-day event that began Thursday in this northern Kentucky city. Getler, 29, of Mullica Hill, N.J., works as a full-time newspaper circulation manager in Atlantic City. But ventriloquism _ which he does part-time _ is his first love. ``During the week, I wear a tie, I'm in the office, I do all the mundane things managers do. On the weekends, I'm on my own. I grab my dolls and go to work,'' he said in an interview at the convention hotel. Getler brought his family _ his 6-year-old daughter has taken up ventriloquism _ and his three dummies with him. He had these exchanges with one of his dummies, named Floyd L. Smith: Dummy: ``I like girls and fast cars. Or, fast girls and cars.'' Getler: ``How old are you?'' Dummy (leaning over to show the top of his wooden head): ``Count my rings.'' Getler said the dummy affords a socially acceptable way to deliver sharp verbal jabs to spectators. ``Floyd's my outlet,'' he said. Getler said he is a self-taught ventriloquist, drawn to the art by curiosity after watching ventriloquist Paul Winchell on television. He got his first dummy for Christmas when he was 8, and taught himself in front of a mirror. The convention is sponsored by the Vent Haven Museum, established by the late William Shakespeare Berger, a businessman and amateur ventriloquist. Berger died in 1972 and what had been his private collection of dummies and ventriloquism memorabilia opened to the public in 1973.

DOC.HEAD: University of Minnesota Dumps Dance Line
DOC.TEXT: The University of Minnesota has ordered its all-female dance line to stop performing at men's sports events, saying the high-kicking dancers don't represent the image of women the university wants to promote. ``I believe that an all-women's dance line at a men's athletic event which is predominantly dominated by men sends all the wrong signals and has all the wrong connotations,'' Rick Heydinger, university vice president for external relations, said Wednesday. Dance line coach Andrea Lilleberg said the dancers feel they have been discriminated against. ``Heydinger has taken it upon himself to decide what is best for women in general. Part of women's rights is the right to choose what organization you want to be affiliated with,'' she said. Without sponsorship and financial backing, the 16-member dance line will become a university club left to raise its own funding.

DOC.HEAD: CIA Reports Lower Pay, Layoffs Hit China's Stability
DOC.TEXT: Layoffs and lower pay for workers have undermined social stability in China after last year's military march into Tiananmen Square, the CIA told Congress on Thursday. The agency predicted that part of a 15 percent increase in Chinese military spending will go to raise pay and bolster troop morale after several years of inflation running over 10 percent. When inflation is taken into account, it will be the first increase in military spending in six years. ``A significant portion ... probably will also go to purchase new equipment, such as riot-control gear for military rapid-reaction units, and repaying the operational costs incurred by the military in enforcing martial law in Beijing and Lhasa during 1989,'' the report said. It gave a dark view of China's situation. ``Growing unemployment _ which has reached its highest level in a decade _ and falling urban living standards are undermining Beijing's efforts to reestablish the country's social stability, which remains tenuous a year following the government's suppression of the pro-democracy demonstrations,'' it said. The CIA report was given to the Joint Economic Committee. It quoted a Hong Kong press report, not further identified, as saying that there had been more than 600 cases of worker unrest in China in the last half of 1989. These included strikes, slowdowns, demonstrations and rallies. ``According to many accounts, layoffs have created an embittered and volatile class of unemployed workers,'' it went on. The report estimated that 60 million to 80 million workers have no regular jobs but move from place to place. Sen. Jeff Bingaman, who presided at the hearing, said that if the CIA assessment is correct, China's economy is in cold storage. ``The reform movement has been frozen partway between central planning and a free market,'' the New Mexico Democrat added. The CIA said that China's national income grew less than 4 percent last year, compared with growth of about 12 percent a year earlier. In the first five months of 1990, China's industry was increasing production at a rate of less than 2 percent annually. The government's budget deficit grew to a record 8 billion dollars, though it is small compared with the deficit of many other countries. Prospects are dim for China to return to an all-out move toward a market economy, the report said. That is the direction being taken by eastern European countries formerly under communist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats See S&L Bailout as Potent Political Issue for '92
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lede to CORRECT by deleting reference to Cuomo handbook; deletes 19th graf, New York Gov.; restores full Cuomo identification in 20th graf; picks up graf 21, Texas Sen.
DOC.TEXT: Mario Cuomo is promoting a bailout tax on the rich, Doug Wilder is calling for an inquiry, Lloyd Bentsen is lecturing on greed and Bob Kerrey is pounding at misplaced priorities. It's only 1990, but Democrats are seizing on the savings and loan mess _ that $200-billion-plus taxpayer nightmare _ as a chance to revive their party and help them win the White House in 1992. ``This is going to play to the most damaging Republican dimensions that they side with business and the rich,'' predicts Harrison Hickman, a Democratic polling consultant. Republicans, too, are out to score political points by blaming the Democrats. ``They're (Democrats) not going to sweep across that field without a lot of casualties,'' GOP strategist Kevin Phillips said. Hardly anyone disputes that Democrats and Republicans alike set in motion the 1980s deregulation process that ultimately led to the collapse of the S&L industry. Democrats as well as Republicans took money from S&L operators and lobbied federal regulators on their behalf. In fact, four of five senators under investigation in connection with such activities are Democrats. But the Democrats, prompted in part by Phillips' own new critique of government-fostered ``greed and glitz'' during the Reagan years, are aggressively defining the S&L debacle early and in their own terms. Depict the scandal as a symbol of 1980s greed and excess, the party is telling its candidates and operatives. Call for a return to economic policies that don't favor the rich. Question President Bush's priorities and his management of the S&L bailout. Democratic National Chairman Ron Brown is expected to outline an S&L campaign strategy Friday at a meeting of state party chairmen. But the new theme already is a staple on the political circuit and a refrain in some congressional races that could be dress rehearsals for the 1992 presidential race. It's unclear whether the party will try to blame the S&L bailout for Bush's acknowledgment this week that tax increases are needed. But at least one challenger lost no time in doing so. ``One of the reasons Bush is going to renege on his promise not to raise taxes is the cost of the S&L bailout,'' California Democrat Calvin Dooley said Wednesday. He said he intends to tell voters that Rep. Charles Pashayan, his opponent, ``is one person that people can hold accountable.'' Pashayan and Rep. Denny Smith of Oregon are two Republicans with S&L problems. Democratic Reps. Frank Annunzio of Illinois and Doug Barnard of Georgia have similar woes. Campaign contributions from S&L operators are among the thrift-related issues at stake in the Annunzio, Barnard and Pashayan races. Smith is taking heat for seeking regulatory favors for a failing S&L while he served on its board. Annunzio chairs a banking subcommittee that the GOP says did nothing to avert the crisis. Annunzio contends the Republicans are merely upset by his criticism of Neil Bush, the president's son, who is being investigated for his role in the $1 billion Silverado thrift failure in Colorado. The Democratic assault led White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater to launch a counterattack last week. ``There are a lot of battles that can be fought on this turf, and we're ready,'' Fitzwater said, contending that ``the Democrats have a big role'' in the collapse. Among those Fitzwater singled out was Nebraska Sen. Kerrey, mentioned often as a 1992 prospect. Kerrey is credited with coining the phrase ``savings and loan president'' in a cutting reference to Bush's spending priorities and his 1988 campaign pledge to be the education president. Along with Jesse Jackson, Kerrey was a pioneer in aggressive S&L rhetoric. But they're no longer alone. New York Gov. Cuomo, another potential presidential candidate, neatly packaged most of the Democratic themes this week in a proposal for ``a tax on the richest people in the country, presumably the kind of people who are involved in savings and loans,'' to finance the bailout and ease the future burden on ``our children.'' Texas Sen. Bentsen, the 1988 vice presidential candidate, blames the scandal not on deregulation but what party officials like to call ``de-supervision.'' ``In 1981 we had 54 S&L regulators in Texas. In 1985 we had 12,'' Bentsen told his state party this month. ``The Republicans looked for easy, short-term savings and they ended up stiffing the American taxpayer with a bill for greed and mismanagement that could reach half a trillion dollars.'' Virginia Gov. Wilder, testing the waters in Iowa and New Hampshire this month, called the S&L mess ``the worst scandal in our country's history'' and has told Bush that an independent inquiry is needed. When the president recently made a show of adding money to step up S&L prosecutions, Wilder retorted, ``You mean you just found out about it today?''

DOC.HEAD: Another Cold War Ends; No Cure After 44 Years of Trying
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUB 10th graf, `The volunteers...' to explain how people heard of project. Pickup 11th, `Many participants...
DOC.TEXT: Another cold war has ended _ not with a bang but a sniffle. The Common Cold Research Center is closing Saturday, having conceded defeat after 44 years in which thousands of noses were bombarded with viruses in the quest for a cure for the common cold. Administrator Arthur Amos insists that the 18,000 volunteers who passed through the hospital near Salisbury, 80 miles west of London, did not suffer in vain. ``Going back in time, we used to think there was only one cold virus. Now we know there are nearly 200, so there is no chance of finding a vaccine,'' Amos said. ``We've been trying to find a compound that acts on a family of viruses, but we've had no luck.'' Some of the center's discoveries cannot be explained, Amos said. Why, for example, did one-third of volunteers never show any signs of a cold while the others, exposed to the same virus, coughed, sneezed and felt miserable. ``Blood tests at the beginning of the trial and at the end often show changes in antibody levels, which means even if it didn't seem like they have a cold, they have a subclinical cold,'' Amos said. The volunteers received no medication, Amos said, unless they were in extreme discomfort, in which case they got aspirin. The research center was housed in the Harvard Hospital, so named because it was sent to Britain by the Harvard Medical School in 1940. During World War II, it was an American military field hospital, and in 1946 it was turned over to the common cold project. The volunteers, who learned of the project through newspaper advertisements and word-of-mouth, ranged in age from 18 to 50, and some were repeat participants. One couple met there and returned the following year for their honeymoon. One man went through the 10-day quarantined program 26 times, but Amos said he was ``a rather odd sort of person.'' Many participants came to vacation at the center, nestled in rolling countryside in the shadow of the 404-foot spire atop Salisbury Cathedral, England's highest spire. Two or three volunteers shared each of the center's 12 apartments. ``We usually have a flat empty in reserve in case they're imcompatible... but in the main they usually get along,'' Amos said. The volunteers were barred from Salisbury and neighboring villages and had to keep at least 30 feet away from anyone but their roommates or the gowned, masked medical staff. ``If they were on a walk and couldn't avoid meeting someone, they were told to put a paper tissue over their nose and walk by quick,'' said Amos. Most volunteers came out of curiosity, Amos said, not for the money, a paltry daily sum of pocket money now set at $3. ``There was also a certain feeling that they were working to help medical research _ that voluntary spirit,'' he said. ``It's pretty here and very quiet. If you live in the rougher spots of Liverpool or London, this is the total opposite.'' Amos, who has had only one cold in his six years at the center, will work for three more months overseeing its closure. The Medical Research Council, which had provided the center's $1 million in annual funding, decided the unit would close after director David Tyrell retired. ``It was so much his work, that it was not really viable without him,'' a council spokeswoman said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st item to UPDATE with inspector saying Charles seemed to be in much pain
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Prince Charles broke his arm Thursday in a polo accident when he fell from his horse, police said. Buckingham Palace confirmed the 41-year-old prince had broken his right arm and was being treated in a hospital. The accident occurred during a match at Cirencester Park, Gloucestershire. It is seven miles from Highgrove, the country home of Charles and his wife, Diana, and 70 miles west of London. The princess was in London. Charles was playing for his team, Windsor Park, when he fell from his horse 30 minutes into play. ``The prince slipped off his horse. He has got a nasty break above the right elbow,'' said police Chief Inspector Colin Handy. A spokesman for Charles said the prince was in the process of making a shot when he lost his balance. ``His horse just trotted away,'' the spokesman said, denying a report that a horse had fallen on Charles. ``There was no contact with any other horse or player.'' The prince was taken to Cirencester Memorial Hospital. ``It looked like he was in a fair bit of pain when he got out of the ambulance,'' said Handy, Charles was in the emergency department, where several other patients were also awaiting treament. He was ``in very good spirits and chatting with staff and cracking jokes with other patients,'' said Handy.

DOC.HEAD: Politician Says Settlements Will Be Expanded
DOC.TEXT: A leading right-wing politician said Thursday that Israel intends to expand Jewish settlements in the occupied territories, despite U.S. warnings that this could jeopardize American aid to Israel. ``We will expand settlements whenever and wherever we can,'' said Geula Cohen, deputy science minister and a leader of the right-wing Tehiya Party. ``We don't have to cave in to U.S. pressure.'' Ms. Cohen refused to confirm reports that there was an unwritten agreement between her party and the dominant Likud bloc specifying construction of 5,000 new units each year in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The Hebrew daily Haaretz reported that a pact between Likud and its right-wing coalition partners stipulates that 5,000 new housing units will be constructed each year in existing settlements. The newspaper said the right-wing parties had agreed to expand existing settlements instead of building new ones as a tactical move to try to avoid U.S. criticism. The Haaretz report calculated that by the end of the Likud government's term in 2{ years, the number of Jewish settlers in the occupied lands would exceed 120,000. There currently are at least 75,000 Jewish settlers living in 130 settlements in the occupied territories, the government has said. Even the current estimate of settlers may be low, Haaretz said. The newspaper said its own survey found 84,000 settlers living in the West Bank and 4,000 in Gaza. Haaretz also said that 1,050 new housing units are under construction and could house 6,800 more settlers when they are completed this fall. The territories, which are home to 1.7 million Palestinians, were captured by Israel from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. The United States opposes settling Soviet Jewish immigrants in the territories, saying it is an obstacle to making peace with the Palestinians. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's spokesman Avi Pazner dismissed the newspaper report as ``pure speculation'' but said: ``It's obvious that nobody has sought to put limits on existing settlements.'' The statements came a day after U.S. Rep. David Obey, chairman of the House Appropriations' subcommittee on foreign operations, warned that he would support cutting Israel's annual $3 billion in foreign aid if it persists in expanding the settlements. Shamir formed a narrow, right-wing government earlier this month after a coalition with the left-leaning Labor Party collapsed over how to proceed with Middle East peace efforts. Likud's partners in the new coalition include three ultra-right nationalist factions _ Tehiya, Tsomet and Moledet _ that are committed to expanding Jewish presence in the territories. Benny Katzover, a West Bank settlement leader, said there were plans for ``thickening'' existing settlements, but he would not say how many new units might be built. ``Construction is going on all the time, and it will continue,'' he said. ``We are relying on Sharon,'' he added, referring to Housing Minister Ariel Sharon. Sharon is an ardent supporter of the settlement movement, and he created a fresh stir Thursday by proposing ``emergency regulations'' to speed construction of housing for Soviet immigrants. The regulations sought by Sharon would allow his ministry to seize private land for construction, possibly bypassing laws protecting archaeological sites and nature reserves, critics said. Settlements have come under heavy scrutiny in recent months because of Arab criticism over Israel's policy of allowing some Soviet Jewish immigrants to move to the occupied territories. The Arabs fear Palestinians may be displaced and that their efforts to form an independent state will be undermined. Israel says that only only a fraction of the more than 52,000 Soviet Jews who have come here in the last year have moved to the occupied lands. It is seeking $400 million in loan guarantees from the United States to help house the Soviet immigrants.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: retransmits a0616 to CORRECT cycle
DOC.HEAD: Auction of Corporate Aircraft An Industry First
DOC.TEXT: A bit of aviation history was made in this city where Charles Lindbergh learned to fly. Twenty corporate aircraft, half of them the popular Learjets, were put on the auction block Wednesday in a first-of-its-kind event for the aircraft industry. ``This has never been done before in aviation, save for an occasional bankruptcy sale and sales of smaller or antique planes,'' said J. Robert Duncan, president of Duncan Aviation. The sale was also a first for Sotheby's, the international auction house that specializes in fine art and antiques. John L. Marion, the head of Sotheby's North American operations, wielded the gavel. Within an hour, Duncan crews wheeled the aircraft, one-by-one, through a clean aircraft hangar. There, Marion bellowed the auctioneer's mantra: ``I have $2 million to start, I have 2 million.'' When it was over, five airplanes had been sold for a total of $7,927,750. Two others, including the most expensive one offered, were snapped up before the sale, bringing the total to more than $20 million, Marion said. Duncan, who heads the 30-year-old business aviation sales and service with 550 employees in 14 cities, said he was pleased with the sale, but had greater expectations. ``We'll analyze the results and evaluate whether or not we want to make this an annual event. I think we might have another sale,'' he said. Prices paid ranged from $309,750 for a 1980 Piper Cheyenne I to ``about $14 million to $15 million'' for a 1988 Canadair Challenger _ one of the two sold before the auction, Duncan said. Gary Conklin, a representative of Great Planes Sales Inc. of Tulsa, Okla., picked up a Westwind 1124 for $2.1 million. He said his company buys planes, renovates them and then looks for a buyer. The names of other buyers were not made public. Lindbergh studied flying at the old Lincoln School of Aviation in the 1920s. He made his solo flight of the Atlantic in May 1927.

DOC.HEAD: Helen Hayes: Broadway Among The Roses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Laurance in 8th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Eighty years ago, 9-year-old Helen Hayes made her Broadway debut. This week, the grande dame of American actresses celebrated the rebirth of a theater on a very different Broadway _ in this Hudson River town. Hayes welcomed friends to a twilight fete Wednesday at her Victorian river mansion 30 miles north of the Great White Way. She told more than 100 friends, including actors Douglas Fairbanks Jr., Colleen Dewhurst and Jose Ferrer, about what she calls the ``little theater'' that will be her 90th birthday gift in October. It's a turn-of-the-century silent movie house that's being renovated into a $5 million arts center in her name. ``This theater was born the same year I was, and I think it will outlive me,'' said Hayes. The playhouse, where actors from Liza Minnelli to Tallulah Bankhead have appeared, was saved from the wrecking ball after a 1970 fire. To see it, Hayes' friends sailed up the Hudson from Manhattan _ not in a ``kayak to Nyack,'' as Cole Porter would have it _ but in a 142-foot yacht. Then they boarded buses that took them past the brick playhouse on South Broadway, wrapped in a huge red ribbon, to Pretty Penny, her home on North Broadway. ``They came to see me, my little theater, and my roses'' _ all 200 bushes of them, said Hayes, who chatted with philanthropists Laurance Rockefeller and Brooke Astor, actress Arlene Dahl and actor Tony Randall. The actress strolled through the rose garden first planted in 1933 when she and her husband, the late playwright Charles MacArthur, moved into the 21-room house. Hayes had met the playwright at a Manhattan soiree at the end of which he put peanuts in the palm of her hand and said, ``I wish they were emeralds.'' At sunset on Wednesday, the Nyack garden became a stage for the chatter of actors and producers who along with Hayes have defined American theater. ``This lady of the theater has been there and back, she has seen it all,'' said Dewhurst. ``You can't believe her energy _ she's a natural survivor, with a very strong spiritual side.'' The 500-seat Helen Hayes-Tappan Zee Performing Arts Center, to open in 1991, is to offer theater, children's events, music and film. The new playhouse will get the children ``off the streets and away from movies about murder and mayhem,'' Hayes said. So far, more than $1 million has been raised. ``The blasted expenses, it's a struggle and you lose money, but the people want to go to the theater,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Making Mark in International Ballet Competition
DOC.TEXT: Seven Americans have a chance to become one of the wonders of the international ballet world. They are among 27 finalists dancing toward that dream in the third round of the International Ballet Competition. The international jury will anounce prize winners in four divisions on Friday. Winners will receive gold, silver and bronze medals and cash awards from $500 to $10,000. The U.S. finalists are three senior women, three junior women and one senior man. ``I feel great, knowing I represent the U.S. male population,'' Mark Arvin. ``But still, it's a real tough competition with the Cuban, the Russians and the guy from Argentina. I expect them to capture a lot of medals.'' But Arvin's favorite fact is that his partner, U.S. senior Martha Butler, also made it to the finals. ``There are only three couples still intact'' since the first round, Arvin said. ``That's an achievement.'' ``I'm thrilled,'' said Butler, 23. ``I feel so fortunate.'' ``It's been tough, but a different kind of tough _ not like anything I've known before,'' she said of the competition. ``There's a lot of pressure.'' The United States had 36 competitors in the competition. In addition to Arvin and Butler, both with the Houston Ballet, the other U.S. finalists are: Lauren Anderson, 25, of the Houston Ballet; Yan Chen, 20, an apprentice with the Washington Ballet; Elizabeth Gaither, 16, of the Houston Ballet; Lauren Gelfand, 15, of Cambridge, Mass.; and Diane Perez, 15, who dances with the Ballet Concierto de Puerto Rico.

DOC.HEAD: High Court to Decide Federal Judges' Power on Sentences
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Thursday agreed to decide what power federal judges have to impose prison sentences stiffer than those called for by new guidelines. The court said it will hear an appeal by a former federal employee convicted of embezzling-related charges who said he was not given fair warning that the judge intended to exceed the guidelines. The new sentencing guidelines took effect in 1987, culminating a decade-long effort to overhaul the old system that many said created unjustified sentencing disparities. The new rules were drawn up by a seven-member commission appointed by Congress. The guidelines remain controversial, with many defendants and some judges saying they improperly curb judicial discretion and give prosecutors too much power. The justices are expected to announce a decision in the case next year. The defendant, William J. Burns, was sentenced to five years in prison although he pleaded guilty with the understanding the maximum penalty would be 37 months. Burns was charged with embezzling $1.2 million in government funds from 1982 to 1988 while he was a financial supervisor with the Agency for International Development. He also was convicted of tax evasion for failing to pay $475,685 in taxes on the money prosecutors said he stole. Prosecutors said Burns diverted AID travel funds into a bank account in the fictitious name of Vincent Kaufman and later claimed the money was in payment for phony furniture moving expenses. Authorities said they discovered the embezzlement when a routine security check revealed that Burns, whose annual salary was $35,000 a year, owned a $400,000 house. He pleaded guilty under an agreement with federal prosecutors that called for him to be sentenced under new guidelines that set a maximum of 37 months in prison for such crimes. But U.S. District Judge Norma Johnson imposed the stiffer sentence without having informed him in advance that she was considering the harsher penalty. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Washington upheld the sentence in January. The appeals court said the guidelines permit judges to impose stiffer or milder sentences if there are special aggravating or mitigating circumstances. ``The trial court is best situated to decide the length of the sentence and its finding should not be reversed unless it is arbitrary or capricious,'' the appeals court said. The appeals court also rejected Burns's claim that he was, in effect, blindsided because he was not given an adequate opportunity by the judge to challenge her plans to depart from the guidelines. The appeals court said, ``Since the defendant had an opportunity to address the court before sentencing ... and has a right to appeal his sentence, he has not been harmed by the trial court's lack of notice.'' Unless Congress amends the guidelines, the appeals court said, the rules do not require the judge to warn defendants in advance that sentences may exceed the guidelines. The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court to reject Burns's appeal. The high court ruled last year that the guidelines do not violate constitutionally required separation of powers between the three branches of government. The justices did not decide whether the new system may violate the rights of defendants. The case acted on Thursday is Burns vs. U.S., 89-7260.

DOC.HEAD: Disabled Children Still Denied Benefits
DOC.TEXT: Four months after the Supreme Court eased the rules on welfare benefits for disabled children, the government can't agree with the plaintiffs on who may be owed money or the best way to find them. The dispute has delayed the process of trying to locate hundreds of thousands of poor children who the court said were wrongly denied Supplemental Security Income benefits. The decision gave the children the right to have their cases reviewed. Total back benefits are expected to reach from $1 billion to $2 billion. But the government has not yet paid a dime. The Social Security Administration has been arguing with the children's attorneys over many facets of the case, including lawyers' fees and how many cases should be included. Children's lawyers estimate more than 600,000 denials need to re-evaluated. The government says about 280,000 children are affected. ``Frankly, in over 20 years of litigating similar cases, we cannot recall a single case in which government counsel were more obstructive or belligerent,'' Philadelphia attorney Jonathan M. Stein said in a June 18 letter to the Justice Department. ``It's unfortunate,'' Deputy SSA Commissioner Louis Enoff said in an interview. ``We wanted to make every effort to move quickly to reach every child that is potentially eligible. I still would like to do that.'' Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., said he fears the government could be inadvertently destroying case files from the 1980s and 1970s necessary for children to prove they deserve benefits. But SSA said system-wide computer safeguards prevented that. ``I don't mean to tell you that somewhere in the past there may not have been a file destroyed,'' Enoff said. ``Sometimes a folder gets lost or destroyed accidentally. But we have developed a class action tracking system.'' More than 290,000 poor, disabled children receive SSI benefits, which vary from state to state and range from $386 to about $700 a month. By a 7-2 vote on Feb. 20, the Supreme Court voided a government regulation that gave children seeking the benefits less protection than adults. The Department of Health and Human Services rule had applied a rigid list of disorders to children, while permitting adults to be judged individually on their ability to work. Stein, the children's attorney in the class-action lawsuit, said the decision should force officials to re-evaluate 600,000 denials going back to 1974, when the regulation was enacted. But the Social Security Administration says legal precedent requires that they only go back to 1983, when the case was originally filed on behalf of Brian Zebley, then 5, of Upland, Pa. Brian, who suffers from congenital brain damage, lost his SSI benefits when an administrative law judge concluded that his medical conditions did not meet government requirements. There have been about 280,000 denials since then that now should be reviewed, according to SSA. Both sides have indicated a willingness to compromise on how many reviews should be undertaken. The administration accuses Stein of delaying negotiations by unreasonably seeking $6 million in legal and other fees in the case. ``Most regrettably, your compensation demands have precluded a settlement which not only would have brought an end to this longstanding litigation but, most importantly, would have been very fair and equitable to members of the `Zebley' class,'' Stuart Licht of the Justice Department's Civil Division said in a June 8 letter to Stein. ``It's a total lie,'' said Stein. He said he has sought $1.2 million for work done between 1983 and the court decision, plus unspecified fees for the past four months.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Say Riflemen Could Disable City Power Supplies
DOC.TEXT: Terrorists could knock out electrical power to an American city by using store-bought rifles on carefully chosen targets, congressional researchers said Thursday. Armed with high-powered rifles available from any gun store and some basic engineering knowledge, terrorists could wreak havoc without having to get past a single guard at generating plants, Robin Roy of the congressional Office of Technology Assessment told the Senate Government Affairs Committee. ``Two or three knowledgeable individuals using only readily available, off-the-shelf supplies could destroy enough facilities to cause a short-term blackout over a metropolitan area, followed by months of reduced reliability and rotating power outages during peak periods,'' Roy told the panel, which is investigating the vulnerability of power plants to terrorists, hurricanes and earthquakes. When asked what he meant by ``readily available, off-the-shelf,'' Roy said, ``Rifles ... if you know what to shoot at.'' Alan Taft Crane of the OTA testified that transmission lines are vulnerable to rifle fire. ``Such damage can be repaired quickly, but the saboteur can repeat it even more quickly,'' he said. ``Many such quick attacks would have much the same effect on the system as eliminating key facilities.'' Blackouts can causes millions of dollars in damage to utilities and public services, not to mention lost business and looting, the report noted. A 1977 blackout in New York City and neighboring Westchester County lasted a full day and caused losses of nearly $350 million. Although power systems can usually withstand hurricanes, ``the lingering, local blackouts following Hurricane Hugo demonstrated that more advance preparation may be warranted,'' Crane said. ``Facilities can be designed to withstand earthquakes, as they are in California, but less prepared areas including the Central Mississippi valley, the southern Appalachians and the Indiana region are also vulnerable to major shocks,'' Crane said. The OTA report also noted economic roadblocks to recovery from serious disasters, growing foreign control of the electrical equipment manufacturing industry and decreasing investment by power companies in backup capacity.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Blocks Execution After Upholding Law Behind It
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court permanently blocked the execution of an Arizona killer Thursday, a day after upholding the death penalty law under which he had been sentenced. One attorney general called the sequence ``a complete fluke.'' Two of the justices who voted with the majority in the 5-4 decision upholding the state law did not take part in Thursday's action, turning Wednesday's dissenters into a 4-3 majority for the one case. In a brief order, the justices refused to reinstate the death sentence of John Harvey Adamson, convicted of murdering Phoenix newspaper reporter Don Bolles in 1976. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1988 threw out Adamson's death sentence after striking down a provision in Arizona law that lets judges, instead of juries, choose between life and death for convicted murderers. The appeals court's ruling called into doubt the validity of death penalty laws in Idaho and Montana, which also allow for sentencing by judges. But the Arizona provision was declared constitutional Wednesday by the Supreme Court in the case of another Arizona killer. Thursday's confusing turn of events came about because Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, a former state judge in Arizona, and Anthony M. Kennedy, a former 9th Circuit court judge, did not participate in Adamson's case. That left only Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White and Antonin Scalia voting to grant Arizona's appeal and set aside the 9th Circuit court's ruling in the Adamson case. Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens, who voted Wednesday to strike down Arizona's death penalty law, voted to deny Arizona's appeal. The net result: both the 1988 appeals court ruling and a contradictory Supreme Court decision are on the books. The practical effect: Adamson cannot be sentenced to death. A surprised Arizona Attorney General Bob Corbin said, ``As we see it, the Arizona death penalty statute is constitutional ... but it doesn't apply to Adamson.'' ``It's a crazy decision but that's what they voted,'' Corbin said. Idaho Attorney General Jim Jones called the sequence of events ``ridiculous,'' but predicted that Thursday's action would affect no death row inmate but Adamson. ``It really means not too much more than Adamson is going to get off because of a complete fluke, and the work of the judges of the 9th Circuit court,'' Jones said. Prosecutors said Adamson was paid $100,000 to attach a bomb to the car of Bolles, who had been investigating organized crime for The Arizona Republic in Phoenix. Bolles died June 11, 1976, nine days after his car exploded. Before dying, Bolles identified Adamson as the man who had made an appointment to see him the day of the bombing. Adamson originally was allowed to plead guilty to second-degree murder in exchange for his testimony against two others allegedly involved in the murder plot. His testimony helped convict Max Dunlap, a building contractor, and James Robison, a plumber. But the Arizona Supreme Court threw out the Dunlap and Robison convictions in 1980 and ordered a new trial for them. The two have not been retried. Adamson, who by 1980 was serving a 20-year prison term, said he would not testify at a new trial unless the state met additional conditions _ including his release and the government's help in establishing a new identity. After Adamson's refusal to cooperate, state prosecutors filed first-degree murder charges against him. He was tried, convicted and sentenced to death. The 9th Circuit court threw out Adamson's death sentence in 1986, ruling he had been subjected to ``double jeopardy.'' The Supreme Court reversed that ruling and reinstated the death sentence by a 5-4 vote in 1987. The high court's 1989-90 term ended Wednesday as the justices recessed until Oct. 1. But they left behind orders in various cases that were released by the court clerk Thursday. In other orders, the court: _Agreed to study the appeal of a Rhode Island college ordered to pay nearly $44,000 to a former nursing student kicked out because she was too fat. _Refused to block an investigation into alleged misconduct by C. Vernon Mason, a lawyer who represented Tawana Brawley, the black New York teen-ager who said she was the victim of a racially motivated assault. _Agreed to decide whether an Indiana woman may sue the prosecutor she says violated her rights by advising police to hypnotize her before asking questions about the shootings of her children.

DOC.HEAD: Key Items in Japan-U.S. Trade Report
With AM-Japan-US Trade, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a summary of items in the final report on Japan-U.S. trade measures published Thursday after four days of negotiations. The two countries agreed to reduce the $49 billion U.S. trade deficit with Japan by increasing access to the Japanese market, cutting U.S. demand for imports and improving the competitiveness of U.S. industry. The two countries agreed to meet three times in the first year to monitor progress in following the accord and twice a year thereafter.
DOC.HEAD: JAPAN'S PROMISES:
DOC.TEXT: _Raise spending on public works to $2.77 trillion in the 1991-2000 decade. Japan spent $1.7 trillion in the 10 years to 1990. _Submit legislation by next March to release more land for housing and buildings and curb high land prices. _Attain 24-hour clearance of imports by 1991. _The Fair Trade Commission is to take more formal action in anti-monopoly cases instead of quiet persuasion; a bill is to go before the current session of Parliament to raise fines to deter cartels. _The commission is to increase monitoring of transactions within business groups to deter anti-competitive practices, publicize findings, enhance foreign companies' ability to sell goods to companies in such groups. _The criminal code is to be amended to increase fines for bid-rigging. _Deregulation is to speed the process for approving large retail stores, widen liquor sales, open the distribution system. _Increase the number of patent examiners and other measures to shorten within five years the time to process patent applications from the current 37 months to 24 months. _Survey and publicize differences between high Japanese prices and foreign prices; the government is to implement 52 measures that have been identified as likely to reduce such price differentials. _Abolish a law under which the government can restrict foreign direct investment if it could affect similar Japanese domestic businesses.
DOC.HEAD: U.S. PROMISES:
DOC.TEXT: _Reduce the federal budget deficit and the government's outstanding debt. _Reform antitrust law to reduce uncertainty about the treatment of joint production ventures that enhance competition. _Reform product liability law to contribute to uniformity among the states and limit damage awards. _Lower the cost of capital to facilitate long-term investment. _Urge Congress to pass a bill to create family savings accounts and other measures to increase the low U.S. savings level. _Export deregulation to eliminate most licensing requirements for trade to Communist countries. _More federal funding for research and development. _Partial relaxation of a ban on exports of California heavy crude oil. _More programs to promote exports. _Measures to reach goals of excellence in education and to improve the quality of the U.S. work force.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Japanese Negotiators Agree to Drastic Changes in Economies
LaserPhotos TOK10,11
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Japanese trade negotiators agreed Thursday to drastic economic changes to help cut the $49 billion U.S. trade deficit with Japan. Officials said the unprecedented pact would improve the quality of life in both countries. In the wide-ranging accord, the United States agreed to raise its tax revenues. Japan said it would spent $1 trillion more on public works in the next decade. The two measures are aimed at helping close the trade gap and easing trade friction. ``I welcome and endorse this joint report,'' President Bush said in Washington as the talks ended at the Foreign Ministry in Tokyo. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said that carrying out the reforms would be painful. ``However, these measures are intended to achieve a major reform of the Japanese economy in the consumers' best interests,'' he said. Kaifu praised Bush's willingness to consider tax revenue increases at the risk of a strong political backlash. Bush commended Kaifu for ``his strong and courageous political leadership.'' Linn Williams, the U.S. deputy trade representative, called the agreement, which followed telephone consultations between Bush and Kaifu on Wednesday night, ``something no two other countries have done before.'' Williams said the talks were ``an important influence'' on Bush's tax move, which is aimed at reducing the federal budget deficit. The deficit is regarded as a fundamental cause of other economic ills in the United States, including the trade imbalance. After four days of intensive talks, haggard but happy trade officials emerged with the 57-page report that included Bush's decision Wednesday to raise tax revenues _ a departure from his campaign promise of no new taxes. The report also carried a pledge by Japan to spend $2.77 trillion over the next 10 years on public works projects to stimulate demand for imports and help offset this nation's huge reservoir of savings. Japan has spent $1.7 trillion in the past 10 years. The decision on public works represented a major compromise. U.S. officials had sought a 10-year, $3.22 trillion package. But Japanese officials resisted increasing their original offer of $2.68 trillion because of fears of inflation. ``We think that plan, along with President Bush's plan, would go a long way toward reducing the imbalance between Japan and the United States,'' said John B. Taylor of the Council of Economic Advisers. He said the reforms were expected to have a gradual but lasting impact on Japan's trade surplus with the United States, which totaled $49 billion last year. Earlier, officials said the results of the reforms were expected to show up within two or three years. Many of the reforms are indirectly related to trade flows. The agreement also called for Japan to increase penalties for violations of anti-monopoly laws, facilitate legal action against unfair business practices and crack down on collusion and bid-rigging. The measures are intended to make Japanese business more open to foreign competition. Japan also promised new policies to slow real estate inflation and encourage more efficient land use. The steps would help lower the cost of doing business in Japan and improve the quality of life for average Japanese, who cannot afford to buy new homes. Japan agreed to relax restrictions on retail sales to let in more imports and open new business opportunities. In addition to stronger action on the budget deficit, Washington pledged to urge Congress to enact laws on family savings accounts and other measures to help increase U.S. savings and investment. The United States said it also would enact measures to improve education and worker training as a long-term investment in the quality of the U.S. work force. Washington also promised to develop programs to promote exports while easing restrictions on oil exports. Officials on both sides expressed satisfaction with the report from the talks, formally known as the Structural Impediments Initiative. ``We believe that this report is a historic document that contains wide-ranging commitments and actions with significant benefits for both economies,'' the U.S. delegation said in a statement issued after the talks ended. Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama said the measures were needed to improve Japanese living standards and ``ensure that relations between the Japanese economy and the rest of the world economy are less tense and more harmonious.'' Some analysts have expressed doubts the fundamental reforms envisioned would actually occur, particularly changes in ingrained business habits that have long gone untouched by fair trade regulators. Williams acknowledged the ``proof will be in what really happens,'' but he said the U.S. delegation was optimistic. ``We believe their intentions are genuine,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Ruling Expected to Generate New Efforts for Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: This week's U.S. Supreme Court abortion ruling already has spurred new efforts in at least one state to make minors tell their parents before getting an abortion. In rulings on Ohio and Minnesota laws, the high court said a state may require a minor, unmarried girl to notify one or both parents before having an abortion _ provided she has the option of getting a judge's permission. On Thursday, a New Jersey lawmaker introduced a bill for one-parent notification, and other states are expected to see a wave of legislative proposals. ``I'm trying to bring back family relationships. Parents have to assume responsibility for children,'' said state Sen. Francis McManimon, the sponsor of the New Jersey bill. New Jersey had a one notification bill pending; the new one was designed to conform with Monday's Supreme Court ruling. That decision could spur enforcement of abortion restrictions for minors in at least nine states. At least 23 states have laws that require a minor to obtain the consent of one or both parents before having an abortion. Eleven states have laws requiring a girl simply to notify one or both parents. A judge's permission can be substituted in some states. But many of the laws haven't been enforced or have been blocked by the courts, some awaiting the high court's ruling. ``These are going to spring to life. And I predict most of the other states will place similar laws on the books,'' said Dr. John Willke, president of the National Right to Life Committee in Washington, D.C. A flood of abortion bills followed the Supreme Court's 1989 Webster ruling, which permitted greater state limits on abortion. But few survived a backlash from abortion-rights advocates. About 350 bills have been considered in state legislatures since Webster, said Kate Michelman, president of the National Abortion Rights Action League. ``We'll see that many and more than that in the coming year,'' she said. ``You're going to see efforts to go beyond parental consent, parental notification. There will be further attempts to undermine Roe.'' The Supreme Court's 1973 decision in Roe vs. Wade established the right to an abortion. Minnesota's notification law could be back in effect in 30 days, said the state's chief deputy attorney general, Jack Tunheim. It went into effect in 1981 but was ruled unconstitutional in 1986. Half the 7,200 teen-agers who got abortions during that time sought a judge's permission and all but eight had their petitions approved, according to Thomas Webber, executive director of Planned Parenthood of Minnesota. Ohio's notification law was never enforced while appeals were pending. Arkansas and West Virginia already enforce their notification laws, and Utah requires parental notification ``if possible.'' Appeals courts were waiting for the high court's decision before ruling on consent or notification laws from Georgia, Kentucky and Tennessee. The ruling also could revive laws in Illinois, Nebraska, Idaho, Maryland, Mississippi and Nevada that were either blocked or haven't been enforced. Abortion foes in Oregon have begun a petition drive to get a notification measure on the November ballot. In Michigan, opponents are collecting signatures to get a veto-proof bill into the Legislature. Gov. James Blanchard vetoed a parental consent law this year. An anti-abortion spokeswoman in Montana thinks the Supreme Court ruling could pave the way for a notification law in that state. ``Given the Supreme Court decision, I think many more legislators would be confident to vote for that,'' said Linda Sargent, executive director of Montana Right to Life. But some Wisconsin lawmakers said the latest decision won't sway legislators. A consent bill passed in the Assembly but died in a Senate committee last year. ``I don't think these decisions will change attitudes or votes on this important issue,'' said Senate Majority Leader Joseph Strohl.

DOC.HEAD: Name Puts Local Businesses at Odds With Country-Music Complex
DOC.TEXT: The peace, contentment and good will in Renfro Valley have been shaken. The picturesque hollow that the late entertainer John Lair described in his song ``The Valley Where Time Stands Still'' is now the scene of a battle over rights to its name. Lair turned the valley 50 miles south of Lexington into an entertainment center when he founded the Renfro Valley Barn Dance in 1939. His song described the valley as a place of ``peace and content and good will.'' But that began to change last year when three investors bought the 110-acre property that Lair had trademarked and copyrighted. The new owners, Renfro Valley Folks Inc., plan to turn the complex near Interstate 75 into a $35 million country-music theme park. The investors maintain that the purchase included the exclusive use of the Renfro Valley name. Several business owners in the unincorporated hamlet of about 75 people balked when the new owners ordered them to stop using the words ``Renfro Valley'' in store names and merchandise. ``When we bought John Lair's property, we also purchased the country music, museum, restaurant, motel and records,'' said Ralph Gabbard, president of Renfro Valley Folks. ``He had many federal trademarks and we filed for others. All we're doing is what (Walt) Disney did before he went into Orlando or California. What we're trying to do is protect the good name.'' The Renfro Valley complex includes a new 1,530-seat auditorium, the old Renfro Valley Barn Dance building, old jamboree building, a recently completed turn-of-the-century crafts village, a restaurant and motel and a country music museum. Valley business owners claim they have as much right to the Renfro Valley name as Renfro Valley Folks. ``This valley will be 200 years old next year,'' said Ailene Collinsworth, who owns Renfro Valley Country Store with her husband, Willard. ``It's been called Renfro Valley all that time. My family has lived in the valley for over 30 years.'' The store has been selling cups, spoons, caps and hats emblazoned with ``Renfro Valley'' for more than 15 years, she said. Renfro Valley Folks filed a lawsuit June 18 in U.S. District Court in London, Ky., seeking to stop Renfro Valley Record Shop from using the name. Store owner Joe Allen said he offered to compromise by dropping ``Renfro Valley'' in exchange for the right to sell records and tapes from the entertainment company without paying royalties. An attorney for Renfro Valley Folks said Wednesday that an agreement had been reached with Allen that would be signed Monday. But that was news to Allen. ``I haven't heard a word from them,'' he said Thursday. ``They want to license the products in my store. I don't have to ask them what I can sell. It's my store, not theirs. I will never pay royalties. They do not own my business.'' Said Mrs. Collinsworth: ``We know they have the trademark on Renfro Valley Folks. We don't want what belongs to them, but we want what belongs to us. ... They want to trademark everything. They want to keep us little folks from selling that, but that's our living, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister Hospitalized Again
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister David Levy was hospitalized again on Thursday for treatment of a heart condition, officials at Jerusalem's Hadassah Hospital said. Levy was released Tuesday from Haemek Hospital in the northern Israeli town of Afula, where he spent 11 days after suffering a minor heart attack. Dr. Shmuel Pinchas, Hadassah Hospital director, told the national Itim news agency that Levy underwent treatment to expand heart arteries and was feeling well. Levy is likely to be released in the next few days, he said. Levy, 52, a member of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc, was housing minister before being appointed to his current post in Shamir's new right-wing government. He also holds the post of deputy prime minister. Levy is regarded as a possible successor to Shamir in Likud.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Fire Destroys Hundreds of Homes in California
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to include acreage of most destructive fire, UPDATE with quotes from residents returning to leveled homes. Picks up 4th graf, ``The fire...' SUBS 22nd graf, `People in... to CORRECT police seeking two people for questioning in connection with Glendale arson, sted two people arrested, UPDATE damages in that fire to $30,000 sted $25,000.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos STB1, STB2, STB8
DOC.TEXT: Raging wildfires set by arsonists burned more than 300 homes in Southern California as wind-driven flames left over 14,000 acres of parched brush blackened today. Forty-six firefighters were injured working fire lines throughout the region, including two prison inmates critically burned in Riverside County. A 3,500-acre blaze destroyed 280 homes in Santa Barbara County late Wednesday and continued to burn today in a canyon north of Santa Barbara. Homeowners in this coastal community today surveyed charred lots where flames torched rows of expensive homes but skipped through the air to spare others. One serious injury was reported. ``It was a beautiful neighborhood,'' Eric Lim said as the remains of his house smoldered behind him. ``I can't find anything, there's nothing,'' Nancy Harvey said, her hands picking through what was once the kitchen of her dream home. ``I'm hoping to find my address book.'' ``The fire is incredible. It came down from the mountains. It spread everywhere. It burned everything in its path,'' said Tim Grasey, spokesman for the Santa Barbara County Sheriff's Department. From Santa Barbara to San Diego, thousands of people were rousted from homes. Santa Barbara residents alerted by smoke, neighbors and roving U.S. Forest Service crews packed what they could and fled in cars or on foot. ``The trees were lighting up like torches,'' said resident Dave Williams, who was just watching the fire until he realized that ``this is serious business. I could die in this stuff.'' The fires were worsened by four years of drought and a searing heat wave that pushed temperatures to record levels well above 100 degrees. Water reserves were at their lowest levels in years. Hot desert winds up to 60 mph fanned the Santa Barbara fire Wednesday, U.S. Forest Service spokeswoman Susan Mockenhaupt said. Dropping temperatures and winds tamed the fire overnight, leaving only isolated hot spots. But fire officials refused to declare it contained today, saying they feared winds could fan the flames again. In one subdivision, every home was gutted, every street a landscape of chimneys and charred kitchen appliances. Occasionally, a geyser of flame shot from a gas main, giving the scene a hellish look. Workers rushed to shut off gas lines. The fire also destroyed businesses and a school for handicapped adults, set a fire station ablaze and prompted evacuation of the county jail. It shut down traffic on U.S. Highway 101 and cut off rail service. Authorities blamed arson, saying they found an incendiary device. Ashes filled the sky more than 35 miles from the blaze. In Arizona, meanwhile, fire burned out of control today in Tonto National Forest, where six firefighters were killed Tuesday. In Montrose, Colo., a lightning-sparked fire in the ponderosa burned at least 1,000 acres. Santa Barbara County's blaze was its first of that magnitude since a 1977 fire burned 234 homes in the area, which is on the Pacific Coast 100 miles northwest of Los Angeles. Its property values were among the state's highest. ``It looks like a war zone out there,'' Grasey said. ``Everything is blackened. It's just total devastation. You never felt more helpless. You look at it and there's nothing you could do to stop it.'' Brenda Rein watched from a shopping mall as the fire marched down a mountain. ``The whole sky was just orange. I looked up and saw the moon through the smoke, kind of a werewolf moon,'' she said. Barbara Jefferson of Santa Barbara came out of a movie theater to find the evening sky raining soot and the wind blowing so fiercely it was hard to stand. In the distant hills, she said, ``we just saw mountains of flames.'' Police in the Los Angeles suburb of Glendale today said they were seeking two people for questioning in connection with a deliberately set fire that destroyed or damaged 55 homes there Wednesday. The homes were valued at $300,000 to $700,000 each, and property losses were estimated at $30 million. ``The California chaparral over here, all that sage and scrub oak, is literally like gasoline,'' Fire Battalion Chief Chris Gray said. Meanwhile, 60 miles to the east of Los Angeles, a fire near the small community of El Cerrito in Riverside County destroyed 12 homes and closed Interstate 15. Nine firefighters were injured, mostly from heat exhaustion and smoke inhalation, officials said. An estimated 2,000 firefighters were trying today to contain the fire at 2,200 acres. The blaze began after a U.S. Forest Service ``controlled burn'' _ an attempt to burn away brush to prevent fires _ raged out of control. An arson blaze in the Carbon Canyon area of Orange County spread over 6,640 acres to the San Bernardino County community of Sleepy Hollow, where eight homes were engulfed. Eight firefighters suffered minor injuries, authorities said. Sleepy Hollow's 2,000 residents fled, said LoVae Pray Martines, a spokeswoman for the California Department of Forestry. Peter Reyes, 29, was arrested for investigation of arson, said Maria Sabol, a spokeswoman for Orange County Fire Department. A 150-acre fire near Hemet, another Riverside County community, injured 17 firefighters. Two inmates working firelines were critically burned, officials said. In the Moreno Valley area of the county, fire destroyed three homes. In Arizona, the Tonto National Forest fire scorched more than 21,000 acres, forest spokesman Ken Palmrose said. Lightning started the fire Monday. The fire has destroyed at least 50 homes and threatened about 700 more, officials said. Firefighters were unable to save a cabin built in the 1920s by Zane Grey, a prolific Western novelist who drew on the picturesque, pine-shaded Tonto Rim country for inspiration. Forest spokesman Bob Celaya said authorities still were trying to learn how five inmates and a prison employee were killed Tuesday while battling the fire. The victims were among several crews who were trapped when a ``dry thunderstorm'' struck the area, spreading the fire in all directions.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Ex-Congressman Released From Halfway House
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Rep. Mario Biaggi quietly was released from a halfway house after serving less than half of a 2{-year sentence for accepting illegal gratuities, an official said Thursday. Ralph Kistner, chief U.S. probation officer in Brooklyn, said Biaggi, 72, was put on a curfew parole program, which means he is confined to his home every night between 9 p.m. and 6 a.m. unless he is given special permission by his probation officer. He will remain under the nighttime curfew until Aug. 7, when his actual parole begins, Kistner said. Biaggi, the Democratic representative from the Bronx for nearly 20 years, was convicted in 1987 of accepting illegal gratuities, obstruction of justice and interstate travel to commit a crime. He served 11 months of his sentence at a federal prison in Fort Worth, Texas, before being transferred to the halfway house March 16.

DOC.HEAD: Welcome to Chick and Bobby's Bonker Hour
DOC.TEXT: Chick Corea and Bobby McFerrin, out to have fun and break some musical ground, wasted no time at the JVC Jazz Festival making clear which of those aims comes first. Grammy-winning vocalist McFerrin strutted to his stool Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, sat down and began bouncing up and down. Corea, the modern legend in jazz composing, perched over his bench and flipped his long shirt tails backward over his head, then grinned. Something was up. They were a perfect match for a disarmingly entertaining evening of improvisation, one-on-one. Two of the most adventuresome artists around sounded together like the Tom and Jerry of jazz, with a healthy dose of cool. This was a fantastic combo that should be seen everywhere. After a bit of silly improv to warm up, the pair opened with a rendition of ``Autumn Leaves'' that quickly evolved into an experiment in sound and laughs that would set the tone for the two-hour concert. McFerrin's expansive voice and Corea's ebullient acoustic piano sounded nearly like a full band. McFerrin threw in some trombone licks while keeping the bass line humming from somewhere in his chest; Corea plucked the piano's strings to add the beat. Soon they both were leaning into the grand piano, backs nearly to the audience, drumming on its frame and yelping and finding sounds in the instrument that Steinway never imagined. The duo brought the audience fully into the show in the second half. McFerrin hopped between two spots on the stage that he designated ``ee'' and ``ahh.'' With a hop he had the nearly full house belting ``ahh,'' then ``ee,'' while Corea added discordant tones of his own. McFerrin would venture into the crowd several times before the concert finished. In one flurry, he had the audience pass a glass of water from front to back, then had them pass towels, and when at a loss for more props, offered himself and traversed Carnegie's 35 rows horizontally. Humor was the key to the show, but it never masked talent. Corea in the second half came up with a delightfully spry rendition of his own ``Spain,'' with McFerrin adding the full orchestra and chorus. Corea also brought out the serious side of the performance, and at times seemed barely able to keep from becoming McFerrin's straight man. But each performer tapped his own highly energized imagination, style and personality to make the concert work in a way few others could. The men clearly understand each other, after just three concerts together, and both exuded McFerrin's concert-ending advice: ``Go bonkers for at least one hour a day.''

DOC.BYLINE: Lithuanian Parliament Begins Debating Independence Moratorium ^By ANN IMSE
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's legislators began debating a freeze of their declaration of independence Thursday, and some questioned whether Mikhail S. Gorbachev has the credibility or staying power to stick to a compromise. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene told the Supreme Council parliament that Gorbachev had promised to end an economic blockade and begin negotiations if Lithuania places a moratorium on the March 11 declaration. She suggested a resolution that would impose a three-month moratorium, to take effect when negotiations with the Kremlin actually begin. Mrs. Prunskiene told parliament Gorbachev will not require a freeze on laws that followed the declaration of independence. One of those laws replaced the Soviet Constitution with a Lithuanian document. ``The moratorium is only on the declaration of independence, not on all the other acts,'' Mrs. Prunskiene told parliament. ``It's a political statement.'' ``The status of Lithuania doesn't change and the Supreme Council remains the same,'' she said, pressing parliament to accept a compromise. Parliament adjourned Thursday without making a decision. But Mrs. Prunskiene's assurances were not enough for many legislators. ``We fear that if we accept this, Moscow would immediately install an alternative government,'' said legislator Klemas Inta. ``We fear that they could deceive us.'' Lithuania was an independent country between the world wars but was occupied by Soviet soldiers in 1940 and absorbed into the Soviet Union. ``There is a panic in the country that we might be tricked,'' said newspaper editor Algis Cekuolis. Inta pointed to the mound of letters the parliament has received from people opposing any suspension of the declaration of independence, despite Gorbachev's blockade. About 50,000 workers have lost their jobs since the Kremlin cut all oil, most natural gas and other raw materials and manufactured goods 10 weeks ago. The blockade is barely visible in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital. Most workers still are earning vacation pay, hot water is flowing, and there is no need for heat. As a result, there is little sign of the economic sanctions wearing down the republic's determination. Several hundred people gathered outside parliament during the debate Thursday to protest the moratorium proposal. ``You cannot give yourself up into captivity,'' said engineer Richardas Nomicas. ``A compromise is needed, but this is not it.'' Mrs. Prunskiene told parliament it must accept a deal because the West is demanding a compromise, and the economic blockade could turn Lithuania into a disaster area by winter. The Kremlin released a statement late Tuesday saying talks with Lithuania cannot begin until the republic declares a moratorium on its independence declaration. It said the talks can only be held in the framework of a nationwide discussion of a new treaty of union among republics. One member of parliament, Eduardas Vilkas, said after listening to Mrs. Prunskiene that he understood her to be requesting ``a political step ... to say that Gorbachev is not the loser.'' Vilkas said he favored a compromise but warned that many Lithuanian legislators oppose a deal. ``This is very difficult psychologically for many deputies,'' he said. Lithuania's president, Vytautas Landsbergis, told the parliament he would speak in more detail on the proposed deal Friday. On Thursday, Landsbergis did not endorse a compromise but said ``it's most important to get the negotiations started.'' In response to a question, he said he understood from talks with Gorbachev that the economic blockade would be lifted immediately when the moratorium went into effect. Landsbergis said the Lithuanian leadership wanted to choose the best conditions for entering critical talks over just how independence could be achieved. There was no indication when parliament would make a decision. Some leaders, including Landsbergis, say the Soviet political landscape is changing so rapidly that Lithuania might do better to wait. On Friday, the Communist Party leadership is scheduled to meet to make final preparations for the national party congress that begins Monday in Moscow. Gorbachev is likely to face bitter criticism from both traditional communists and reformers, and may face a challenge to his party leadership. Cekuolis, the newspaper editor, said he believes Gorbachev wants to enter the party congress saying he has solved the Lithuanian crisis. Lithuanian legislators acknowledged that their plans partially hinged on whether they think Gorbachev has the power to withstand any challenge to his leadership. Legislator Valerijonas Sadreika said, ``If the situation in Russia changes, and a more conservative leader emerges, it would be more complicated to negotiate with Russia.'' In that case, Lithuania should act on Gorbachev's offer while it can, Cekuolis said.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Occupy Agriculture Ministry to Demand Price Guarantees
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts 2 grafs after 8th, `Poland's post-Communist...' to ADD background on other strikes, and SUB 9th pvs, `The government...' to conform. Pickup 10th pvs, `The reform...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WAR50
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of farmers seeking guaranteed minimum prices for their produce occupied the Ministry of Agriculture on Thursday and rejected demands they end the protest to clear the way for negotiations. The 600 farmers blocked employees from entering the ministry. They marched through central Warsaw to the building Wednesday and occupied it overnight after a delegation reported no results from preliminary discussions with Cabinet members. ``Our demands are the same ones we've been presenting to the government for half a year,'' said Boguslaw Wlodarczyk of the farmers' strike committee. Farmers will occupy the building ``until it is solved,'' he said. Agriculture Minister Czeslaw Janicki said ``substantial talks'' could begin if the protesters left the building. But strike committee chairman Wladyslaw Wrona said that would signal defeat. ``We shall let in (only) those who come to settle our problems,'' he said. He also turned down an invitation to hold talks with the Solidarity caucus of parliament. The protesters occupied a conference room and sat in hallways. Farmers at the door tussled with employees who tried to enter. The farmers seek government-set minimum prices as a buffer against the effects of a government program to create a market economy from Poland's socialized system of the last four decades. They also want more favorable loan terms and assurances of profitability for farming. Poland's post-Communist government has repeatedly stated that the success of the reforms depends on consistency, and that to yield to strike pressure will only unleash a torrent of requests from other sectors. The farmers' protest is the third serious challenge to the government reform drive in the past two months. The other two, involving dairy farmers and railway workers, were suspended at Solidarity leader Lech Walesa's appeal. The government has appealed for labor peace to give the reforms time to work and has taken a firm line against negotiating with strikers. It likens the farmers' demands for minimum prices to the subsidies the Communist regime used to satisfy farmers. Those subsidies kept consumer prices artificially low. The reform program cut most subsidies, lifted price controls, let interest rates rise to reflect the level of inflation and opened the economy to private ventures. While refusing to set guaranteed prices, the government has created an Agricultural Market Agency to begin work in July. It will buy grain as needed to help support price levels. The government also has indicated a willingness to take limited steps to regulate other agricultural sectors, including the especially hard-hit dairy industry. The farmers, accustomed to guaranteed markets in food-short Poland, have been chided for failing to react to new competitive market conditions. ``Once could discern ... statements of farmers longing for times when farmers didn't have freedom, but when they knew how much they could sell their products for and when everything they offered was being bought,'' the newspaper Rzeczpospolita said, reporting on the Agriculture Ministry protest. The growers contend that special conditions of farming, including the year-long cycle of sowing, harvesting, selling and planning investment for the next planting, require government flexibility. Seventy-five percent of Poland's farmland is privately owned. But nearly half the farms are small plots whose tillers say they have neither the time nor transport to seek markets for their products other than the local, quasi-governmental cooperatives established under the socialist system. These cooperatives have cut prices paid to farmers because of huge inventories, created by consumers unwilling to buy at prices that have increased up to 1,000 percent in the last year.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: big impact.''
DOC.TEXT: Nordlinger's firm is just one of several that assist lobbyists nationwide without actually doing any lobbying themselves. They are an unregulated and potentially potent force that is one part of the future of legislative lobbying. Another glint of things to come shines in the 27th floor offices of TRW Inc. in Arlington, Va. From this steel and glass aerie overlooking Washington, Ernie Labelle shapes TRW's sophisticated approach to state legislative lobbying. Labelle, who directs state and constituent relations for the huge space and defense contractor, talks about government as a ``partner'' and says business must do more than respond to legislation _ it must shape it. TRW employs a ``vice president for public policy analysis'' whose full-time job, essentially, is to think deeply about important issues. It doesn't matter whether they have anything to do with TRW directly; the company sees benefits in the most tangential things. On a more down-to-earth level, TRW sends lobbyists into 15 or 20 states a year. It also has designed a computerized ``constituent network'' that allows Labelle to instantly tap into the company's 50,000-plus employees in the United States and get them on the phone to their legislators. ``It's a very structured, focused, disciplined, systems approach to grassroots lobbying,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: FAA: Eight Close Calls in Chicago Area Recent Days
DOC.TEXT: Air traffic controllers in the Chicago area allowed eight close calls between airplanes in a recent 10-day period, the Federal Aviation Administration said. One of the most serious involved two Northwest Airlines jets, both flying at 33,000 feet, which came within nine-tenths of a mile of each other, according to a preliminary FAA investigation. A second incident involved a flight on which the governor of Iowa was a passenger, the FAA said. ``We're upset about it,'' Mark Scholl, an official of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, said of the rash of incidents that occurred between June 17 and Tuesday. ``We don't have an explanation for it. There's not a common thread.'' But Scholl said Wednesday he believed the eight incidents at the Chicago Air Route Traffic Control Center in Aurora were an aberration. None of the incidents was classified as a ``near midair collision,'' FAA spokesman Mort Edelstein said. Edelstein said an investigative team was looking at all eight incidents. He said some changes went into effect Wednesday in an effort to correct the situation, but declined to elaborate. In all of 1989, controllers made 34 ``operational errors,'' in which planes stray closer than the minimum separation allowed by the FAA, Edelstein said. So far this year, 25 such errors have occurred, he said. The Northwest Airlines incident took place Saturday when a DC-9 with 32 passengers came within nine-tenths of a mile of another Northwest jet, a Boeing 727, with 131 passengers. The incident involving Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad occurred June 21 over Indiana when an American Airlines 727 came within 200 feet vertically and 1.6 miles horizontally of an Iowa National Guard plane carrying 16 people, including Branstad. Scholl said a controller trainee apparently issued incorrect altitude orders to the American flight. In six of the incidents, a computer alerted controllers to the problem. In the two others, the alert system was not activated. Those two incidents were classified as minor because 80 percent of the minimum separation was maintained.

DOC.HEAD: Hijack Attempt Foiled
DOC.TEXT: Two youths tried to hijack a Soviet jet to Turkey on Thursday and threatened to poison the 165 passengers on board, but crew members and others foiled the attempt, Tass said. There have been three successful hijackings this month of Soviet planes. Also this month, a pilot seized an empty Soviet airliner and flew it to Turkey. Tass said two people were arrested, and identified one as 17-year-old Yu. Kapirushov. Criminal charges have been filed, it said. The plane, a medium-range Tupolev 154 jet with 165 passengers on board, was seized Thursday afternoon on a flight from Krasnodar in southern Russia to the Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk. Hijackers threatened to poison the passengers, Tass said. But it reported that the pilot, V. Alexandrov, landed the plane in Orenburg, about 870 miles northeast of Krasnodar, and that the hijackers were captured ``thanks to ... actions by the crew and a special force.'' It did not identify the force or give any more details. On Sunday, a young Soviet man claiming to have a bomb in his briefcase forced a Soviet domestic airliner to land in Finland, then surrendered to police. The 21-year-old man asked for political asylum. Another Soviet airliner was diverted June 19 to Helsinki. The 20-year-old hijacker of that flight also asked for political asylum.
