A day earlier, a 29-year-old pilot flew a 12-seat plane from the Ukraine to Turkey, where he asked for political asylum. On June 9, a 17-year-old youth forced a domestic Soviet plane to land in Sweden by threatening the pilot with a fake hand grenade. The youth has been arraigned in court but has not asked for political asylum. He said he wanted to leave his home in Byelorussia after a quarrel with his father.

DOC.HEAD: Effi Barry Says She Tried to Darken Skin at Husband's Request
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lede to note incident was 12 years ago
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Barry Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Effi Barry, wife of Mayor Marion Barry, says she tried to darken her skin at her husband's request 12 years ago after a reporter erroneously said she was white. ``I'm mulatto,'' Mrs. Barry said in a recorded interview with the syndicated television show ``A Current Affair.'' Her husband, ``the consummate politician,'' urged her to ``get a suntan'' after the press ``tremors'' shook his first mayoral campaign in 1978. The sunlamp treatments did not work, she added. ``So, a group of us, of my friends, we went to Hilton Head (South Carolina) and the mission was to get me a suntan so I would not appear to be too white in pictures. ``These are some of the kinds of things that are really silly when it comes to color and race,'' she said. Mrs. Barry said she remembered teaching in New York City in the 1960s and being too white to be part of the civil rights movement. ``So you really can't win sometimes,'' she said. Mrs. Barry, whose father was white and mother was black, made the comments in the interview which will be broadcast on July 2.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks Senate to Ratify Nuclear Testing Accord
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday officially asked the Senate to ratify the agreement he made with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev on underground nuclear weapons tests. The accord signed by the two countries June 1 during Gorbachev's visit to Washington spells out measures against cheating on existing treaties that limit nuclear tests. The agreement will permit both nations to ratify the 1974 Threshold Test Ban Treaty and the 1976 Peaceful Nuclear Explosion Treaty, which limits U.S. and Soviet underground nuclear tests to 150 kilotons. The accords recently agreed to by the two countries ``represent the successful culmination of several years of effort to provide for effective verification of compliance with the treaties,'' Bush said in his letter transmitting the treaty protocols to the Senate. Changes at the U.S. nuclear test site in Nevada that are required to meet the agreement ``were considered carefully and have been judged manageable and therefore acceptable in the interests of effective verification,'' Bush wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses Ask For More Help To Cut Drug Abuse By Pregnant Women
DOC.TEXT: Greater efforts are needed to prevent pregnant women from abusing drugs, witnesses told a Senate panel Thursday. But they differed on how to deal with the problem of drug-addicted babies. ``We have a public health emergency with crack cocaine,'' said Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., who presided over a Senate Finance Committee hearing on the scope of the drug baby crisis. Two reports released at the hearing said the number of babies born to women who abused drugs during pregnancy may be several times higher than is reported by hospitals. Estimates that between 100,000 and 375,000 drug-exposed infants are born each year may be far too low because many hospitals do not screen and test pregnant women for drug use, a General Accounting Office study said. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said federal programs and demonstration projects are making more treatment available, but he said ``we need the help of the American people.'' ``Anyone who knows a drug- or alcohol-using pregnant woman has the duty to warn her away from these substances ... this is especially the responsibility of the baby's father,'' Sullivan said. He also said he is asking the Public Health Service to educate the public about the risks of drug use during pregnancy _ including the greater likelihood that the baby will have medical and developmental problems. Sullivan did not say more money was needed in the drug war. Rather, he said, ``I firmly believe that the administration is meeting these challenges effectively.'' But Comptroller General Charles Bowsher said a General Accounting Office study released Thursday showed the drug problem could decrease with more federal funding. After visiting hospitals in Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, New York and San Antonio, GAO investigators concluded that ``nationwide, drug treatment services are insufficient,'' he said in his prepared testimony. He cited a recent survey by the National Association of State Alcohol and Drug Abuse Directors estimating that 280,000 pregnant women nationwide needed drug treatment, but less than 11 percent of them received care. Less than 1 percent of the federal anti-drug funding is targeted specifically at treatment for women, and the percentage is even less for addicted pregnant women, he said. ``Expanding drug treatment services might reduce the number of drug-exposed births and alleviate some of the family dysfunction that is contributing to the growing number of child abuse and neglect cases and foster placements,'' he said. The cost of services for a baby born with problems because of its mother's drug use is estimated to be about $750,000 for the first 18 years of life, he said. Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D., said more emphasis is needed on preventing drug and alcohol abuse, but he added skeptically: ``When all is said and done, there's always a lot more said than done.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Releases List of Disciplined Doctors
DOC.TEXT: Consumer advocates opened a new window on the health-care community Thursday with a state-by-state roster of 6,892 medical professionals who have been disciplined by state and federal agencies. The two-inch-thick compendium, put together by the Public Citizen Health Research Group, lists actions taken against physicians and other medical professionals in 40 states and the District of Columbia. ``If your doctor is among the 6,892 on this list, you ought at least to question the quality of his or her care,'' said Dr. Sidney Wolfe, director of the Public Citizen Health Research Group. ``At the very minimum, you should find out why'' the doctor is on the list. The nation's system for protecting the public from incompetent physicians has ``vastly improved'' in the last 15 years, but remains inadequate, said the group, founded by consumer activist Ralph Nader. ``Gaps the size of the Grand Canyon may have shrunk to Texas arroyos (desert stream beds), but they still snake everywhere across the landscape,'' the group's report said. ``And those dangerous doctors who fall through the cracks continue to kill, maim, defraud and otherwise injure their unknowing patients.'' The guide contains the names of physicians, dentists, chiropractors and podiatrists who have been disciplined by state medical boards, Medicare or the federal Drug Enforcement Administration. Also, each state's section lists doctors who have addresses in that state but were disciplined by medical boards in other states. It also contains the reason for the action, where available. Public Citizen said its compendium is the first such nationwide roster available to the public. The federal government is preparing to open a National Practitioner Data Bank, which will have information on state disciplinary actions, malpractice payments and revocation of hospital privileges. Public Citizen has complained that this information will not be available to the public. It will be accessible primarily to hospitals, health maintenance organizations and government agencies. Public Citizen asked state medical boards and federal agencies for actions taken against doctors since 1985. Some states provided actions that went back even further, while others provided data for only the last year or two. Still others didn't provide any information at all. State medical boards in Alabama, Alaska, Colorado, Oklahoma and South Dakota ``adamantly refused'' to provide the requested data, Public Citizen said. Five other states _ Arizona, Arkansas, Maine, Mississippi and New Mexico _ were willing to provide at least some information, but for various reasons did not, Public Citizen said.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Copies of the guide can be ordered from Public Citizen Health Research Group, Department QD, 2000 P St. N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036. The cost is $30 for individuals, consumer groups and government agencies; $100 for businesses, doctors and lawyers.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Begins Deliberations in Marcos, Khashoggi Fraud Trial
DOC.TEXT: A jury Tuesday began deliberating whether former Philippines first lady Imelda Marcos looted her country of $222 million and secretly invested the money with the help of Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi. The panel was given the case after hearing instructions from U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan. Keenan dismissed the five alternate jurors and requested they not discuss the case with reporters until after a verdict. As the jury left the courtroom to begin deliberations, family members and supporters embraced Mrs. Marcos. Mrs. Marcos, who turns 61 Monday, told a reporter, ``Pray for me a happy birthday.'' She faces up to 50 years in prison and a $1 million fine if convicted of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstructing justice. The jurors also are considering mail fraud and obstruction of justice charges against Khashoggi, 54. The judge told the jury to consider how much Mrs. Marcos knew of the alleged crimes. But he added that she can be found guilty if she ``closed her eyes'' to whether stolen money was used for investments in the United States. Mrs. Marcos' knowledge was a central theme in closing arguments earlier in the week. Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella said the widow of ousted Phillipines President Ferdinand Marcos had to know ``dirty money'' was used to buy four New York buildings, jewelry and art work. Her attorney, Gerry Spence, denied she was aware of the transactions, and said the case was a prosecutor's fantasy. Keenan said the jury must consider whether Mrs. Marcos knew the money was taken by fraud or whether she ``deliberately closed her eyes.'' He said the jurors can convict only if they find the defendants' guilt was proven beyond reasonable doubt. He said direct and circumstantial evidence are given the same weight. In addressing the racketeering charges, the judge said the government did not have to prove that Mrs. Marcos herself committed the fraud. ``A person who aids or abets the commission of an offense is just as guilty of that offense as if he or she committed it himself or herself,'' he said. ``Of course, the mere presence of a defendant where a crime is being committed, even coupled with knowledge that a crime is occurring ... is not sufficient to establish aiding and abetting.'' Mrs. Marcos is alleged to have helped her husband embezzle $222 million from their country's treasury, using the money for secret investments and spending sprees. Khashoggi allegedly served as a front for the Marcoses to conceal ownership of the four New York buildings and art works after they were ousted from power in February 1986 and the new government sued to recover their riches. He could draw a 10-year prison term and $500,000 in fines if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: Three Van Gogh Paintings Stolen When Security System Fails
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUB 6th graf, `It was...' to correct 18 months to two years. pickup 7th, `The Noordbrabants...
DOC.TEXT: Thieves smashed a museum window Thursday and made off with three van Gogh paintings after the museum's alarm system, described as fail-safe, did not go off. The Noordbrabants Museum lost the prize paintings of its collection to thieves who jumped several fences and broke the ground-floor window of the gallery where the paintings were hanging, officials said. Stolen were ``The Sitting Farmer's Wife,'' ``The Digging Farmer's Wife'' and ``Wheels of the Water Mill in Gennep.'' The museum's deputy director, Peter Veenland, said their total value was $2.7 million to $5.4 million. He said the paintings were insured but refused to say for how much. Vincent van Gogh painted them while living in what is now the town of Nuenen, 18 miles from the museum. It was the third time in two years that paintings by the Dutch impressionist had been stolen from museums in the Netherlands. The Noordbrabants Museum has what Veenland called a ``state-of-the-art updated alarm system.'' It has two elements designed to detect intruders _ seismic sensors measure movement and infrared sensors to measure body heat. The security system was turned on and being monitored by a security firm, but both sets of sensors in the van Gogh gallery were found to be inoperative, Veenland told The Associated Press in an interview. ``The system should have showed up that the sensors were not working,'' Veenland said. ``But it didn't happen, and it is a mystery to us why.'' Veenland refused to speculate on whether the alarms were intentionally disabled, or on the possible involvement of museum staff. Police were questioning staff members. Neighbors heard the sound of breaking glass at about 12:30 a.m. and called police. Veenland said the thieves, who police believe numbered three, had to tear the framed paintings off anchors in the wall. It was the first theft from the museum, which moved about two years ago to its current home, a converted granite mansion in this provincial capital 53 miles south of Amsterdam. The museum has about 300 works. The 25-by-32.7 inch ``Water Mill'' was painted in 1884. The 15-by-11.25 inch ``Sitting Farmer's Wife'' and the 15.6-by-10.7-inch ``Digging Farmer's Wife'' were done in 1885. Van Gogh painted them during his so-called Brabant period, when he used as his models the poor peasantry of the Brabant, which encompasses a large part of the southern Netherlands. Guy Jennings, an impressionism expert at Christie's auction house in London, called the stolen paintings ``minor works'' compared to van Gogh's later output, but both he and Veenland said it would be impossible to sell them on the open market. Van Gogh's Brabant period works are generally dark in tone and employ none of the bright impressionist colors, such as those used in ``Irises,'' which have brought record auction prices. The most significant of the Dutch impressionist's works are in Amsterdam's van Gogh Museum and the Kroeller-Mueller Museum near the eastern Dutch town of Otterloo. In December 1988, three van Goghs, including one version of his famous depiction of rural poverty, ``The Potato Eaters,'' were stolen from the Kroeller-Mueller. In May of 1988, three other works by modern masters, including van Gogh's ``Carnations,'' were taken from Amsterdam's Municipal Museum. All were recovered.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Expected to Seek NATO Declaration of No Threat
DOC.TEXT: President Bush probably will ask NATO allies to declare formally next week that they do not pose a threat to nations of the Warsaw Pact, Secretary of State James A. Baker said Thursday. The declaration would be intended to calm Moscow's anxieties about a united Germany being a military and political member of NATO. Baker said it would be premature now for the United States to give cash aid to the Soviet Union to help its sickly economy. Instead, he suggested that the major industrialized nations, at an economic summit in Houston next month, consider guidelines for financial assistance for Moscow. Western European leaders on Wednesday agreed in principle to aid Moscow but have not considered specific proposals or amounts, and some analysts have suggested trading such aid for Soviet military cutbacks. Germany already is guaranteeing loans to the Soviet Union. Baker spoke at a White House briefing to set the stage for a 16-nation NATO summit in London next week and the seven-nation economic gathering in Houston the following week. At his briefing, Baker said NATO should stick with its decades-old policy of threatening to fire nuclear weapons first in response to a major Soviet attack with conventional weapons. Though this so-called ``flexible response'' strategy may be discussed, ``I would suspect that there won't be any (change),'' Baker said. ``I don't think we ought to make Europe safe for conventional war.'' The idea of a non-aggression statement was raised by Bush in an interview with foreign journalists on Wednesday. ``It's appropriate to at least give some consideration to this idea that there could be some sort of a declaration of nonaggression, defensive intent, peaceful intent,'' Baker said. He said any such statement probably would be directed at the member states of the Warsaw Pact rather than the Soviet-led alliance itself. Baker said the United States is not trying to restrain other nations from coming to the Soviets' aid, but feels Moscow must reform its state-controlled economy before the money can be spent in a meaningful way. ``I've been to 10 of these economic summits, the last 10, and I've never been to one yet where there's been total agreement on every issue,'' Baker added. Bush departs Friday for a long holiday weekend at his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine before flying to London on July 4. With the two summits, he will be away from Washington until the early morning hours of July 12. The Pentagon announced that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is delaying a visit to several NATO nations to confer with Bush in Maine before the London meetings Cheney had been scheduled to leave Saturday for a two-week NATO tour, but has put off his departure until Monday evening so he can meet with Bush earlier in the day at the president's summer home in Kennebunkport. The two men are expected to discuss, among other things, the East-West conventional force reduction talks in Vienna and the alliance's response to the revolutionary changes that have swept the Soviet bloc. The defense secretary is slated to visit nations on the flanks of the alliance, including Norway, Greece, Turkey, Portugal and Spain. ``The secretary has already visited the principal NATO allies in the central region and he believed it was very important to give equal attention to our very important allies in the southern and northern region,'' a senior defense official said. The official, speaking on condition he not be identified, said ``the Soviet posture on the flanks and those borders is still quite significant.'' While in Greece, Cheney plans to sign a new defense agreement that allows U.S. bases to remain there for the next eight years, the official said. The United States has four bases and about 20 smaller units in Greece, but is closing two of them in part of a world-wide cost-cutting drive.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Asks Congress for Speedy Debt-Limit Hike
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, saying the federal government will run out of money and borrowing authority late this summer, asked Congress on Thursday to raise the debt limit before its August recess. The current ceiling is $3.12 trillion. The nation's debt stood at $3.05 trillion on Thursday after topping the $3 trillion mark for the first time in April. ``Based on our current estimate, it appears likely that, without an increase in the debt limit, the Treasury will run out of cash and borrowing authority and default on the government's obligations in mid-August,'' Brady said in a letter to Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn. But Brady added that a significant increase in spending on the savings and loan bailout could require a debt-limit increase earlier that month. ``In any case, it is highly likely that default would occur before Congress returns in September,'' the secretary said. His letter to the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee did not include a dollar amount, saying that would follow as soon as the midyear review of the budget is available next month from the Office of Management and Budget. ``At that time, we will also advise you of our best estimate of the date that default would occur absent action to increase the debt limit,'' Brady wrote. The government narrowly averted its first default last November, when Congress raised the debt limit from $2.8 trillion for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30. Although the government has never defaulted, it has come close on several other occasions. For example, it had to dip into Social Security funds to keep its line of credit open in 1985. And in 1983, a delay in increasing the debt limit forced the government to exhaust its line of credit, leading to a suspension of savings bond sales, restrictions on deposits to the Social Security funds and cancellation of scheduled securities auctions. The national debt has more than tripled since the beginning of the decade as the Treasury was forced to borrow more and more money to finance government spending that exceeds tax receipts. The annual deficits have gone down from their peak of over $200 billion a year, but the deficit still totaled $152.1 billion in the year ending last Sept. 30. It totaled $151.68 billion after the first eight months of the current fiscal year and some analysts say it could return to the $200 billion level again by year's end.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Apartheid Leader's Visit Exposes Miami's Racial Tension
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands gathered outside the Miami Beach Convention Center where Nelson Mandela spoke Thursday. Some hoped for a glimpse of their hero, others protested his support for Cuba's Fidel Castro. Blacks and Hispanics have long been at odds in the Miami area. Tensions rose to a fever pitch late last year during the trial of a Hispanic policeman whose shooting of a black motorcyclist triggered three days of rioting in Miami during January 1989. The Mandela visit with its political rhetoric and rejection of the anti-apartheid leader by several Cuban-American mayors in south Florida inflamed those tensions once again. Metal barricades and police in riot gear and on horseback kept the mostly black pro-Mandela crowd away from several hundred Cuban exiles, who burned a Soviet flag and shouted ``Down with Mandela!'' Police broke up several scuffles between the factions and quickly ushered away two self-described rednecks carrying signs saying Fight Communism: Support the Afrikaner Resistance Movement. There were no arrests, police said. While Cubans denounced the 71-year-old Mandela for his ties to Castro, blacks harshly criticized the protests, chanting ``Free South Florida.'' They promised to retaliate on election day against Miami Mayor Xavier Suarez and other Cuban-born politicians who denounced Mandela and stayed away during his visit. ``I'm very embarrassed. I feel this is one of the bleakest moments Miami has experienced,'' said Willie Haywood, a 34-year-old postal worker. ``They had ticker-tape parades for him in New York and hundreds of thousands saw him speak in Boston,'' Haywood said. ``Now we have the distinction of being the most racist city in America.'' At a rally across Biscayne Bay in Miami's predominantly black Liberty City, former federal Judge Alcee Hastings, a longtime black leader, lamented Mandela's treatment. ``It's shameful we didn't do better,'' said Hastings. ``We're the only city that didn't provide this world-class leader with a grand welcome.'' Thursday's gathering of exiles in Miami Beach was the first large-scale protest on Mandela's U.S. tour. South Florida, which has seen three inner-city riots in the 1980s, is the only area where politicians have not clamored to share Mandela's spotlight. ``They should be here with the keys to the city,'' said Joe Cook, 40, with long dredlocks and an African medallion on his chest. ``Anybody who turns his back on him is a little bitty man.'' While waiting for Mandela, supporters outside the convention center sang the African National Congress' anthem and musicians in traditional African costumes pounded a steady drumbeat. Hundreds of people sprinted around the block in hopes of catching a bit of history when he finally pulled into a side entrance. ``I saw him! I saw Mandela!'' shouted Rovan Locke, the publisher of Miami-based Caribbean Commentary magazine. ``Such a great human being in my midst. It's the greatest feeling in my life.'' Mandela left for Detroit immediately after his speech to the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees union, bypassing an invitation to address the impromptu rally in Miami's Liberty City, the scene in 1980 of one of the nation's worst race riots. Cuban exiles said they would have no praise for Mandela until he disassociates himself from Castro. On national TV last week, Mandela praised the Cuban president for his help in the years when the West refused to support his anti-apartheid struggle. ``Mandela is a traitor,'' said Ricardo Acabader, 67, who wore a Cuban flag over his shoulders. ``We're not singling out Mandela's cause. We are opposed to anyone who does not oppose Castro,'' added Rafael Cabezas, a veteran of the failed Bay of Pigs invasion. Mandela has also cited Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat and Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi for their help. Jewish leaders said the comments were troubling, but only a few Jewish protesters joined the demonstration against Mandela.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Rescue Team Pulls Boy Alive from Quake Rubble
LaserPhoto NY22
DOC.TEXT: Soviet rescuers pulled a 9-year-old boy alive from the rubble of his home nearly a week after his family's residence was flattened by an earthquake, the official news media said Thursday. The Islamic Republic News Agency said Morteza Amirpour was found late Wednesday next to the bodies of family members in the ruins of Rahmatabad, 125 miles northwest of Tehran. He was freed 162 hours after the quake, IRNA said. The boy, who was in a coma, was taken to a provincial hospital for treatment, the agency said. It provided no further details. A week after the temblor, casualty figures varied: officials of the Red Crescent, Iran's equivalent of the Red Cross, say they counted 40,000 dead and 60,000 injured. Government officials say 50,000 Iranians died, 200,000 were injured and 500,000 were left homeless. The earthquake, centered near the Caspian Sea about 125 miles northwest of Tehran, destroyed 1,755 schools and caused an estimated $625 million in damage, IRNA said. Also Thursday, Iran's ambassador to the United Nations thanked the 86 nations that contributed aid and issued an appeal for international assistance to rebuild the devastated regions. ``There is an urgent and continued need for international cooperation, not only to alleviate present suffering but also to make the areas as safe as possible in the future,'' Kamal Kharrazi told the General Assembly. To date, Kharrazi said, 171 planeloads of supplies have reached the Iranian capital of Tehran. In addition, about 100 teams have been set up to fight disease and to disinfect disaster areas, he said. Fifteen aftershocks Wednesday and Thursday jolted the northwestern provinces of Gilan and Zanjan, which bore the brunt of the June 21 earthquake, the agency said. Reporting from the devastated township of Rudbar, the agency said one grieving woman who lost her husband and five children in the quake was refusing to eat. ``How can I eat while I myself wrapped the bodies of my beloved children in shrouds and buried them?'' it quoted the woman, Goncheh Ibrahimi, as saying. The June 21 quake, which registered 7.3 to 7.7 on the Richter Scale, according to Western and Iranian accounts, is the deadliest since an estimated 200,000 people died in a 1978 earthquake in China. There have been more than 400 aftershocks in the Iranian fault zone the last week. The Geophysics Center at Tehran University said the strongest aftershock measured 4.8. But IRNA quoted an unidentified senior official at the Tehran center as saying the tectonic fault that caused the deadly quake was ``gradually stabilizing.'' That was welcome news for the thousands of Iranian and foreign rescue workers who have been clawing through the rubble of 342 flattened towns and villages in the rugged region. The aftershocks have blocked roads, halting truck convoys carrying tents, blankets, medicine and food into the stricken provinces. IRNA said one of the latest tremors caused landslides that blocked a key road between Rasht on the Caspian Sea and Rudbar to the southwest for the second time in a week. Relief officials said that with hope running out of finding survivors trapped in the rubble, the relief operation is concentrating more on taking care of the living. IRNA said Mohammad Hassan Eftekhari, a member of the 270-seat Majlis, or parliament, who died in Wednesday's crash of a relief helicopter was given a hero's burial in his hometown of Fouman in northern Iran. Four of the other 14 relief workers aboard the U.S.-built Chinook transport were critically injured when it crashed in bad weather in the mountainous Kelishom region in the southern sector of the quake zone.

DOC.HEAD: Leaner Burgers Headed For School Cafeterias Next Fall
DOC.TEXT: Children next fall may find leaner hamburgers in school cafeterias. The Agriculture Department said on Thursday it soon will begin buying bulk ground beef and frozen beef patties for distribution under the school lunch program for 1990-91. Part of the meat will be a test purchase having a maximum fat content of 22 percent, compared with the current standard of 24 percent fat, said the department's Agricultural Marketing Service. Also, the agency said, a pilot program is being planned for testing beef patties with a fat content as low as 10 percent. Technical details for that project will be worked out with the industry.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Cutting 78 Generals, Admirals
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has decided there will be fewer stars in the Pentagon's firmament and will cut 78 general and admirals over the next four years, it was announced Thursday. Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had recommended that the slots be eliminated, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said. Currently, there are 1,073 such positions in the military _ 407 generals in the Army, 338 in the Air Force, 70 in the Marine Corps and 258 flag officers in the Navy. The cut will bring the new level to 995 such slots by 1995. At the end of April, there were 2 million men and women on active duty in the nation's armed forces. The move is part of the Pentagon's effort to cut back its forces amid the drive to save money and adjust to lessened East-West tensions, Williams said. The reduction amounts to about a 7 percent cut in the number of general and flag officer positions, a far cry from the much larger cuts in store for some of the services. Army officials have predicted that they may be cutting one soldier in four from the ranks over the next five years. Powell, in a statement released at the Pentagon, said his proposal had the backing of the service chiefs. ``The Joint Chiefs and I believe this plan reflects an appropriate balance between continuing requirements and changing force structure,'' Powell said. ``In light of anticipated force structure changes, we recognize the necessity for general and flag officer requirements and inventory to drop below current levels.'' Williams said Cheney and Powell wanted to emphasize that it was appropriate to begin force level reductions ``at the top'' and among all the services. The cut means the elimination of 33 generals from the Army, 27 from the Air Force, three from the Marine Corps, and 15 flag officers from the Navy. A total of 20 positions will be eliminated before the end of 1991, an additional 20 in each of the next two years and 18 in 1994, Williams said. The spokesman said that an attempt would be made to reduce the numbers through retirement and attrition, but that additional steps may have to be taken to make the cuts. ``I don't think retirement and attrition are going to do it,'' he said. Williams said that the exact job positions have not yet been designated for elimination and that such decisions will be left to the various services.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Studies Shamir Letter; Weighs Baker-Levy Meeting
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is taking a close look at a letter from Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Mideast negotiations and may set up a meeting between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and the new Israeli foreign minister, David Levy. Sources said Shamir reaffirmed his commitment to his own proposal for elections among Palestinian Arabs on the West Bank and Gaza and his interest in Baker resuming his effort to implement the plan. The sources, declining to be identified, said the prime minister did not specifically exclude Palestinians deported from the territories from the negotiations. Shamir sent the letter in response to one from President Bush inquiring about the prime minister's intentions now that he has formed a new government. The last Israeli government, headed by Shamir, collapsed in March in disagreement over whether to approve Baker's formula for Israeli-Palestinian talks. A key stumbling block was a provision to include Palestinians deported by the Israelis from the West Bank or others who had homes in East Jerusalem. Even before Shamir replied, American and Israeli diplomats discussed having Baker meet Levy, the new foreign minister. ``It's a foregone conclusion they will meet eventually,'' a U.S. official said. But plans have not jelled. Levy has been hospitalized with a heart condition, complicating the situation. ``A meeting is one option under consideration, the idea being to discuss the letter,'' a second U.S. official said. The sources said Shamir reaffirmed his intention to open the elections to all residents of the West Bank and Gaza. He spoke in general terms, thereby not excluding deported Palestinians, the sources said. Baker declined to discuss the letter at a news conference at the White House. The main topic of the session was the NATO summit meeting to be held next week in London. ``We need more time to study the letter,'' Baker said. He implied there were positive and negative aspects to what Shamir wrote to Bush. ``There are elements on both sides of the equation,'' Baker said ambiguously. But he repeated: ``I don't want to make judgments until we have more time to look at the letter.'' Shamir's plan is to have elected Palestinians negotiate limited self-rule with Israel. After five years, there would be wider negotiations to arrange a lasting settlement.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Considers Exempting Canadian Meat From Border Inspection
DOC.TEXT: A one-year experiment to exempt imports of Canadian meat and poultry from U.S. border inspection is under consideration as a move toward freer trade between the two countries, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Ronald J. Prucha, associate administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service, said the products would still be thoroughly inspected at slaughter and processing plants in Canada under a system that is nearly identical to U.S. inspection. However, he said, Canadian products in the proposed one-year experiment would no longer be randomly sampled at the border. A reciprocal arrangement would be used for U.S. meat and poultry products entering Canada. Prucha said the proposal would help implement the United States-Canada Free Trade Agreement. The proposal will be open for public comments through July 30 before a final decision is made. Comments can be sent to: FSIS Hearing Clerk, Attn: Linda Carey, Room 3171, South Building, USDA, Washington, D.C. 20250.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says U.S. Has No Plan to Send Troops to Peru
DOC.TEXT: A top State Department official said Thursday that the United States has no intention of sending military troops to fight the drug war in Peru. That scenario is the ``farthest thing from our mind,'' said Melvyn Levitsky, assistant secretary of state for international narcotics. Levitsky also told members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee he is optimistic U.S. officials can reach an agreement with Peruvian President-elect Alberto Fujimori about a strategy to reduce the production of coca while encouraging economic development. The U.S. plan calls for sending military equipment and ``trainers'' to help Peru's law enforcement agencies fight drugs. Fujimori said during his campaign that he would reject any ``foreign intervention'' in the war against drugs. But Levitsky said there may have been a misunderstanding on the part of Fujimori about what the United States wants to do. Officials at the U.S. Embassy in Lima have not discussed the situation with Fujimori, Levitsky said. Sen. Chris Dodd, D-Conn., said there was apparently ``confusion about the new government's'' position on U.S. participation in Peru's war on drugs. ``I am wary about the administration's plans,'' he said. Fujimori, who must contend with a decade-long war with leftist Shining Path guerrillas as well as with cocaine traffickers, said he favors economic support to military force in eradicating coca plantations. Last week, William J. Bennett, the administration's drug policy coordinator, said he hopes to complete a formal agreement soon with Peru so the United States can start providing military equipment and training to Peruvian police and military.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Prepared to Provide Food Assistance to Angola
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Thursday it is prepared to provide emergency humanitarian assistance to Angola, where independent estimates indicate that 250,000 people are at immediate risk of starvation. The affected area is in the southern part of the country and includes regions under the control of the government and the U.S.-backed UNITA rebels. The department's statement welcomed a proposal by UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi to establish ``corridors of peace'' to permit rapid distribution of emergency assistance. ``We hope that the government in Luanda will respond favorably to the proposal,'' the statement said. It also urged that Angola's neighbors permit the use of their territory for passage of humanitarian aid. Savimbi outlined his proposal in letters to President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, whose government has provided substantial aid to Angola for years. Savimbi, who called for a cease-fire in Angola's 15-year civil war, also asked Bush and Gorbachev to undertake an emergency airlift of food and medicine to the affected areas. Bush and Gorbachev agreed earlier this month to mount a joint airlift of food for starving Ethiopians with U.S. food flown on Soviet planes. The U.S. and Soviet leaders also discussed joint sponsorship of peace talks between Savimbi and Angolan President Eduardo Dos Santos. The International Committee of the Red Cross has estimated that a quarter million Angolans may face starvation. Dos Santos has put the figure at 1.55 million.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Deny Secret Documents Hidden From Defense
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega's prosecutors acknowledged Thursday they have not given secret Panamanian files to the defense, but blamed the failure on the enormous volume of documents, not interference by intelligence agencies. Michael O'Kane, an attorney for Noriega co-defendant Daniel Miranda, had charged that a ``secret inventory'' discovered by one of his investigators showed about 40 file cabinets seized during the U.S. invasion were missing from a U.S. military warehouse in Panama. Federal Magistrate William Turnoff held a hearing Thursday on the issue, and prosecutors, while not disputing the inventory's authenticity, played down its importance. ``There are far more documents than we have actually placed in the warehouse,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan said. ``We have just yards and yards of documents.'' But he added that he could not say why the documents were not made available to defense investigators in the Corozal warehouse in Panama. ``We asked our people in Corozal for a reason and haven't received one yet,'' he said. Sullivan promised to turn over any relevant files once they were examined, but said that could take up until ``the morning of the trial,'' which is set for Jan. 28. Following the government's assurances, O'Kane withdrew his motion accusing prosecutors of violating Turnoff's order to hand over appropriate documents. But he said the U.S. attorney's office had still not addressed the question of whether documents were removed by U.S. intelligence agencies. ``I think all you can say is they don't know either,'' O'Kane said after the hearing. Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office, said later that prosecutors have no indication so far that any files are missing. O'Kane noted that Panamanian officials investigating corruption under Noriega also have been denied access to the files. He said the list he found shows that during the December invasion, the Army confiscated file cabinets containing Panamanian intelligence files, weapons import-export records, confidential correspondence and files on Noriega foes who plotted a coup. The list is far more extensive than an inventory turned over to the defense by the U.S. attorney's office. The New York Times and The Washington Post have reported, quoting unidentified sources, that Army intelligence officials have complained they fear the CIA ``sanitized'' the captured files. The CIA has denied the charges. Attorneys for the ousted Panamanian dictator have insisted that many of his activities were sanctioned by the United States. They have said that U.S. and Panamanian intelligence records would show he cooperated with the CIA and the Drug Enforcement Administration. The disputed records are in the custody of the U.S. Southern Command's 470th Military Intelligence Group at a warehouse in Corozal. O'Kane said he sent a private investigator to the warehouse to rummage through boxes of documents listed by the government. The investigator found wadded up in one of the boxes as garbage what O'Kane believes is the real inventory, the attorney said. O'Kane's client, Miranda, is out on bond on charges of helping to fly drug money from Fort Lauderdale to Panama. If convicted, he could be sentenced to five years in prison. Noriega, confined at the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside of Miami, faces up to 145 years in prison if convicted of accepting $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn Panama into a safe haven for U.S.-bound drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Services Differ On How To Wash Away War Chemicals
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force will rely on hot, soapy water to rid its military equipment of the remnants of chemical warfare while the Navy plans to use a bleaching agent. But the Army and Marine Corps have for years been using a decontaminating chemical called DS2 that six years ago ate through an electronic cable on an M-1 tank. The selection has concerned lawmakers and prompted congressional investigators to urge Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to direct the Army and Marine Corps to chose a safer, cheaper alternative. ``It could be, literally, another Agent Orange sitting out there,'' Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., chairman of the House Government Operations subcommittee on environment, energy and natural resources, told Army officials. The criticism came as representatives from the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, detailed serious problems with DS2, ranging from leaking containers that were improperly stored to sales to private individuals who were never informed of the hazards. In defense of their selection, Army officials said that unlike the Navy and Air Force, the service's troops live in the field and must take their equipment with them. ``This requires the availability of a decontaminant which can effectively be used in an efficient and immediate manner in locations where water may be severely limited in availability,'' said Brig. Gen. David A. Nydam, commanding general of the U.S. Chemical Research, Development and Engineering Center. The military services have purchased about 5 million gallons of DS2 since the early 1960s with the Army requiring the largest amount _ 666,000 gallons at a cost of nearly $18 million. The chemical solution is manufactured by Dalden Corp. of Roanoke, Texas, and Poly Research of Holtsville, N.Y. The GAO found that DS2 is toxic and highly corrosive and can cause severe burns, liver damage and reproductive or birth defects. Based on the problems, the Air Force and Navy have opted for less toxic alternatives. The GAO found that at five of the U.S. facilities the DS2 was improperly stored and in some cases, the cans were leaking. At Fort Sill, Okla., the chemical was stored with supertropical bleach, a combination the GAO said could set off an explosion. Meanwhile, at Fort Lewis, Wash., cans of DS2 were stored in a shed without walls, exposing the material to the elements. Nydam said the Army was aware of the problem and was correcting the mistakes at the storage facilities. The GAO also found that the Defense Logistics Agency sold cans of the chemical to private citizens but failed to provide them with Material Safety Data Sheets, which identify the health and environmental hazards associated with DS2.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Urged To Reject Time Limits For Reporting Rape
DOC.TEXT: Arbitrary time limits for rape victims to report the crime would throw another obstacle in the path of victims already reluctant to push the issue in court, witnesses told a House panel on Thursday. ``I think we know it is a fact that many victims don't report rapes for days, months, even years,'' said B. Joyce Dale, president of The National Network for Victims of Sexual Assault in Arlington, Va. ``I don't think you can possibly set an arbitrary time limit on victims.'' Testimony before the House Select Committee on Children, Youth and Families centered on a continuing congressional debate over whether arbitrary reporting deadlines _ perhaps 24, 48 or 72 hours _ ought to be imposed on people intending to seek help under federal and state victim compensation laws. Some congressional proponents of time limits believe such measures filter out those who might lie about being raped to receive funds for abortions. But rape victim advocacy spokesmen said they believed the reporting and prosecuting procedures victims have to face prevent women from crying rape untruthfully. ``In recent months, Congress has debated adding new hurdles to the legal obstacle course that must be traversed by victims of rape before they can get the help they need,'' said Rep. George Miller, chairman of the House panel. Witnesses said the trauma of rape prevents many victims from reporting an attack immediately after it occurs. Martha Zehner, who was raped by a co-worker, described why she didn't report the attack. ``One reason was that I was too scared, and I was too much in shock,'' she said. ``I couldn't believe this had happened to me. I wanted to make believe it hadn't happened. ``Years later, when I had created enough emotional distance from this experience, I could begin to understand what happened to me, how frightened I was and really how ill equipped I was to deal with it,'' Zehner said. According to government estimates, nine out of 10 rapes aren't reported to authorities. Based on police reports, every hour 16 rapes are attempted and 10 actually occur. Experts report that an estimated 60 to 80 percent of rapes are committed by someone the victims know.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Says She's Trying `Every Lead' on Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Thursday told the House of Commons that Britain was continuing to ``use every contact and follow up every lead'' to help free British hostages in Lebanon. But she gave no indication of any progress. She also avoided criticizing Iran, which is believed to have influence over Moslem fundamentalist groups holding captives. ``Any nation which has any information about anyone who is held hostage should do all in its power to secure the release of the hostages. That is the only normal, civilized behavior,'' she said. Answering lawmakers' questions, Mrs. Thatcher said it was not yet ``right'' to resume diplomatic relations with Syria. Britain broke relations in 1985, charging Syria with complicity in a foiled plot to blow up an Israeli airliner over London. Iran severed relations with Britain in March last year after Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called on Moslems to kill Salman Rushdie, British author of ``The Satanic Verses,'' which many Moslems say blasphemes Islam. There are five Britons among the 16 hostages missing in Lebanon. The others are six Americans, two Swiss, two West Germans and one Italian. Longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Corn Planting Up 3 Percent for 1990 Crop, USDA Says
DOC.TEXT: Corn farmers have planted 74.6 million acres for 1990 production, up 3 percent from last year's 72.3 million acres, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. The new plantings figures were down only fractionally from 74.8 million acres of corn indicated in a March survey of farmers, despite delays in some areas because of wet weather. Soybean plantings were estimated at 58 million acres, down 4 percent from 1989, the report said. And that was down from the 59.4 million acres of beans farmers had indicated in the March survey. Cotton plantings, at 12.4 million acres, are up 17 percent from last year and the same as indicated in March. The 1990 tobacco crop is being planted on 725,000 acres, up 7 percent from 1989 but down from the 731,000 acres indicated by the March survey. Total wheat plantings were shown at 77.3 million acres, up 1 percent from 1989. The March survey showed total wheat at 77.6 million acres. The report did not include 1990 production forecasts. New wheat figures will be issued by USDA on July 12, and estimates for corn and other spring-planted crops on Aug. 9. Meanwhile, a related report showed the nation's corn inventory as of June 1 was an estimated 2.84 billion bushels, down 17 percent from a year earlier. Of the total, 1.62 billion bushels were stored on farms. The use of corn in March, April and May was estimated at 1.97 billion bushels, up 11 percent from ``disappearance'' in the second quarter of 1989, the report said. Stocks of old-crop wheat on June 1, the beginning of the new wheat marketing year, were reported at 535 million bushels, down 24 percent from a year ago and the smallest carryover since 1975. Even so, that was much larger than the 452 million bushels estimated previously. The soybean stockpile at 596 million bushels on June 1 was up 28 percent from a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
`Santa Barbara' Cops Top Emmys; Lucci Lose 11th Time for Emmy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with winners, their comments; INSERTS in penultimate graf the groups presenting the Emmys. A list of winners, AM-Emmy List, is upcoming; no pickup. A Martinez in 7th graf is correct.
DOC.TEXT: Soap opera star Susan Lucci remained a nominee and not a winner Thursday as Kim Zimmer of CBS' ``Guiding Light'' won the best-actress Emmy and NBC's ``Santa Barbara'' was named outstanding series. Talk show host Joan Rivers broke down in tears when she won her first Emmy as best talk show host. Rivers, host of the syndicated ``The Joan Rivers Show,'' dedicated her Emmy to her late husband, Edgar Rosenberg. Lucci, the Erica Kane of ABC's ``All My Children,'' has been nominated a record 11 times and never has won. She was reported filming an ABC movie, ``The Bride in Black,'' and wasn't at the 17th annual Daytime Emmy Awards show here. A joyous Zimmer told the black-tie audience she's leaving ``Guiding Light,'' in which she plays Reva Shayne Lewis. However, she said without elaboration, ``I will be back some day.'' Her show also won best-writing honors. ``Santa Barbara,'' which last year won a best-drama Emmy, took home other major Emmys this time. In addition to outstanding series, the show won a best-direction award and Emmys for the actors who play father and son on the show. A Martinez, the Cruz Castillo of ``Santa Barbara,'' won best-actor honors, and Henry Darrow, who plays his father Rafael, was named best supporting actor. Julia Barr, the Brooke English of ABC's ``All My Children,'' won as best supporting actress. Cady McClain, the Dixie Martin on that show, also won as best juvenile actress, while an Emmy in the juvenile actor category went to Andrew Kavovit, who plays Paul Stenbeck in CBS' ``As the World Turns.'' Thursday's two-hour show, broadcast by ABC-TV, was hosted by Oprah Winfrey, a previous Emmy winner. Her syndicated show was nominated for four awards but didn't win. Rivers, after accepting her first Emmy for hosting ``The Joan Rivers Show,'' broke into tears into tears as she recalled her dark days and a personal tragedy after Fox Broadcasting axed her late-night talk show several years ago. ``Two years ago I couldn't get a job in this business ... people said I wouldn't work again,'' she said, then alluded to the suicide of her husband, a producer, in a Philadelphia hotel room in 1987. ``It's so sad that he's not here because he ... always said, `You can turn things around,''' she said. ``And except for one terrible moment in a hotel room in Philadelphia when he forgot that.'' She started crying. ``I'm so sorry he's not here,'' she said. A rival of Rivers' show, the syndicated ``Sally Jessy Raphael'' series won an Emmy as best daytime talk show. A lifetime achievement Emmy was given veteran game show producer Mark Goodson, 75. His shows include ``What's My Line,'' ``To Tell the Truth,'' ``The Match Game'' and ``The Price is Right.'' Bob Barker, host of the latter, won an Emmy for best host of a game show, an honor also given Alex Trebeck of the syndicated ``Jeopardy!'' for the second consecutive year. Trebeck's series also was named best game show. In categories of children's shows, PBS ``Reading Rainbow'' won as best children's series, and a CBS ``Schoolbreak Special,'' ``A Matter of Conscience,'' won as best children's special. Best-animated program honors went to two ABC shows, ``Beetlejuice'' and ``The New Adventures of Winnie the Pooh.'' The ceremonies were jointly presented by the Los Angeles-based Academy of Television Arts & Sciences, and the New York-based National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences. Nominees for prime-time Emmys are to be announced Aug. 2 in Los Angeles, with the prime-time awards show to be broadcast Sept. 16 from Los Angeles by the Fox Broadcasting Co.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Cutting Evening Interstate Rates About 5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said Thursday it will reduce its evening interstate long-distance rates by about 5 percent and daytime rates by about a half-percent Sunday as part of a $300 million overall price cut. The company also will reduce the prices of operator-assisted calls, calls to Canada and its Reach Out America long-distance calling plan. Overall, if the Federal Communications Commission approves, interstate calling rates will fall an average 2.2 percent, AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said. The company said it would eliminate the one free call now allowed to interstate directory service, meaning all such calls will cost 60 cents each. The cost of a 10-minute, direct-dialed evening call anywhere in the country will drop to $1.49 from $1.58, or less, from 5 p.m. to 11 p.m., Sunday through Friday. AT&T's prices have dropped nearly 43 percent since the demise in 1984 of the old Bell system, primarily because of FCC-ordered reductions in local access charges. The FCC last week ordered the nation's local telephone companies to reduce by $1.1 billion, effective Sunday, what they charge long-distance companies to connect with local phone networks. Long-distance carriers typically pass along to their customers savings from these reduced ``access charges.'' Other long-distance companies, such as MCI and US Sprint, usually follow AT&T's lead in rate reductions. AT&T, the nation's largest long-distance company, had announced last month that it would cut its rates by $160 million annually based on earlier requests that local phone companies had made with the FCC. Local companies in April had asked to reduce their access charges by $405 million on July 1, but the FCC last week increased that amount to the $1.1 billion figure. Before July 1989, when AT&T's earnings were restricted to about a 12 percent rate of return on its investments, the company passed on to its customers nearly all the savings whenever local phone companies reduced their access charges. But AT&T now is under a regulatory scheme that controls its prices within a prescribed range of ``caps'' tied to the rate of inflation, not its profits. Last November, AT&T raised prices for night and weekend calling by 1.3 percent. AT&T's residential and small business prices currently are at the cap, so this weekend's reductions were necessitated, Linnen said. Large business prices are well below the caps, he added. AT&T said it will cut prices for: _Direct-dialed, interstate calls between 5 p.m. and 11 p.m. Sunday through Friday by an average of 5 percent. _Daytime (8 a.m. to 5 p.m.) direct-dialed calls by an average of 0.5 percent. _The Reach Out America evening discount plan from $8.15 to $7.80 per hour a month and the Reach Out Half-Hour plan to $4 from $4.35. _Per-minute operator-assisted calls an average of 3 percent. _The first minute of Canadian calls at all times.

DOC.HEAD: Another B-Grade Tape from the FBI Filmmakers
With AM-Barry Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The shadowy, blurred image of Mayor Marion Barry smoking crack cocaine in a hotel room is the latest in a series of B-grade tapes produced by law enforcement agencies. The fuzzy, gray and grainy pictures of accused criminals acting out the drama of a case behind numbers that tick off the date, hours, minutes and seconds are not usually of high cinematic quality. Even the owner of a home video camera can generally produce a better picture. But the FBI, which recorded Barry's arrest in a downtown hotel last January, and other police agencies operate at a distinct technical disadvantage when they set up a concealed camera. The lens on a concealed camera must be very small. It's ``not the kind you have on your home video camera, a nice big, large one that would be big and clear and treat light very well,'' said one federal law enforcement official. The quality of the picture also depends on the lighting and ``how much time they have to set it up,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. During the Abscam bribery investigation of the late 1970s, the FBI concealed its cameras inside a television, said a former law enforcement official. Since then, camera technology has improved, but concealment is still the biggest obstacle to a high-quality picture.

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Radio Reports Two Churchmen Sentenced in China
DOC.TEXT: Two officials of the clandestine Roman Catholic Church in China have been sentenced to three years in a labor camp, Vatican Radio said Thursday. The report from Hong Kong said the two were picking up garbage and cleaning latrines after being sentenced without trial on May 21. The radio did not identify the labor camp or say where it was located. The officials were identified as Monsignor Peter Liu Guandong, bishop of Yixian, and the Rev. Xu Zhemin, vicar-general of the diocese of Baoding. They were accused of organizing and participating in illegal activities, the radio said. Liu was earlier reported arrested during a crackdown late last year on clergymen loyal to the pope. China broke diplomatic relations with the Vatican in 1957 and allows worship only under the guise of the state-sponsored Chinese Patriotic Catholic Church, which consecrates its own bishops. The church claims more than 3 million members, but an unknown number of Catholics remain secretely loyal to the pope. Liu participated in a meeting last November that the Vatican Radio described as the first gathering in decades of bishops loyal to the pope.

DOC.HEAD: Racing Champion Reviews ``Days of Thunder''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: As a special assignment for The Associated Press, defending NASCAR (National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing) Winston Cup racing champion Rusty Wallace reviews ``Days of Thunder,'' starring Tom Cruise and Robert Duvall. The movie opened nationally Wednesday.

``Days of Thunder'' is the best racing movie I've ever seen. It's realistic because actual NASCAR race cars were used in the production, and the film relied heavily on real participants for true-to-life impact. Much of the racing action came from actual NASCAR races. The results are tremendous. Robert Duvall's performance was exceptional. Many of the characters in the movie triggered almost instant real-life parallels to people currently involved in the sport. The plot should be of interest to both racing enthusiasts and non-race fans alike. There's action, humor, action, romance and more action. The intense personal competitiveness found in our racing was realistically portrayed. The competitive spirit off the racetrack, and the importance of sponsors to the sport was accurate. One of the most impressive aspects of the movie was its realistic portrayal of the camaraderie we have in the sport. Arch rivals Cole Trickle (Cruise) and Rowdy Burns (Michael Rooker) help each other during a crisis. It's a genuine relationship we have in racing. We may strap on our helmets week after week and go at it against one another, but we come to each other's aid in a real time of need. There's a multi-car crash scene in the movie which really struck home. Cole comes wide open through the smoke and gets caught up in the crash. I faced a similar situation last year in a race at Pennsylvania International Raceway. I crashed big time, too, but luckily I didn't get hurt. ``Days of Thunder'' shows the fear and apprehension racers face. It's something with which you live, rarely ever discuss and try to keep in the right perspective. People involved with racing on a daily basis will probably feel there's a bit too much dramatization in ``Days of Thunder'' because of all the crashing. We do ``rub sheet metal'' a lot, but not as much as is depicted in the movie. And the heat of the battle seems to always focus on only two cars, but I guess that is the basis for classic competition. As for the added drama, my feelings toward ``Days of Thunder'' parallel what a real fighter pilot might think about the level of drama in ``Top Gun'': Things tend to be just a little bit different when you get a bird's eye view. Still, I can't wait to go back to see ``Days of Thunder'' again, this time with my family. The next time around, I'll probably sit in the back row and really soak it in. I'll probably look at it a bit more critically and with more scrutiny next time. The Paramount Pictures release is rated PG-13.

Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G _ General audiences. All ages admitted. PG _ Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: Mirror Maker Trying to Figure Out What Went Wrong
LaserPhoto NY41
DOC.TEXT: Engineers who spent years designing and manufacturing the mirrors now blamed for blurring the Hubble Space Telescope's view of the universe scrambled Thursday to figure out what went wrong. A team of about 40 people at Hughes Danbury Optical Systems Inc. was gathering every document on the Hubble dating back to 1977, when the company was awarded a $450 million contract to build the telescope's precision optics. ``My understanding is that they will review all the documents related to the entire procedure,'' said Thomas Arconti, spokesman for Hughes. Hughes made the two mirrors that were called the heart of the Hubble and which were cited Wednesday as the cause of a focusing problem which has made the space telescope no more powerful than one on the ground. National Aeronautics and Space Administration officials in Washington said the flaw cannot be repaired from the ground. Engineers will install a correcting lens in a replacement camera scheduled to be placed aboard Hubble by space shuttle astronauts in 1993. But the observatory never will be able to capture all the spectacular views of the universe that had been expected, officials said. Scientists are working on ways to salvage some research from the $1.5 billion observatory, and a NASA team is being organized to investigate the problem. Jack Rehnberg, chief of Hughes' space science office, said Wednesday his company was prepared to cooperate fully with the NASA investigation. He said it appeared that ``something inherently, fundamentally was not done right.'' Arconti insisted Thursday that all work related to the Hubble was ``tested and retested, checked and rechecked'' with NASA scientists. He said no one could pinpoint the problem until all the documents had been examined. ``All of our test results met specifications, so that's where the mystery lies,'' he said. He said a team of NASA engineers was expected to arrive in Danbury soon. In the main lobby of Hughes headquarters, business appeared normal. Employees met with clients and even joked occasionally about the Hubble problem. One employee, who refused to give his name but said he had not worked on the Hubble project, said company morale was holding up ``real well.'' Arconti, the only Hughes employee available to comment, said news of the mirror problem ``naturally'' was surprising and disappointing for those who had worked on the telescope. The Hubble Space Telescope was supposed to be able to see into the outer reaches of space, at distances up to 14 billion light-years, or 84 billion trillion miles. NASA Hubble scientist Ed Weiler said at a news conference Thursday that a minute error in the curve of one of the two mirrors is causing the reflected light of the stars to miss a precise point of focus by only 4 percent of the diameter of a human hair _ just enough to spoil the extremely sharp photos astronomers expected. Aside from the mirrors and the other precision hardware, Hughes also supplied the telescope's fine-guidance sensors, which work like an ultra-precise sextant to allow the telescope to literally steer by the stars. Nearly 2,000 employees have worked on the development of the telescope's optics since 1973, four years before Hughes _ then a division of the Perkin-Elmer Corp. _ received the contract. Perkin-Elmer sold its optics division to Hughes Aircraft Co. of California last year.

DOC.HEAD: Rich-Vs-Poor Battle Sparked By Bush Tax Stand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 10-13 pvs, The negotiators, with 4 grafs to update with talks recessing until Friday.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's call for a tax increase is reigniting the partisan, rich-vs-poor battle that ripped through Congress last year over the president's demand for a cut in the capital gains tax. House Speaker Thomas Foley denied Thursday that Democratic leaders implicitly agreed that Bush will win a cut in the capital gains tax in the budget summit in exchange for abandonment of his no-new-taxes campaign pledge. ``We are all interested in reaching an agreement, but there were no preconditions and no agreements,'' said Foley, D-Wash. But supporters of the tax cut read Bush's statement differently, and it has rejuvenated the issue which had been hovering ghost-like ever since Democrats barely succeeded in blocking a cut last year. When the speaker and other Democratic leaders joined Bush Tuesday in endorsing a statement that a ``tax revenue increase'' was needed, the next two words were ``growth incentives.'' In the code of Capitol Hill, that almost always refers to a cut in the capital gains tax rate which would affect people who sell investments, such as stocks or a second home, at a profit. ``I think we should use the current budget negotiations as a brand-new opportunity to put forward a pure, pro-growth capital gains initiative,'' said Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., said after Bush's announcement. The Democratic Study Group, an organization which Foley used to head, countered the Republicans with a letter signed by 134 members saying that ``if the president insists that we need new taxes, we feel they must be levied against... those at the very high end of the income scale.'' The rhetoric is a prelude to what eventually must be tackled in the closed-door budget talks between Congress and the White House. The negotiators continued their meetings Thursday first with discussions of possible cuts in benefit programs and Pentagon spending, but recessed for the night with no decisions made, bargainers said. Reducing spending on the entitlement programs, which include Social Security and Medicare, is extremely sensitive politically because so many voters could be directly affected. ``Everybody flinched,'' Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said to describe the negotiators' reactions when those reductions were discussed. A proposal to reduce military spending by roughly 5 percent next year, to about $290 billion, was offered by Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif. and chairman of the House Budget Committee. Talks on that topic were to continue Friday. Bush maintained as part of his 1988 campaign that cutting the tax would increase federal tax revenues by luring more people into investments that help the economy to grow. The 1986 tax overhaul had eliminated the tax differential on the theory that the economy was best served by a neutral system. Democrats said Bush was trying a reprise of failed trickle-down economics and when he pushed his plan last year they waged their fiercest battle against the new president. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., spearheaded the debate and portrayed Bush as trying to further enrich his wealthy friends _ an attack Bush later complained was too personal. The Democrats lost in the House but succeeded in blocking Bush's plan with procedural maneuvers in the Senate. However, a clear majority in both chambers favored the idea, and opponents including Bentsen, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, indicated they could go along with it if it were part of a fair package of deficit-reduction measures. Foley said Thursday he agreed with the position of Democratic liberals, who point to statistics showing that the bulk of the benefits from a capital gains tax cut would go to the wealthiest members of American society. ``I think the ... position that they want to see tax equity is one that I understand and support,'' Foley said. ``But that does not say there is some kind of absolute condition on the specifics.'' ``I think ultimately there has to be some type of capital gains reduction,'' said Rep. Ed Jenkins, D-Ga., one of the Democrats who voted with the president last year. Jenkins, a member of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, said he could support combining the capital gains cut with a rise in the marginal tax rate for the wealthy. Under the 1986 tax law, people making more than $200,000 a year pay less on each additional dollar in income than do those who make half that much. One top Democratic aide said Democrats who fought Bush on capital gains last year might be willing to accept some sort of reduction if it were part of an overall budget and tax package that forced the wealthy to pay more taxes, such as raising that top income tax rate. ``I think the question is whether you can raise taxes on the rich'' given Bush's presumed continued opposition to raising income tax rates, said the aide, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ``Do you want to double what the rich are paying and then give a little of it back... to finance a tax break for some of them?'' Sen. Alan K. Simpson, R-Wyo., predicted flatly that a capital gains cut ``will be part of the package.'' ``A capital gains tax reduction can be well described in the vernacular of a tax revenue increase,'' said Simpson, the deputy Republican leader. Equity arguments aside, estimates show reducing the capital gains rate would in the short term increase tax revenues as people shift their money into new investments to take advantage of the break.

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Problem Like a Pair of Misfit Glasses
With AM-Hubble Trouble, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Know how fuzzy the world looks when you peer through someone else's glasses? That's how the universe looks to the Hubble Space Telescope. One of two mirrors that collect and reflect star light aboard the $1.5 billion telescope was somehow built with a microscopic error in how it focuses light. The surfaces of both the primary and secondary mirrors on Hubble are perfectly smooth and both are curved to cause light to be magnified. The problem, says NASA scientist Ed Weiler, is that ``one is slightly too convex or too concave.'' This means that the curve of the surface is not aligned perfectly with the curve of the other mirror so that the reflected light collected in the telescope instruments is slightly scattered. The result is that the concentrated starlight has a slightly fuzzy look. There are no sharp, crisp edges. It is similar to the effect when a film projector is not adjusted properly. Weiler said the error is minute. The precise focus error is only 2 microns, a distance about equal to 4 percent of the diameter of a human hair. But it's enough to seriously blur Hubble's celestial sight.

DOC.HEAD: Scorching Heat Continues In West, Southwest
DOC.TEXT: Searing heat still gripped parts of the West and Southwest on Thursday, and the usual summertime thunderstorms and showers moistened sections of the South, the Midwest and the West. Phoenix opened shelters for the homeless and Southern Californians headed for the beach Thursday for relief from the heat wave that began at the beginning of the week. The death toll stood at six in Arizona and California. Unusually high temperatures continued in San Diego County, Calif. Heat advisories were posted through Friday for inland parts of the county. Advisories to agricultural interests were posted into the weekend. The temperature in Pueblo, Colo., hit 104 degrees, breaking the 103-degree record for the date set in 1888 and tied in 1963 and 1970. Early-afternoon thunderstorms and rain showers extended across parts of Minnesota, Iowa, Wisconsin, Missouri, Illinois, Michigan, Indiana, Ohio and Pennsylvania. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered from the Virginia coast through the South Carolina coast, across northern Florida and southern Georgia, and along most of the Gulf Coast. Scattered showers also fell in parts of Montana, the Idaho Panhandle and Washington state. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included more than 2 inches at St. Cloud, Minn., where the rain caused urban flooding. In Minnesota, morning thunderstorms brought hail three-quarters of an inch in diameter to Upsala and 1 inch in diamater to St. Cloud. Thunderstorm winds gusted to 60 mph at Lovilia, Iowa, and 65 mph west of Gettysburg, S.D. Tornadoes touched down near Ackley, Iowa, and thunderstorm winds gusted to about 60 mph at Conrad, Iowa. The twisters blew the roofs off an apartment building and a business in Ackley, but no injuries were reported. Thunderstorms insured a record rainfall for the month at Minneapolis-St. Paul. The Twin Cities have received nearly 10 inches of rain, breaking the record of 9 inches set in June 1897. The nation's temperatures at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 59 degrees at Quillayute, Wash., to 111 at Phoenix. The low temperature for the Lower 48 was 31 degrees in Truckee, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: AMA Doctors Speak Out Against Violent Rock Music
DOC.TEXT: The American Medical Association Thursday threw its support behind voluntary record labeling by the music industry, and declared its concern about the impact of destructive themes in certain kinds of rock music. ``Just as we got into tobacco and we got into alcohol, we should be in all aspects of preventive medicine,'' said James S. Todd, executive vice president of the 290,000-member AMA, the nation's largest physicians' group. At its annual convention, the AMA said vivid depiction of, for example, drug use, demonology and racism could harm young people, and urged the music industry to label its goods _ something it already does, voluntarily. A statement adopted by the AMA's 436-member House of Delegates reads: ``The vivid depiction of drug and alcohol use, suicide, violence, demonology, sexual exploitation, racism and bigotry could be harmful to some young people, especially vulnerable children and adolescents who are socially alienated from traditional value systems and positive support groups.'' The music targeted includes heavy metal, punk rock and rap. The chairman of the committee that debated the issue said the AMA was not seeking to censor, but simply to ensure that parents know of possible dangers to their children. ``I wouldn't want us to be seen as moral arbiters,'' said Neil O. Ward, an otolaryngologist from Phoenix. ``We're not wanting to dictate what's on the marketplace, as much as to make people aware of the destructive themes and make them aware of the dangers to family and adolescent health.'' The move was lauded by the Parents' Music Resource Center, the educational group founded by Tipper Gore. ``With the inclusion of the AMA we now have a very strong message to the music industry _ that educators, parents and medical professionals share a very valid concern about the messages marketed to young people,'' Jennifer Norwood, executive director of the center, said in a telephone interview from her office in Arlington, Va. The American Academy of Pediatrics, which has 39,000 members, adopted a policy last year asking the music industry to exercise taste and restraint. But music industry representatives pointed out that record companies already label music voluntarily. The AMA is ``a little late on this,'' said Tanya Blackwood, spokeswoman for the Recording Industry Association of America, whose members produce about 90 percent of the recordings made and sold in the United States. In 1985, the recording association reached an agreement with the Parents' Music Resource Center and the national PTA for voluntary labeling. Last month, the recording association established a standard label, also voluntary, that is affixed to the permanent packaging on compact discs, records and cassettes. Norwood said she believes about 90 percent of the industry uses labels. The AMA statement was adopted as the delegates wrapped up their annual five-day, policy-making convention. Measures accompanying the statement call on the music industry to label albums voluntarily and on the entertainment industry to ``exercise greater responsibility in presenting music to young people.'' But Blackwood said, ``We are being responsible in the fact that we are voluntarily labeling products, and we've been doing so for five years.'' The doctors also urged parents to monitor the concerts their children attend, the music videos they watch and the albums they buy, and to discuss the music with their kids. And the doctors called upon their colleagues to be aware of destructive themes in rock music and to work to heighten awareness among patients and their communities. ``This is something broadly supported by physicians,'' said Ward.
