The statement and measures were adopted in a clear voice vote and without debate. During discussion in committee, no doctors voiced opposition, Ward said.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors See Barry Smoking Crack Cocaine on Videotape
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 3-5: ``I didn't,'' details from videotape; ADDS two grafs on Farrakhan.
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial watched a riveting videotape Thursday showing the mayor smoking crack cocaine and then being arrested by FBI agents during a hotel-room sting operation. The fuzzy tape shows Barry twice inhaling from a pipe, and a few moments later, agents bursting into the room where he had come at the invitation of a longtime friend cooperating with the FBI. ``I didn't do anything,'' Barry said at first. Then, realizing his situation, he muttered, ``I've been set up'' and uttered a string of expletives at the friend, ex-model Rasheeda Moore. Barry, talking as much to himself as anyone else in the room, repeated his curses and complaints over and over as FBI agents and city police searched him and carried out other routine post-arrest procedures. ``So what do you think about all this?'' one police officer asked politely. ``I'm pissed off. I should have followed my goddamn instinct and not come up here,'' Barry said. ``Simple as that.'' As the videotape was played, Barry studied a transcript in the courtroom. His wife Effi stared, expressionless, at a television monitor. Moore, seated on the witness stand, viewed the tape on a small television set nearby. Asked during a break in the proceedings how he felt about the tape, Barry smiled slightly but did not speak. Barry attorney R. Kenneth Mundy began cross-examination shortly before the trial adjourned for the day, quickly asserting, ``I think she brought up the subject'' of drugs. Mundy contended Moore had cooperated with the government because she needed money. The tape was the talk of the city where Barry retains substantial popularity. It was played and replayed on local television stations, interrupted only by newscasters' and Washington residents' comments. The crowd around a bank of television sets at one department store included Joe Perry, who sighed and said, ``He didn't want to go up to that hotel room in the first place but he was so arrogant that he thought he was bulletproof.'' Three FBI cameras hidden in a downtown hotel room recorded Barry's visit to Moore's room on Jan. 18 and his purchase of an amount of the drug from an undercover agent posing as a friend of Moore's. The tape shows Barry initially expressed reluctance to smoke the cocaine unless Moore did so, too. She declined his repeated requests, saying, ``It makes me too hyper, I get really hyper.'' ``You do it,'' he insisted. ``No, I'm not doing nothing,'' she replied. ``No, you do it,'' he repeated. ``I thought you bought this 'cause you wanted to take a hit,'' Moore said. ``Aw, naw, you do it,'' responded Barry. But she didn't. At one point Barry said of a drug pipe, ``I don't know how this work. ... I never done it before.'' But a few moments later he walked over to a dresser, picked up the pipe, lit it and inhaled the drug. He appeared momentarily wobbly. Moore was across the room. Barry then inhaled again, and the federal agents burst into the room moments later. Barry acknowledged a month ago that he smoked crack that night, and said federal prosecutors were trying to kill him by providing a potentially lethal dose of the drug. His lawyer contends the mayor was the victim of government entrapment, a reluctant, inexperienced drug user on the night in question. However, Moore testified Wednesday that she and Barry used illegal drugs together more than 100 times over several years. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine-possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. One possession charge stems from the night of his arrest. The videotape was shown after a morning of testimony during which Moore said Barry was reluctant to come to her room. In one telephone call between the two, tape recorded by federal agents and played for the jury, he complained, ``There are too many nosy rosies around.'' The videotape shows Barry asking Moore if her friend Wanda _ the undercover agent _ would ``mess around.'' ``Yeah, sometimes,'' Moore said. ``She toots (snorts cocaine) more than she'll do anything else.'' Later, Barry said, ``Let's go talk to her.'' Barry first gae Moore money _ she testified it was $100 _ to buy drugs from Wanda after the undercover agent returned to the room. The two went into the bathroom, and Moore emerged with a packet, the tape showed. Barry only looked at the packet as Wanda left, saying, ``I don't smoke no more honey.'' ``You ... don't want to smoke?'' Moore asked Barry. ``Oh, just powder,'' he answered. But several minutes later, after Moore has said she didn't get any new drugs from Wanda, Barry asked her to get the crack back and provided her with $20, the tape showed. After debating about who would smoke first, Barry finally did and was arrested shortly afterward. Jurors in the case also saw Barry attempting to rekindle what Moore has described as a longtime sexual relationship. ``Can we make love before you leave, before you leave town?'' the mayor asked at one point. ``It would be a good idea just for old time sake, you know, catch up.'' Moore resisted. ``I can't caress your breast?'' Barry asked Moore. ``I'm serious,'' Moore said. ``I can't caress your breast?'' the mayor repeated. Moore testified Wednesday that she stopped sleeping with Barry in June 1988 ``because there were too many drugs during that period.'' Before the phone call and the video recordings were played, Moore testified that she is a recovering alcoholic and cocaine addict. She said it had been only 45 days since she ``last abused cocaine or alcohol.'' She testified that Barry told her at one point he was addicted to cocaine. She also said she was concerned for Barry's health. In an additional development, U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson barred Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan from the courtroom, saying his presence would be ``potentially disruptive and very likely intimidating.'' Mundy said he likely would appeal that decision on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Drugs Found at Home of Rock 'n' Roller Chuck Berry
DOC.TEXT: A search of rock 'n' roll great Chuck Berry's home turned up drugs and guns, authorities told reporters _ and Berry. Berry made a surprise visit to a news conference. He sat quietly as officials recited a laundry list of items, including his driver's license, removed from his estate in Wentzville, about 40 miles west of St. Louis. The estate was raided Saturday while Berry, 63, was away. St. Charles County drug agents found and seized several plastic bags of marijuana, an unspecified quantity of hashish, two rifles and a shotgun, $122,000 and pornographic videotapes, slides and books, said county Prosecuting Attorney William Hannah. No charges were filed; Hannah said none could be filed until all the evidence was reviewed, probably not before Tuesday. In an affidavit filed in circuit court, authorities outlined a continuing investigation of Berry dating from December 1988. The investigation began after federal drug agents said they suspected Berry of carrying cocaine in his guitar case and briefcase. In March 1989, authorities at St. Louis' Lambert Airport searched Berry's baggage but found nothing, the affidavit said. The investigation intensified last week when an informant told authorities Berry had received a large amount of cocaine and would have it at his estate for 10 days, according to the affidavit. But Saturday's raid found no cocaine. ``We would have felt better if cocaine was found,'' Hannah said. ``But that doesn't negate the search. We're going to look at it the same whether cocaine was found or not.'' Berry's attorney, Wayne Schoeneberg, questioned the basis for the investigation and called some of the allegations in the affidavit ludicrous. ``I have never used cocaine ... and nobody in my band has used it,'' Berry, known for hits like ``Johnny B. Goode,'' told reporters after the news conference. According to Schoeneberg, the affidavit also alleged Berry had $36 million in liquid assets, of which $9 million was obtained through drug sales. ``Where's the cocaine? Where did they come up with that? This whole thing is a tragedy to me,'' Schoeneberg said. He said he believed the raid was connected to a civil lawsuit filed in December by a former cook at Berry's Southern Air restaurant in Wentzville who alleged Berry videotaped her and other women in the ladies' room.

DOC.HEAD: Videotaped Evidence Difficult to Explain Away
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 13th graf to detail relevance to Barry case
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Barry Trial Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Videotapes of a criminal defendant taking a bribe, selling drugs or plotting wrongdoing are powerful evidence, difficult though not always impossible to explain away, defense lawyers say. The videotaped image of Marion Barry putting a makeshift pipe to his mouth and smoking crack cocaine is just the latest in a series of well-known undercover operations captured on tape for juries to see. Prosecutors say such evidence is powerful because it puts defendants in a defensive posture, trying to come up with an innocent explanation for what jurors can see with their own eyes. ``Generally speaking, if you get the tapes on and unless the defendant can seriously damage the tape (with other evidence), unless the tapes are deficient, they generally work,'' said William C. Hendricks III, former head of the Justice Department's fraud section. The videotape camera was an effective tool in the Justice Department's Abscam bribery investigation that resulted in the convictions of seven members of Congress in the early 1980s. For example, a tape of Rep. Michael ``Ozzie'' Myers, D-Pa., taking a $50,000 payoff from an undercover FBI agent posing as an Arab shiek led to the lawmaker's conviction and expulsion from Congress. For defense lawyers, videotaped evidence poses problems that ``generally are momentous since it is the prosecution that is staging the event in the sting operation,'' said Richard Ben-Veniste, who defended a Philadelphia lawyer convicted in Abscam. ``At best, an appearance in front of a hidden camera by an individual who later finds himself a defendant in court is ordinarily not going to be a very pleasant thing to watch,'' Ben-Veniste said. But in a few notable cases, defense lawyers who challenged the conduct of police or federal agents who ran ``sting'' operations have won acquittals for their clients. Automobile maker John Z. De Lorean was acquitted in 1984 of participating in a $24 million cocaine conspiracy despite a tape showing him looking into a suitcase purportedly filled with drugs and saying: ``It's better than gold. Gold weighs more than that, for God's sake.'' Defense attorneys put the conduct of government agents on trial, eliciting admissions that an FBI agent destroyed potential evidence and a Drug Enforcement Administration agent backdated documents in violation of agency policy. The defense argued that De Lorean was pressured into participating in the drug deal, claiming there were death threats against his children if he backed out. ``What the defense can do is highlight the means under which the recorded portion of the evidence was set up,'' Ben-Veniste said. As in the De Lorean case, Barry's lawyers are contending that the mayor was the victim of entrapment. The tape of Barry's encounter with Rasheeda Moore at the Vista Hotel provides the defense with material for arguing the mayor was coaxed into smoking crack despite his reluctance. In the Barry case, ``there is substantial ammunition if you are dealing only with that incident'' that resulted in the mayor's arrest on Jan. 18 in a downtown hotel room where he was invited by a friend cooperating with the FBI. The defense will try to show that ``this was really the misuse of great authority to utilize an attractive former girlfriend to get an individual using a controlled substance that he had not brought with him, that the governent supplies along with the apparatus for using it,'' Ben-Veniste said. Washington defense lawyer Robert P. Watkins said he believes evidence of police misconduct helped win a 1976 acquittal of a former federal prosecutor who was videotaped taking money from an undercover policeman. The evidence showed that the former prosecutor, Donald Robinson, was having an affair with a prostitute, who was caught on camera selling credit cards she had stolen from her customers to the undercover sting operation. Robinson was lured in front of the camera and taped accepting the money in return for a file on police informants. Despite this evidence, the tape was not enough to convict Robinson, who testified that his wife had received threatening phone calls. Watkins, who represented Robinson, said the defense produced evidence that undercover police asked the prostitute to undress in their presence. This evidence seriously hurt the credibility of the police, Watkins said. ``It was a factor that didn't bear directly on the issue Robinson was charged with but it certainly was, I believe, crucial, in showing that these policemen were doing extracurricular things other than just running a sting operation.'' ``You have to embrace the tapes and then explain them away,'' Watkins said. ``That's what happened in this case.'' The defense was able to answer the question: ``Why was this guy put in this situation?''

DOC.HEAD: Far-Right Leader Le Pen Charged With Racial Defamation
DOC.TEXT: Jean-Marie Le Pen, president of the far-right National Front, was charged with racial defamation Thursday for a remark about ``international Jewry'' in a newspaper interview. No date was set for further proceedings in the case. Le Pen, whose party advocates deportation of immigrants, is a member of the European Parliament. The current case marks the second time his parliamentary immunity has been lifted to allow defamation proceedings. Le Pen said he was being prosecuted for one sentence in an interview published by the daily newspaper Present in August 1989. He said that ``international Jewry plays a non-negligible role in creating an anti-national spirit.'' Le Pen denied the statement was defamatory and said it should be taken in the context of the full interview.

DOC.HEAD: Demjanjuk Lawyer Pleads Against Death Sentence
LaserPhoto JRL1
DOC.TEXT: Convicted Nazi war criminal John Demjanjuk should not be executed because sufficient doubt exists about his identity, his lawyer told the Supreme Court in a final plea Thursday. Yoram Sheftel, Demjanjuk's Israeli attorney, ended the longest appeal in Israel's history by asking the panel of five justices to overturn the death sentence because of ``lingering doubt'' about Demjanjuk's guilt. Sheftel also asked the Supreme Court not to hand down a decision before Jan. 1 in order to give the defense time to investigate new evidence that might prove Demjanjuk's innocence. ``There is no case that potentially could contain a mistake more than this case,'' he said . Sheftel said the justices should find Demjanjuk innocent, a victim of mistaken identity. The appeal began on May 14 and included 13 days for defense arguments and 12 days for the prosecution. Chief Justice Meir Shamgar said the justices would consider the request to postpone their decision but did not indicate when they would rule. Demjanjuk, 70, a retired Cleveland autoworker, was convicted and sentenced to death in April 1988 for crimes against humanity and crimes against the Jewish people. His trial lasted 14 months. The three-judge trial court agreed with the prosecution that Demjanjuk was ``Ivan the Terrible,'' a Ukrainian gas-chamber operator at the Treblinka death camp in World War II who raped and beat Jews as they were forced into the gas chambers. More than 850,000 Jews were murdered at Treblinka in Nazi-occupied Poland in 1942-43. A Ukrainian native, Demjanjuk claims he is a victim of mistaken identity and says he spent those years in German POW camps as a captured Soviet soldier. Demjanjuk changed his first name from Ivan to John when he became a U.S. citizen in 1958. Demjanjuk's 24-year-old son, John Jr., said the defense hopes to question a Treblinka guard who claimed in a 1979 statement to Soviet investigators that the surname of the Treblinka gas-chamber operator was Marchenko. Demjanjuk's son said the guard failed to identify Demjanjuk from photographs. He said the defense just learned the guard is still alive and lives in the Soviet Union. Sheftel argued Thursday that ``Ivan the Terrible is Ivan Marchenko,'' a Ukrainian guard who resembled Demjanjuk. The claim was supported by two affidavits from a guard who said Marchenko was posted with him at Treblinka and a deposition from a liquor store owner whose wife was a prostitute who slept with Ivan the Terrible, Sheftel said. The liquor store owner identified Ivan the Terrible from a 1942 photograph that prosecutors allege is of Demjanjuk, but said the man in the photo was named Marchenko. The name Ivan Marchenko also appears on a partial list of Treblinka guards compiled by Polish prosecutors. Marchenko is Demjanjuk's mother's maiden name, which prosecutors claim Demjanjuk sometimes used as an alias. Demjanjuk was identified from photo lineups by Treblinka survivors. He was also identified by Otto Horn, a German Nazi who supervised Jews forced to take corpses from the gas chambers and arrange them in a burial pit. Five Treblinka survivors and Horn testified against Demjanjuk. Demjanjuk was stripped of his U.S. citizenship in 1981 and extradited to Israel from Ohio in February 1986. Demjanjuk was convicted in Israel under a 1950 law allowing the prosecution of Nazis and Nazi collaborators. It is the sole crime that permits the imposition of the death penalty in civilian courts in Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Colonel's Testimony an Obstacle to Prosecution of Jesuit Massacre
DOC.TEXT: In a major setback to the investigation into the slayings of six Jesuit priests, a colonel has denied hearing a colleague was involved in the massacre, judiciary officials said Thursday. Army Col. Carlos Aviles had been considered a crucial witness against Col. Guillermo Benavides, a colleague who along with three lieutenants and five soldiers has been charged with the Nov. 16 murders. Sources close to the case described Aviles' denial, made in sworn testimony Wednesday, as a blow to successful prosecution of the case. ``With the colonel's testimony, the case becomes even more difficult. Based on the evidence we have now, I'd say there is about a 10 percent chance of taking the case to trial,'' one prosecutor said. The slow pace of the investigation along with the disappearance of evidence and witnesses has been criticized by a U.S. Congressional committee and officials of the Roman Catholic Church. Authorities say a military death squad went to the Jesuit-run Central American University before dawn and shot the priests, their housekeeper and her teen-age daughter. The U.S.-backed military at first denied any connection to the killings, which took place amid an offensive by leftist rebels in the capital. The military had said the priests were rebel sympathizers. The case blew wide open after a U.S. military advisor said Aviles told him on Dec. 20 that Benavides was involved. U.S. Army Maj. Eric Buckland, in sworn testimony, said Benavides confessed his role to an officer who then told Aviles. U.S. officials say Aviles' information was directly responsible for moving the investigation from detective work to the arrest stage. All the named suspects are in custody except for one of the privates. Aviles denied Wednesday telling Buckland that Benavides was involved, said Violeta Lugo, a government prosecutor. ``Col. Aviles denied having any information about Col. Benavides' supposed role in the massacre, much less having passed such information on to the U.S. major,'' Ms. Lugo said. ``He said he went to the U.S. major after this version of events became public to rebuke him for involving him (Aviles).'' Aviles gave his testimony to Judge Ricardo Zamora, who is in charge of the investigation. Zamora on Wednesday issued a warrant for the arrest of Lt. Col. Camilo Hernandez for allegedly taking part in a cover-up. Hernandez allegedly ordered the burning of military log books that traced the movements of the troops accused of carrying out the massacre. Hernandez said Thursday he was awaiting orders from his superiors before turning himself in. Hernandez said he was awaiting instructions from either the defense minister, Gen. Humberto Larios, or from the chief of the joint chiefs of staff, Col. Rene Ponce. Larios has repeatedly pledged full military cooperation with the investigation. No Salvadoran officer has ever been prosecuted for a human rights crime, despite the deaths of tens of thousands of people at the hands of death squads linked to the armed forces and to President Alfredo Cristiani's ARENA party. To date, the only evidence presented against Benavides has been that of other defendants, which is not admissible in Salvadoran courts. Two of three lieutenants leading the death squad said Benavides ordered the massacre. Rightists considered the left-leaning priests subversives because they had said El Salvador's decade-long revolution was a war on social and economic injustice, rather than a reflection of international Communist expansion. The massacre provoked an international outcry and calls from some quarters in the U.S. Congress for sharp cuts in aid to El Salvador, the largest recipient of U.S. aid in the hemisphere.

DOC.HEAD: Army Proposes Civilian Job Cuts
With AM-Pentagon-Officer Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The Army is thinking about trimming 7,000 civilian jobs, many of them in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and Texas, it was announced Thursday. The reductions would come mostly at installations for the Army Materiel Command, which is the Army's largest civilian employer. The command is in charge of research, development and procurement for equipment and weapons for the Army, its ammunition production and storage, and the operation and maintenance of troop supply and storage distribution facilities. Many more announcements of such relatively minor reductions in the Pentagon's 1.1 million-strong civilian work force are expected in the coming months and years, given the Pentagon's current budget-cutting drive. ``These are proposed, not approved, reductions,'' the Army told Capitol Hill lawmakers in a memo designed to inform them of the possible move. ``In view of the continued decrease in military forces, plans are being implemented to reduce appropriate civilian support activities through fiscal year 1994,'' the memo said. The Army said it would inform lawmakers as the reductions are approved. In proposals submitted to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney earlier this year, the Army also has proposed cuts in its active duty force that would take one soldier in four out of the ranks. Currently, there are some 2 million men and women in the armed services and about 745,000 in the Army. In the memo sent to Capitol Hill, the Army said it recognized the hardship that will result from the reductions in the civilian job force and that ``every effort is being made to ease the trauma precipitated by these displacements.'' The three states that could be hit hardest by the proposal include Pennsylvania, which leads with 1,122 proposed cuts, followed by Texas with 1,006 reductions and New Jersey with 943. The reductions could be made on an involuntary basis unless the Office of Personnel Management gives the Army the authority to grant voluntary early retirement to older employees, the Army said. The proposed cuts announced Thursday in each state are: Alabama, 805; California, 268; Colorado, 95; Georgia, 68; Indiana, 6; Illinois, 449; Iowa, 4; Kansas, 2; Kentucky, 447; Louisiana, 85; Michigan, 535; Maryland; 84; Missouri, 565; Mississippi, 31; Nevada, 17; New Jersey, 943; Oklahoma, 116; New York, 307; Pennsylvania, 1,122; South Carolina, 95; Tennessee, 13; Texas, 1,006; Utah, 124; Virginia, 202.

DOC.HEAD: Former Brockton Police Chief Sentenced in Cocaine Theft
With AM-Barry Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A former police chief was sentenced to seven to 10 years in state prison after pleading guilty to stealing cocaine from his department's evidence room. Richard J. Sproules also was sentenced to a concurrent seven-to-10-year term for embezzling city funds and to three to five years on two counts of intimidation of a witness and one count of attempting to procure another to commit perjury. Sproules, 46, is believed to be the highest-ranking Massachusetts police officer to be charged with drug offenses. In a plea for leniency, Sproules told Plymouth County Superior Court Judge Suzanne V. DelVecchio: ``My actions are inexcusable. For all the youngsters who looked up to me, I'm ashamed ... You look at me a ruined and destroyed man _ but there's no one to blame but me.'' Sproules, who had faced up to 35 years in prison, had originally pleaded innocent to seven indictments. On Thursday, he pleaded guilty to the cocaine theft charge. Sproules had planned to acknowledge there was sufficient evidence to convict him of stealing city money, but not to admit to all of the allegations. DelVecchio, however, refused to accept that plea and found him guilty of the embezzlement charge. State police arrested Sproules, who had been a leader in the fight against drugs in Brockton, in his office Oct. 24. The arrest shocked this city of 95,000 people 23 miles south of Boston. He had been proclaimed the city's best hope in the fight against drugs when he was appointed police chief in 1987. A grand jury indicted Sproules last year on charges of larceny of cocaine, attempting to get another person to commit perjury, obstruction of justice, larceny of more than $250 and two counts of intimidation of a witness. The same grand jury indicted him on a charge of embezzlement last March. No action was planned on the charges of obstruction of justice and of larceny in excess of $250, said Dolores Sullivan of the court clerk's office. The Norfolk County district attorney's office investigated the case because Sproules and Plymouth County District Attorney William O'Malley have been friends since childhood. Sproules' attorney, Bruce Edmands, said Wednesday they had accounted for all but about $4,300 of nearly $200,000 Sproules controlled as police chief. Sproules did not steal money for his own use, but spent city money inappropriately on police operations, Edmands said. But prosecutors said in court Thursday that $74,764 in city funds remain unaccounted for.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Nominate Mueller as Criminal Chief
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS Lede and 4th graf: ``Mueller is,'' to CORRECT that Mueller is not a Boston lawyer but a Justice Department aide
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday he will nominate Robert S. Mueller III, a special adviser to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh on criminal matters, to run the Justice Department's criminal division. Mueller will succeed Edward S.G. Dennis Jr., who announced earlier in the day that he was leaving his post as assistant attorney general on Aug. 31 to become a senior partner in a Philadelphia law firm. From 1985 until 1988, he served as assistant U.S. attorney, deputy U.S. attorney and U.S. attorney in Boston, where he had once been a partner in a law firm. Mueller is currently an assistant to Thornburgh, overseeing major criminal investigations, including the prosecution of deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Norieta. Earlier, he worked in the U.S. attorney's office in the Northern District of California. A Marine during the Vietnam War, Mueller was awarded the Purple Heart, Bronze Star and two Navy commendation medals. Dennis is a career federal prosecutor who has headed the criminal division since 1988. Dennis said in a statement that he will become a senior partner at the prestigious Philadelphia law firm of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius. Justice Department officials stressed that Dennis's resignation was unrelated to recent staff turmoil, which came to a head in May when Deputy Attorney General Donald B. Ayer resigned. Nevertheless, two sources said Dennis had grown frustrated with Thornburgh's management style, which had centralized decision making in the attorney general's office. In a statement, Dennis said Thornburgh ``has provided outstanding leadership to the department, and I am delighted to have had the opportunity to work under him.''

DOC.HEAD: Girl Killed by Car Bomb, 13 Wounded in Lebanese Hills
DOC.TEXT: Bombs exploded in Beirut and two southern cities Thursday, killing a 7-year-old girl and wounding 13, police said. The girl was slain in a bomb blast that wrecked the first-floor office of the pro-Iraqi Baath Arab Socialist Party in the southern provincial capital of Sidon. Four people were wounded, police said. Iraq and Syria, ruled by rival wings of the Baath Party, have been feuding for 11 years. An hour earlier, a car bomb exploded 400 yards from a Syrian Army checkpoint in the Talel el-Khayyat district of Moslem west Beirut, wounding six, a police spokesman said. The compact car, which had been parked in the street for more than a week, contained about 66 pounds of dynamite, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. The explosion shattered windows, damaged apartment buildings and set five cars on fire. It was the fifth car bombing in Lebanon this year. By police count, two people were killed and 31 wounded in earlier explosions. The third bomb exploded before dawn outside a PLO office in the Palestinian refugee camp at Rashidiyeh, 50 miles south of Beirut. Three Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas were wounded, police reported. The bombing came 11 days after guerrillas loyal to PLO chairman Yasser Arafat cracked down on supporters of renegade terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal in Rashidiyeh, leaving four people dead and 16 wounded. As is usual with bombings in Lebanon, there were no claims of responsibility for Thursday's blasts by any of the armed groups in the splintered country. There has been a chain of bombings since the Syrian army moved into west Beirut in 1987 to quell militia anarchy. It has been seen as a campaign designed to undermine the Syrian peacekeeping effort. Also in south Lebanon, police said one person was killed and two were wounded in clashes between the Sidon-based Nasserite Popular Organization of Sunni Moslem leader Mustafa Saad and militiamen of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army. The clashes around the hilltop village of Kfar Falous, east of Sidon, flared intermittently throughout the day with mortars, rocket-propelled grenades and machine guns.

DOC.HEAD: Stomach Reducers Recalled
DOC.NOTE: EDs: The company has established 1-800-244-7808 for calls from customers about the device
DOC.TEXT: The manufacturer of a stomach reducing device Thursday recalled 700,000 of the exercisers because of several incidents in which consumers were hurt while using them. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Harrison-Hoge Industries Inc. recalled the ``New Gym Stomach Eliminators'' after the company and agency learned of 62 incidents in which consumers using the exercisers suffered ``serious facial or body injury'' after a spring or clip broke. The devices, sold nationwide from 1985 to December 1989 by mail and in retail outlets, are composed of three 12-inch black metal springs attached to a black plastic handlebar and footbar. The footbar, footstrap or handlebar are marked ``Made in Italy'' or ``Brevattato'' Consumers should immediately discontinue use of the execisers and contact Harrison-Hoge for a refund or credit toward other company products, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Charged with Burying Son Alive, Ordered Held Without Bail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th graf, `Defense lawyer...' to UPDATE with defense lawyer withdrawing, burial delayed.
DOC.TEXT: A man who reported his 11-month-old son had been abducted was charged Thursday with killing the child by burying him alive. An autopsy found Michael Christopher Chapman died of asphyxiation as he struggled to breathe and claw his way from under several inches of dirt. ``He probably lost consciousness quickly, probably within seconds,'' said Coroner Shirley Hofmaier, who conducted the autopsy. ``And I hope that's what happened.'' Peter Chapman, 39, of Germantown was jailed without bail, and a preliminary hearing was set for July 5. Washington County Circuit Judge James Schwalbach rejected a defense request to allow him to attend his son's funeral Thursday. Defense lawyer Jerome F. Statkus said his client would probably plead innocent to the charge of first-degree intentional homicide, which carries a mandatory life prison sentence on conviction. Statkus said later Thursday he had withdrawn from the case because Chapman lacked funds to hire a forensic pathologist to examine the child's body. The court agreed to a public defender's request to delay the boy's burial to allow for such an exam, Statkus said. Germantown Police Chief Frank Riemer said no motive for the killing was known. Riemer said it was the worst case he had dealt with in his 25 years as chief of police in the Milwaukee suburb. ``The other cases I've had were understandable,'' he said. ``This is not understandable.'' Chapman initially told police his son was abducted Sunday morning from his car outside a Milwaukee service station. But under questioning, Chapman changed his story and told police he awoke Sunday morning and found his son dead. He said he panicked, put the body in his car and drove until finding a site for a grave. He led authorities to the grave Monday in a secluded, wooded area of Germantown. Police found the child's body in a hole with his head 4 inches below the surface and the rest of his body at a depth of up to 22 inches. The coroner's report said dirt was lodged in the boy's esophagus and stomach, indicating he had been smothered. Dirt was also found in the boy's clenched hands, and the position of his head, arms and feet indicated he was struggling to breathe and claw his way out. ``There's no way this is an accident _ not when you dig a hole, put someone in it and cover it up,'' Riemer said. ``That's just not accidental.'' Sheriff Robert Shulteis, who supervises the county jail, said Chapman was being kept in isolation after he was harassed by other inmates. Chapman was not married to the boy's mother, Gina Godlewski, 24, of Menomonee Falls. Court records show she sought a restraining order against him earlier this year, saying he had a history of physical abuse and ``looks at times like he's going to kill me.'' A hearing over custody of the child had been scheduled for Friday, court officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Returned Coup Leader to Serve Rest of Prison Term
DOC.TEXT: Former President Nicos Samson, the convicted leader of an abortive coup who has returned home after 10 years in exile, must serve the remainder of his 20-year prison sentence, a government spokesman said Thursday. Samson was arrested Wednesday as he stepped from an Air France jetliner at Larnaca airport and taken to the Central Prison in Nicosia. He returned to Cyprus after a decade of exile in Paris. Speaking at a press conference, government spokesman Akis Fantis said the deputy attorney general had ruled Samson, who was president briefly in 1974, would have to serve the remaining 17 years of his sentence. Newspapers, however, speculated that President George Vassiliou might pardon Samson, 54, a right-wing extremist, former newspaper publisher and member of Parliament. Samson was considered by Greek Cypriots a hero of the 5-year uprising against British colonial rule in the 1950s. Cyprus became independent in 1960. He was sentenced in 1976 for his involvement in the violent coup that briefly overthrew the late President Archbishop Makarios in July 1974. The right-wing officers who engineered the coup with support from Greek Cypriot supporters of union with Greece installed Samson as president but he was forced to step down only eight days later, after a Turkish invasion. Turkey continues to occupy 37 percent of the territory of the east Mediterranean island. An amnesty was granted for all repentant participants in the coup and the unrepentent Samson was the only person prosecuted and jailed. In April 1979 his sentence was temporarily suspended so he could travel abroad for urgent medical treatment unavailable locally. Instead of returning to Cyprus, Samson sought political asylum in France. Following his arrival at the Nicosia prison, Samson said in a statement he had decided to return voluntarily. ``It is better to return and serve the rest of my sentence, rather than stay abroad,'' said the statement, which was read by his son, Sotiris.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Governor Signs $3 Billion Environmental Lands Law
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists hailed a $3 billion, 10-year program to protect Florida's natural spaces from rampant development, which Gov. Bob Martinez signed into law Thursday. ``Probably for the first time in anybody's memory, the state of Florida has placed a priority on land acquisition (and recognized) that there is a need to preserve and conserve their lands,'' said Curt Blair of the Sierra Club's Florida chapter. ``I think we're certainly on the cutting edge.'' The Preservation 2000 law, which Martinez proposed, authorizes use of $30 million as collateral for the sale of $300 million in bonds for purchase of wetlands, beaches, scenic river areas and forests. The $30 million would be raised by taxing real-estate transfers and investments. The Republican governor signed the measure while on a re-election campaign stop in West Palm Beach. ``Preservation 2000 is the most ambitious land acquisition program in the nation and will enable Florida to lead the way in protecting its environment for future generations,'' Martinez said. The measure includes a commitment to sell the bonds through 2000. But the Legislature must return each year to re-authorize the $300 million bond sale. Martinez' original proposal would have authorized the entire $3 billion once the bill was signed, but lawmakers did not want to give up their constitutional year-by-year authority over tax dollars. Environmentalists, despite the prospect of having to fight anew each year, acclaimed the measure as one of the strongest commitments in the country to save land from developers. Blair said other states like California and New York have similar programs but few are as large as Florida's, particularly if the entire $3 billion is authorized to buy environmentally sensitive land. Dominic Calabro, president of the Florida TaxWatch public interest group, said the new program is good but warned that the state must beware of cheats. ``We need to be very thoughtful and very careful as we purchase these lands,'' he said. ``We must make sure they are the correct and needed lands.'' A state grand jury found recently that Florida often pays far too much for environmental and recreational lands, sometimes because owners overstate value, and sometimes because of a law that lets the state pay 125 percent of value in some instances.

DOC.HEAD: Excursion Train Crash Injures 40 Tourists
DOC.TEXT: A locomotive crashed into a train of passenger cars carrying sightseers on a tour of the historic Klondike gold-rush trail, injuring 40 people, officials said Thursday. None of the passengers were seriously injured in the accident Wednesday. All rejoined their tour group aboard the cruise ship SS Viking Serenade in Juneau on Thursday, said Paul Taylor, vice president of the White Pass and Yukon Route Railroad. The accident happened after the train, carrying 170 people on an excursion trip from Skagway, reached the top of the 2,800-foot White Pass summit on the Canadian side of the border. The locomotive was preparing to re-couple with the passenger cars for the return trip when it apparently failed to slow down and rammed into the cars, Taylor said. Thirty passengers were treated at the Skagway medical clinic and released. Another 10 were flown by small airplane to Juneau, about 100 miles south. The narrow-gauge railway was built in 1900 during the gold rush. About 70,000 passengers ride the train to White Pass annually. Taylor said an investigator from the Canadian National Transportation Agency would arrive Friday to investigate the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Outside Medellin Police Station Kills 14, Wounds 30
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with death toll rising to 14, details from police communique about explosion, edits to conform. Pickup 17th graf pvs, `At least...'
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded Thursday on a crowded street outside a police station in the cocaine capital of Medellin, setting nearby vehicles on fire, killing 14 people and wounding 30, authorities said. Four of those killed as well as many of the wounded were children, Medellin Police Chief Col. Jorge Ferrero said in a communique. No one claimed responsibility for the bombing, but authorities blame the the Medellin drug traffickers for waging a terror campaign of bombings and assassinations in Colombia's second largest city. On Wednesday night, security forces deactivated a car bomb loaded with a half-ton of dynamite in a parking lot near a city government office building in Medellin, police said. In Thursday's attack, witnesses saw a man running away from a compact car parked in front of the police station minutes before the bomb exploded at about 11:30 a.m., according to radio reports. Police said the small sedan with false license plates was packed with 330 pounds of explosives. ``We heard a tremendous roar,'' a local businessman said in an interview with the radio network Caracol. ``Several people were trapped in their cars and were burned up or blown apart by the explosion.'' Another unidentified witness told the radio network RCN: ``The only thing I felt was a huge explosion that threw me from my car.'' Associated Press photographer Ricardo Mazalan said that after the explosion people were screaming hysterically, crying and searching for loved ones. ``They've done me in! They've done me in! They killed my son!'' a man screamed as he dropped to the ground weeping, Mazalan said. The blast destroyed at least 10 cars and left a crater five-feet deep and 12-feet wide, Mazalan said. It also damaged a number of nearby stores. Four people were pronounced dead at the scene and the others died in hospitals, Bernardo Guerra, president of the Medellin government's Emergency Committee, told RCN. The dead included Miriam Nasa Sampayo, a reporter for the Caracol network, a policeman, and the wife and two children of a federal senator from Medellin representing the governing Liberal Party, Ferrero said. Guerra said 30 people were injured, and many of them were in critical condition. One of those injured was a policeman. The blast went off minutes after Ferrero was sworn in as Medellin's new police chief at a police base several miles away. He took over from Gen. Humberto Camero as part of a major shakeup of the Colombian police force this month. Medellin, about 160 miles northwest of Bogota, the capital, has about 3 million residents. It is also a major center in the cocaine trade. The Medellin cartel has announced a campaign to assassinate policemen. In April, the cartel offered $4,300 for each slain law enforcement officer. So far this year, 150 policemen have been killed in the state of Antioquia, whose capital is Medellin. All but 17 of the police officers were slain in Medellin. At least 285 people have been killed in hundreds of bomb attacks in Colombia the past 10 months since the cartels began fighting the government's efforts to extradite suspected drug traffickers to the United States. Colombia has extradited 15 suspected traffickers to the United States since President Virgilio Barco ordered a crackdown on the drug trade last August. However, the Bogota daily El Tiempo, the country's largest daily circulation newspaper, reported Thursday that the Barco goverment may have temporarily halted the extraditions. The newspaper said there have been no extraditions for three months. It added that 15 Colombians facing extradition had been moved from secret police headquarters to La Picota prison, indicating they won't be extradited soon. The newspaper said Barco may have suspended the extraditions in order to allow his successor to decide his own policy. President-elect Cesar Gaviria, who takes office Aug. 7, has declared he would continue the war against the drug trade. However, he has hinted he will not make extraditions a major part of that war unless Colombia gets more help from the United States and Europe and preferential trade treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Governor's Office Receives Abortion Bill
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer's office Thursday received the toughest anti-abortion bill passed by any state in the country, but did not say when he will issue his promised veto. The bill, which carries a 10-year prison term for anyone who performs an abortion and provides no exceptions for victims of rape or incest, passed the Legislature this week. Its supporters designed it as a direct challenge to the U.S. Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision establishing the right to an abortion. Roemer has repeatedly promised to veto the bill because of the lack of exceptions. On Thursday, New Orleans Archbishop Francis Schulte and six Roman Catholic bishops from Louisiana urged him to reconsider. Copies of a telegram from the bishops to Roemer were distributed on the House floor by Rep. Woody Jenkins, the Democrat who was the bill's author. ``Our state is the only one this year which still has the opportunity to place the matter before the (Supreme) Court,'' the bishops wrote. ``We pray that you will reconsider your announced plan to veto the legislation.'' Roemer has promised to meet with supporters of the bill before he acts. He has until July 7 to issue his veto, but has said he will allow the House and Senate ample time to attempt an override before the legislative session ends July 9. Roemer and abortion-rights advocates have predicted the Legislature would sustain a veto. The Senate passed the bill Tuesday 24-15, two votes shy of the two-thirds majority needed for a veto override. In California, the president of the Los Angeles chapter of the National Organization for Women has said the chapter is drafting a resolution calling for a boycott of all tourism and conventions in Louisiana. The resolution would be considered at NOW's annual meeting beginning Friday in San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Protests Occur as Romanian Prime Minister Wins Support for Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of workers demonstrated Thursday in the industrial city of Brasov to demand more radical economic reforms, and the parliament backed plans by Prime Minister Petre Roman to introduce a market economy. Roman presented his new 23-member Cabinet, composed largely of technocrats and experts, at a joint session of both houses of Parliament. It includes few members of the interim cabinet that governed Romania after Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was ousted and executed in December. That government had been criticized for a lackluster pace of reform and, in the case of some ministers, allegedly close ties to Ceausescu. Roman, who also headed the interim government, was entrusted last week by President Ion Iliescu with forming the new cabinet. In his speech to Parliament, Roman promised to carry out radical economic reforms to deal with the country's economic crisis. ``The present state of the economy can only be overcome by radical reform, carried out in quick steps,'' Roman said. ``Plastic surgery and superficial adjustments of the old structures cannot but deepen our crisis.'' He said an initial package of reform laws would be presented to Parliament within six months. He pledged to carry out ``the historic transition from a super centralized economy to a market economy,'' saying the state ``must abandon to the greatest possible extent its role as proprietor and manager.'' After the joint session, the two houses met separately and overwhelmingly approved Roman's Cabinet and program. But opposition leaders _ who criticized Roman's interim government for limiting private enterprises to a maximum of 20 employees _ remained skeptical that his current pledge of reform is sincere. ``So far we've heard promises,'' said Radu Campeanu, leader of the National Liberal Party, the largest opposition group. ``I hope they come true, but I don't know, I don't know.'' Meanwhile in Brasov, the country's second-largest city, about 4,000 workers staged a demonstration to demand more far-reaching reforms, shouting demands for ``real privatization'' and ``freedom and humanity,'' witnesses said. The demonstrators belong to a new independent union, the Territorial Trade Union Convention of Brasov, which claims to represent some 300,000 workers. Brasov, about 80 miles north of Bucharest, was the scene of massive worker protests in 1987 that were suppressed by the Ceausescu regime. At Thursday's demonstration, the workers also called for ``safeguarding our intellectuals and students.'' Earlier this month, vigilante miners answering a government appeal for support beat up students and other government opponents in Bucharest after police broke up a 53-day anti-Communist protest. In the western city of Timisoara, public transportation workers went on strike Thursday to protest their obsolete equipment and lack of spare parts, according to media reports. In Bucharest, 300 students and several professors staged a one-day strike Thursday to demand the release of student leader Marian Munteanu. Munteanu was arrested June 14 on charges of ``instigation and participation in violence.'' He was one of the leaders of the marathon anti-government protest in University Square and was badly beaten by the miners. The protests have been directed at Iliescu's National Salvation Front, which opponents say is dominated by former Communists. Iliescu and the Front won an overwhelming victory in the May 20 elections. At his inauguration last week, Iliescu vowed to remove ``disgraced, corrupt and incompetent persons'' in an apparent bow to opposition demands for the ouster of those compromised by serving under Ceausescu. The foreign minister in the interim government, Segiu Celac, who in the 1970s had been Ceausescu's personal translator, was replaced with Adrian Nastase, a former aide to Iliescu and a spokesman for the Front. Retaining their posts were Culture Minister Andre Plesu, Defense Minister Victor Stanculescu and Adrian Severin, the minister in charge of Reform and Relations with Parliament. Doru Viorel Ursu was kept on as interior minister, a post he assumed after his predecessor, Mihai Chitac, was ousted in the wake of violence that rocked the capital earlier this month. Most of the ministers in the new government are in their 40s and many hold doctorate degrees in fields related to their ministries.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Bust Exchange Houses Along Mexican Border
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents busted money-exchange houses in eight Texas cities along the Mexican border Thursday and arrested at least 19 people for money laundering, officials said. Authorities said the undercover investigation was the most extensive yet of the so-called ``casas de cambio.'' ``I think this will have a very significant impact not only on the Texas border, but all the way to San Diego,'' U.S. Attorney Ron Ederer told a news conference. The 21-month-long investigation by the U.S. Customs Service and the Internal Revenue Service _ code-named Operation Vagabond _ resulted in 26 arrest warrants and eight search- and-seizure warrants, officials said. Agents served the warrants Thursday at exchange houses in Laredo, Del Rio, Eagle Pass, Roma, Hidalgo, El Paso and Brownsville. Nineteen people were arrested and checks totaling $290,000 were seized, said John Alanis of the IRS criminal investigation division. Other arrests in San Antonio were possible, officials said. The arrests effectively shut down some of the casas de cambio, although authorities did not officially close the businesses, Ederer said. ``They were involved in money laundering in one form or another,'' Ederer said. Undercover agents went to the exchange houses and offered money for pesos or checks, telling the operators the money was linked to drugs, said Charles Harrison, acting head of the U.S. Customs Office in San Antonio. In some cases the exchange houses did not file currency transaction reports required when more than $10,000 is involved, Harrison said. And in some cases the money flowed out of the country and back into the United States, he said. A total of $2.1 million in government money was laundered in the undercover probe, authorities said. Ederer said he believes Operation Vagabond will send a message to other exchange houses laundering drug money. ``The other casas de cambio are going to see what has happened, and they don't know if this investigation (still) going on,'' he said. ``There are millions of dollars being laundered in these operations.'' It is impossible to know how many casas de cambio operate along the United States-Mexico border because the businesses are unregulated and can spring up from the trunk of a car, Ederer said. In a hearing late last year in San Antonio, the U.S. House Banking Committee heard testimony on the role casas de cambio play in laundering drug money.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language throughout
DOC.HEAD: Barry Couldn't Believe It
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 6th graf: ``The tape,'' with network play report
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Barry Trial Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``I'll be God damned,'' says Marion Barry to the FBI and to three cameras hidden in the bedroom and the bathroom. ``I'll be God damned. She set me up. The bitch!'' He says it again and again. He cannot accept it, cannot believe he is the victim of a sting operation that, the government says, caught him on videotape smoking crack cocaine in the hotel room of a beautiful woman. ``She set me up, I'll be God damned.'' That is the absorbing part of the videotape that was made on the evening of Jan. 18. Talk about the tape has occupied the people of this city for five months, and it played on local television all afternoon and into the night. The tape was prominent on all three major evening broadcast news shows, all of which made the trial their lead story _ 2 minutes 10 seconds on NBC, 2:58on CBS and 2:30 on ABC. On this fuzzy tape, the criminal act _ if that is what it was _ is unclear. It passes quickly. What happened will be the subject of courtroom argument. But what happens when the mayor realizes what's going on _ that lasts for minute after tense minute on the tape. The mayor cannot believe his fate. The tape is the centerpiece in the government's case against Barry. Son of a Mississippi sharecropper, civil rights activist in the 1960s, proud and popular in the nation's capital for three terms, he is on trial on charges of perjury and using cocaine. By day, he lectured schoolchildren on the dangers of drugs in a city blooded by drug wars; by night, the government has set out to prove, he was a drug user. He has pleaded innocent to all counts. What the jurors decide that the tape proves could be crucial, although the prosecution has plenty of witnesses to testify that they had used drugs with Barry. One day ago, the woman on the tape, Rasheeda Moore, 39, sexy magazine cover girl, the government's agent in the sting operation at the Vista Hotel, testified that she and Barry used drugs together often _ in 22 places and more than 100 times. She said she even delivered drugs to him in his office. The tape was shown in court Thursday. It is flickering movie. For most of it nothing happens. Ms. Moore wears silky pants and a flowing jacket. Barry's in a suit. He takes off his suit jacket. He has on suspenders. A television set plays in the background. He paces. He sits on the bed. He preens before a mirror. He gives Ms. Moore some money for ``Wanda'' _ an FBI plant _ to make a purchase. When Wanda delivers, they argue over who will go first and fill the crack pipe. ``You do it,'' he says. ``No, you do it,'' she says. It is done at last and it is smoked, apparently, and the FBI and members of Barry's Metropolitan Police Force break in, running by the cameras. ``FBI! FBI! You're under arrest! FBI!'' They hustle Ms. Moore out. The mayor says he's done nothing wrong. He is told to put his arms against the wall. He complies, the severity of his problem sinking in. ``I shouldn't have come up here,'' he says. ``I'll be damned.'' ``How'd I get tricked into this stuff?'' An agent reads him his rights. Barry has no interest. He is still stung by the sting. ``That was a setup,'' he says. ``You have the right to remain silent...,'' says the agent. ``I'll be God damned,'' says the mayor. ``...You also have the right to stop answering...'' ``...set me up.'' ``...at any time until you talk to a lawyer.'' ``She set me up.'' The FBI worries about its suspect's health. He has been drinking cognac. He has a history of heart trouble. They will take his blood pressure and monitor his heart. He has no interest. He sits down. He curses. ``I shouldn't have come up here.'' An agent: ``We'll just have them take a quick look at you, take your blood pressure, your vital signs. ...'' Barry: ``I'm all right. That God damn bitch!'' The mayor asks for permission to call his wife. Not now, he's told. Another officer explains ``in deference to your office'' that he will be taken down a service elevator. ``We're not going to parade you through the lobby.'' A judge will be asked to release Barry on his own recognizance so he won't have to spend the night in jail. The medics get busy. Barry lets them do their work. He is told body fluids will be drawn to check for consumption of drugs. Does he have chest pain? Does he have a headache? Does he have any allergies? Is he allergic to medications? The mayor answers the questions but he is not interested. He has one thing on his mind. ``I should have stayed downstairs,'' he says. `God damn.''

DOC.HEAD: Steady, Undramatic Growth Projected for Western Powers
DOC.TEXT: The West's major economies are expected to remain on a steady course over the next 18 months, undisturbed by political and economic upheavals in Eastern Europe, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said Friday. The 24-nation secretariat, in its latest semi-annual report, said the inflation-adjusted growth rate for its members is likely to remain steady in 1990 and 1991 at 2.9 percent, down from 3.6 percent in 1989. Inflation is expected to stay unchanged at an annual rate of around 4.5 percent in the OECD region through 1991. David Henderson, head of the OECD's economics and statistics department, told journalists the ``orderly and undramatic evolution'' of OECD economies contrasts starkly with the uncertain reforms under way in central and eastern Europe. But he said developments in these countries _ with the exception of East Germany _ aren't likely to have much impact on the OECD economies. Exports and imports from central and Eastern Europe account for only 2.5 percent of the OECD total, he said. The OECD report says fears that German economic and monetary union could aggravate inflation ``may seem exaggerated'' given the resolve of German banking officials to keep inflation under control. The OECD expects German inflation as measured by consumer prices to rise to 3.3 percent in 1991 from 2.6 percent this year and 3.1 percent in 1989. Germany's growth rate is likely to remain around last year's 4 percent level, but a deceleration to 3.4 percent is projected for 1991. The report said the U.S. economy should settle down to a growth rate of 2.3 percent this year and 2.5 percent in 1991, compared with 3 percent in 1989 and 4.4 percent in 1988. Inflation is projected to rise to 4.8 percent this year before easing to 4.6 percent in 1991. The OECD report expresses concern over the size of the U.S. federal deficit, which it says could reach $135 billion in both 1990 and 1991. OECD officials agreed President Bush's shift in favor of tax revenue increases has improved the budget outlook. The OECD said Japan's economy is likely to grow by 4.7 percent this year, slowing to 4 percent in 1991. Inflation may accelerate by about one percentage point to 2.8 percent this year before easing to 2.5 percent in 1991. ``With the internationalization of the Japanese economy proceeding rapidly, both further liberalization of the domestic market ... and policies to stimulate competition are needed both for the benefit of Japanese consumers and to avoid trade friction,'' the report said. The OECD projects a steady decline in Britain's current account deficit in 1990 and 1991, with inflation subsiding from the second half of this year onwards. France gets a clean bill of health, with practically all its economic indicators expected to move in the right direction while growth continues at a 3 percent annual rate. Eastern European countries probably will have to rely on their own austerity measures, rather than outside help, to finance restructuring of their economies, the OECD also said. The organization said in its annual report on the region that Eastern European governments must provide stronger incentives for their citizens to save money. The flow of public and private funds into the region from abroad may increase in coming years, the OECD said, but the broad economic significance of these funds ``is likely to be modest'' and may not offset the loss of Soviet energy subsidies. ``Financing of economic restructuring in central and eastern European is thus likely to be dependent on strong domestic savings flows,'' the report said. The OECD said private foreign investment is widely viewed as a panacea for Eastern Europe's economic adjustment problems, but it suggested this view should be treated with caution. The development of large-scale private foreign investment ``is likely to depend on the pace of domestic reform processes in these economies, particularly as regards the definition of property rights, which remains a murky area,'' the report said. Except for East Germany, the report said, Eastern European countries face difficulty obtaining more foreign resources because their export earning potential is limited and existing debts restrict their borrowing capacity. The flow of official government support is likely to increase, with loans from the newly created European Bank for Reconstruction and Development added to loans from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, the OECD said. But it said these sums _ which could total $6 billion this year _ ``are small in relation to potential requirements.''

DOC.HEAD: Teacher Says He was Hospitalized Two Days After Beating By Gang
DOC.TEXT: A schoolteacher testified Thursday that he spent two days in the hospital with injuries inflicted by a gang of teen-agers in Central Park the night a female jogger was gang-raped and nearly beaten to death. John Loughlin testified at the trial of three teens charged with the rape and attempted murder of the jogger and assaults on Loughlin and another man in a series of attacks in the park on April 19, 1989. Loughlin said he suffered cuts on his head and his eyes were blackened after he was hit with what he thought was a baseball bat. Bruises covered most of his body, and he said he still has ``occasional throbbing pain'' and difficulty moving his right knee. He also said he was ``95 percent certain'' he recognized one of his assailants later in a police lineup. The blood-splattered jacket and pants Loughlin was wearing the night he was attacked were shown to the jury. Loughlin said he was jogging in the park when he saw what looked like ``someone in trouble'' and stopped to investigate. ``I saw a person on the ground,'' he said. ``Around him there were a dozen or more people who looked like they were attacking him. ... ``Someone came up to me. He said, `What are you looking at?''' Loughlin recalled. ``Then he called to some people in front of me and said, `Here's one of those vigilantes. They repeated the word `vigilante.' They were approaching from 10 to 15 feet away. ``The next thing I remember I was face down on the ground being hit in the back of the head,'' Loughlin said. ``It appeared to be something heavy like a baseball bat. I put one hand up to ward off the blows, and I felt something hard and heavy and smooth.'' After the beating stopped, Loughlin said he got up and walked until he spotted a police car. The defendants in the trial _ Antron McCray, 15, Raymond Santana, 16, and Yusef Salaam, 16 _ allegedly were part of a larger gang that rampaged through the park, randomly attacking people. Three other youths are to stand trial later this year. The jogger, an investment banker who was then 28, was gang-raped, savagely beaten, and left naked and near death in a puddle of mud and blood. She survived but suffered brain damage, and prosecutors say she does not recall the attack.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot: Didn't Know it Was Loaded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-6, `The lead ...,' to ADD that practice missile remains attached to plane, CLARIFY that armed missile exploded.
DOC.TEXT: The pilot of an F-15 fighter jet did not know he had a live missile aboard until he fired it at another plane during a practice dogfight, causing nearly $1 million damage, the Air Force said Thursday. The pilot was suspended from flying, and several other personnel _ including the wing commander _ were transferred to other duties. The incident occurred March 19 while the two F-15s from the 21st Tactical Fighter Wing at Elmendorf Air Force Base were en route to the forward deployment base at King Salmon. The lead plane was carrying a practice training missile, which simulates the weight of a real missile and remains attached to the plane. The other aircraft was carrying one inert practice missile and one armed AIM-9M Sidewinder, the Air Force investigation board said in its report. They were doing some practice intercepts 180 miles west of Anchorage when the second plane mistakenly launched the armed heat-seeking missile, the Alaskan Air Command said in the accident report released Thursday. The lead plane's pilot ``immediately pulled the throttles to the idle position to cool the engines and increased the rate of turn to the left'' in an effort to evade the heat-seeking missile. The missile struck the left side of the plane's tail, and exploded, knocking off the left horizontal stabilizer. ``The warhead severely damaged the right rudder and fragments penetrated the external fuel tanks, engine burner cans and left flap. One fragment struck the left side of the fuselage just behind the cockpit,'' the report said. Lt. Col. Jimmy Harris, pilot of the stricken plane, regained control of the fighter after bringing it out of a roll, jettisoned the external fuel tanks and returned to Elmendorf. The missile caused $992,058 in damage to the $32.2 million F-15C, the Air Force said. First Lt. Michael Lynch, who was flying the fighter with the live missile, was grounded pending the results of a review by a flight evaluation board, said Maj. Doug McCoy, an Elmendorf spokesman. The accident report said although an entry ``was clearly present'' on a maintenance log that is required reading for pilots before takeoff, ``evidence indicates that Lt. Lynch was unaware that a live missile was on the aircraft.'' McCoy said the command has changed the way it moves live missiles from one base to another. ``We are still ferrying a combination of live missiles and practice training missiles to forward bases,'' McCoy said. ``But approval and training practices have been tightened.''

DOC.HEAD: Ancient Wedding Gives Japan Its First Taste of New Era
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details from wedding ceremony, edits to conform, deletes outdated material. No pickup. ^By ERIC TALMADGE
DOC.TEXT: Kneeling before an altar to the sun goddess and sipping sacred rice wine, Emperor Akihito's youngest son wed his college sweetheart Friday morning in a ceremony replete with symbolism. The solemn 15-minute ceremony at the shrine dedicated to the sun goddess Amaterasu ended with the symbolic sipping of rice wine from a white ceramic cup, sealing Prince Aya's nuptial bonds with graduate student Kiko Kawashima. Miss Kawashima, who has no royal background, has generally been welcomed as representing another step in bringing the palace and Japan's people closer together. She is the second commoner to marry into the royal family. Empress Michiko became the first when she and Akihito, then crown prince, wed in 1959. The wedding was the first for an imperial family member in six years, and the first in three decades for a prince of Aya's rank. Aya, 24, is second in line to the Chrysanthemum Throne after his elder brother, Crown Prince Naruhito, 30, who has yet to marry. Clad in the black silk robe and cap with arched tailpiece that designate him as an imperial prince, Aya and Miss Kawashima, 23, walked to the shrine in slow, deliberate steps. An attendant carried the train of the bride's green, maroon and orange kimono, nearly a dozen layers thick. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and other government leaders and imperial family members were among the 156 guests watching from outside the wooden ``Kashikodokoro'' shrine. In the ceremony, the prince, kneeling beside his bride, made vows to the sun goddess in the classical Japanese used by priests of Japan's indigenous Shinto religion. Reflecting the royal couple's special fondness for Thailand, a country they have both visited, Thai Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn was also invited to the wedding, the first member of a foreign royal family to receive such an honor. Aya's royal parents, in keeping with tradition, were absent Friday morning, but like the rest of the nation could watch the ceremony on live television. They will receive the couple later in the afternoon in the Imperial Palace. The emperor was also to bestow Aya with a new title, Prince Akishino, to mark Aya's establishing an independent household. Akishino is the name of a town in western Japan with close ties to the imperial family. Many aspects of the wedding ceremony closely followed imperial traditions, some going back 1,000 years or more. Traditions aside, the ceremony was being hailed as the public's first taste of the new imperial era, called Heisei or ``achieving peace,'' which began with the death of Emperor Hirohito on Jan. 7, 1989. Akihito ascended the throne immediately afterward, and he has been credited with trying to create a more open, softer image for Japan's often distant and mysterious imperial family. ``This is the first big event of the Heisei Era,'' said former imperial chamberlain Minoru Hamao, who served as a close attendant to Akihito for 20 years. ``The princess is the perfect person for today's imperial household, and I'm sure that as time goes on she will gradually help bring the monarchy even closer to the people,'' he told The Associated Press. Though Miss Kawashima has not created a sensation along the lines of the ``Michiko boom,'' her warm smile and quiet, conservative manner have won over much of the public. Because of her relatively humble background _ her father is an economics professor at Gakushuin University, a former peers school _ she was called a modern-day Cinderella by the popular media. She was also dubbed the ``Apartment Princess'' because she lived with her family in faculty housing on the Gakushuin campus, where she is working on her masters degree in social psychology. Aya, a Gakushuin graduate, met Miss Kawashima at a bookstore on the campus in 1985. Soon after their engagement was approved by the government in September, it was rumored that Aya and Miss Kawashima would honeymoon in Thailand, a country Aya particularly likes. For the honeymoon, however, tradition has taken precedence. The royal couple's first trip together will be to the Grand Shrines of Ise and the tomb of the Emperor Jimmu, both in central Japan. Emperor Jimmu, according to myth, was Japan's first monarch and ascended in 660 B.C. Police say that because of threats from leftist radicals, 9,000 officers were assigned to guard the wedding activities, though most were being held at either the Imperial Palace, which is surrounded by a moat and forbidding stone walls, or the Akasaka Palace, the well-secured residence of the emperor and empress.

DOC.HEAD: Willie Settles With IRS, Owes $5.8 Million Plus Penalties
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT Nelson's birthplace from Waco to Abbott
DOC.TEXT: Country music star Willie Nelson will pay $6.5 million in personal and business taxes and penalties stretching back to 1972 under a settlement with the government approved by a Tax Court judge. Documents made available Thursday show Nelson was penalized under sections of the tax code regarding negligence, failure to file a tax return and failure to pay taxes. Tax Court Judge Mary Ann Cohen approved the settlement June 6. Nelson's tax trouble began in October 1984 when Internal Revenue Service investigators alleged he owed $1.6 million in back taxes for 1972 through 1978. In May 1988, the IRS charged he owed another $9.4 million for 1979 through 1983. The IRS assessed hundreds of thousands of dollars in penalties both times. The singer disputed the charges in lawsuits filed in U.S. Tax Court in 1985 and 1988. Nelson's attorney, Charles Meadows Jr. of Dallas, said he would not discuss the case. Nelson did not immediately return phone messages left at his motel in Powell, Wyo., where he will perform Friday night. Nelson is best known for his songs ``On the Road Again,'' ``My Heroes Have Always Been Cowboys'' and ``You Were Always On My Mind.'' He also performed in the movies ``Honeysuckle Rose'' and ``Barbarosa.'' The tax documents indicate Nelson must pay $5.8 million in personal taxes and a penalty of about $500,000. His music company must pay about $139,000 in taxes plus a penalty of about $29,000. The IRS initially charged Nelson with civil tax fraud, saying he understated his taxable income through unreported earnings and improper deductions. But Judge Cohen assessed no penalty under the fraud provisions of the tax code. Nelson's attorneys also successfully argued that his company was not liable for about $728,000 in personal holding company tax. Such a tax, at a rate of up to 70 percent, is imposed on undistributed earnings from personal services. Nelson's attorneys argued those earnings were all distributed to Nelson and members of his band. Most of the company's money comes from royalties. Nelson established the company to meet a music publishing house's requirement for royalty distribution. Nelson, 57, was born in Abbott, Texas, and grew up playing for tips at central Texas beer joints and ice houses. He now lives near Austin. He will be there next Wednesday for his annual Fourth of July picnic, a tradition that grew from a 1971 reunion of Texas musicians and now attracts thousands.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Charles Breaks Arm in Fall from Horse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 2 `The prince' to drop extraneous words `of his arm.' Picks up 3rd pvs, `The accident...'
DOC.TEXT: Prince Charles fell from his horse during a polo match Thursday and broke his right arm. The prince underwent a 45-minute operation under general anesthesia to set two breaks above the elbow, said his spokesman Dickie Arbiter. Charles was spending the night at a local hospital. The accident happened during a match at Cirencester Park, Gloucestershire, seven miles from Highgrove, the country home of Charles and his wife, Diana. Highgrove is 70 miles west of London. The princess was in London and decided to carry out a private engagement there Thursday evening, but was expected to visit her husband Friday. Charles' mother, Queen Elizabeth II, was informed in Canada where she is visiting. Charles, 41, was playing for his team, Windsor Park, when he fell from his horse 30 minutes into play. ``The prince was in the process of making a shot when he lost his balance,'' said Arbiter. ``His horse just trotted away.'' Charles, who once joked he would continue playing polo ``as long as I bounce when I fall off,'' lay motionless for some time before being put on a stretcher and taken by ambulance to nearby Cirencester Memorial Hospital, a witness said. He spent about an hour in the emergency room with several other patients awaiting treatment, police Chief Inspector Colin Handy said. Charles was ``in very good spirits and chatting with staff and cracking jokes with other patients,'' said Handy. A surgeon and anesthetist were summoned from a nearby golf course to treat the prince. Rodney Sweatman, the queen's orthopedic surgeon, arrived from London and examined the injury. ``The prince will remain overnight in a single room off one of the wards and a further decision will be made tomorrow as to the next move,'' said police Inspector Mike Pennington.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Starts Investigation into Space Telescope Problem
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS grafs 4-7: ``Terence Facey,'' Hughes Danbury confident now that error made in grinding and polishing of mirrors and that mistake will be found in search of files; grafs 24-28 and graf 30 bgng: ``George Alexander,'' deleted to trim
DOC.TEXT: NASA started a formal investigation into why the Hubble Space Telescope was launched with a fuzzy focus as scientists searched Thursday for ways to salvage some research from the flawed $1.5 billion observatory. NASA officials said an investigation team, led by Jet Propulsion Laboratory Director Lew Allen, was being organized. At the same time, engineers at a Connecticut company that made the telescope's mirrors under a $450 million contract were trying to find out what went wrong during a years-long process of grinding and polishing. Terence Facey, an executive with the Hughes Danbury Optical Co., said that a study of signals from the Hubble has led to the conclusion ``with fairly high certainty'' that one of two main mirrors in the telescope was ground or polished to wrong shape. ``The shape is not correct,'' he said Thursday night, ``but we don't know which one (mirror) it is.'' Facey said that records still exist on the tedious three-year grinding and polishing effort to make the mirrors and that Hughes Danbury officials expect to be able to pinpoint precisely when and how the mistake was made. Jack Rehnberg, another Hughes Danbury official, said earlier that a manufacturing error was a strong possibility and that his company was prepared to cooperate fully with NASA's investigation. National Aeronautics and Space Administration officials announced Wednesday that either the primary mirror or secondary mirror on Hubble were not focusing light as they were supposed to, giving blurred and low-light images to the two cameras and three instruments on the spacecraft. The flaw, officials said, cannot be repaired from the ground and the space observatory never will be able to capture all of the spectacular views of the universe that had been expected, although a repair mission scheduled for 1993 may restore one camera. NASA Hubble scientist Ed Weiler said at a news conference Thursday that a minute error in the curve of one of the mirrors causes the reflected light to miss a precise point of focus by only 4 percent of the diameter of a human hair.
