DOC.HEAD: Diabetes Patients May Soon Get Implanted Pumps
DOC.TEXT: The implanted insulin pump may soon offer more independence for diabetics, doctors at the American Diabetes Association convention said. But two specialists said relief through organ transplants or an implanted glucose sensor that doesn't require patients to monitor blood sugar levels is a long way away. Dr. Christopher Saudek, an associate professor of medicine at Johns Hopkins University who has worked on implanted insulin pumps for a decade, told about 300 association members at last month's convention that studies on the pump have been so successful it may be on the market by 1993. The pump is a disc of titanium about 3 inches thick implanted under the skin in the abdomen with a catheter that delivers insulin, which is absorbed directly into the liver. Diabetics cannot produce or process insulin, a hormone that acts on sugars and starches in the blood. With the pump, insulin is delivered at a basic rate, except before meals, when the wearer decides how much of a bonus boost to deliver. In 1986, the pump was implanted in 10 people at Johns Hopkins and eight at the University of California. ``The results of these trials showed they could control their diabetes very well,'' Saudek said. ``They love it.'' Pumps have been implanted in 13 people since January, and will be implanted at seven hospitals in the United States and three in France. If these trials succeed, Saudek said, he will seek Food and Drug Administration approval to market the pump. The pump will be expensive _ $10,000 to $12,000, Saudek predicted _ and not without maintenance problems. Tissue has a tendency to block the catheter, resulting in an operation to clear it in six of the 10 Johns Hopkins patients. But the costs more than cover the cost of complications _ blindness, amputations, coronary artery disease _ that result from inability to control insulin flow, he said. Saudek and Dr. David Scharp, a professor at Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis, said the 1990s will bring basic research into such advances as ``closed-loop'' implants and islet-pancreas transplants. In the closed-loop system, glucose sensors would monitor blood sugar levels and automatically adjust insulin flow from implanted pumps. Saudek thinks it will take three to five years to develop an accurate sensor. Scharp is conducting studies to determine if transplanting islets _ pancreas cells that produce insulin _ will allow patients to achieve insulin independence. So far, two have, he said. Scharp believes islets show promise for relieving diabetes without the longer operation and recuperation time of whole pancreas transplants. But there are many questions about the procedure _ primarily rejection rates, he said. Anti-rejection drugs like cyclosporin can suppress natural insulin productivity, defeating the purpose of the transplant, Scharp said.

Also at the convention: A federal researcher who set out to see what doctors know about diabetes and what they're doing about it says many diabetics aren't getting the care they need. In a survey of more than 2,000 family physicians, general practitioners, internists and pediatricians who treat diabetic patients, 87 percent agreed with the importance of maintaining blood glucose levels. More than two out of three are relying on a ``fairly useless'' diagnostic test, and only about half are prescribing the right number of insulin injections, said Dr. Lois Lipsett of the National Institute of Diabetic and Digestive and Kidney Diseases. ``The major problem is how to reach these people,'' she said after presenting her findings. ``People with diabetes could be, and should be, receiving better medical care.'' The survey was conducted between June and December last year among 3,481 general physicians who were not diabetes specialists; 67 percent participated. Lipsett said general physicians treat four out of five of the nation's diabetics. Only about one-third ordered regular glycosylated hemoglobin tests _ a recommended monitoring test for diabetes _ and only about 17 percent performed such tests every three months, as recommended by the diabetes association. Nearly 70 percent were relying on urine dipstick tests to monitor their patients, even though that is no longer regarded as appropriate by the association. Single daily insulin injections were the standard for 39 percent of the doctors treating diabetics ages 18 and 39, and for 51 percent of those treating patients 40 and older. The association's standards of care call for multiple insulin injections in most cases.

DOC.HEAD: Computers Help in Diagnosis of Heart Ailments
DOC.TEXT: A new computer system that lets doctors view a chronological sequence of electrocardiograms will help with the diagnosis of heart ailments, researchers said. The system has been tested for three years with several thousand heart patients, researchers from the University of Florida Health Science Center and Duke University Medical Center said last month. The researchers say the system offers major advantages over the standard computer analysis of single electrocardiograms, or EKGs, in detecting changes in heart function. An EKG is a tracing of wave forms that reflect the pattern of electrical impulses depicting contractions of the heart. ``Comparing electrocardiograms in patients is literally a must, and this kind of system has definitely arrived,'' said Dr. Irene Ferrer, professor of clinical medicine at Columbia University in New York. Tracking the progression of a heart attack is probably the most important clinical benefit of serial comparison, said University of Florida cardiologist Lamar Crevasse and computer scientist Mario Ariet. The scientists, who developed the system in conjunction with Hewlett Packard Co., said the computer attaches a time and date to each episode of unusual electrical activity in the heart. The system ``can analyze in 15 seconds what it would take a trained physician two hours to perform with measurements comparable to those of the computer,'' Crevasse said. Dr. Joseph Greenfield, Duke University's chairman of medicine and chief of cardiology, said the comparative analysis still has shortcomings and needs more precise data programmed into it to improve the accuracy of its interpretations.
DOC.HEAD: Lab Part of Effort To Develop Important Chips
DOC.TEXT: A specialized, tiny mirror could help scientists play a major role in a race with the Japanese to move onto the next plateau in computer technology, researchers say. The University of Arizona's Optical Sciences Laboratory makes precisely ground mirrors the size of a contact lens. Scientists hope the mirrors will aid the university's attempt to dominate a $100 billion market for faster, more powerful electronic semiconductor chips, which are the basic building blocks of modern computers and electronic devices. By developing small mirrors to focus X-rays, rather than visible or ultraviolet light, scientists hope to be able to etch a thousand times more circuits onto the surface of semiconductor chips than now possible. Such a breakthrough would usher in another revolution in speed and miniaturization for computers, consumer electronics and military technology. ``The whole name of the game is to cram more processing power onto the surface of a fingernail-sized semiconductor chip,'' said Charles Falco, director of research on X-ray optics. ``The technique that we've been using for four decades has been taken to its physical limits.'' At present, electronics engineers can place about 1 million circuits onto the surface of a chip. Falco, his team and researchers at Princeton University and Bell Laboratories _ partners in a joint venture _ hope to put 1 billion circuits on a chip. To achieve the goal, they must narrow stencil lines now only 1 percent as wide as a human hair.
DOC.HEAD: Florida Researchers To Help Treat Chernobyl Victims
DOC.TEXT: University of Florida researchers will help treat thousands of victims of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in a study that could help prepare the United States for a similar accident. Researchers from the university's Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences are helping Ukrainian colleagues to develop a process for extracting pectin from sugar beets, said Donald Price, vice president for sponsored research. Doctors from the university's Health Science Center will help determine how much pectin is needed to rid the body of heavy metals left behind by the accident. ``This collaboration will serve as a giant clinical study on the effectiveness of pectin in treating these illnesses,'' Price said. Pectin is a carbohydrate normally extracted from citrus and apples and used in jams, jellies and candies. University researchers patented a process last year to extract pectin from sugar beets, which are plentiful in the Soviet Union, Price said. Thousands of Soviet citizens have dangerously high levels of metals such as uranium in their bodies. The metals were introduced into the air, water and food chain by the April 1986 explosion at the Chernobyl plant north of Kiev, said Kenneth Finger, university vice presient of health affairs. Pectin attracts these metals as it travels through the intestinal tract and removes them from the body, Finger said. Doctors will work with the Soviets to determine the proper dosage and if mixing pectin with other chemicals increases its effectiveness, he added. Finger said damage to internal organs and respiratory problems are examples of damage done by radiation poisoning.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, July 2

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators on Final Lap of Japan-US Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: Aided by President Bush's concession on taxes, Japanese and U.S. negotiators appeared close to agreement today on measures to resolve their structural trade problems. Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu talked on the telephone late Wednesday about Japan's increased offer to boost public works spending _ a key area of disagreement. Japanese officials said Bush expressed appreciation for Kaifu's efforts. ``This represents a breakthrough,'' said a Foreign Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Japanese news reports said this morning's talks had produced agreements on the remaining two issues: Japan's long process for approving patents, and how to monitor the anticipated accord resulting from the trade talks, called the Structural Impediments Initiative. Kyodo News Service quoted S. Linn Williams, the deputy U.S. trade representative, as saying Japan had agreed to reduce, within five years, the time needed to process a patent application from the current 37 months to 24 months. Japan Broadcasting Corp. said the two countries also agreed to meet at least twice a year to monitor compliance with the accord. A top U.S. negotiator on Wednesday used Bush's announcement of his acceptance of the need for tax revenue increases to prod Japan to boost its offer on public works spending. ``It took more political courage to raise (tax) revenues that it would to increase public spending,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The president made an important decision. We hope our Japanese friends realize that.'' Afterward, Kaifu met with Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto. Japanese media reported they decided to pledge an added $96.77 billion to Japan's public works spending over the coming 10 years. The new spending total of $2.77 trillion was still short of the U.S. demand for $3.22 trillion, and U.S. officials refused to confirm Japanese reports that the matter had been resolved. An announcement was expected later in the day after Kaifu's cabinet meets to discuss the draft accord. The linkage between U.S. taxes and Japanese public spending showed the interdependence of the immense U.S. and Japanese economies, the world's two largest. That interdependence is at the heart of the trade talks, which seek fundamental economy policy changes to slash Japan's $49 billion trade surplus with the United States. Japan has argued that the United States must cut its budget deficit to reduce the trade gap. The budget deficit helps stimulate U.S. consumer demand, which in turn increases sales of Japanese products in the United States. U.S. negotiators, on the other hand, have argued that increased spending on public works in Japan could reduce the trade deficit by boosting demand for U.S. imports and construction services. Such spending also could soak up some of the Japanese hoard of savings and investment funds, another source of friction between the two countries. The structural talks also covered such Japanese issues as high land prices, laws restricting large retail stores, collusive practices of large business groups and pricing mechanisms. On the U.S. side, the issues included measures to promote exports, training of workers and competitiveness of U.S. products. The structural trade talks were launched last September and an interim report was agreed in April. The current round started Monday with the aim of producing a final report on Tuesday, but disagrements forced a two-day extension.

The government's main economic forecasting gauge climbed 0.8 percent to a new high in May, in a new sign the nation's longest peacetime expansion will last at least through the end of its eighth year. However, Wednesday's report also pointed to a sobering new dropoff in consumer confidence, and one analyst said the economy ``could be close to a recession by the end of the year.'' The Commerce Department said its Index of Leading Economic Indicators, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months ahead, rose to 146.2 percent of its 1982 base.

The Supreme Court said the federal government may favor minorities in awarding broadcast licenses, a surprising victory for affirmative action from a court that has recently trimmed racial preferences. The justices, in a 5-4 vote released Wednesday, ruled that Federal Communications Commission policies designed to bring diversity to the nation's airwaves do not violate the rights of white people.

President Bush proposed a free trade zone for the entire Western Hemisphere and offered to forgive some U.S. government loans to Latin American and Caribbean countries. The president, in a major speech Wednesday on U.S. trade and investment policies toward the region, also proposed ``debt-for-nature'' swaps to encourage Third World countries to protect natural resources.

The West German economics minister urged foreign companies to invest in East Germany, saying they would find a stable market and a ``bridge to East Europe.'' Helmut Haussmann made his statement Wednesday at a meeting in Hamburg as the giant West German electronics firm, Siemens, announced it would invest $600 million in East Germany over the next three years. Meanwhile, West Germany said the last borders between the two Germanies would fal Sunday, the day the two countries merge their economies.

Aided by President Bush's concession on taxes, Japanese and U.S. negotiators appeared close to agreement today on measures to resolve their structural trade problems. Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu talked on the telephone late Wednesday about Japan's increased offer to boost public works spending _ a key area of disagreement. Japanese officials said Bush expressed appreciation for Kaifu's efforts.

News that AT&T's second-quarter profit will be lower than a year ago _ and below analysts' expectations _ sent the price of the nation's most widely held stock sliding. Wednesday's announcement by American Telephone & Telegraph Co. was the first time since the 1984 breakup of the former Bell System that the nation's largest phone company has given advance warning of a lower profit. AT&T shares closed at $39.12{ on the New York Stock Exchange, down $2.12{.

Apparel manufacturer Salant Corp. sought refuge in bankruptcy court after struggling unsuccessfully with debts incurred in buying a larger rival two years ago. Wednesday's filing under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code was the second for the New York-based clothing company, whose nationally known brands include Dr. Denton sleepwear, John Henry shirts and Lady Manhattan sportswear. Salant, which bought Manhattan Industries Inc. for $105 in 1988, attributed its troubles to weakness in the retail business.

Regulators formed a legal task force to seek compensation for taxpayers from bankrupt Drexel Burnham Lambert Group for junk bond losses suffered by failed savings and loans. Alfred Byrne, general counsel of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said Wednesday the agency has preliminary information linking Drexel and its former junk bond chief, Michael Milken, to millions of dollars lost by a number of failed thrifts in junk bonds. The FDIC, which insures bank and thrift deposits, and the Resolution Trust Corp., responsible for handling failed thrifts, may be Drexel's largest creditors, he said.

Merger activity fell sharply in the first half of the year as the takeover business continued to contract because of the scarcity of financing. Securities Data Corp., a financial research firm, reported Wednesday that 2,110 transactions involving U.S. firms worth a total of $88.2 billion took place in the first six months to date, down 50 percent in value from the 2,420 deals worth $193 billion in the first half of 1989.

Stock prices pulled out of their recent slump with a rally Wednesday, shrugging off unwelcome earnings news from American Telephone & Telegraph. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had fallen 59.40 points over the past three sessions, climbed 19.80 to 2,862.13. The dollar drifted higher, as did gold. Bond prices advanced, encouraged by unusually strong demand for the Treasury's auction of new four-year notes. Sugar futures prices bounced sharply higher after the Agriculture Department predicted world sugar consumption would outstrip production for the sixth straight year. Elsewhere, oil futures fell; grains and soybeans, livestock and meat, and precious metals were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds East Bloc Consumers Recognize Brand Names
With BC-East Bloc-Brands List
DOC.TEXT: East Bloc consumers recognize a wide range of Western brand names even though many of the products have not been actively marketed or may not be available in their countries, a survey says. The results suggest East European countries that are opening their borders to trade may be particularly appealing to Western companies looking for new markets, the brand management consulting firm that conducted the survey said. ``We found an overwhelming recognition of brands in what are not market economies,'' Stewart Owen, an executive of San Francisco-based Landor Associates said Wednesday. ``Very few Russsians have ever seen a Honda or a Toyota, yet they seem to have a very clear image of it,'' he said. The report was based on interviews with 1,500 consumers in the Soviet Union, Poland and Hungary. Five hundred people in each country were given lists of 400 global brand names and asked to identify the ones they recognized and how they felt about them. The interviews were conducted in April and May. Sony, the Japanese electronics brand, scored highest on a scale that combined recognition and perceived quality among consumers in the Soviet Union and Poland, the survey said. Sony placed fourth in Hungary, where German automaker Mercedes-Benz topped the list, it said. Ford was the lone American company to make the top 10 lists in all three countries. Fanta and Pepsi-Cola joined it among the top 10 in the Soviet Union. The survey said Soviets were able to identify an average of 100 brand names, while Poles were familiar with 175 and Hungarians with about 250. The differences were attributed to the degree of exposure to Western media. Although the numbers of familiar brands were far lower than the thousands American consumers can identify, Owen said they are ``still amazingly high'' considering each country has had a closed economy until recently. ``Very few of those products are for sale there, very few of them could be afforded there and very few have ever been seen there,'' he said. ``It is very clear to us that people who are going to invest to create these brand images have a great potential there,'' he said. Landor said the survey also turned up a ``disturbing undercurrent'' relating to American brands. Landor president Don Casey said many American brands scored much lower when ranked by perceived quality than on the basis of mere consumer recognition. Among soft drink companies, for instance, Pepsi-Cola ranked sixth and Coca-Cola ninth in terms of recognition in Poland. But Pepsi dropped to 34th and Coca-Cola was 26th when ranked by perceived quality. In Hungary, the differences were even more striking. Pepsi-Cola was fourth and Coca-Cola was fifth in terms of recognition, but Pepsi dropped to 74th and Coke fell to 47th in terms of perceived quality. Owen said one explanation may be that luxury goods have an inherent advantage over soft drinks in terms of how they are perceived. But Casey said there was no such gap for Japanese or Western brands. ``It suggests that American companies must quickly address the perception of their product quality in Eastern Europe or risk losing ground to European or Japanese competitors,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Challeges Saudi's OPEC Leadership With Production, Price Statements
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has warned Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates to curb their excess oil production and called for a sharp rise in world oil prices, a newspaper reported. The moves represent a challenge to Saudi Arabia's leadership in setting oil policy in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, The New York Times reported in Thursday's newspaper. The warning from President Saddam Hussein said the two small Persian Gulf nations were harming Iraq's vital interest, as well as those of the oil cartel, by exceeding their OPEC production quotas, the newspaper reported. Iraq, which has emerged triumphant from its war with Iran, has been trying to anoint itself as the leading military, political and economic power in the Middle East. The warning was in a letter delivered Tuesday by Iraq's deputy prime minister, Saadun Hamadi, to the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the Times said, quoted Arab oil industry sources. Hamadi also was quoted in Gulf newspapers as saying that oil prices should rise to $25 a barrel from about $14 a barrel currently, the newspaper said. OPEC's official target price is $18 a barrel. Oil industry officials estimate that Kuwait and the UAE are exceeding their production quotas by a combined total of nearly 1.4 million barrels a day. Overall OPEC output recently has been about 23.5 million barrels a day, compared with the cartel's official ceiling of 22 million barrels.

DOC.HEAD: Reform Bills Increasing SEC Powers Advance in House
DOC.TEXT: Bills giving the Securities and Exchange Commission authority to curb penny stock fraud and other illegal activities have moved a step closer to becoming law. The House Energy and Commerce Committee, which oversees the Wall Street regulator, voted Wednesday to send the Penny Stock Reform Act and the Securities Law Enforcement Remedies Act to the full House for consideration. The penny stock bill, introduced just two months ago, would give the SEC power to bar crooked promoters and consultants from selling the highly speculative stocks that usually sell for a dollar or less. Rep. Matthew J. Rinaldo, R-N.J., a co-sponsor of the bill, noted that ``the speed with which we have moved'' to get the bill through committee ``underscores the depth of concern in Congress about this problem.'' Penny stocks are not traded on most stock exchanges. Most information about the low-priced and often risky securities comes from the brokers who sell them. While not illegal, penny stocks _ which typically are used to finance new or small companies _ are considered to be chancey investments at best. The penny stock bill would allow the SEC to: _Close a loophole that now allows unscrupulous penny stock brokers to evade SEC banishment from the securities business by calling themselves promoters or consultants, whom the SEC has no power to regulate. _Tighten disclosure requirements for highly speculative investments known as ``blank checks'' and ``blind pools.'' _Facilitate at ``the earliest feasible time'' an automated stock quotation system to help investors keep track of penny stocks nationwide. The proposed legislation is supported by the SEC, the Consumer Federation of America, and the North American Securities Administators Association, a state-level stock regulators group that estimates American investors lose about $2 billion a year to penny stock scams. The committee also approved the remedies act, which would widen the SEC's authority to seek court orders imposing civil fines and barring convicted securities law violators from serving as officers or directors of companies whose stock is publicly traded. An earlier version of the bill would have given the SEC direct authority to bar miscreant officers and directors, but it was softened at the request of SEC officials, who said only federal judges should have that authority. The SEC, which now can seek fines only in illegal insider trading cases, could ask a judge to impose fines of up to $100,000 against an individual and $500,000 against a company. Another provision of the bill would give the SEC power to order alleged wrongdoers to ``cease and desist'' illegal activities without first having to go to court and obtain a restraining order. ``This cease and desist authority is similar to that granted the banking regulators in last years savings and loan legislation,'' said Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., a co-sponsor of the bill. The remedies bill was introduced by Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Bank To Pay $8 Million in Largest-Ever Student-Loan Fraud Case
DOC.TEXT: Florida Federal Savings Bank, once among the country's top providers of guaranteed student loans, has been ordered to pay $8.2 million for cheating a federally-backed loan program. Senior U.S. District Judge Ben Krentzman sentenced the thrift Wednesday to pay $6 million in restitution and an additional $2.2 million in fines. The judge could have imposed fines of up to $21.5 million Florida Federal and two of its student-loan executives were convicted last month of conspiring to submit 17,000 fraudulent claims for government reimbursement on defaulted student loans worth $35 million. The thrift doctored documents to show attempts to collect the loans when in fact no efforts had been made, the government said. The St. Petersburg-based thrift received some $18 million from the U.S. Department of Education before payments were halted. Prosecutors said it was the largest federal student-loan fraud case ever prosecuted. Prior to the sentencing, the government had collected about $11 million from the thrift. Two thrift executives also were sentenced Wednesday. Robert O. Harmas, 42, of Noblesville, Ind. received two years in prison and James. J. LaMantia, 59, of Largo, was sentenced to three years probation. Harmas, a vice president and operations manager in the student loan department, had faced as much as 240 years in prison and fines of more than $10 million. LaMantia, collection manager of the division, faced up to 165 years and $7 million. A federal jury convicted the thrift and Harmas on all 43 counts of fraud, conspiracy and theft. LaMantia was found guilty on 23 of the counts. Florida Federal was the third-largest provider of student loans in the country from November 1986 to July 1987, the period covered in the indictment. At the time some 11.7 percent of its assets _ or $642 million _ were student loans, the government said. Prosecutors said that instead of contacting students who failed to pay back their loans, Florida Federal employees faked doing the work. Then after the falsified data was put into a student's file, the thrift submitted the information for reimbursement from the education department.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler-GM Venture Signs Deal With Rover Group
DOC.TEXT: New Venture Gear Inc., the first joint venture between major U.S. automakers, has made its first sale to an outside company. New Venture, a joint effort between Chrysler Corp. and General Motors Corp. announced Wednesday a four-year deal to supply parts to British automaker Rover Group. ``This piece of business is very important for us,'' said David R. Zimmer, president of New Venture, which makes Chrysler and GM parts. Zimmer said the deal was one of many planned by New Venture, formed earlier this year by Acustar, a Chrysler division, and GM. New Venture will make five-speed manual transaxles for Rover's new 825 Turbo Diesel cars. Rover is headquartered in Birmingham, England. Transaxles are a combination transmission-axle for front-wheel drive cars. The transaxles are built at New Venture's New Process Gear plant in Syracuse, N.Y. Edwin C. Zimmerman, New Venture's vice president of operations, said Chrysler had been negotiating with Rover for two years.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Offer Benefit Program Cuts at Budget Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Talks resume 10:30 a.m. EDT, lead prospects uncertain; also moved on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Democrats at the budget summit are responding to President Bush's easing of his no-tax stance by discussing possible cuts in some of their favorite benefit programs, including Social Security. The closed-door talks between leading lawmakers and White House officials resume today, a day after the bargainers accelerated their pace and plunged into specific suggestions for saving billions of dollars next year. No agreements were reached, but participants said real work was finally being done. ``Whatever deadlock there was in our negotiations has disappeared,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M. The talks began in mid-May. They had inched along until Bush's declaration on Monday that ``tax revenue increases'' _ along with spending cuts _ had to be a part of any deficit-reduction package. On Wednesday, Democrats presented a menu of cuts in a wide range of benefit programs that one official said would save $5.7 billion and another said could produce $10 billion in savings. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity. Democrats have long been protective of benefit programs _ called entitlements _ because the poor and elderly who are covered tend to support their party. ``Today, we Democrats are raising the whole question of entitlement programs,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. ``That's a very sensitive area for Democrats.'' Overall, the negotiators are seeking $45 billion to $60 billion in savings for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. Officials said that among the options were a three-month delay in the annual cost-of-living increases in benefit programs for which people qualify automatically, such as Social Security. That one-time postponement _ from next Jan. 1 to April 1 _ would save the government $3 billion next year. The proposal ran into flak from Domenici and House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. People at the meeting said Rostenkowski told his fellow negotiators that ``death'' would be the political consequence of adopting the idea. Other options discussed included: _Boosting from 50 percent to 85 percent the amount of income subject to federal taxes earned by couples receiving Social Security and earning more than $32,000 annually. The increase would raise $3.1 billion for the government next year and $54 billion over five years. _Medicare reductions. _Cuts in spending on various federal employee benefit programs. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., the lead Democratic negotiator, said there was a consensus that bargainers should try to concoct a plan that would balance the budget by fiscal 1995. That would be two years after the Gramm-Rudman law requires the deficit to be eliminated. ``It's fair to assume ... that the targets are going to be changed,'' Domenici said. Outside the bargaining room, however, members of both parties clung to partisan positions on the questions of taxes. Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., and 12 of his 44 Senate GOP colleagues signed a letter saying the deficit must be controlled ``through spending reductions and economic growth, not through tax increases.'' On Tuesday, 90 of the 176 House Republicans signed a similar note. Democratic leaders said they remained unconcerned about the petitions, saying unhappy lawmakers might change their minds if tax hikes were part of a solid deficit-reduction package that included spending cuts. But other Democrats sought to use the GOP disarray to their party's advantage. ``How is the president going to lead the country if he can't lead his own party?'' Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., asked on the House floor.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 458.87 up 1.98 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Subaru Maker Looks for Rescue by Nissan
DOC.TEXT: A former Nissan executive was elected Thursday as president of Fuji Heavy Industries Co., giving Nissan effective control over the slumping manufacturer of Subaru cars. Fuji shareholders approved the selection of Isamu Kawai, former president of Nissan Diesel Motor Co., a subsidiary of Nissan Motor Co., during a meeting here. Nissan, Japan's second largest automaker, is Fuji's largest shareholder, with a 4.2 percent stake, and its superior in a corporate grouping, or keiretsu. Japan has many such groups, bound together by cross shareholdings, other financial ties and common business strategies. ``Fuji would have been probably taken over if it were in the United States, and I'm sure even Nissan had difficulty deciding whether it should acquire it,'' said Kimihide Takano, an analyst with Chemical Securities Co. But, he said, Nissan chose a typically Japanese way, taking advantage of its superior position in the group to send an executive to exercise effective control. ``This way, Nissan can obtain the same economic effects as acquiring the whole company,'' Takano said. He said Nissan plans to use Fuji facilities to expand its production and to obtain Fuji's technology in the defense and aerospace industry. Fuji is one of the nation's largest makers of military, aerospace and railroad equipment, but such production accounted for only 20 percent of the company's sales last year. Eighty percent of Fuji's 1989 sales of 658 billion yen, or $4.3 billion, came from automobiles. The 1989 sales were down 15 percent from the previous year, and Fuji ran up nearly 30 billion yen, or $194 million, in debt in the year. Meanwhile, sales of Nissan, Toyota Motor Corp., Honda Motor Co. and Mitsubishi Motors Corp. were booming in Japan and the United States. Industrial Bank of Japan, Fuji's main bank and its second largest shareholder, with a 4 percent stake, is also sending one of its former executives to Fuji's management. In a similar case, Sumitomo Bank rescued Mazda Motor Corp. 15 years ago when Mazda was in trouble. Until about a decade ago, Fuji's U.S. subsidiary distributing four-wheel-drive models was highly profitable, but its sales have plunged in the last few years. Analysts say the problem is weakness in its sales network. Fuji previously had no seats on the board of Subaru of America Inc. because it did not fully own its U.S. subsidiary. It announced recently, however, that it had bought the rest of the shares in Subaru of America. ``To tell you the truth, the situation has been very difficult for us,'' said a Fuji official, speaking on condition that he not be identified. ``Of course there is a weird feeling among us Fuji employees to have a president from Nissan, but that's the way it goes. We have to get over this tough time,'' he said. ``Mr. Kawai is familiar with our company, and he has a reputation for reviving Nissan Diesel, which was not doing very well before he was president, but now its doing just fine,'' he added. After resigning as Fuji's president to take responsibility for its problems, Toshihiro Tajima has taken the ceremonial position of chairman. Chemical Securities' Takano said there are too many automakers in Japan. ``The latest case suggests how Japanese auto industry can be restructured,'' he said. ``Small comanies will disappear by being merged into the big ones.''

The stock market showed some spotty gains today, following through on Wednesday's rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 5.69 to 2,867.82 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 7 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 686 up, 475 down and 563 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 44.11 million shares at midmorning. Buyers appeared to be encouraged by the market's steady showing Wednesday in the face of earnings disappointments from several large companies over the past few days. Analysts say traders are in a cautious mood as they await formal profit reports for the second quarter, which will begin to flow as early as next week. But some market participants evidently have opted to seek out stocks of companies with histories of strong earnings growth and lines of businesses that are perceived as recession-resistant. Worries about the business outlook, meanwhile, were calmed a bit Wednesday when the government reported that the index of leading economic indicators rose 0.8 percent in May. American Telephone & Telegraph dipped [ to 39 as the most active NYSE issue after a 2[-point loss Wednesday, when the company projected lower profits for the second quarter. Nike class B shares gained 2} to 76 in the over-the-counter market. The company said its latest quarterly earnings are expected to come in above estimates. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks added .58 to 194.45. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .89 at 357.94.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators Reach Agreement on Trade Deficit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2 grafs for 4th pvs, `Linn Williams...' to UPDATE with Bush reaction. Pickup 5th pvs, ``It is...'
DOC.TEXT: Japanese and U.S. negotiators today reached an agreement to help trim the $49 billion U.S. trade deficit with Japan. They hailed the accord as an unprecedented step toward easing tensions between the two partners. Details of the accord were to be announced later, but officials emerging from the talks in the Foreign Ministry said there had been compromises and cooperation. They said there was no need to schedule further sessions. There had been concern that this round in the so-called Structural Impediments Initiative might have to be continued next week in the United States to reach agreement on a final report about far-reaching economic policy changes. President Bush welcomed the accord and said ``the effects will be beneficial for the entire world.'' In a written statement in Washington, Bush credited the ``strong and courageous political leadership'' of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu for the progess achieved. Linn Williams, the U.S. deputy trade representative, said Bush and Kaifu had taken important steps, especially Bush in his announcement of willingness to consider tax revenue increases. ``It is a remarkable thing that these two economies have done,'' Williams said. ``I see this as a kind of joint leadership. Japan and the United States got together on difficult issues and worked together constructively. We should be pleased with the efforts and results.'' ``Particularly Prime Minister Kaifu and President Bush can be proud. They have done something no two other countries have done before,'' he added. Bush and Kaifu talked by telephone late Wednesday about Japan's final increased offer to boost public works spending _ a key area of disagreement. Williams said the trade talks were ``an important influence'' on Bush's tax move, which is aimed at reducing the federal budget deficit. The deficit is regarded as a fundamental cause of the trade imbalance, because it fuels U.S. demand for consumption and imports from Japan. Raising U.S. tax revenues may thus reduce Japanese exports and cut the trade surplus. Bush's announcement was followed by a Japanese compromise Wednesday to increase planned public works spending. That might help reduce the trade imbalance by increasing sales of U.S. products and construction services in Japan and soaking up some excess Japanese savings and investment funds. ``We have an international responsibility, and we had to cooperate to come to a compromise,'' a senior Japanese official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The talks had stretched from their scheduled two days to four before they ended late today. ``After four days of looking at each others' faces, friendships tend to develop,'' the Japanese official said. Another Japanese official said both countries had taken politically dangerous steps. Bush risks political strife if taxes are increased, and the Japanese worry about inflation resulting from boosts in public works spending. The Japanese side added $96.77 billion to its offer on public spending, boosting the total to $2.77 trillion over 10 years, Japanese media reported. The U.S. side had asked for $3.22 trillion for the decade. The linkage between U.S. taxes and Japanese public spending showed, if nothing else, the interdependence of the immense U.S. and Japanese economies. That interdependence was at the heart of the structural trade talks, which also covered such Japanese issues as high land prices, laws restricting large retail stores, collusive practices of large business groups, pricing mechanisms and long delays in procesing patent applications. On the U.S. side, the issues included the budget deficit, measures to promote exports, training of workers and competitiveness of U.S. products. The structural trade talks were launched in September. An interim report was agreed upon in April, and the current talks started Monday. Some commentators regarded the talks as dangerous because, rather than focusing on specific trade issues, they gave a forum for each country to criticize fundamental things in the other such as education systems, cultural business practices and savings habits. If the talks had failed, each side could have had good reason to be more angry than ever. ``The more you become interdependent, the more problems you will have,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said earlier this week. ``But you will be more used to solving problems.''

For release Sunday July 1
DOC.HEAD: REPEAT FOR ALL NEEDING
Rise and Fall of Flamboyant Builder Mirrors Thrift Crisis
LaserPhoto NY308 of June 26
DOC.TEXT: Kenneth M. Good wore a jogging suit the night he clinched one of the biggest land deals of his high-flying career. It was January 1985 and Good was racing in fast times. The savings and loan money machines were in overdrive, real estate was hot, and Florida swarmed with speculators who had cash or knew how to get it. Good swaggered into town from Denver and pledged nearly $38 million cash for 5,400 acres of Spanish moss-draped woodlands north of Tampa. Plans for fine homes, offices and a high-brow country club were envisioned. Five years later, the unfinished Tampa Palms development is controlled by two banks and up for sale, another victim of a faltering real estate market. Good says his net worth has plummeted from $100 million into the red. Congressional investigators have grilled Good about links to the failed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver and a scandal that has ensnared President Bush's son, Neil. ``I feel no shame,'' the 45-year-old Good told the House Banking Committee recently. ``Shame implies guilt. I think I was as much a victim of the markets as anyone else.'' The saga of Ken Good is a microcosm of the S&L crisis: risky ventures, free-spending splendor, collapse. Deeply indebted to Silverado and others, Good managed to convince the financially troubled owners of the Tampa site that he was their savior. People familiar with the negotiating session said Good attended the final signing in a jogging suit, a symbolic reflection of his go-go personality. But ultimately, he came up with less than half the $38 million he promised. Site owners agreed to let him finance the rest. He then used Tampa Palms as collateral for loans and a $70 million high-risk ``junk bond'' issue to finance other ventures, including the $250 million debt-financed takeover of Gulfstream Land & Development Corp, one of Florida's major builders. Good looked like the best thing that ever happened to Tampa until his mounting debts and the slowing real estate market toppled his empire. ``What can you say? It's the story of the last couple years,'' said James Apthorp, a former Gulfstream executive kept on as consultant at Tampa Palms after foreclosure. Good, a Methodist minister's son raised in a Kansas farm town, followed prosperity around the nation with what acquaintances call a barnstormer's zeal. In 1969, he formed Good Financial Corp. in Dallas and began amassing properties before a slump in the late 1970s. Stuck with dozens of sites and no buyers, Good dissolved the company in 1979 and moved to Denver. It was in the shadow of the Rocky Mountains that Good honed his flamboyant personality and enlarged his network of high-profile connections. Good helped found a home-building company, Talley Corp., which became one of Denver's most successful developers. He resigned as chairman and sold his share for an undisclosed amount in January 1986, just before the end of Denver's oil boom. Talley liquidated later that year. Meanwhile, Good had become a star in Denver's social scene. He tossed money to charities and sipped champagne with the city's elite. A lavish party marked the opening of his $10 million mansion, decorated with contemporary art and expensive furniture _ later used as collateral for real estate deals. Good's circle of influential friends included Neil Bush, a Silverado director. Years later, the links between the two were still strong. Documents filed with the House Banking Committee show Good's Silverado debt was reduced by $8 million shortly after Gulfstream agreed to invest more than $3 million in JNB Exploration Co., an oil and gas partnership managed by Bush. The transaction also reduced Bush's personal liability in a line of credit for JNB. Bush, who appeared before the House panel in May, denied any improprieties in the deal. Silverado, seized by federal regulators in December 1988, has been the target of some Democrats who question whether the administration moved too slowly against the thrift and are too lenient with Neil Bush. Thrift regulators have denied the allegations, but decline to specifically discuss the case. Silverado lost an estimated $31 million on Good's speculative investments in Colorado. Cost of the Siliverado bailout is estimated at $1 billion. ``He has an uncanny sense of timing for business,'' Bush said of Good two years ago. Bush did not return telephone calls for comment on this article. Good swept into Tampa in late 1984 unknown, but quickly crafted a reputation as a free-wheeling visionary. He billed Tampa Palms _ strategically located near an interstate highway _ as one of the ``best pieces of dirt'' east of the Mississippi and a future national showplace. His image was further enhanced by the quick acquisition of Gulfstream, based in Plantation, Fla., upping his portfolio to more than 30,000 acres. He poured money into Tampa Palms, adding a fancy clubhouse and exquisite landscaping. He staged grand news conferences each step of the way and cultivated the local press with personally guided tours of the property. He was toasted by politicians, courted by the chamber of commerce and revered as a deity by fellow developers. A builder at a trade meeting, where Good was a guest speaker, introduced him simply as ``Mr. God.'' He wore silk suits and drove a maroon Maserati. Weekends might find him flying to Monte Carlo or New York aboard his six-seat private jet. On election night in 1988, Good flew to Houston for President Bush's victory party. Good's own party in Tampa soured with the economy. Tampa Palms sales slowed, business relocations fell through, lenders pressed for payments. It was Dallas and Denver all over again. Ironically, billboards for Tampa Palms proclaim, ``It Only Happens Once.'' Good himself dismissed talk of his demise. In one of his last public speeches, in May 1989, Good labeled the rumors ``cocktail conversation'' and unveiled plans for other projects. In March, a group of lenders and junk-bond holders agreed to swap more than $200 million in debt for control of Tampa Palms, other properties and Gulfstream. Good was ousted from the company. During negotiations, the lenders forced Good to stay away. ``They would not even let him in the room,'' said Apthorp. ``They had so lost confidence in him.'' Meanwhile, Good faced bank foreclosure on his posh Tampa Palms home, averted only by a last-minute payment. His Denver home fetched $3.3 million at an auction last October. Good has pulled up stakes again, this time to New York. He's expressed interest in becoming a commodities broker. Reached in New York by telephone, Good said he now ``never comments to the press.'' Good's attorney, Gil Thurm, said he has no comment on his client. ``I really don't know what his plans are,'' said Charles Knight, a Tampa real estate appraiser and friend of Good's. ``But a man that's been able to do what's he's done _ you're not going to keep him down.''

DOC.TEXT: The stock market eked out a slight gain today, following through on Wednesday's rally. DOC.HEAD: Norway Laments Extra U.S. Duty on Imported Salmon
DOC.TEXT: The Norweigan government said it may fight an extra import duty the United States begins imposing Friday on Norwegian farmed salmon. The U.S. government established the temporary 2.45 percent additional tariff in response to U.S. fish farmers' concerns. They complained Norwegian farmers can export fish at unfairly low prices because they allegedly receive state subsidies, a Norwegian foreign ministry statement said. The ministry said Norway may appeal the penalty under the terms of the international General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Norway exported 13,000 tons of its 100,000 tons of farmed salmon to the United States last year, according to the national news agency, NTB.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Accepts EC Judgment on ``Sweeteners'' in Rover Sale
DOC.TEXT: Britain on Thursday said it had accepted a judgment by the European Commission against the government's inclusion of ``sweeteners'' in selling the state-owned Rover automobile group to British Aerospace PLC. Trade Secretary Nicholas Ridley said although the government differed on some details of the EC's rulings, it would support the EC's jurisdiction in the matter by accepting the judgment in general. Ridley said the department would take up its differences with the EC after consulting with British Aerospace. The commission ruled in Brussels Wednesday that the Department of Trade and Industry illegally granted 44.4 million pounds, or $77 million, in aid when it sold Rover to British Aerospace for 150 million pounds, or $261 million, in July 1988. The commission, which seeks to enforce fair competition in the European Community, decided the sweeteners were illegal, hidden state subsidies. The aid consisted of delayed payment of the sale price, under which British Aerospace benefited an estimated 33.4 million pounds, or $58 million; and 11 million pounds, or $19 million, provided to the two companies to offset the cost of buying a small number of Rover shares left in public hands. The commission ordered the British government to recover 42.9 million pounds, or $75 million, of the aid from British Aerospace and a further 1.5 million pounds, or $2.6 million, from Rover. British Aerospace had no immediate comment, a spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Second in a Series
Losses and Layoffs Devastate Northeast Economy
LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Recession has rolled across some regions and may well have taken hold unofficially in much of the country. Perhaps no area is dragging now as much as New England, one of the brightest stars of the 1980s boom. This second part of a four-part series examines the Northeast's problems.

The go-go days of booming economies in the Northeastern states are gone-gone. The ``Massachusetts Miracle'' is a mirage. As Bill Mallon found, even some Salvation Army shelves are nearly bare. Mallon said he made $75,000-a-year as a self-employed carpenter three years ago. But by last November, there was no work at all for Mallon and many like him. As a last resort in his direst moment, he turned to the Salvation Army one day recently, seeking canned goods to help feed his disabled wife and three children, and money to pay his utility bills. ``When your children say, `Hey Dad, there's no food in the house, I'm her the horse was gone _ are pressuring bankers to deny credit to deserving borrowers.'' In economic theory at least, limits on credit supplies are supposed to serve useful purposes even as they inflict pain. If banks won't lend, for example, to developers of condominiums, shopping centers and office buildings, says Edward Yardeni, director of economics at Prudential-Bache Securities, there may be good reason for that reluctance: ``There is a glut of these projects all around the country. We simply don't need any more condos, strip malls and office space.'' Should the economy keep sending out signs of weakness, however, pressure on the Fed to change its position almost certainly would increase. At the moment, says Mitchell Held at Wall Street's Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., ``that fine line between slow growth and recession seems to be getting even finer.''

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Up at General Mills, Conagra in 4th Qtr
DOC.TEXT: The food giant ConAgra Inc. said Thursday its fourth-quarter earnings rose 12.5 percent to a record, while General Mills Inc. said its earnings more than doubled in its fourth quarter from year-earlier results depressed by losses from discontinued operations. ConAgra, which is based in Omaha, Neb., said its earnings for its latest fiscal year rose 17 percent and expects another year of record earnings for 1991. The company agreed on June 7 to purchase Beatrice Co. for $1.34 billion in cash and stock. Minneapolis-based General Mills, which markets Big G cereals and Betty Crocker foods and operates the Red Lobster restaurant chain, said its earnings rose 19 percent in its latest fiscal year.
DOC.HEAD: ConAgra
DOC.TEXT: ConAgra said it earned $73.5 million, or 59 cents per share, in the three months ended May 27 compared with $65.4 million, or 53 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 35 percent to $4.01 billion from $2.97 billion a year earlier. For the fiscal year, ConAgra said it earned $231.7 million, or $1.87 per share, compared with $197.9 million, or $1.63 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the year rose 36.7 percent to $15.5 billion from $11.34 billion a year earlier. The main reason for the big increases in sales for both periods was the inclusion of results from a company formerly known as Swift Independent Packing Co. ConAgra acquired the 50 percent share it did not already own in that company during the latest fiscal year. Reults from that unit are included in the latest fiscal year's results but not in results from fiscal 1989. The company said its operating profit in its biggest operating segment, prepared foods, rose 19 percent for the year to $349.2 million on a 56 percent sales increase to $11.03 billion. Among its brands are the Healthy Choice line of frozen foods and it markets fresh beef, chicken, turkey, pork, dairy and food oils products. For the current fiscal year, ConAgra's chairman and chief executiuve, Charles M. Harper, said the addition of Beatrice will ``improve ConAgra's food chain balance and the overall stability of our business mix.''
DOC.HEAD: General Mills
DOC.TEXT: General Mills said it earned $75.3 million, or 93 cents per share, in the three months ended May 27 compared with $35.6 million, or 45 cents a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter sales rose 19 percent to $1.71 billion from $1.44 billion a year earlier. Results from the final quarter of 1989, however, included a $22.1 million loss on the discontinued operations of Talbots and Eddie Bauer clothing chains, York cafeteria-style restaurants and Vromans frozen foods. Compared to General Mills' continuing operations in last year's fourth quarter, earnings jumped 26 percent from $57.7 million and sales grew 19 percent to $1.71 billion. For the year, General Mills said net earnings dropped 8 percent to $381.4 million, or $4.64 a share, from $414.3 million, or $5.06 a share, a year ago. Sales rose to $6.46 billion, up 14.9 percent from $5.62 billion a year ago. Chairman Bruce Atwater said consumer foods, the division which accounts for 70 percent of the company's total sales, had an 18 percent increase in operating profits for the year and a 31 percent increase for the fourth quarter. Sales of Betty Crocker products jumped 11 percent on the year, led by growth in Hamburger Helper and several snack food lines, he said. Big G cereals, including Cheerios and Wheaties, grabbed 27 percent of the $7 billion retail ready-to-eat cereal market reached in fiscal 1990, about 2.5 points higher than the prior year, Atwater said. Restaurants owned by General Mills, including Red Lobster and Olive Garden, had 19 percent sales growth to $1.93 billion for the year while operating profit leaped 21 percent to $154.2 million.

DOC.HEAD: PHOENIX: it's fragile.''
DOC.TEXT: Like much of the rest of the country, Arizona faces what some economists are calling a credit crunch, or a shortage of loan money. That not only has crimped housing, but also other small businesses. SupeRx Corp., a chain of 130 drug stores in four states, sought bankruptcy protection after government regulators who seized the firm's main lender were unwilling to renegotiate debt. Chicken-chain El Pollo Asado was forced to liquidate after regulators cut off financing. ``They made a bad situation a whole lot worse,'' said Ron Paradise, former president of El Pollo Asado. ``All we needed was another 30 days to put a reorganization plan in place.'' Seven of Arizona's 10 S&Ls are controlled by the federal government, which must sell or dispose of $15 billion worth of assets in the state. A survey by the accounting firm Kenneth Leventhal & Co. found the worst shortage of credit in Arizona in nearly two decades. ``We're virtually redlined in terms of new financing,'' said former Phoenix Mayor Terry Goddard, now a gubernatorial candidate. But across the country in Washington, talk of a credit crunch is dismissed by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman and the most powerful banker in the country. Nonetheless, Greenspan acknowledged to Congress last month, some lenders have tightened their practices, and ``this cautious stance in the granting of credit could cumulate to threaten the economic expansion.'' Whatever it's called, the declining availability of credit doesn't seem to have drastically affected consumer spending, at least not yet. Consumers account for much of the nation's economic activity. Findings of the University of Michigan's respected Survey Research Center, for example, show many consumers remain upbeat in their outlook. ``Consumers say these are good times, in contrast to the volatile 1970s,'' said survey director Richard Curtin. ``After the '70s, slow and steady are not viewed as negatively as what they might have been.'' But viewed another way, Curtin's survey barely gets 50 percent of consumers polled to say these are good times. Another prominent consumer survey produced by the Conference Board, a New York business research group, shows consumer confidence dropped significantly in June, the first serious decline this year. ``For those who like to categorize things as boom or bust, this is difficult because it's neither,'' Curtin said. ``One of the reasons it's not (a severe bust) is because we didn't go into an excessive boom.'' Confident consumers have kept up their spending ways, even as their personal debt load has increased. Eggert said that's one reason the economy shows signs of strength. ``We're avoiding a recession by spending,'' Eggert said. ``One of the reasons for our prosperity is that all three groups _ government, consumers and business _ are still borrowing.'' To some economists, whether the economy is truly in a recession boils down to a question of words, definitions and interpretations. ``We are limping along, and that's different than being crippled,'' said Brusca. ``It really is a game of semantics. But to some, being in a little bit of a recession is like being a little bit pregnant.''

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Down This Week

DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 224,867 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 242,325, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is higher than the same week a year ago, in which 198,089 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 143,912 cars this week, compared with 149,895 a week ago and 119,800 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 80,955, compared with last week's 92,430 and last year's 78,289. Canadian automakers were to build 26,142 cars this week, down from 27,214 a week ago and up from last year's 16,756. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 20,101, compared with 21,153 a week ago and 19,632 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Contract is Biggest for Fluor in Decade
DOC.TEXT: A contract to oversee the near-doubling of Saudi Arabia's oil production capacity is the biggest project for engineering and construction giant Fluor Corp. in a decade. Officials at the Irvine-based company and Saudi Arabia's state-owned Aramco put no exact value on the contract, awarded Wednesday. Published reports quoted industry analysts saying the contract could be worth $2 billion to $5 billion. But Fluor said Thursday the reports could be misleading. It said in a news release that the program still is being defined and work will be released in phases over five years. ``Certainly, this is the most significant contract we have received in more than a decade,'' said Les McCraw, Fluor's vice chairman and chief executive. But McCraw added: ``While we are extremely pleased to be a part of Saudi Aramco's comprehensive expansion program it's premature to speculate on its ultimate value to Fluor and its shareholders.''

DOC.HEAD: Corn Futures Surge, Other Crops Mixed Ahead of USDA Report
DOC.TEXT: Corn futures prices rallied strongly late in Thursday's session on the Chicago Board of Trade ahead of an Agriculture Department report that was expected to show a drawdown in the U.S. corn stockpile. Wheat futures closed moderately lower; soybeans ended narrowly mixed. The Agriculture Department's quarterly grain stocks report, which was released after the closed, showed corn stocks at 2.84 billion bushels as of June 1, slightly below the expected 2.86 billion bushels and well below last year's 3.42 billion on the same date. Soybean stocks were near expectations at 596 million bushels; wheat stocks were higher than expected at 535 million bushels. A USDA report on planted acreage showed farmers planted more corn and fewer soybeans than traders had expected. Corn futures also were supported by expectations that no delivery notices will be posted Friday against the soon-to-expire July contract, an indication of strong domestic demand for the grain. At the close, wheat futures were 1{ cents to 3 cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $3.31 a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 9 cents higher with July at $2.96 a bushel; oats were { cent lower to } cent higher with July at $1.35} a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to 1 cent higher with July at $6.07{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises New U.S.-Japan Trade Agreement
With AM-Japan-US, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday hailed a trade reform agreement with Japan as ``an important framework'' for reducing the $49 billion U.S. trade deficit with Tokyo. The president said he welcomed the joint report Thursday by U.S. and Japanese negotiators in Tokyo. In it the two countries identified internal economic practices that hinder open trade, took corrective actions, and ``made commitments to take further steps to resolve a wide range of structural problems,'' Bush said in a written statement. ``We expect that the structural policy actions to be taken will have a positive effect on our economies, encouraging open and competitive markets, promoting sustained world economic growth, contributing to a reduction in global payments imbalance, and enhancing the quality of life in both Japan and the United States,'' he said. Further, the president said in the statement, the U.S.-Japan agreement will benefit ``the entire world.'' Bush was expected to discuss the matter further on Saturday when he meets with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu in Houston where both are attending the economic summit of industrialized nations. The agreement Thursday emerged from a series of complex negotiations called the Structural Impediments Initiative, or SII, involving the removal of barriers to open trading. The joint report in Tokyo followed Bush's acknowledgment this week that new taxes may be needed to reduce the U.S. federal deficit, a key factor in getting the agreement, officials said. The announcement that the president would consider such taxes was followed by a Japanese compromise Wednesday to increase planned public works spending. That might help reduce the trade imbalance by increasing sales of U.S. products and construction services in Japan and soaking up some excess Japanese savings and investment funds. ``As Japan tackles its structural problems,'' Bush said in his statement, ``so must the United States.'' The president said he wants to work closely with Congress in the ongoing budget negotiations to strengthen public and private savings and lower the deficit. ``Both our governments recognize that further effort will be necessary in order to address fully these structural problems and to maintain the momentum of our adjustment efforts,'' Bush said. Bush lauded Kaifu for his personal efforts in fashioning the agreement and for ``strong and courageous political leadership.''

DOC.HEAD: Coffee Marketers Look for Alternatives in Shrinking Market
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The declining presence of coffee in American diets has marketers scrambling for ways to attract younger drinkers and to expand in overseas markets. The impact of the decades-long slide in U.S. coffee drinking was highlighted Wednesday when Maxwell House announced plans to close a 50-year-old coffee roasting and grinding plant in Hoboken, N.J. The company, a division of Philip Morris Cos.' Kraft-General Foods International, blamed declining consumption for the move. Americans drank an average of 1.75 cups of coffee per person last year, down from a peak in 1962 of 3.12 cups per day, according to the London-based International Coffee Organization. The organization represents coffee-producing countries such as Brazil and Colombia. ``People are moving from hot, acrid drinks to sweet, cold drinks. I think they will continue to do so because of our lifestyle. People don't want to sit around blowing on coffee or tea,'' said Jack Maxwell, an industry analyst for Wheat First Securities Inc. In 1962, nearly 75 percent of Americans drank coffee regularly, according to the coffee producers' group. By 1988, the percentage was 52.5 percent. And the fraction of people aged 20 to 29 who drink coffee fell from 80 percent in 1962 to 35 percent last year. ``I think it really has more to do with the quality of the coffee, which has not been as high in the last 20 years,'' said Steven Gregg, marketing director for the organization's Coffee Development Group. ``And it's an image problem. Coffee has not been marketed to younger people as soft drinks have.'' The collapse last July of an international coffee-price treaty briefly slowed the decline in consumption, said Celeste Georgakis, a commodities analyst for Cargill Investor Services Inc. The futures market price fell at that point from $1.20 a pound to 68 cents, although it since has rebounded to the 86-cent range. ``Even that did not stimulate consumption, because the younger generation has turned to soft drinks,'' Ms. Georgakis said. Soft drink makers have been working to exploit declining interest in coffee by trying to win a place on breakfast tables. Pepsi-Cola Co. last year began test marketing in Waterloo, Iowa, for Pepsi A.M., which has more caffeine than regular Pepsi but less than coffee. ``A.M. has been going well,'' Pepsi spokesman Tod MacKenzie said, although he said the company hasn't decided whether to market the product nationwide. He also said the company was testing advertising that pitches regular Pepsi as a morning drink in Fort Wayne, Ind. For several years, market leader Coca-Cola Co., has provided its bottlers with advertising for use at their discretion that promotes ``Coca-Cola in the morning.'' Gregg said his group is trying to attract younger drinkers by promoting flavored coffees and unusual blends. ``Over the last five years, growth rates for specialty coffees are estimated at 15 to 25 percent a year,'' Gregg said. ``We're particularly doing a lot with iced coffee. We're seeing a lot of success with local entrepreneurs and some of the larger companies getting into iced coffee products.'' Overseas, where the coffee market still is growing, Maxwell House is introducing new instant coffees in Europe and has formed joint ventures with Japanese and Korean food companies, Maxwell House spokesman Richard Collins said. ``In China, we have a small business. A few months ago, we introduced 100 percent Colombian coffee,'' Collins said. Philip Morris also has agreed to buy the Swiss company Jacobs Suchard, the world's third-largest chocolate and coffee group, for $3.8 billion. Among the largest coffee marketers, Philip Morris, whose brands include Yuban, Master Blend and Sanka as well as Maxwell House, is tied for leadership of the market with Procter & Gamble Co.'s Folgers brand. Wheat First's Maxwell estimates each held about a 32 percent share of the $3.9 billion U.S. coffee market last year. Nestle held a 13.5 percent share of the market with its Hills Brothers and Chase & Sanborn brands, according to Maxwell. All other makers, including Chock Full O' Nuts and Butternut, totalled 22.2 percent of the market. ``I think the big guys are going to continue to do well. There are a lot of others who are disappearing, and they are a large percentage of the total,'' Maxwell said.

DOC.HEAD: Law Partner Charged With Insider Trading
DOC.TEXT: A name partner in a Manhattan law firm was charged Thursday with allegedly using inside information to make $34,000 in illegal trading profits in the stock of WearEver-Proctor Silex Inc. In a civil complaint filed in U.S. District Court in New York, the Securities and Exchange Commission accused attorney Henry A. Singer of violating insider trading laws in 1987. According to the SEC, Singer, a partner in the firm of Morrison Cohen Singer & Weinstein, was retained as counsel by WearEver's board to consider offers to acquire WearEver, a Glen Allen, Va.-based electrical appliance maker. The SEC charged that Singer, 52, of Harrison, N.Y., while in possession of confidential corporate information about pending deals to buy the company, bought WearEver stock in the fall of 1987 and sold it on or about April 8, 1988. WearEver was acquired by NACCO Industries Inc. on April 15, 1988. Singer's lawyer could not be reached immediately for comment, but Singer's law firm issued a statement. ``Despite the overwhelming evidence that there was no improper trading, the SEC is pursuing a civil action against Mr. Singer,'' the firm said in a statement issued by managing partner, Robert Stephan Cohen. ``The SEC's decision to file a civil suit is inexplicable. We are convinced, without any doubt whatsoever, that Mr. Singer did not violate, either intentionally or inadvertently, any SEC rules or regulations.'' Cohen added that ``the firm stands behind'' Singer.

DOC.HEAD: RESENDING FOR ALL NEEDING
Interest Rates Lower at Auction
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on 52-week Treasury bills fell in Thursday's action to the lowest level in more than four months. The Treasury Department sold $10.26 billion of the bills at an average discount rate of 7.52 percent, down from 7.65 percent at the last auction on May 31. The rates were the lowest since Feb. 13, when the one-year bills sold for 7.42 percent. The new discount rate understates the actual return to investors _ 8.09 percent with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,237.60.
