For release Sunday July 1
DOC.HEAD: For Many, Economy Seems Stuck In `Unofficial Recession'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf, _ An official..., to CLARIFY that GNP has been growing less than 2 percent since October, one of the slowest periods since the 1982 recession.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY305,306 of June 26; Graphic in AP Access under RECESSION1
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Webster's defines recession as ``a period of reduced economic activity.'' Federal economists, however, have more technical definitions. Today's weak economy may not qualify as an official recession, but for millions of Americans, this year feels an awful lot like a recession, at least of the dictionary variety. This first of a four-part series examines the nation's ``Unofficial Recession.''

Richard Lyon and his son tried to make a living with a two-truck shipping company. But bills outran them, the business shut down, and Lyon drove straight into bankruptcy court. Don't tell him the economy's not in a recession. ``We're just one of the statistics now,'' Lyon shrugged. R.A. Ballard went from building 78 homes a year here in 1986 to six this year. The three savings and loans that financed him each were declared insolvent and seized by federal regulators. He's found it difficult to borrow more money. ``I have essentially closed my company down,'' said Ballard, a director of the National Association of Home Builders. ``I thought it was only happening to me. I thought it was isolated to Texas, Arizona and some other problem areas. But it's not. It's happening everywhere.'' A recession? Not based on officially sanctioned economic statistics. They show the U.S. economy continues to eke out slow growth, prolonging the longest peacetime expansion in history. But in some regions, such as the Northeast and parts of the Sunbelt, local economies have slipped dramatically. In some industries, most notably housing, a recession is clearly underway, many economists say. For millions of Americans, from clerks in debt-laden retail stores to defense industry machinists facing unemployment, and truckers and builders like Lyon and Ballard, the times feel like a recession _ an unofficial recession. ``Official proclamations aside, I think for certain sectors and certain states, it is a recession,'' said Robert Brusca, chief financial economist at Nikko Securities Co. International in New York. ``This is not a typical business cycle recession, but the regional problems may finally drag down the rest of the country,'' said Albert Sindlinger, a forecaster whose Wallingford, Pa. firm tracks ``household liquidity'' as a measure of the economy's health. Sindlinger's survey predicted the last two recessions when it found more than 50 percent of U.S. households responded negatively to at least one of his key questions dealing with household income, jobs and business conditions. That happened again for the first time in January. ``Historically, every time that we've had the nation with over 50 percent of the population in recession, that was the month that the government later issued a declaration saying that was when the recession started,'' Sindlinger said. Consider: _ The Labor Department reported no job growth in the private sector during March, April and May. _ An official forecasting gauge called the index of leading economic indicators has remained sluggish this year. The gross national product, the broadest official measure of economic activity, has been growing at less than a 2 percent annual rate since October, one of the slowest periods since the 1982 recession. _ New home sales have fallen for six months, also to the lowest level since the recession year 1982. The auto industry is stalled and defense contractors are laying off thousands. _ Bankruptcies are growing. They range from the huge corporate variety resulting from junk-bond debt like that of Federated Department Stores, to the personal variety resulting from unemployment or too many bills. _ The latest report on regional economies by the Federal Reserve, the nation's central bank, said most are weak or growing only slowly. Still, the Fed's periodic assessment released late last month found healthy economies in the northern Midwest and the Pacific coast states. Moreover, economists say key ingredients are missing to lay the groundwork for a recession _ most notably the high inflation that causes interest rates to jump sharply and bring business to a halt. They also say the economy today is far more diversified than in the past. ``If the economy was still as heavily dependent on housing and autos as it was in the '60s and '70s, then I'd say we're in a recession. But it's not,'' said Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. economist Edward Yardeni, who coined the term ``rolling recession'' to describe the regional downturns that have swept across the country in recent years. ``I would still characterize it as a rolling recession,'' Yardeni said. ``If you want to find recession, you can find it. But it's not economy-wide.'' The National Association of Business Economists still predicts the economy will skirt a recession through 1991. Economist Robert J. Eggert, whose Sedona, Ariz., firm compiles the Blue Chip Consensus forecasting report, agrees. ``I feel very strongly that we will not have a recession as a nation this year or next,'' said Eggert. On the other hand, he said, ``recession-like conditions are likely to prevail in some industries and regions of the nation. It's going to seem like a recession to some people.'' It seems that way in Kevin O'Brien's business, which grew by a record 18 percent last year, and this year is up 24 percent over that pace. Customers line up before opening and use a night-drop slot long past closing. The number of employees has nearly tripled in four years. O'Brien's shop isn't the hippest high-tech firm or video store. He's the clerk for the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Phoenix, now one of the busiest in the nation. By the looks of the rows of people poring over stacks of bankruptcy documents, you might say the local economy was in a recession. But like the rest of the nation, Arizona's economy is growing sluggishly. A few office buildings are still under construction in Phoenix. State unemployment is running around 5.3 percent, about the national average. ``It is a very soft economy here,'' said Ron Simon, economist with the Arizona Department of Economic Security. ``Within Arizona you could say that construction and related industries are in a recession, but overall, we are still growing as a state, so we are not in a recession as a state, but it's fragile.''
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Kodak Would Sell Assets if Polaroid Damages Top $2 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. would consider selling off assets if it is fined more than $2 billion for infringing on Polaroid Corp.'s instant camera patents, Chairman Kay R. Whitmore said in an interview with Barron's magazine. Polaroid has asked for $14 billion in damages, while attorneys for Kodak suggested the amount should be $187 millin plus interest. Industry analysts say a realistic amount would be somewhere between $1 billion and $2 billion. Whitmore said that he has received no indication when Judge David Mazzone of the U.S. District Court in Boston will decide on a damage figure. The case has dragged on since 1986, when Kodak was barred from making or selling the instant cameras it had introduced a decade earlier. Whitmore said in the June 25 edition of Barron's, the business weekly, that Sterling Drug, the pharmaceutical company purchased by Kodak in 1988, would be a possible sale target if the award is more than $2 billion. ``I have to recognize that there is a scenario where we won't have a choice, where I would have to sell something to raise the cash,'' Whitmore said. ``Which one? Well, the most obvious one, the one we just bought, is Sterling. We could get more for that today than the $5.1 billion we paid.'' Whitmore said Kodak would fight an award it considers too large. ``I can tell you if we think the award is excessive, we will appeal,'' he said. ``It could all drag on a while yet.'' Despite the looming damage award, Barron's expressed confidence that cost-cutting measures will boost Kodak earnings this year, film price increases will firm up film margins, and new camera and film technology will bolster the company's market share.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: FIXES date in lede
DOC.HEAD: Companies Allowed to Continue Using Operating Revenues
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge on Thursday extended an order that allows Greyhound Lines Inc. to continue daily operations while the company arranges to pay off creditors. Judge Richard S. Schmidt also gave temporary approval to the Dallas law firm Gardere & Wynne to represent unsecured creditors of the nation's largest bus transportation company. Dallas-based Greyhound and its subsidiaries on June 4 filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Brownsville, where its Eagle Bus Manufacturing Inc. subsidiary is based. The company has suffered financially since a walkout nearly four months ago by its 6,300 bus drivers. The order allowing Greyhound to use operating revenues ``in the ordinary course of business'' extends indefinitely a similar temporary order the judge approved at a June 7 hearing. Greyhound attorney Oscar Cantu estimated the company takes in ``from $1 million to several million in revenues daily.'' Schmidt authorized Gardere & Wynne to represent the creditors until a July 12 hearing in McAllen, when he plans to take up the matter again. Greyhound's June 4 bankruptcy filing included a 1,800-page list of debt holders owed a total of about $540 million.

DOC.HEAD: Polaroid, Minolta Agree to Produce Instant Camera
DOC.TEXT: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. _ Polaroid Corp. and Minolta Camera Co. Ltd. said Thursday they have agreed to manufacture and distribute an instant camera in the United States. Under the pact, Minolta will market in this country an instant camera manufactured by Polaroid in Scotland. The agreement marks the first time Polaroid instant cameras have been available under another brand name, the statement said. The camera, the Minolta Instant Pro, will be distributed beginning in August. It will include a special close-up lens allowing picture-taking at a distance of 10 inches, Polaroid said. With a suggested price of $219, the camera will be geared toward industrial and professional users, said Lee Brewer, vice president of worldwide sales for Polaroid. He said the camera would open up specialty camera stores to Polaroid. Involving another firm in the instant photographic business was part of a strategy to stimulate Polaroid's overall growth, he said. Jim deMerlier, a vice president of marketing for Minolta, said the agreement would give his company an entree into the instant photographic business. ``Minolta has been very strong in other areas, but we've never been in instant cameras,'' he said. I. MacAllister Booth, Polaroid's president and chief executive officer, said in a statement the two companies ``see this as a first step to explore a potential long-term collaboration between our two companies.'' Cambridge-based Polaroid Corp. had sales of $1.9 billion last year from its instant photographic cameras and film, and conventional and electronic visual communications products. Minolta Corp. (USA), headquartered in Ramsey, N.J., is a subsidiary of Minolta Corp. of Japan. The company has annual sales of more than $2 billion from cameras and business equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Rumor-Related Rally Helps Oil Prices Rebound
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices finished sharply higher Thursday after the oil market snapped out of its recent slump. A rumor early in the session of Israeli military action against Libya sparked a rally on the New York Mercantile Exchange. As the buying waned after the rumor was dispelled, fresh news of OPEC efforts to prop up world oil prices renewed the rally. The contract for August delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, jumped 47 cents to $17.15 a 42-gallon barrel, more than making up for Wednesday's 46-cent loss. Contracts for later delivery advanced by similar amounts. Among refined petroleum products traded on the exchange, the July contract of wholesale unleaded gasoline surged 1.44 cents to 60.93 cents a gallon after dropping 1.83 cents on Wednesday. Later delivery contracts posted more moderate gains. The July home heating oil contract added 1.10 cents, settling at 49.03 cents a gallon following Wednesday's slide of 0.56 cent. Subsequent contracts also rose. In natural gas trading, the August contract rose to $1.515 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.500 Wednesday. The Wednesday settlement was the lowest for the near-month contract since the New York Merc began trading natural gas in early April. Contracts for later delivery were mixed. James Steel, an energy analyst at Refco Inc., said trading started out with a bang as a rumor that Israel had bombed Tripoli circulated in the market. Within an hour, an Israeli government spokesman had denied the rumor and buying interest began to fade. But news that the acting president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has scheduled further strategy sessions with several cartel members pumped new life into the rally. The cartel leader has had a series of meetings to discuss ways to shore up the slumping market. Energy analysts said the rally caught some traders off guard. Many of them have been shorting the market, or selling contracts in anticipation of further price declines. The outlook for oil prices remains bearish due to abundant supplies and sluggish demand. Part of the buying Thursday was technically-motivated as traders scrambled to cover their short positions.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturers Hanover To Take 2nd Qtr. Charge; Analysts See Layoffs
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 14th graf to UPDATE with closing stock price
DOC.TEXT: Manufacturers Hanover Corp. said Thursday it will take an unspecified one-time charge in the second quarter related to a restructuring that analysts say may result in the loss of more than 1,000 jobs. The charge, which did not surprise analysts, stems from the bank's efforts to reduce expenses, according to a preliminary prospectus covering an offering of Manufacturers Hanover preferred stock. Bank spokesman John Meyers had no comment as to whether there would be layoffs. But several analysts estimate Manufacturers Hanover, the nation's eighth-largest banking concern, is attempting to slash $100 million in annual expenses. To do so, they say, more than 1,000 jobs may have to be eliminated. ``Somehow all New York money center banks have got to get their costs down,'' said Mara Hilderman, a senior analyst with Moody's Investor Service. ``There is a problem with core profitability that has to be improved,'' she said. Cutting costs appears to be easier than trying to generate income by increasing fees and other banks have taken the same route. Earlier this month Chase Manhattan Corp., for example, unveiled a plan to cut $300 million in expenses, a move analysts said could result in the elimination of 3,200 jobs. Manufacturers Hanover would not specify how large its charge might be, but the prospectus said the bank expects it to be less than operating earnings for the quarter. In the regulatory filing, the bank said only that operating earnings for the quarter ending Saturday would be below the $96 million in operating earnings reported during the year's first quarter. ``There was very little surprise'' with the news, said Judah S. Kruashaar, senior banking analyst at Merrill Lynch & Co. He predicted the charge would total about $50 million. ``It won't create a quarterly loss, and very importantly it will set the stage for the company to move ahead on impelementation this year'' of its restructuring plan, he said. Kruashaar also said expenses on a quarterly basis should move lower in the final two quarters of this year. Manufacturers Hanover traditionally releases its second-quarter earnings report in late July, coinciding with a regularly scheduled board of directors meeting. But full details of the restructuring plan might not be outlined until fall, industry watchers say. Manufacturers Hanover in May announced a major realignment of its wholesale bank business that split its operations into four groups, eliminating a layer of management. The move is expected to result in ``significant annual savings'' in the future, the bank said. Manufacturers Hanover stock slipped 25 cents to close at $34.50 a share in composite trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Separately, the bank said it expects its non-performing assets to increase by 15 percent ``in the near future principally as a result of problems being experienced by one of the corporation's major real estate customers.'' That customer is developer Donald Trump, who missed a $30 million interest payment due Manufacturers Hanover earlier this month. Manufacturers Hanover, along with Trump's other major banks including Citicorp, Chase Manhattan Corp. and Bankers Trust Co., recently negotiated a $65 million, five-year bailout and debt-restructuring deal. The deal includes delayed payments on some debt. As of March 31, Manufacturers reported non-performing assets of $1.044 billion. Trump's share will account for around an additional $157 million. Kruashaar predicted the bank would be able to report relatively flat non-performing assets, exclusive of problem loans to less developed countries, by the end of the year. ``In this environment that is an exceedingly strong accomplishment,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Moves Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mostly higher Thursday in relatively quiet trading on world currency markets. Gold prices firmed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for June delivery closed at $352.10 a troy ounce, up 70 cents. Later, Republic National Bank in New York quoted a troy ounce of gold at $351.10, up $1 an ounce as of 4 p.m. EDT. Traders said much of the day's activity centered on the Japanese yen, which got a boost early in Asian trading on the expecation that another hike in Japanese interest rates was in the offing. When activity shifted westward, traders sold the West German mark and the Swiss franc in order to buy yen, and the dollar retreated to the sidelines. ``It looked as if the yen sort of caught on,'' said Curtis Perkins, a trader at Chemical New York Capital Markets Group. He said there was only marginal interest in the dollar. Volume was relatively light on U.S. markets, said Ian Spence, chief dealer at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. Trading also was subdued in Europe, where dealers awaited Sunday's economic and monetary union of the two German states. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar gained against the Japanese yen, closing at 154.42 yen, up from 154.35 yen. Later in London, the dollar slipped to close at 153.20 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 153.15 yen, down from 154.40 yen on Wednesday. In London, one British pound cost $1.7400 late Thursday compared with $1.7445 late Wednesday. In New York one pound cost $1.7384, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.7428. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday included: 1.6730 West German marks, up from 1.6637; 1.4200 Swiss francs, up from 1.4095; 5.6155 French francs, up form 5.5915; 1,228.00 Italian lire, up from 1,221.50, and 1.1699 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1695. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Wednesday included: 1.6675 West German marks, up from 1.6625; 1.4125 Swiss francs, up from 1.4033; 5.6015 French francs, up from 5.5775; 1.8772 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8700; 1,224.25 Italian lire, up from 1,217.50, and 1.1692 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1705. The late price of gold in London was a bid of $352.25 a troy ounce, up from $350.05. In Zurich, the late bid was $352.60, up from $349.90. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $350.55, unchanged. Silver prices also rose. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.813 a troy ounce, up from $4.794 on Wednesday. In London the metal traded at a bid of $4.85 a troy ounce, up $4.84.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Fell $444.9 Million in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 513 money market mutual funds fell $444.9 million in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline, to $384.99 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a revised $1.32 billion increase in the funds' assets the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. The previous week's increase originally was reported as $988.6 million. The funds' assets hit a record high $392.14 billion in the week ended March 21, 1990. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 250 general purpose funds rose $27.7 million to $133.99 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds dropped $356.4 million to $159.17 billion, and assets of 161 institutional funds declined $116.2 million to $91.83 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds was 7.67 percent in the week ended Tuesday, unchanged from the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield also was unchanged at 7.67 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 44 days, unchanged from the previous week, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts was 6.18 percent as of Wednesday, unchanged from a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, also was unchanged, at 5.04 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.91 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, unchanged from the previous week. Yields were 8.10 percent on 1-year CDs, unchanged; 8.10 percent on 2{-year CDs, unchanged; and 8.17 percent on 5-year CDs, unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Some Japanese Indicate Pickens Battle Raises Important Issues
DOC.TEXT: T. Boone Pickens Jr. failed again Thursday to breach what he calls the closed Japanese business system. But his efforts to gain a greater say in management of Koito Manufacturing Co., of which he owns 26 percent, have highlighted the differences in how Japanese and American businesses operate. The battle also has begun to stimulate debate in Japan over the pros and cons of Japan's successful but insular business culture. The Texan oilman has for the last year been demanding, among other things, four seats on the 20-member board of directors of the auto parts maker. At a Koito shareholders meeting Thursday, Pickens lost on that point and on other proposals, including higher dividends and having shareholders vote on salary and retirement benefits of board members. Koito has said it could not accept on its board someone it believed to be interested only in forcing the company to buy back his stock at premium prices in order to keep control. Reacting to raucous behavior by Japanese racketeers and what he claimed was deliberate discrimination against Americans by Koito, Pickens stormed out of the three-hour meeting shortly before it ended. ``It was a sham, an absolute farce. Here today, Koito completely showed the world what it's all about in corporate Japan,'' he told reporters. The ``sokaiya'' racketeers were incidental to Pickens' battle. They plague many companies' shareholders meetings, buying a few shares to gain entry and seeking hush money to allow the meetings to proceed undisturbed. Behind Koito's resistance to Pickens lies stiff Japanese corporate opposition to the strong investor control practiced in the United States and symbolized by him. Japanese companies frequently attempt to weaken shareholder control by transferring much of their shares to docile shareholders who promise not to trade them. They also have been able to keep shareholders happy _ despite low dividends _ with rising stock prices that make possible large capital gains. Pickens also attacked Japan's entrenched ``keiretsu system,'' in which companies have formed closed links through shared stock, financial and personnel links and corporate strategies. He said Koito, in its link to Toyota Motor Co., had its profits squeezed by the automobile giant. Toyota owns nearly 20 percent of its stock and buys 45 percent of its output. But Koito officials denied that Toyota had any control over Koito activities. They said its large share of purchases from the Koito reflected Toyota's overall strength in the Japanese market. Pickens' failure in his efforts to reduce the company's dependence on Toyota and increase stockholders' rights came as the United States and Japan were working out a final agreement on reforming business practices seen as contributing to the large U.S. trade deficit with Japan. Their talks, begun in September 1989, represent a recognition that the two sides' highly divergent business cultures influence the sales of goods and services between them. One of Japan's pledges was to curb exclusionary practices by keiretsu groups. Japanese press reports and comments on the Koito-Pickens controversy suggest that some Japanese are beginning to rethink the benefits of their exclusive system. News Station, a popular evening news program, suggested Wednesday that although Pickens' motives for seeking to influence Koito were unclear, he clearly demonstrated the exclusivity of Japanese companies. An editorial in the prestigious economic journal Nihon Keizai Shimbun said earlier: ``It is a very typically Japanese phenomenon for a company to treat unfavored shareholders coldly. If we simply say, `When in Rome, do as the Romans do,' there will arise nothing but friction. The Koito-Boone issue indicates a need to reconsider the customs and practices of our corporate society.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Drug and consumer-products issues led the way as the stock market posted its second straight gain Thursday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 19.80 points on Wednesday, rose another 16.58 to 2,878.71. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 911 up, 559 down and 523 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 136.12 million shares, against 146.62 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 162.52 million shares. Buyers appeared to be encouraged by the market's steady showing Wednesday in the face of earnings disappointments from several large companies over the past few days. Analysts say traders are in a cautious mood as they await formal profit reports for the second quarter, which will begin to flow as early as next week. But some market participants have opted to seek out stocks of companies with histories of strong earnings growth and lines of businesses that are perceived as recession-resistant. Worries about the business outlook, meanwhile, were calmed a bit Wednesday when the government reported that the index of leading economic indicators rose 0.8 percent in May. Pharmaceutical stocks, a favorite target lately of buyers seeking out consistent growth companies, chalked up more gains. Abbott Laboratories rose 1[ to 42; Bristol-Myers Squibb 1\ to 64{; Schering-Plough 1 to 48\; Glaxo Holdings { to 28}, and Eli Lilly 2} to 83}. Food and other consumer products issues that share a reputation as ``defensive'' stocks also stood out. General Mills gained 3| to 90; Pepsico 1{ to 78; Gerber Products 2[ to 54~; Colgate-Palmolive 1 to 68~, and Procter & Gamble 2 to 85}. American Telephone & Telegraph dropped ] to 38} as the most active NYSE issue after a 2[-point loss Wednesday, when the company projected lower profits for the second quarter. Pennzoil picked up 3{ to 76]. The company said it planned to withdraw a registration statement covering 3.69 million shares of its stock issued as part of an acquisition made earlier in the year. Nike class B shares gained 4\ to 77{ in the over-the-counter market. The company said its latest quarterly earnings are expected to come in above estimates. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $22.79 billion, or 0.67 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks climbed 1.31 to 195.18. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 3.46 to 420.24, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 2.49 at 357.63. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 3.49 to 460.38. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 358.57, up 1.52.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T to Cut Some Rates
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said Thursday it will reduce its evening interstate long-distance rates by about 5 percent and daytime rates by about a half-percent on July 1 as part of a $300 million overall price cut. The company also will reduce the prices of operator-assisted calls, U.S.-Canada calls and its Reach Out America optional long-distance calling plan. Overall interstate calling rates will go down an average 2.2 percent, AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said. The cost of a 10-minute direct-dial evening call anywhere in the country will drop to $1.49 from $1.58. The cuts require approval by the Federal Communications Commission. The FCC last week ordered the nation's local telephone companies to reduce by $1.1 billion, effective July 1, what they charge long-distance companies to connect with local phone networks. Long-distance carriers typically pass along to their customers savings from these reduced ``access charges.'' Other phone companies such as MCI and US Sprint usually follow suit to remain competitive. AT&T, the nation's largest long-distance company, had announced last month it would cut its rates by $160 million annually based upon earlier requests that local phone companies had made with the FCC. The local companies in April had asked to reduce their access charges by just $405 million on July 1, but the FCC last week increased that amount to the $1.1 billion figure. Before July 1989, when AT&T's earnings were restricted to about a 12 percent rate of return on its investments, the company passed on to its customers nearly all the savings whenever local phone companies reduced their access charges. But AT&T now is under a regulatory scheme that controls its prices within a prescribed range of ``caps'' tied to the rate of inflation, not its profits. Last November, AT&T raised prices for night and weekend calling by 1.3 percent. AT&T's residential and small business prices currently are right at the cap, so the July 1 reductions were needed, Linnen said. Large business prices are well below the caps, he said. AT&T said that on July 1 it will cut prices for: _Direct-dial, interstate calls between 5 p.m. and 11 p.m. Sunday through Friday by an average 5 percent. _Daytime (8 a.m. to 5 p.m.) direct-dial calls by an average 0.5 percent. _Reach Out America evening discount plan from $8.15 to $7.80 per hour a month and Reach Out Half-Hour plan to $4 to $4.35. _Per-minute operator-assisted calls an average 3 percent. _The first minute of Canadian calls at all times. The company said it would eliminate the one free call now allowed to interstate directory service, meaning all such calls will cost 60 cents each. AT&T's prices have dropped nearly 43 percent since the 1984 of the old Bell system, primarily because of FCC-ordered reductions in access charges.

DOC.HEAD: Toyota Says It Will Buy More U.S. Semiconductors
DOC.TEXT: Toyota Motor Corp. said Thursday it plans to buy about $76 million worth of semiconductor components made by U.S. manufacturers over the next three years. The Japanese carmaker also said it selected five U.S. semiconductor manufacturers to make custom electronics components for Toyota vehicles. Toyota said the agreements are part of its drive to increase the amount of U.S. electronics it uses. The five companies are Intel Corp., International Rectifier Corp., Motorola Inc., National Semiconductor Corp. and Texas Instruments Inc. Toyota officials announced the agreements in New York and Washington after completing their second mission to the United States in search of electronics suppliers. The five companies will work with Toyota to develop 23 types of electronic components, including custom computer chips that control automobile suspension systems, engines, instruments and stereo systems. The agreements could result in more than $17 million worth of sales over a three-year period beginning April 1, 1991, Toyota said. Hiroshi Arai, general manager of Toyota's electronics engineering division, said the company began to buy U.S. semiconductors last year. Those sales were of off-the-shelf semiconductor products, as opposed to the custom chips envisioned under the new agreements. ``We would like to begin on a small scale and build up to a big business,'' he told reporters, speaking through a translator. ``Our impression is that we have been able to develop very good teamwork with the U.S. semiconductor manufacturers.'' About half of the types of custom components to be purchased from the five U.S. companies would cost slightly less if they were obtained from Japanese suppliers, Arai said. He encouraged U.S. chip makers to improve their manufacturing efficiency to cut costs. Toyota would not say how much it intended to spend on each company's products. James Edson, a Motorola marketing official, said the new agreements represent an advancement over last year's pacts, which included purchases from Motorola, because the components to be purchased are more sophisticated. The components Motorola will supply will be made throughout the world, including Japan, Edson said. Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., is the world's largest supplier of semiconductors for automotive use. Though he praised Motorola's relationship with Toyota, Edson said Toyota is not Motorola's largest customer among Japanese carmakers. He said he could not reveal the other company. Millard Phelps, a technology analyst at the San Francisco brokerage Hambrecht & Quist Inc., said the automobile industry represents an important market for U.S. electronics companies. Although automotive uses account for less than 10 percent of U.S. semiconductor production, the percentage is growing rapidly as automobile control devices become more sophisticated, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Strife and Strike Fears Fuel Copper Rally
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices rose sharply Thursday on New York's Commodity Exchange amid speculation of a strike at an Arizona copper mine and supply disruptions from Zambia, the world's sixth-largest copper producer. On other commodity markets, precious metals, orange juice and energy futures advanced; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Copper futures settled 3.1 cents to 5 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July up 4.3 cents at $1.143 a pound. Analysts said most of the buying was caused by the threat of a strike at Asarco Inc.'s Ray copper mine, which produces 115,000 tons of copper concentrate per year. Workers have set a strike deadline of midnight Saturday and analysts saw little hope for a new contract agreement before then. The mine's production is substantial. But the market is in a period of seasonally slow demand and could weather a strike of two or three weeks comfortably, said James Steel, a metals analyst with Refco Inc. in New York. ``It wouldn't matter, but that's not the way the market reacted,'' he said. Copper prices also were supported by continuing unrest in Zambia, where about two dozen people have died this week in riots sparked by the government's abolition of food subsidies. The disturbances have not occurred in Zambia's two major copper-mining areas but there is speculation the rioting might spread, Steel said. In precious metals trading on the Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled 70 cents to 80 cents higher with August at $354.10 a troy ounce; silver was 1.2 cents to 1.8 cents higher with July at $4.813 a troy ounce. Orange juice futures surged on the New York Cotton Exchange as the market continued recovering from last week's technically inspired collapse. Thursday's rally accelerated after the July contract surpassed $1.85 a pound, the price level that some analysts had cited as the trigger for the recent sharp decline. Frozen concentrated orange juice settled 1.95 cents to 5.7 cents higher with July at $1.879 a pound. Energy futures finished sharply higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange after the oil market snapped out of its recent slump. A rumor early in the session of Israeli military action against Libya sparked a rally. The buying waned after the rumor was dispelled but fresh news of efforts by the Organization of Petroleum to prop up world oil prices renewed the rally. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 6 cents lower to 47 cents higher with August at $17.15 a barrel; heating oil was .85 cent to 1.1 cents higher with July at 49.03 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .50 cent to 1.44 cents higher with July at 60.93 cents a gallon. Corn futures rose strongly on the Chicago Board of Trade ahead of two Agriculture Department reports. Wheat futures closed moderately lower while soybeans ended narrowly mixed. The USDA's quarterly grain stocks report contained no surprises. But a report on spring planting intentions showed that farmers surveyed during the first two weeks of June planned to plant more corn and less soybeans than traders had expected. Corn came in at 74.6 million acres compared to market expectations of 73.9 million; soybean plantings were projected at about 58.1 million acres compared with an expected 59.6 million. Some analysts pronounced the corn number bearish and the bean number bullish. ``But what will really determine the size of the crop is the weather over the next 60 to 90 days,'' said Gerald Zusel, manager of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s floor operations at the exchange. A National Weather Service 90-day forecast released after the close predicted above-normal temperatures and normal rainfall for Midwestern corn and soybean areas. Wheat futures settled 1{ cents to 3 cents lower with July at $3.30\ a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 8\ cents higher with July at $2.95\ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to } cent higher with July at $1.35} a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents lower to 1 cent higher with July at $6.07 a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle futures settled .13 cent lower to .03 cent higher with August at 73.17 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .25 cent higher with August at 84.37 cents a pound; live hogs were .08 cent to .57 cent lower with August at 58.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.85 cent lower to .10 cent higher with July at 59.25 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: M1 and M2 Up, M3 Down
DOC.TEXT: Two narrow measures of the nation's money supply increased in the week ended June 18 but a broader measure fell, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $807.6 billion from $807.5 billion the previous week. A slightly broader measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,269.4 billion from $3,265.8 billion the previous week. A broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,055.9 billion from $4,059.2 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,267.3 billion, a 2.9 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,059.6 billion, up 0.7 percent, while M1 rose 3.6 percent to an average of $806.5 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks fell $92 million, compared with a drop of $318 million a week earlier. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $419 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $345 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $309.4 billion in the two-week period ended June 27, up from $306.9 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: ENTel Awarded to Spanish, U.S. Companies
DOC.TEXT: U.S.-based Bell Atlantic and Telefonica of Spain were awarded Thursday a combined 60 percent share in Argentina's state telephone company ENTel. President Carlos Menem signed the decree, saying the two companies' bids were the highest when bids were opened three days ago. A formal takeover is scheduled for Oct. 8. Before then, 30 percent of the new company will be offered to investors and the remaining 10 percent given to employees. The private U.S. company and the Spanish state monopoly paid a combined $214 million cash and $5 billion in debt papers for the Argentine company that has 3 million lines and 45,000 employees. The companies pledged to pay $379 million more within six years, and to invest several hundred million dollars in the new enterprise. ``This is a moment of triumph,'' said Menem, who has made privatizations the centerpriece of his efforts to introduce free market reforms to Argentina's state-dominated economy.

DOC.HEAD: Company Admits Lying Over Bomber Windshield Flaws
DOC.TEXT: A maker of aircraft windows pleaded guilty to lying to the Air Force about flaws in windshields for the B-1B bomber, and agreed to pay a $400,000 fine. The plea Wednesday by Swedlow Inc. of Garden Grove, Calif., was made in a deal with federal prosecutors that resulted in U.S. District Judge Alice-Marie H. Stotler dismissing three other fraud charges against the company. As part of the deal in federal court in Santa Ana, the government also agreed to drop its case against Swedlow Vice President Norman Gene Nixon if, after one year, he is not convicted of any other crime. Nixon and the company were charged with scheming to misrepresent the seriousness of defects in four windshields. Swedlow lawyer Dennis Kinnard said the company believed the indictment was unfair because the flaws were too minor to impair the windshields' fitness for flight.

DOC.HEAD: SEC-CFTC: Words Battle Over Turf Heats Up Again
DOC.TEXT: The government's top securities regulator Thursday defended a study of last October's stock market slide against a bitter critique by the rival Commodity Futures Trading Commission. ``We stand by our report and every word in it,'' Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden told a small group of reporters in his office. Breeden said the CFTC's study of the 1989 market mini-crash had serious methodological defects. He likened the report to saying, ``except for the period of time between 7 a.m. and noon, Pearl Harbor day was a good day.'' Breeden's sharp comments came in response to a published report of the critique by CFTC Chairman Wendy Gramm. In a letter to the chairman of a House subcommittee that oversees the CFTC, Ms. Gramm called the SEC study ``misleading,'' ``imprecise'' and ``contradictory.'' The SEC regulates stocks, bonds and the exchanges that trade them. The CFTC oversees the futures markets. The two have been locked in a war of words over which agency has jurisdiction over financial products that share aspects of both securities and futures contracts. Both regulatory agencies studied causes of the 190-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average last Oct. 13, which occurred shortly after UAL Corp. announced that a leveraged buyout had fallen through. The CFTC concluded last month that index arbitrage _ a computerized program trading strategy blamed by many for exacerbating the 1987 stock market crash _ was not a major factor in the 1989 stock slide. It also found no evidence of manipulation in the stock-index futures market. The Bush administration is pushing legislation that would hand over authority over stock-index futures to the SEC from the CFTC. Stock-index futures, often used in program trading strategies by large institutional investors such as pension funds, allow investors to trade on the movement of a basket of stocks without having to buy the underlying stocks. Program traders try to take advantage of small price differences between the stock and futures markets by simultaneously buying large orders in one market while selling in the other. The SEC and other opponents claim it causes wild price swings. The SEC study, also released last month, found that index arbitrage and other program trading strategies accelerated the 6.9 percent market drop and accounted for an unusually high percentage of share volume during the 90-minute slide. Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., chairman of the panel that oversees the CFTC, asked Gramm to explain the discrepancies between the SEC and CFTC reports. In a nine-page letter to English, Gramm said the reports agree on most of the facts. But she accused the SEC of ``selectively omitting'' critical data. ``The most obvious case is their emphasis on sell volume and only perfunctory mention of contemporaneous buy volume by the same trader groups,'' she said. Not so, Breeden said. ``Our report looks at trading from the moment in time in which the UAL announcement was made until the end of the day,'' he said. ``We look at the level of index arbitrage activity and the pattern of net activities _ buying and selling. ``The CFTC report chose to analyze the level of index arbitrage averaged over the entire day. That's a little bit like saying that except for the period of time between 7 a.m. and noon, Pear Harbor Day was a good day and on average there weren't many problems.'' ``There was a specific event, it began at a specific point in time and to try and disguise the developments that occurred during that period of time by averaging them in over a period of time that is totally irrelevant, demonstrates the significant methodological defects of the CFTC report,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pathe Stymied in Bid for Time Warner Loan
DOC.TEXT: Pathe Communications Corp. said Thursday its attempt to get a loan from Time Warner Inc. had stalled and it would look elsewhere for money to buy MGM-UA Communications Co. for $1.3 billion. Time Warner's failure to lend Pathe $650 million is the latest setback to efforts by Kirk Kerkorian, MGM-UA's controlling shareholder, to sell the company. Pathe spokesman Craig Parsons said the company was looking at ``a broad universe of options'' for raising the rest of the money. ``It could take any shape _ equity, financing, investors,'' Parsons said. ``They're confident despite how this might be perceived by others.'' Pathe has already made $200 million in cash down payments to MGM-UA. Rumors had flown for weeks that Time Warner would decide against making the loan. In the two years Kerkorian has had MGM-UA on the auction block, nearly every big entertainment and media company has examined its assets. Australia's Qintex Group agreed to buy MGM-UA for $1.5 billion last year, but was unable to arrange financing. Media mogul Rupert Murdoch, who had offered $1.4 billion, declined to re-enter the bidding. The Time Warner loan had been a centerpiece of Pathe's original $1.2 billion, $20-per-share offer for MGM-UA. Time Warner was to have gotten a lien on the United Artists library as security, plus distribution rights to the library and future Pathe and MGM movies. But Pathe's chief, Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti, and Kerkorian negotiated a new deal last week. The new deal was crafted when Parretti was unable to meet a Saturday deadline for arranging the rest of the financing to Time Warner's satisfaction. The new deal raised the offer by $100 million to $1.3 billion. Time Warner had insisted that Pathe put at least $450 million in equity into the deal, plus $150 million in equity from outside sources. Pathe instead proposed to raise funds primarily by borrowing money from European affiliates, although it said it intended to convert that debt to equity by issuing stock to the affiliates. The new buyout bid, which was finalized Thursday, structured the deal as a merger rather than a tender offer and made no mention of Time Warner. ``Pathe intends to continue a dialogue with Time Warner,'' Pathe said in a brief statement. It added: ``Pathe will seek alternative sources of financing to conclude its acquisition of MGM-UA.'' MGM-UA spokesman Scott Tagliarino said MGM-UA would have no comment on the latest announcement. He noted that so far, Pathe has made all its good-faith payments. Kerkorian already had surrendered most of the control over his studio to Qintex when that deal fell apart over a $50 million down payment. Determined not to be burned again, he has made his agreements with Parretti contingent upon a series of monthly $50 million payments, of which Parretti has made four beginning in March. Another $53 million is due this month. It and the $200 million in previous down payments will be distributed to MGM-UA stockholders as a $4-per-share payment. Parretti has agreed to make additional $50 million payments in August and September, and come up with the balance of the money by Oct. 23. Investors have been skeptical about the chances of the deal going through at its current level of $21.50 per share. MGM-UA stock closed Thursday at $17.87{, up 12{ cents per share, on the New York Stock Exchange before Pathe announced its negotiations with Time Warner had stalled.

DOC.HEAD: Personal Bankruptcies Up 15 Percent, Group Says
DOC.TEXT: Personal bankruptcy filings nationwide rose 15 percent in the first three months of the year, led by sharp increases in the Northeast, a financial industry group reported Thursday. There were 166,694 personal bankruptcy filings in the first quarter, compared with 144,725 in the same period of 1989, the American Financial Services Association said. The increase exceeded the rate of 1989, when personal filings increased 12 percent over 1988. New Hampshire led the nation with a 90 percent increase to 393 filings from 207 in the first quarter of 1989. Massachusetts followed with a 76 percent increase. California, the state with the most personal bankruptcies, had 18,587 filings, a 7 percent increase over 17,431 in the first quarter of 1989. The AFSA, which represents companies that provide financial services to consumers and small businesses, based its findings on statistics compiled by the Administrative Office of U.S. Courts. The 1st U.S. Circuit, which includes Maine, Rhode Island and Puerto Rico as well as New Hampshire and Massachusetts, showed the largest gain in filings with a 54 percent increase. The 2nd Circuit, which includes Connecticut, Vermont and New York, ranked second with a 36 percent increase. The only judicial district to report a decrease was the District of Columbia where there were 204 cases, down 21 percent from 259 in the first quarter of 1989. The 5th U.S. Circuit Bankruptcy Court, which covers the oil-dependent states of Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas, reported only a 4 percent increase. The region had reported large increases in previous years.

DOC.HEAD: Maxwell House To Close Hoboken Coffee Plant
DOC.TEXT: Maxwell House will close its 50-year-old coffee roasting and grinding plant here by early 1992 and expand a plant in Jacksonville, Fla., the company announced Wednesday. None of the 600 workers at the Hoboken plant would be laid off immediately, said Raymond G. Viault, company president. ``People simply aren't drinking as much coffee as they used to,'' Viault said. A 24 percent decline in American coffee consumption since 1963 left Maxwell House's four United States plants operating at only 55 percent capacity, Viault said at a press conference in Secaucus. In February, parent company General Foods USA announced that either Hoboken or Jacksonville would be closed. Despite workers' concessions and enticements from the city, the company chose the 66-year-old Jacksonville site, where workers make an average of $3 an hour less. As positions are phased out, workers would be offered counseling, retraining and possible relocation to other positions in General Foods and its parent company Philip Morris Co., Viault said. Jacksonville operations manager Frank Meegan said that over the next 18 months, new roasters and process control equipment would be installed and production would be expanded by 40 percent. The plant's 380 workers cheered the news when it was announced Wednesday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Falls, Dollar Steady
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, dollar, comments
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange dropped Thursday morning, while the dollar remained stable against the Japanese yen. Kojiro Narimatsu, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co., said the Nikkei index fell as investors stepped to the sidelines following Wednesday's surge. The Nikkei gained 740.98 points Wednesday. ``Because it was not due to active selling, the index is unlikely to fall further,'' he said. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 258.52 points, or 0.80 percent, ending the early session at 32,054.23. The dollar ended the morning session at 154.35 yen, unchanged from Wednesday's close. It opened at 154.57 yen, up 0.22 yen from Wednesday's close, and ranged between 154.27 yen and 154.63 yen during morning trading. The dollar opened higher following dollar-buying in the Sydney market, which opened earlier than Tokyo's. But the currency weakened later as participants adjusted positions before a series of important political and economic news scheduled for next week, dealers said. Among the events are German monetary unification, the U.S. Federal Reserve Board's open market committee meeting and the Soviet communist party congress. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds slipped to 86.75 points, down from Wednesday's close of 87.05. The yield was higher at 7.24 percent, up from the previous day's 7.175 percent.
